HEADLINE: Cost of Farm Subsidies Cited as Trade Issue

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7

 BODY:
In an effort to persuade West European countries to end farm subsidies, the Bush Administration has begun citing new estimates of the high costs of agricultural support, which is now put at $200 billion for both the United States and the European Community, nearly 10 times higher than was estimated earlier.
The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said today that the revised numbers, put together recently by the staff of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris, added urgency to the need to agree on an agriculture trade liberalization pact at the so-called Uruguay Round of trade talks currently being held in Geneva.
The new study takes into account the cost of farm subsidies in both the community and the United States and examines policies on rural development, processing, marketing, inspection services and the impact of price and income support. 
 
Level Down from 1987
The O.E.C.D. breakdown shows that in 1988 the cost of farm support was $119.4 billion in the community and $73.8 billion in the United States. Both calculations were down slightly from 1987, when the cost of support in Europe was put at $123.9 billion and in the United States at $86.1 billion.
National and international organizations have tried for years to establish reliable estimates of the cost of farm support. The O.E.C.D. study, which was completed by its agricultural trade committee last May, is believed to be the most comprehensive.
Previous estimates by both the European Community and the United States Agriculture Department had generally placed spending in the range of $25 to $35 billion a year. The new study seeks to incorporate all agricultural outlays whereas earlier numbers focused primarily on specific subsidies like price supports and loan programs.
''The cost is astronomically high,'' Mrs. Hills told reporters here today in preparation for a negotiating trip next week to Western Europe during which subsidies are expected to be a major issue.
 
Competition a Factor
She added that the costs were pushed even higher because of subsidized export competition.
''Even here, when we talk to members of the farm community about export enhancement,'' she said, referring to subsidies, ''it's always that the community provides subsidies for their sales and we have to meet the competition.''
The United States and the West Europeans last April concluded a framework agreement for the trade negotiations in which both sides said they would accept a ''progressive and substantial reduction'' of subsidies. But there has been little progress since.
The Uruguay Round, the eighth and most complex postwar effort to establish freer trade under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, is being conducted by 108 nations and is scheduled to end next year.
Besides cutting farm subsidies, negotiators are trying to liberalize trade in services, like insurance and tourism, establish greater protection for copyrights, trademarks and other intellectual property, and chart a course for eventual freer trade in textiles.

HEADLINE: Treasury Prices Narrowly Mixed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities ended narrowly mixed in continued sluggish trading yesterday.
Note and bond prices were up by as much as a quarter-point early in the session, but the gains did not hold as dealers took profits later in the day.
The early gains came as market participants reacted positively to a continued strength in the dollar, which moved higher after the Bundesbank of West Germany, contrary to rumors that had circulated in recent trading sessions, chose not to raise certain primary short-term interest rates.
 
Dollar Is Restrained
Dollar selling by several European central banks and the Federal Reserve pushed the currency down from its peak levels of the day, the traders said. 
For the first time in several weeks, the dealers said that retail investors were buying securities.
''Every day the market holds at these levels helps because customers don't like volatility,'' said one government securities trader. ''And the dollar is also giving people some comfort. We have seen pretty good buying of intermediate-term issues by both foreign and domestic clients.''
Lawrence N. Leuzzi, a managing director at S. G. Warburg Securities Inc., said: ''The economic fundamentals underpinning the dollar are helping the credit market. But the Federal Reserve appears to have monetary policy on hold, and as a consequence, the market is moving sideways.
''The Fed is taking a bow, and the markets seem to be applauding them by not moving in one direction or another.''
 
Funds Rate Under 9%
Yesterday, the overnight Federal funds rate, the rate that is most closely controlled by the Fed, traded at or slightly under the 9 percent target level it has held for the last six weeks. The rate is what the Fed charges on overnight loans to banks.
''We see little rationale for any near-term change'' in Fed policy, analysts at MMS International, an economic information service company in Belmont, Calif., noted in their daily market commentary, ''so a 9 percent funds rate will likely persist through early October, until new data on the economy and prices becomes available.''
By late yesterday, the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent bonds that mature in 2019 were offered at a price of 100 5/32, down by 3/32, to yield 8.11 percent.
Among the secondary Treasury note issues, intermediate-term securities dipped somewhat in price, while the short-term instruments inched higher.
In late trading, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 98 26/32, down by an eighth of a point, to yield 8.24 percent. And the 8 1/4 percent five-year notes dipped by 3/32, to a late-offered price of 100 6/32, to yield 8.19 percent. 2-Year Notes at 8.30% Among the shorter-term issues, the 8 1/4 percent two-year notes were offered late yesterday at 99 29/32, up by 2/32, to yield 8.30 percent.
Secondary Treasury bill rates edged lower.
Three-month bills were offered in late trading at a discount rate of 7.78 percent, down by 2 basis points, or hundredths of a point. Meanwhile, six-month bill rates dipped by a basis point, to a late-offered rate of 7.78 percent. And one-year bills were offered at a rate of 7.66 percent, also down by 2 basis points.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve reported that all three measures of the nation's money supply fell during the week that ended on Aug. 28. The report did not affect prices in the credit markets.
Activity in the secondary corporate and tax-exempt municipal bond markets was extremely light again yesterday, the dealers said.
The prices of most secondary corporate issues were unchanged to down by one-eighth of a point, the market participants said, while the prices of most secondary tax-exempt issues were unchanged to up by an eighth of a point.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Hits 3-Month High As Central Banks Intervene

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Traders carried the dollar to its highest levels in nearly three months yesterday, although selling by central banks knocked the currency off its peak of the day.
Central banks in West Germany, France, Spain, Italy and Switzerland confirmed that they had sold dollars to restrain the currency, and the traders said that the Bank of Canada and the Federal Reserve in the United States joined in the action.
The bankers are committed to keeping exchange rates stable to avoid damaging world trade. 
At its peak in late European trading, the dollar went above 1.99 West German marks, just shy of the important level of 2 marks to the dollar. It ended the trading day in New York at less than 1.98 marks.
Propelling the dollar upward have been attractive interest rates in the United States and confidence in the health of the American economy and financial markets. The dollar is near its levels of mid-June, when a rally moved it to two-year highs.
Yesterday's trading volume was not especially heavy, reflecting the traders' uncertainty about the strength of the current rally, said Keith Raphael, an assistant vice president at Bank Brussels Lambert Inc. in New York.
In the absence of heavy buying demand, the central banks could get some results from a relatively modest amount of dollar selling. But many of the traders still expected the market to keep testing the central banks' resolve.
''There's fundamentally no reason for the dollar to come off,'' said Bill Doyle, a trader at the Hong Kong and Shanghai Banking Corporation branch office in New York.
In late New York trading, the dollar was at 146.65 yen, below its levels of earlier in the day but above its close of 146.10 yen late on Wednesday. The pound traded at $1.5520, weaker against the dollar than $1.5525 on Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late on Wednesday, included: 1.9798 West German marks, up from 1.9753; 1.7075 Swiss francs, up from 1.7048; 1.1859 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1802; 6.6685 French francs, up from 6.6560, and 1,419.30 Italian lire, up from 1,417.90.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery fell to $360.20 an ounce, from $361.60 on Wednesday. Silver for current delivery rose to $5.117 an ounce, from $5.103 on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Joseph Kaskell, 97; Lawyer Helped Bonn

 BODY:
Joseph Kaskell, an international lawyer who was active in the effort to rebuild Germany after World War II, died Tuesday at his summer home in Madison, N.H. He was 97 years old and also lived in Manhattan.
Mr. Kaskell was an organizer of the American Council on Germany in 1950 and served as its legal counsel until he retired in 1980. Earlier he had been a founder of the Committee for a Democratic Germany, which opposed harsh measures by the Allies that would have restricted the postwar reconstruction of the German economy.
In 1968 the West German Government in Bonn awarded Mr. Kaskell its highest honor, the Bundesverdienstkreuz, for his efforts in furthering German-American ties.
Mr. Kaskell, who was born in Posen, Germany (now Poznan, Poland), came to the United States in 1939 after having practiced law in Berlin. After receiving a degree from the Columbia Law School, he resumed practice in New York.
He is survived by his wife, the former Liselotte Wachter; a son, Peter, of Manhattan; a daughter, Marinne Cohen of Chapel Hill, N.C.; four grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Report for U.S. Says Somali Army Killed 5,000 Unarmed Civilians

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 8

 BODY:
A report commissioned by the State Department says the Somali Army ''purposely murdered'' at least 5,000 unarmed civilians over 10 months ending in March.
In one instance, at least 500 men of the Isaak clan, whose members make up the major armed opposition to the Somali Government, were rounded up and killed by the army, most with their throats cut, and then buried in mass graves, says the report by a State Department consultant that documents wide-ranging human rights abuses.
The Somali Government denied today that the army had killed 5,000 people.
 
Recipient of U.S. Arms Aid
The Somali Army has received United States military aid as part of Washington's support of the military Government of President Mohammed Siad Barre over the last 12 years. 
The United States has an agreement with the Somali Government that allows it military use of the port of Berbera on the Gulf of Aden, where the report said the 500 Isaaks were killed. There are no United States military personnel based at the port, a State Department official said.
As an expression of Washington's disapproval of the Goverment's human rights abuses, $2.5 million in military aid to Somalia has been recently suspended along with $21 million in economic aid, the State Department said.
 
'Disintegration' Seen
A decision on whether to still include Somalia in joint military exercises scheduled to take place in the fall with the United States and other countries in the region is under review, a department official said.
Somalia is in a state of ''disintegration,'' he said, adding that the Government had lost control of most of the country and that clan rivalry had taken the upper hand. ''It's a situation of everyone for themselves,'' he said.
But the official described the port of Berbera as ''still important to our interests,'' because of its strategic position as a staging post for sending troops to southwest Asia.
A thinly populated, mostly desert country on the eastern wing of the Horn of Africa, Somalia juts out into the Indian Ocean and the Gulf of Aden. President Siad Barre, believed to be in his 80's and ailing, took control in a coup 20 years ago. The findings in the report by Robert Gersony, a consultant to the State Department who did a similar investigation for the department last year on Mozambique, are based on more than 250 interviews with Somali refugees who have fled as well as with Somalis and foreigners in the country.
It covers the period from May 1988 - when fierce fighting broke out in the north between the Government and the Somali National Movement, based on the Isaak clan - to March 1989. #300,000 Go to Ethiopia As a result of that fighting, concentrated around the northern town of Hargeisa, more than 300,000 Somalis of the Isaak clan walked across the border to Ethiopia, where most remain in camps run by the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. The report states that none of the Isaak refugees interviewed were willing to return home under the current circumstances.
The report said the Somali National Movement had also killed unarmed civilians but asserted the number was much smaller than on the Government side. At least several hundred civilians were killed by the rebels during the first three months of their 1988 offensive, the report said.
In documenting what appeared to be ''widespread, systematic and extremely violent assault'' on the unarmed civilian Isaak population in northern Somalia, the report said the brutalities took place even though there was no danger to the Somali armed forces.
The army appeared to have made systematic attacks against Isaak villages, watering points and grazing areas while at the same time conducting ''roundups, summary executions and massacres of many hundreds, if not more, of unarmed civilian Isaaks.''
''The appearance that victims were selected for these killings principally because of their ethnic identity is unmistakable,'' the report said.
 
Torture Is Charged
Civilian detainees of the Government were subjected to ''severe beatings, stabbing, prolonged choking, use of metal clips and electric shock on flesh and testicles and immersion in excrement.'' it said. ''This ill treatment sometimes resulted in death.''
In July, after the period covered by the State Department account, renewed violence broke out when troops fired on demonstrators protesting the jailing of four Islamic leaders in the capital, Mogadishu. A human rights group, Africa Watch, estimated that 450 people were killed in the fighting. The Government said 23 had been killed and 59 wounded.
On July 16, Western embassies in the capital reported that the army had killed 46 men of Isaak origin on a beach outside the capital. With rare exceptions, journalists have been refused entry to Somalia in the last 18 months.
A Western aid worker with an international organization, who left Mogadishu 10 days ago after spending 10 years in Somalia, said a semblance of order returned to the capital in August, with businesses re-opened and a curfew cut back.
In the central and northern regions, there ''was a complete breakdown of law and order with widspread looting by bandits,'' he said. A major leader of the army in the north who was from the Ogadeni clan had defected, taking fellow Ogadeni soldiers with him, the aid worker said.
 
SOMALIA DENIES REPORT
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (Special to The New York Tiems)- Commenting on the report, Abdi Awale Jama, charge d'affaires at the Somali Embassy, denied today that 5,000 people had been killed by the Somali Army.
''This is an old, rehashed story,'' Mr. Jama said. ''I can't say that it accurately reflects what happened.''
''The mission of the Somali Army is to defend Somali territory, not to kill Somali citizens,'' he said. ''But sometimes mistakes happen. The Somali Army was not the initiator of the violence. Elements opposed to the Somali Government came across the border from Ethiopia, armed to the teeth. Some innocent civilians were caught in the crossfire and were killed.''
Mr. Jama said he did not know the number of victims because he was ''not an eyewitness.''

HEADLINE: Parking in Fortress Los Angeles Bares the Angeleno Psyche

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your ''Los Angeles Journal'' of Aug. 16, ''Parking: Even an Angel Would Cry,'' mentions permit parking and its disastrous effects on nearby shops and would-be shoppers or strollers, but not the closing of whole residential streets to any parking at all.
Nor do you mention the growing trend to withdraw whole blocks of residential streets from public use, by turning them into gated communities closed to any drivers except residents. Permit parking is meant to discourage unruly outsiders. Gated communities hope to increase the security of their residents by keeping out drive-through criminals. They also hope to increase property values.
Los Angeles is engaged in an ominous escalation. Many streets are already closed to all parking and deny all drivers, including residents, facilities we used to consider normal. We all pay taxes, but not all of us are allowed to use the facilities our taxes buy. Like the process you describe, the setting up of gated communities is part of an inflation. We are all concerned with the security of our families and our homes. But Los Angeles drifts toward becoming a collection of semifortified enclosures, where those who can afford the costs of relative security take refuge, while their neighbors take pot luck.
Angelenos are trying to deny that our city has become a great metro-polis, with all the problems a metropolis faces. We run the risk of cutting off our nose to spite our face. Crime, disorder, congestion are serious issues that cannot be tackled in dispersed order. Sundering the city by creating private enclaves, and the legislation of private privilege, can only weaken the common interest we have in our common headaches.
 
EUGEN WEBER
Los Angeles, Aug. 22, 1989

HEADLINE: How Much to Fence In the Fed

 BODY:
The chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, Lee Hamilton, wants to tighten regulation of the Federal Reserve system. The legislation he has co-sponsored sounds innocent enough. It would strip away some of the secrecy the Fed now enjoys and make it more accountable to elected politicians. 
But lurking behind Representative Hamilton's bill is a troubling dilemma. An institution as powerful as the nation's central bank ought to be politically accountable. But if White House or Congress truly determined monetary policy, the economy would almost surely suffer.
The Hamilton bill strikes a careful balance between accountability and autonomy. If Congress ventures much beyond his modest provisions, it will risk serious economic damage.
The Fed controls what is arguably the most powerful economic lever in the world: the U.S. money supply. Not Congress, not the White House, not any foreign government exerts more short-term control over prices, output and jobs. The trick to setting correct monetary policy is to recognize the profound difference between the Fed's short-term impact and its long-term impotence.
In the short term, the Fed can drive down interest rates and thereby increase total spending, output and jobs (a ''loose'' money policy). But in the long run, such a policy drives up inflation, interest rates go back up and the employment and output gains evaporate. A Fed that sacrifices long-term price stability to dabble in short-term expediency creates havoc. The Congressional economic perspective can be frighteningly short-term. It tolerates immense budget deficits even though they threaten economic health. Congress routinely engages in budget trickery that lowers one year's deficit by worsening the deficit every year thereafter. The prospect of Congress forcing the Fed to drive down short-term interest rates to meet Gramm-Rudman budget targets is numbing. Fed autonomy is essential.
Mr. Hamilton's bill would place the Secretary of the Treasury on the Fed's primary policy-making body, allow a new President to appoint his own chairman and require publication of the Fed's budget. This amount of accountability is appropriate. Mr. Hamilton would also permit the Government Accounting Office to audit Fed procedures more closely. The precise purpose of this provision is murky and needs to be clarified.
The most controversial portion of the bill would require that the Fed disclose changes in monetary policy immediately rather than wait its customary six weeks. Most monetary experts agree with Alan Blinder of Princeton and William Poole of Brown University that Fed policy will work better with immediate disclosure. What is certain is that immediate disclosure will subject the Fed to more intense debate, which might weaken its economic resolve.
Mr. Hamilton's attempt to integrate monetary policy better into the political process is constructive and measured. If Congress does not reach beyond the current proposals, economic policy can be democratized in a manner that does no harm.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Divining the Motives Of Socialistic Ravens

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:

Ravens in Winter
By Bernd Heinrich
Illustrations by the author. 379 pages. Summit Books. $19.95.
''Ravens in Winter'' isn't about politics; it's about birds. Yet in this fascinating book, Bernd Heinrich theorizes about the ''left-wing behavior'' of ravens. Ornithology and anthropomorphism are all part of this scientific investigation clothed in the form of a zoological detective story. 
Are ravens socialistic birds who believe in sharing the wealth beyond their immediate families? In search of the answer to that question, the author spent four years in the Maine woods watching them. Sometimes he was himself perched like a bird in a tree, freezing in winter, waiting for hours in darkness, luring the ravens with the bait of dead animals, hoping they would land nearby so he could spot them through his binoculars and observe their behavior.
Setting up his theory about ravens, the author, a professor of zoology at the University of Vermont who previously wrote ''Bumblebee Economics,'' draws the political analogy himself:
''In some of the same fields and woods where I had made the observations on bumblebees, I had often noticed a pair of ravens. I now saw the birds, which had always seemed to me solitary animals, doing something solitary animals are not 'supposed' to do: They were sharing valuable food - those who had, it seemed, were giving to those who needed. It was the most left-wing behavior I had ever heard of in a natural system.''
These initial observations about ravens - supposedly the most intelligent as well as the most garrulous in the bird kingdom - aroused Professor Heinrich's curiosity. As a biologist, he was always looking for some evolutionary, self-serving reason to explain why animals did certain things. He decided to turn his instinct into a scientific investigation. Could ravens possibly possess motives? As a teacher, he knew that an anthropomorphic approach (that is, ascribing human characteristics to nonhumans) could help students understand his ideas more clearly. In ''Ravens in Winter'' he uses the same analogies for readers.
Professor Heinrich started with a minimal knowledge of ravens when he first began studying them at the edge of Mount Blue State Park in western Maine. He found most of the literature anecdotal rather than factual and many of the conclusions about the birds, even those written by ornithologists, misleading. Ravens resemble crows but weigh about four times more; their wingspan can be up to four feet. The author observed hundreds of ravens and wrote down details of their behavior in carefully kept notebooks. He saw them as ''big, black and beautiful,'' with the ability to dive and roll ''like a black thunderbolt'' or to speed along ''with liquid, gliding strokes.''
He learned that ravens follow any animals that kill large game, picking over their remains. They associate with human beings by scavenging at garbage dumps. Their intelligence has been recognized in every culture for centuries. In ancient Ireland, future events were divined from the calls of the raven, and even now the Irish phrase ''raven's knowledge'' means to see and to know all. Several times he cites lines from Edgar Allan Poe's dispiriting 1845 poem, ''The Raven,'' for no particular purpose other than as literary decoration. But his close-up observations result in his own excellent drawings of ravens.
His study shows that most of the meat bait he set out was consumed by crowds of ravens - ranging from 15 to nearly 300 - even though the birds normally don't band together in such numbers. By contrast, species like blue jays defended bait vigorously against other birds instead of sharing. Ravens at the bait were very noisy, suggesting that this was a signal to other ravens to come and get it.
Why did the ravens recruit other ravens to share their food? ''Perhaps ravens sought a crowd to have 'more eyes' to be alert to danger,'' he writes. Another ''perhaps'' is offered: ''Perhaps a raven that shares is recognized by its peers and thereby gains 'friends' or a friend from whom it is able to choose a mate later.'' He surmises that recruitment of other ravens at feeding places could be related to sexual selection.
How does all this information add up? Fitting his data together, Professor Heinrich finds that young ravens leave home to wander. They are gregarious, joining other juveniles to roost and feast with, enabling them to choose an attractive mate. An unmated raven finding food invites eligible singles to join him (or her) at the feast, ''thereby not only gaining or maintaining access to the food, but possibly also increasing its status and demonstrating fitness as a future provider for rearing offspring.''
Professor Heinrich calls this motivated sharing ''an elegant, simple, and beautiful system. But it is clothed by intricate detail and subtlety. As far as I know, no other animal shows a similar system.'' His detective story doesn't really offer a solution, nor does it conclude that ravens are left-wingers or right-wingers, socialists or neoconservatives. Nevertheless, in ''Ravens in Winter'' he does challenge the reader to think about the meaning of altruistic behavior of ravens and humans. Gulf and Westernd(Summit Books)

HEADLINE: 2 New Fronts in Charles's Architecture War

BYLINE: By TERRY TRUCCO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
Contemporary British architecture has been debated fiercely here since May 30, 1984. That night Prince Charles attended the 150th anniversary dinner of the Royal Institute of British Architects and stunned its members by accusing them of having ''consistently ignored the feelings and wishes of the mass of ordinary people.''
This week the Prince did his best to see that the great British contemporary architecture debate rages on. On Thursday, Doubleday in Britain published the Prince's first book on the subject, ''A Vision of Britain, a Personal View of Architecture,'' which is to be published in the United States in November. Thursday night the Prince attended the opening of a companion exhibition at the Victoria and Albert Museum, also entitled ''A Vision of Britain,'' of which he was a principal architect. 
In addition, the BBC broadcast a 90-minute television program written and narrated by Charles, in which he detailed his architectural likes and dislikes.
The program, which was seen by six million viewers when it was first broadcast in October, inspired both the book and the exhibition, as well as spirited architectural debate throughout the nation.
Among the things that most displease the heir to the British throne are concrete tower blocks, impersonal functional structures and buildings that do not fit with neighboring buildings.
This time the architects whose works and beliefs the Prince has criticized were prepared to defend themselves. Earlier in the week Architects Journal, a respected trade magazine, published a survey indicating that a majority of British architects think the Prince is wrong on fundamental issues.
Maxwell Hutchinson, the new president of the Royal Institute of British Architects, aimed a spirited salvo at the Prince in his inaugural lecture at the institute in July. He said, ''The intervention of the Prince of Wales has made honorable that which would have been considered cowardly half a century ago: the renunciation of the new in favor of the old.''
And Mr. Hutchinson has written a rebuttal to the Prince's book. ''The Prince of Wales: Right or Wrong? An Architect Replies'' will be published this month by Faber.
 
A List of Preferences
All this raises not only architectural and esthetic issues but also constitutional concerns over the Prince's beliefs and the influence he wields.
The latest round in the debate centers on the Prince's 10 principles or guidelines for good architectural design, which form the centerpiece of both book and exhibition. (At the Victoria and Albert, visitors can walk through a trim red wood-framed house in which the Prince's architectural views are displayed on poster-size panels.) In brief, the Prince says that new architecture should respect the landscape, that a building's size should reflect its public importance, that buildings ''must relate to human proportions,'' that buildings should be in harmony with surrounding structures and that buildings should create a sense of privacy and safety.
The Prince also thinks that buildings should be made from local materials, that new architecture should respect the landscape, that decoration on buildings helps ''to enrich our spirits,'' that art should accompany new structures, that signs and lights should be part of the architecture and that buildings should encourage a sense of community.
Among the new buildings and developments he admires are the aptly named Princes Square, a Glasgow shopping mall built in an old Victorian warehouse; the planned town of Seaside, Fla., which boasts pastel houses with porches, and the English architect Quinlan Terry's neo-18th-century development in London's Richmond district.
 
From Words Into Mortar
The Prince has also decided to put his principles into practice with the creation of four planned villages on 400 acres of his land in the Duchy of Cornwall. The plans, produced by the architect Leon Krier, reflect the Prince's concern for so-called balanced communities, with houses, shops, schools, factories and public buildings all within walking distance. The plan has been criticized by some residents who prefer more conventional zoning in which homes and work places are more widely separated.
In his speech, Mr. Hutchinson condemned the Prince's design principles, or Ten Commandments, as they have been called by the press. ''There is absolutely no evidence to suggest that this sort of proselytizing does anything to improve the overall quality of architectural design,'' he said.
In contrast, Colin Amery, the architecture critic of The Financial Times, wrote: ''The whole of the Prince's book is really a plea for us all to shake out of our esthetic idleness.'' Some prominent architects do agree with certain points the Prince makes, though many attribute unattractive public and private buildings to a lack of planning controls and greedy developers, not to architects. #20th-Century Constraints Richard Rogers, who designed the Lloyd's of London building - which is not one of the Prince's favorites -says that with notable exceptions there is a prevailing emphasis on cheapness and speed rather than quality in much contemporary British architecture.
Some architects have called the Prince unrealistic about the financial and design constraints placed on architects by the demands of 20th-century buildings and 20th-century budgets.
Prince Charles's frankness, unusual in Britain's usually noncommittal royal family, has sometimes had pronounced results. When he called a proposed addition to the National Gallery a ''monstrous carbuncle,'' the project was jettisoned, taking hundreds of jobs with it.
''No person so close to the throne in the past has ever taken a stand with such unbelieveably strong economic repercussions,'' said Harold Brooks-Baker, director of Burke's Peerage, the 163-year-old directory of British aristocracy.
 
Support for the Prince
Yet Prince Charles's views have proved extremely popular with the so-called ordinary people he claims to represent when he criticizes postwar buildings like the National Theater at London's Southbank Center or London's Paternoster Square, next to St. Paul's Cathedral. In the introduction to his book, he writes that 99 percent of the 5,000 letters he received after his television program agreed with him.
''I'm very pro-Prince, and I share his architectural views,'' said Stanley Roth, a London taxicab driver who also gives tours of the city. ''People say he has no right to say what he does. But when the Prince declares that something is a carbuncle, people listen and he gets results. The average person may feel exactly as the Prince does, but no one is going to listen.''
Doubleday, which paid $480,000 for the rights to the book, is printing 200,000 copies in Britain alone; architectural books usually have a first printing of 3,000 here, according to a Doubleday spokeswoman. The book sells in Britain for about $27, and proceeds will go to the Prince of Wales's Charities.
Indeed, even Mr. Hutchinson agrees that the Prince's efforts have had at least one positive effect. ''Prince Charles has hit a vein in public opinion; there is no doubt about that,'' he said at the opening of the Victoria and Albert exhibition. ''He has started a debate, and that at least is an enormous benefit.''

HEADLINE: Yeltsin, Soviet Opposition Figure, Is Due Today for U.S. Tour

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
Boris N. Yeltsin, the swashbuckling Soviet populist whose mass appeal made him the symbol of growing political pluralism in Moscow, arrives in New York on his first American visit Saturday to offer Americans an insight into Soviet politics and to take a crash course in American capitalism.
The former Politburo member's hectic schedule, now compressed to eight days from the two weeks originally planned, has him speaking in eight cities - at about $25,000 a lecture -meeting with leading economic and business figures including David Rockefeller, Lester C. Thurow and Peter J. Sprague, and soaking up as much information as possible about entrepreneurship.
The burly former Moscow party boss cemented his reputation for tenacity earlier this year, when he emerged from the obscurity of a construction ministry to win a seat in the new Congress of People's Deputies with 90 percent of the vote. 
Mr. Yeltsin has reportedly requested a meeting with President Bush, but it is not clear whether he will see him.
 
No Decision on Bush Meeting
''No decision has been made as to whether to meet with Yeltsin,'' a senior Administration official said Thursday, referring to the proposed meetings with Mr. Bush and Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser.
He will, however, meet with Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and Senator Bill Bradley, the New Jersey Democrat who has developed a strong interest in the Soviet Union.
Mr. Yeltsin, who was banished from the ruling Politburo in 1987, is making the trip as a private individual, under the sponsorship of the California-based Esalen Institute, the onetime home base of the human potential movement and recently a promoter of Soviet-American exchanges and dialogues.
The arrangements for the trip have had a jury-rigged, perils-of-Pauline quality, an odd counterpoint to the obvious significance of this visit by the first nationwide political opposition leader to emerge from a tradition of rigid political conformity.
 
Late Visa and Tickets
As of Wednesday, when invitations to a lunch for Mr. Yeltsin by the Council on Foreign Relations were arriving at members' homes, Mr. Yeltsin had not received an exit visa from the Soviet Government. As of Thursday, when plans for similar meetings in Baltimore, Washington, Philadelphia, Dallas, Minneapolis, Indianapolis and Chicago were being completed, Mr. Yeltsin did not have his plane tickets.
''We didn't know until 3 or 4 o'clock this morning that he was coming,'' Jim Garrison, Esalen's executive director, said Thursday. ''The Foreign Ministry didn't give him an exit visa until 9 o'clock Thursday night.''
Mr. Thurow, who is dean of the Sloan School of Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said of the visit: ''It's a revolution. He's really the leader of the political opposition in Moscow, and to think that the leadership would let him visit the United States - well, there would have been no way on God's green earth that could have happened 10 years ago.''

SECTION: Section 1; Page 48, Column 1; Style Desk

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD;
Safety Questions Raised About Generic Drugs

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
As questions are raised about the Government's system of approving generic drugs, some doctors are asking whether these drugs are as effective as they are said to be. The questions are troubling many consumers who use generics instead of more expensive brand-name drugs.
Generic drugs are now used to fill about a third of all prescriptions written in the United States. They cost about half as much as their brand-name counterparts because of price competition among makers once the patent on a brand-name product expires, usually after 17 years. Manufacturers claim that generics are just as effective as the name brands. 
In recent months, three employees of the Food and Drug Administration who reviewed applications from manufacturers seeking approval for new generic drugs have pleaded guilty to accepting money and favors from some manufacturers. One company, Vitarine Pharmaceuticals Inc. of Queens, has admitted substituting the patented drug for its own when making its application. A report by the inspector general of the Department of Health and Human Services has found weaknesses in the F.D.A.'s drug-review procedures.
 
Plant Inspections
 The F.D.A. is considering withdrawing its approval for two dozen or so generic drugs made by Vitarine and Par Phamaceutical Inc. of Spring Valley, N.Y. The agency claims that false information was included in the companies' applications. And last month the F.D.A. started inspecting 20 major manufacturing plants, in an effort to assure consumers that that there is no danger in using generics.
Some insurance companies and government health programs require pharmacists to use a lower-cost generic if it is available. Any changes in these requirements would be up to state legislatures.
The American Academy of Family Physicians, a professional group, is to vote next week on a proposal that for certain patients, diseases and drugs, there should be no mandatory substitution of generics for name brands.
None of these developments are likely to inspire consumer confidence in generic drugs. But Dr. Sidney M. Wolfe, director of the Public Citizen Health Research Group affiliated with Ralph Nader, said, ''At the present time, there is no reason why a physician should stop prescribing generic drugs or a patient should stop using generic drugs.''
Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, Secretary of Health and Human Services, said the Government had ''no evidence that the safety or effectiveness of generic drugs has been compromised.''
And spokesmen for the generic-drug industry, while condemning individual instances of wrongdoing, say there is no reason for consumers to lose confidence in generics.
''We've got an extraordinary 20-year record,'' said Dee Fensterer, president of the Generic Pharmaceutical Industry Association.
The American Association of Retired Persons, which has a large mail-order service for generic and brand-name drugs, has no plans to change its procedures. ''We still certainly believe that generic products have a very viable interest for our consumers,'' said Carl L. Jesina, executive vice president of the association's pharmacy service.
Nevertheless, some physicians and other health professionals are concerned whether certain generic drugs perform as well as the original brand-name products. Cost containment is a worthy goal, they say, but not if the drug has a lesser therapeutic effect.
''The main issue is whether the public is getting the product which, in fact, the F.D.A. approved,'' said Dr. Leroy L. Schwartz, president of Health Policy International, a nonprofit foundation in a Princeton, N.J., that studies health-policy issues from a scientific point of view. ''The F.D.A. has not assured the public that there will be the same therapeutic effect once substitution takes place. And the elderly and the poor are the ones most affected.''
Dr. Ralph E. Schlossman, a physician in family practice in Queens, said: ''I have had many instances where a generic medication was not working where it should have. When I switched to a brand, it did.''
Members of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, which represents the major drug companies, make generic as well as brand-name products. Nevertheless, in a position paper on generics issued early this year, the association said generic drugs ''are being approved for marketing that are not in practice therapeutically equivalent to the pioneer products.'' The paper also said, ''Patients on maintenance regimens whose daily dosage must be individualized are especially at risk when drug products are changed.''
 
Formulations Vary
 The F.D.A. requires that a generic product contain the same active ingredient as the brand-name product and that the ingredient be absorbed by the body in the same way. Whether it does is determined by comparing the rate and extent of absorption of the brand-name drug and the generic. The F.D.A. allows new generic formulations to vary by up to 20 percent compared with the brand names, but the average difference since 1962 has been only 3.5 percent, according to an agency study.
A number of doctors are wary about substituting generics for particular medical conditions. Dr. Ray W. Gifford, a Cleveland internist and a trustee of the American Medical Association, said he would not recommend digoxin, a generic product used to treat heart conditions, instead of the brand-name product Lanoxin.
''This requires very precise dosing,'' he said. ''You can get toxicity or you can lose control of the patient if there are too many variations.''
Reina Davis, executive director of the Epilepsy Institute in New York, warns that generic anti-convulsant medications may vary from manufacturer to manufacturer. She advises users to ask their doctors to choose a generic medication from a particular manufacturer, then to write the name of the maker on the prescription so the pharmacist knows not to fill it with any other product.
In general, experts say, consumers should make sure they know when they are taking generic drugs, and to talk to their doctors if they are concerned about continuing to do so.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 15, 1989, Friday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on the Consumer's World page last Saturday about generic drugs misidentified the executive director of the Epilepsy Institute. She is Reina Berner. A chart accompanying the article misstated the generic equivalent of the drug Dyazide. It is hydrochlorothiazide and triamterene.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises Near June Peak In Generally Light Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar yesterday approached the peaks reached in its June rally, with its confidence in a thin market bolstered by a comment from a Swiss national banker. Gold edged down.
Jean Zwahlen, a member of the Swiss National Bank's governing board, was quoted as having said that the dollar was likely to rise in the immediate future because of a strong American economy. 
He said the central banks' ability to restrain the dollar's rise would depend upon the strength of market sentiment toward the currency.
Trading was light to moderate, so price movements were exaggerated, said Jack Adkins, an analyst at the Refco Group Ltd. in Chicago. ''It didn't take a whole lot to get things going,'' he said.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to 146.62 yen, from 146.87 yen late on Thursday. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 146.45 yen. In New York, the currency moved up to 147.20 yen, from 146.65 on Thursday.
In London, the dollar fell against the British pound. It cost $1.5505 to buy a pound, more than $1.5460 late on Thursday. In New York, the dollar gained as the pound fell to $1.5380, from $1.5520.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those late Thursday, included: 1.9950 West German marks, up from 1.9798; 1.7245 Swiss francs, up from 1.7075; 1.1875 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1859; 6.7195 French francs, up from 6.6680, and 1,493 Italian lire, up from 1,419.30.
In June, the dollar reached 148.53 yen and 2.02 marks, levels unseen in about two years.
In London, gold rose to a late bid of $360 an ounce, from $359.50 late on Thursday. In Zurich, the metal rose to $360 an ounce, compared with $359.75 late on Thursday.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery fell to $359.40 an ounce, from $360.20. The Republic National Bank of New York later reported that it had fallen to $358.75, from $359.70.
Also in London, silver rose to $5.12 an ounce, compared with $5.11 late on Thursday. On the Comex in New York, the metal for current delivery fell to $5.053 an ounce, from $5.117.

HEADLINE: DOW ENDS UP SLIGHTLY AFTER EARLY LOSSES

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
Stock prices made slight advances yesterday, driven by takeover rumors and some positive economic data.
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 2.66 points, to 2,709.54, as blue chips recovered from steep losses in early morning trading after an unexpected drop in July consumer credit figures was announced. Lower interest rates also gave the markets a lift. 
Volume on the Big Board stood at a weak 154.1 million shares, down from 160.2 million shares on Thursday, with advances outstripping declines by 746 to 685.
The week's decline for the Dow of 42.55 points, or 1.55 percent, was the first drop in 10 weeks. Not since 1922 had the Dow risen in every week between Independence Day and Labor Day. Institutional Caution Cited Analysts attributed the decline to a growing caution by institutional investors. ''A lot of money managers remember 1987 and 1988,'' said Michael Metz, chief market strategist for Oppenheimer & Company. ''The lesson is that you had a great second quarter, so don't press your luck; lock in your gains and walk away.''
The Dow transportation average had its worst week in more than a year, closing lower for three straight sessions as airline stocks continued their recent pullback after a dramatic rise this summer. The average was down 7.29 points yesterday, to 1,473.68.
For the week, the transport average was down 52.99 points, or 3.47 percent. That is the worst week for the average since it fell 3.96 percent, to 857.38, in the week ended July 22, 1988. In points, it was the worst week for the average since the index fell 67.43 in the week ended Dec. 4, 1987. Still, last week's drop did not erase the 58.33-point gain of the prior week.
''The transportation average has deteriorated to a speculative football as a lot of people bought the airline stocks for the wrong reasons, expecting everything to be taken over the next day,'' Mr. Metz said. ''When nothing developed, those who bought them for instant gratification sold and walked away.'' UAL, AMR and Delta Fall UAL, the parent of United Airlines, fell 1 1/2, to 280 1/4, on renewed rumors that Marvin Davis, the California investor who had made a bid for the company, had begun liquidating his position in UAL.
AMR, parent of American Airlines, lost 1 5/8, to 81. Delta fell 3/4, to 74 1/4.
The blue chips were mixed in weak trading as Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing advanced 3/4, to 74 3/4; I.B.M. dropped 1/4, to 116; A.T.&T. rose 1/4, to 39 1/8, and General Motors moved down 1/8, to 49 7/8.
Woolworth rose 3, to 71 3/4, on speculation of a possible takeover bid, traders and analysts said. Woolworth declined to comment.
Broader market indexes also recorded small advances. The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.17 point, to 193.95. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks inched up 0.41, to 348.76. The American Stock Exchange market-value index was up 0.91, to 384.10, showing a weekly gain of 0.14 point. The Nasdaq composite index rose 1.63, to 471.31.
Allergan, the most active Big Board issue, was down 1/2, to 20 1/4. The company announced early in the week that it expected lower 1989 sales growth.
Heilig-Meyers moved up 3, to 24 3/4, in heavy trading after a Malaysian investor, Vincent Tan, said he would like to discuss with directors a negotiated acquisition of the company.

HEADLINE: Late Rally Pushes Bonds Higher

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
A late rally sent prices of Treasury securities soaring yesterday. Dealers attributed the rally to an unexpected drop in comsumer credit spending in July, which was reported by the Government shortly after 2 P.M. Until then, dealers said, prices were slightly higher in lackluster trading.
''With many of the heavy hitters still on vacation, the market was just marking time'' when the report came out, said Roberta D. Olson, manager of the fixed-income portfolio at Banc One Asset Management, in Columbus, Ohio. ''The news that consumer credit contracted by $280 million last month was enough to prompt short covering,'' she said. 
But Ms. Olson said there was little fresh buying ''because many participants in the fixed-income market are waiting to see what next week's flow of economic statistics will show.'' She added, ''Next Friday, for example, we expect to get the July trade deficit figures, August Producer Price Index, as well as last month's industrial output and factory capacity indexes.'' Because Wall Street has not been selling the market short, she said, ''we expect prices will back off their highs toward the close.''
 
Long-Term Bond at 8.07%
Ms. Olson was correct. Late in the session, the Treasury's benchmark long-term bonds, the 8 1/8 percent issue maturing in 2019, eased a bit from their highs and were being offered at 100 18/32, up 13/32. This caused the yield to fall to 8.07 percent, from 8.11 percent Thursday and 8.12 percent a week ago.
In Chicago, the spot September Treasury bond futures contract, which expires on Sept. 20, closed up 13/32, to 97 20/32.
Among shorter-term Treasury issues traded in the cash secondary market, the 8 1/4 percent notes of 1991 rose 4/32, to 100, for a yield of 8.25 percent; the 8 1/4's of 1994 added 7/32, to 100 11/32, and now yield 8.15 percent; the long notes, the 8's of 1999, climbed 8/32, or a quarter-point, to 99 2/32, as the yield dipped to 8.14 percent, from 8.16 percent a week ago.
Steven R. Ricchiuto, chief economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Government Securities, said the rush to buy back Treasury paper that had previously been sold short ''was caused as much by confusion over the unexpected contraction as by the size of the actual decline; the last time consumer credit shrunk was in January 1987, when it fell by $1.63 billion.''
 
Less Car Financing
One explanation, Mr. Ricchiuto continued, may be found in the $1.5 billion drop in car financing credit in July and the relatively small rise of $1.3 billion in bank and credit card revolving credit. The latter development has caused many banks to lower interest rates on their overdraft, or revolving credit, accounts.
''We think the increased use of home equity loans to finance car and other consumer purchases could be the major reason,'' he said. ''After all, interest on home equity loans is still tax deductible, while the deductions on other consumer loans are being phased out. But the rise in home equity loans in recent months is really not that great. In any event, this still does not explain why revolving credit grew by such a small amount last month.''
Meanwhile, the Federal Reserve did not intervene in the credit market, although some analysts thought the central bank would drain part of the huge amount of dollars it sold earlier in the week to keep the dollar from rising further. In any case, the key Federal funds rate that banks charge each other for temporary funds traded at 8 15/16 all day.
Good demand for Treasury bills caused the discount rate on the 90-day issue to slip three basis points, to 7.77 percent; the six-month bills dipped two basis points, to 7.78 percent, and the one-year bills fell six basis points, to 7.62 percent.

HEADLINE: Brazil Seeks Extension for Getting Money

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Brazilian negotiators asked commercial bankers yesterday to allow Brazil more time to qualify for a $600 million payment from the banks that was scheduled to be made this month, bankers said.
The Brazilian request comes as the country apparently heads toward missing a September deadline for a $1.6 billion interest payment on outstanding commercial loans. Brazil's total debt, the largest of the developing countries, is $110 billion. 
The request came during a meeting in New York with the banks' advisory committee, which is headed by Citibank.
Under the loan agreement with the banks, Brazil cannot get the $600 million until it is in compliance with the International Monetary Fund's guidelines for reorganizing the country's economy. One banker said that if the $600 million is not taken by the end of September, it would no longer be available. The banker said the banks would consider the request.
Because Brazil's budget deficit, now about 7 percent of the country's gross domestic product, exceeds the I.M.F. guideline, an agreement with the I.M.F. seems far off. The lack of an agreement with the I.M.F. not only jeopardizes the $600 million payment, but is also holding up more than $3 billion in loans from the I.M.F., Japan and other sources.
The Brazilians have said they do not want to declare a moratorium on interest payments. That would damage the prospects for negotiating debt reduction under the program started by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. The timing of the start of the debt negotiations is also expected to depend on the progress the country is making on its economic program and the outcome of the coming presidential election.
The Brazilians, however, do not want to drain their foreign reserves, estimated at around $6 billion, just to make interest payments. They are still trying to work with the I.M.F. on an agreement that would free the loan money and give them enough to make the interest payments.
One banker said the interest payments were discussed in the meeting yesterday, but he said the Brazilians did not give a direct signal about what they are going to do. ''They didn't say they couldn't, and they didn't say they wouldn't,'' the banker said.

HEADLINE: Patents;
Running Diesel Engine With a Coal Slurry

BYLINE: By Edmund L. Andrews

 BODY:
An engineer at Defense Research Technologies Inc. of Rockville, Md., a research concern specializing in fluid control, has patented a device that makes it possible to power a diesel engine with a coal slurry.
The inventor, Allen B. Holmes, said the device could be an economical alternative to petroleum fuels for large engines like those used in ships and locomotives. 
The coal slurry consists of roughly equal parts of water and coal dust, and it must be sprayed into a combustion chamber as a fine mist in order to be burned. Mr. Holmes said the problem was that the slurry is a balky fluid that comes out of a nozzle as a mist only under very high pressure. The pressure of the streaming coal particles, however, wears out nozzles almost immediately.
Mr. Holmes's invention resolves that with a new nozzle that spews out liquid as a conical sheet, like a witch's hat. As the cone spreads out, the sheet becomes thinner and the particles separate into droplets. By applying comparatively small amounts of pressure, Mr. Holmes said, the liquid becomes a mist virtually as soon as it leaves the nozzle.
The device is being incorporated in an experimental engine being built by Adiabatics Inc. of Columbus, Ind.
Mr. Holmes received patent 4,862,837.

HEADLINE: Fall in Consumer Debt Is First in 2 1/2 Years

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Consumers repaid more debt than they took out during July, as installment debt outstanding fell for the first time in two and a half years, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday.
Economists warned, however, that the decline was probably not a sign of a spending collapse, even though it did show more reluctance to borrow.
''It could be a sign that consumers are getting more cautious and approaching the limits of how much debt they are comfortable with,'' said Paul Kasriel, an economist at the Northern Trust Company, Chicago. ''But we know that retail sales were strong in July and that car sales have strengthened the past few months.'' 
Many economists said future reports would probably show a resumption of increases in consumer indebtedness. July's decline of one-half of one percent followed monthly increases of 4.7 percent in June and 7.3 percent in May.
The drop in July, with loan repayments exceeding new borrowings by $280 million, resulted mostly from a $1.46 billion decline in car loans and a much smaller than normal increase of $1.27 billion in revolving loans, which are primarily from credit cards. In June, when consumer debt rose $2.72 billion, car loans fell $549 million, but revolving credit loans rose by $3.12 billion.
Some analysts were surprised by the July report because car sales in the month improved to an annual rate of 7.6 million units, up from about 7 million in June. Several economists said the Fed data on debt for July might be revised to show more borrowing for cars and an overall increase in consumer debt.
''There has been a general slowdown in consumer spending this year,'' said Ysabel Burns McAleer, an economist at the American Financial Services Association, a group representing consumer finance companies. ''But July's decline in consumer debt probably exagerrated the extent of any consumer retrenching.''
During the first half of this year, consumer spending grew at a 1.7 percent annual rate, down from 7.4 percent in 1988, Ms. McAleer noted.
Much of the spending slowdown came in automobiles, a sector that has revived in recent months as car producers have offered larger incentives in the form of rebates and low-interest financing. In August, sales continued to improve to an annual rate of 8.3 million units.
The Fed's consumer debt report does not include home equity loans, a rapidly growing form of second mortgage. Because mortgage interest payments are generally tax-deductible, while the deductibility of interest on personal debt has been sharply curtailed, some consumers have been trying to borrow against the value of their houses to make purchases that they would previously have financed by installment debt.
According to other Federal Reserve data published yesterday, home equity loans at large banks nationally totaled $23.4 billion in the week ended Aug. 30, up $154 million in the latest week and $5.2 billion in the last year.
Borrowing for mobile homes in July declined for the sixth consecutive month. Loans dropped $60 million, or by 3 percent on an annual basis. That followed drops of 13.4 percent in June, 2.1 percent in May, 2.8 percent in April, 8.2 percent in March and 2.9 percent in February.

HEADLINE: Former Mayor of Danbury Is Indicted in Racketeering

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 8

 BODY:
A former Mayor of Danbury was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges that he led a racketeering enterprise from the Mayor's office in the mid-1980's, using extortion to profit from the real estate and construction boom then sweeping western Connecticut.
Four other former city officials were charged with evading Federal income taxes on money earned from city projects in which, prosecutors said, the defendants had a hidden financial interest.
The former Mayor, James E. Dyer, who served two terms from 1979 to 1987, was charged with using the power of his office to extort $90,000 from a real estate developer and a bank over five years, including $1,000-a-month payments from the developer of the Danbury Fair Mall that went on for more than four years, the indictment said. 
Mr. Dyer denied the charges, calling them ''unsubstantiated.''
 
Investigated in 1987
Mr. Dyer, who is 42 years old, was also indicted in March on Federal charges that he extorted money from the Danbury Savings and Loan Association. The indictment today used those charges, along with the new allegations about payments from the mall developer, as the basis for the racketeering charge.
Mr. Dyer, a Democrat in a traditionally Democratic city, was under investigation by Federal prosecutors in 1987, when he ran for re-election and was defeated by a Republican, Joseph H. Sauer.
Mr. Sauer, running for re-election this fall, said he would not use the Dyer case against his opponent, Gene F. Eriquez, who served on the city's 21-member Common Council during the Dyer years. But Mr. Sauer said he had ordered a local police investigation into the bidding and contract-awarding processes in a $20 million downtown revitalization project that began in 1984. Mr. Dyer was accused in the indictment of ''agreeing to accept'' a $100,000 payment from the developer of the project.
Mr. Eriquez, who said he had no knowledge of any illegalities in city government during his years on the council, called the charges against the former Mayor ''shocking and, if proven, disgusting.''
The United States Attorney for Connecticut, Stanley A. Twardy Jr., said more indictments were expected in the case.
 
Possible 72-Year Sentence
Beginning in the early 1980's, millions were invested here in real estate, and prices appreciated rapidly. Mr. Dyer's possible role in that boom was an issue in the last mayoral election here, in 1987. The Democrats lost control of the Common Council, on which they had held all 21 seats through most of the decade.
If Mr. Dyer is convicted on all counts, he could get a combined maximum sentence of 72 years and $1.6 million in fines.
Reached at his home by telephone, Mr. Dyer said, ''I never extorted five cents from anyone in my entire life.''
Mr. Dyer is to be arraigned on the charges Tuesday and said he would enter his formal plea of not guilty then.
The other men charged today are all to be arraigned on Sept. 20. Two former Planning Commission members, Richard J. Ramey and Richard A. Durkin, are charged with tax evasion. Two other officials and two other men involved in separate land-development deals were charged with failing to file Federal tax returns. The officials are a former Zoning Commission member, Nicholas Falzone, and former State Representative Joseph Walkovich.
The other men charged are Charles J. Durkin, Richard Durkin's father, and Edward Simon Jr. Richard Durkin, Mr. Ramey and Mr. Simon were also charged with conspiracy to defraud the the Government.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 20, 1989, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Sept. 9 about a former mayor of Danbury, Conn., indicted on Federal racketeering charges misstated the number of terms he served. The former Mayor, James E. Dyer, served four two-year terms between 1979 and 1987.

HEADLINE: Party, Described as Cult, Seeks Role in Primary

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
The New Alliance Party, a small left-wing organization whose 1988 Presidential candidate was on the ballot in all 50 states, is presenting itself this year as the alternative to the regular Democrats running for City Council president, comptroller and several other posts in the New York City Democratic primary Tuesday.
The party, founded 10 years ago in New York, describes itself as an organization led by black women and dedicated to the rights of black, Hispanic and gay people. Members claim it is the nation's fastest growing party.
But critics contend that the New Alliance Party is a fringe group with hazy politics and few concrete proposals. They say it is dominated by the teachings and personality of a white psychotherapist, Fred Newman, who helped found the group. 
 
Small, Cultlike Core
Some people, including a former member who was the party's Presidential candidate in 1984, say it has a small, cultlike core that rigorously follows Dr. Newman's psychological and political theories. Dr. Newman has also been denounced by the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith for statements it calls anti-Semitic.
Chip Berlet, a researcher with Political Research Associates, a nonprofit group in Boston that investigates authoritarian groups, called the party ''your garden variety totalitarian political cult.''
Dr. Newman said it was ''an absurd characterization'' to call the party a cult. He said the accusations come from people on the left who were ''being sectarian and refusing to recognize the extraordinary accomplishments'' of the party's leaders.
Those leaders maintain that their organization is not a cult and that they work to unify black, Jewish, Hispanic, and gay people and others.
''We've outdone every left force in the country, and that's why we're being challenged,'' said the party's chairwoman, Leonore B. Fulani, who was its 1988 Presidential candidate. ''The controversy is testament to the fact that we're stepping on the right toes.''
In New York's municipal elections, the party is employing a dual strategy, running members in the Democratic primary Tuesday while reserving its own line for the general election.
An exception is the party's support of Borough President David N. Dinkins of Manhattan in the Democratic mayoral race. Should Mr. Dinkins lose, Dr. Fulani will run on the New Alliance line in November. Dr. Fulani, a developmental psychologist, ran for mayor in 1985 and received 7,597 votes, or 0.6 percent of the 1,170,904 votes cast.
Dr. Fulani said she received about 250,000 votes nationally last year. She had 10,502 votes, or 0.5 percent, of the 2,126,418 cast in New York City.
Dr. Fulani and other party candidates talked passionately in a recent interview about the need to address unemployment, inadequate housing and health care and other problems in poor communities, but they offered no new programs or ideas of their own. They said instead that the prime issue is ''fair elections.''
Party leaders said their views have been ignored or misrepresented by the media and the established political parties. ''It's the big-money interests that control the political process,'' said the party's candidate for Council president, Rafael Mendez.
Party members have been demanding that Mr. Dinkins shift on several matters. The tone of their effort, which has included demonstrations and heckling of Mr. Dinkins at public appearances, has been far more harsh than any attacks made by his opponents.
''We're involved in a fight to save his soul,'' Dr. Fulani said of Mr. Dinkins.
Among the demands is that Mr. Dinkins withdraw a television commercial that highlights his rejection of Louis Farrakhan, the head of the Nation of Islam, for making anti-Semitic remarks. The party contends that Mr. Farrakhan's statements - along with those by Dr. Newman that have been condemned by the Anti-Defamation League - have been quoted out of context and were not anti-Semitic.
The party is demanding that Mr. Dinkins support Dr. Mendez, a Bronx psychologist running in the primary against the incumbent Council president, Andrew J. Stein. The party contends that only by endorsing Dr. Mendez can Mr. Dinkins demonstrate support for Hispanic New Yorkers.
Other party members running in the Democratic primary are Steve Rose, a nurse and a candidate for comptroller, and Barbara R. Taylor, who is challenging Councilwoman Ruth W. Messinger for the nomination as Manhattan borough president.
Ms. Taylor called Ms. Messinger, perhaps the most active liberal on the Council, ''the official liberal cover of the Democratic Party.''
Ms. Taylor, who runs a private elementary school in Harlem, said Ms. Messinger had no business trying to win support in Harlem without first acknowledging the New Alliance Party as a prime representative of black and Hispanic people.
''She's pretty stupid to have nerve enough to come into this community and not dialogue with Dr. Fulani and the New Alliance Party,'' Ms. Taylor said.
''In the very few encounters we've had,'' Ms. Messinger responded, ''I've not understood any of the attacks she's made on me.''
 
Attacks Progressives
Critics say the New Alliance Party often concentrates its attacks on progressive politicians and groups. Sue Hyde, an official with the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force, said many local gay and lesbian groups complained last year that party members had tried to disrupt their meetings or take over their organizations.
Some people contend that the party is in essence a front for Dr. Newman. ''The people they put forward as leaders are black women, and their avowed politics sound terrific, but it's a con game,'' Mr. Berlet said. ''The ideological leader of the group is now, has been and will be forever Fred Newman.''
Mr. Berlet said that Dr. Newman had been allied with Lyndon LaRouche, the political extremist, during the 1970's, and then severed ties when Mr. LaRouche drifted into right-wing politics.
Party leaders said Dr. Newman has staunchly opposed Mr. LaRouche since then, and they argued that opponents were trying to discredit him by raising an old, brief alliance.
Mr. Berlet said members of the inner circle are required to be in therapy, applying Dr. Newman's psychological and political theories, which he called ''an amalgamation of Stalin, Freud and Lyndon LaRouche.''
Mr. Berlet estimated that the core includes about 100 people, with another 1,000 people active in the party's political efforts nationally. Dr. Fulani said that the party's membership stood at 20,000 in 1987 and had grown since, but that the exact number was not known. ''We're in the process of putting our membership files in order,'' she said.
Dennis Serrette, the party's Presidential candidate in 1984 who has since broken with the group, described it as dominated by Dr. Newman and ''very, very cultlike.''
He said Dr. Newman was ''as close to a guru as anybody could be.''
Dr. Fulani called Mr. Serrette's contentions ''a lie'' and ''cult baiting.''
''Serrette's attack was really a low-level, cowardly attack on the black female leadership of the party,'' she said.

GRAPHIC: The New Alliance Party candidates running for city office in the Democratic primary: Dr. Rafael Mendez, for City Council president; Barbara Taylor, for Manhattan borough president; Dr. Lenora B. Fulani, chairwoman of the party, for mayor; and Pedro Espada Jr., for councilman. (NYT/Don Hogan Charles)
