HEADLINE: Revisiting Promises Koch Made in '85

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
While opponents speak in hopeful generalities, an incumbent mayor campaigning for re-election can - and Edward I. Koch does - hold forth the prospect of specific new housing and workplaces, pinpointing their locations and describing them appreciatively, almost as if they had already been built.
But what happens after the election is over?
A look at more than a dozen building and reconstruction projects that Mayor Koch announced in the weeks before the 1985 primary suggests that the tangible results of such announcements are slow to materialize - sometimes not even by the next election.
Delays have plagued large-scale commercial developments, which city officials ascribe in part to the stock market collapse of October 1987 and in part to lawsuits brought by the projects' opponents, things beyond a mayor's control. Smaller-scale housing projects seem to have fared better. 
Speaking yesterday of the projects announced in 1985, Mr. Koch said City Hall fulfilled its responsibility. ''In all these areas, maybe with some exceptions, the governmental process worked,'' he said.
 
Creating an 'Atmosphere'
About the announcements and press releases four years ago, he said: ''It is helpful to the city to create an atmosphere, an environment, of development and new jobs. The announcement is not an announcement to say in stone, 'It will be done exactly this way.' Now, the press always wants to know when will the ground be broken. So you make an estimate. It can never be a certainty.
''The important thing,'' he said, ''is that in all of these areas we have built more housing and more economic development than was expected at the time of that particular announcement. We've done much more - maybe not that particular project in exactly that way. And I don't have to defend that.''
Nor does he have to curtail it. One day last month, for example, he broke ground for the reconstruction of the Kings County Hospital Center, announced a new shelter for the homeless and other housing in Brooklyn and announced the renovation of four neighborhood shopping areas in the Bronx.
In 1985, Mayor Koch was challenged for the Democratic nomination by Carol Bellamy, the City Council President, and Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr. of Manhattan.
These are the major housing and development announcments he made between July 1 of that year, when the fiscal year began and public attention started turning to the election, and the Sept. 10 primary. The current status is given for each project, largely based on information from city officials.
July 1 In Brooklyn, a 100-unit apartment building for the aged was to be ready by 1986, Mayor Koch said, and ''our commitment to provide Carroll Gardens with top-notch housing for low- and moderate-income senior citizens will be realized.''
The building, at 41 First Street, between Bond and Hoyt Streets, started receiving tenants in the spring of 1986. It is operated by Catholic Charities, Diocese of Brooklyn.
July 9 In the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, a 276-unit Housing Authority project was to be built. ''We said we would bring back this area and we have kept our word,'' Mr. Koch said.
The project, bounded by Knickerbocker, Gates and Wilson Avenues and Menahan Street, was completed in 1986 and is now home to about 910 people.
July 11 Boston Properties was to buy the city-owned site of the New York Coliseum at Columbus Circle for $455 million and develop an enormous complex - shops, apartments, a hotel and the headquarters of the Phibro-Salomon financial concern. ''What a wonderful affirmation of New York City's primacy as the financial and real-estate capital of the world,'' Mayor Koch said. Demolition of the Coliseum has not begun. Salomon is no longer involved. The project has been redesigned and scaled down, following a successful legal challenge led by the Municipal Art Society. The price for the land has dropped to $337 million. A new lawsuit against the project by a coalition of elected officials and community groups was begun Tuesday.
July 18 A 12-story office building was to be built on Livingston Street in downtown Brooklyn by Cohen Brothers Realty and Starrett Housing, taking advantage of tax benefits and energy savings. It was to be finished in 1988.
Construction of Livingston Plaza is to begin next month, with completion in 1991. The New York City Transit Authority will be its tenant.
July 19 The Park Avenue Retail Market, or La Marqueta, under the elevated railroad tracks between 111th and 119th Streets was to be redeveloped, Mayor Koch said, and ''once again benefit East Harlem residents, business people and shoppers throughout the city.''
Developers were selected, but there were lengthy negotiations and the project was stalled by maintenance work by the Metro-North Commuter Railroad. Site preparation is to begin this month.
July 30 The Atlantic Terminal area in Brooklyn was to be redeveloped by Rose Associates into Atlantic Center, to include 1.8 million square feet of office space, with the Health and Hospitals Corporation as a major tenant, and 680 ''town house-style'' condominiums. The project ''is well under way and proceeding on schedule,'' Mr. Koch said in 1985, forming ''a key part of our plans to create new jobs in the revitalized heart of downtown Brooklyn.''
The first phase of the project, with the hospital offices, was to be finished in 1988, with overall completion in 1992. Nothing has been built. The hospital agency is out of the project. Four lawsuits are pending in state and Federal courts, concerned with economic and environmental impacts. Potential settlement offers include some reduction of density.
Aug. 1 The area around the Staten Island Ferry Terminal in lower Manhattan was to be completely redeveloped. ''With refurbished ferry facilities and new office, hotel and cultural space,'' Mayor Koch said, ''South Ferry Plaza will provide a new focus to the downtown area for visitors and residents.''
Construction was to begin in 1988. It now appears that the start is three years away. Reasons for the delay include the city's expansion of the developer selection process as well as the need for state legislation to permit changes in park land. Developers and cultural tenants have been chosen.
Aug. 6 A nine-story office and shopping center called Executive Plaza was to be built in Jamaica, Queens, by the Mack Company of New Jersey. Mayor Koch said it would ''further enhance the area's position as a prime office location, commercial shopping district and residential neighborhood.''
Construction was to begin by January 1986. Mack did not follow the timetable, city officials said, and after several extensions, was removed as developer, with a $175,000 penalty. The site on Jamaica Avenue is still being marketed.
Aug. 15 As many as 1,700 new homes were to be built in the East New York section of Brooklyn - 1,550 under the Nehemiah program of the East Brooklyn Churches coalition and another 150 by the New York City Partnership. ''It should provide the catalyst for the rejuvenation of the entire area,'' Mr. Koch said.
Today, 232 of the Nehemiah houses are finished and 372 are in construction. Land has been acquired for another 636. The Partnership homes were not built but 44 other units are being developed. Commissioner Abraham Biderman of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development said the rebuilding of East New York was always envisioned as a ''long-term effort.''
Aug. 16 Winning bids were announced in the sale of 149 vacant, city-owned brownstones in Harlem. Mayor Koch said the houses, ''when rehabilitated, will be some of the best housing in Harlem.'' So far, 131 of the properties have been conveyed to new owners. Of these, 10 are complete. Another 23 are in construction, with 56 getting plans or financing. The rest have not been started.
Aug. 27 The former Brooklyn Army Terminal in Sunset Park was to be redeveloped as what Mayor Koch called ''a new first-rate, modern industrial center,'' with 1 million square feet renovated in the enormous Building B. This was supposed to create or keep some 1,500 jobs at the terminal and was to be ready in 1987.
Today, some 2,000 people work there, and the project was completed on time and under budget, said officials of the city's Public Development Corporation. Over 90 percent of the renovated space has been leased to 29 businesses, including printers, garment makers and other light manufacturers.
Sept. 3 The city and the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York were to work together to create housing in Manhattan for people with AIDS who did not need acute-care hospitalization. This was, Mr. Koch said, ''a pressing concern.''
In December 1985, the Gift of Love home opened on Washington Street, between Christopher and West 10th Streets, run by the Missionaries of Charity. It has 15 beds for homeless people with AIDS. No city funds are involved.
Sept. 6 In the University Heights section of the Bronx, 117 homes were to be built ''for a vital segment of New York City's population - middle-income families,'' Mr. Koch said. ''I look forward to welcoming 117 new homeowners into the Aqueduct Homes.''
The project, Aqueduct Avenue New Homes, was to be completed in 1987. But the original builder defaulted. Another developer built nine homes and then defaulted. The balance of the project has been awarded to a third developer, who is to build 110 two-family homes beginning this fall.
Sept. 9 The Brooklyn Renaissance Plaza Hotel, operated by Hilton Hotels, was to be developed as part of a 29-story complex across from the State Supreme Court Building. The Mayor said Hilton's decision ''reaffirms Brooklyn's position as America's newest, most desirable business address.''
Construction was expected to begin in 1986. Nothing has happened yet. What is missing is an office tenant and the search for one was complicated by the market collapse. City development officials said there have been serious lease negotiations and that Hilton is still part of the project.
Sept. 9 In virtually his last formal statement before the primary, Mayor Koch announced ''another major coup'' for New York - that the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company would keep its headquarters in Manhattan, in a tower to be built by the developer George Klein at 60 Wall Street.
''If I wanted this to be nonpartisan, I would have announced this on Wednesday,'' the Mayor said. And, he added, ''I would have had to have my head examined.''
The tower is nearing completion.

HEADLINE: GORBACHEV SAYS INTERNAL ENEMIES ENDANGER CHANGE

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 9

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said tonight that his program of change was endangered by internal enemies who have whipped up public alarm and disorder.
In his first appearance after a monthlong vacation during which the country has been rattled by ethnic unrest and economic anxiety, the Soviet leader condemned the protest strikes that have spread through several republics, and asserted that conservatives and radicals were trying to push the country to the brink of instability.
 
Warning to Nationalists
''In this multivoice choir, we can hear threats of approaching chaos and talk of a threatened coup, and even of civil war,'' Mr. Gorbachev said. ''It is a fact that some people would like to create in this society an atmosphere of alarm, a feeling that there is no way out, a feeling of uncertainty.'' 
''We should not fall for this,'' he said. ''We should not halt in our tracks, but continue along the road of planned change.'' [In Washington, officials said that in recent months, a feeling has spread through the upper reaches of the Bush Administration that Mr. Gorbachev's policies have an increasingly poor chance of success over the long term. Page 16.] A Somber Address Somber in tone, the televised 25-minute address was evidently intended as a warning to nationalist movements challenging the Communist Party's authority and to conservatives who hope for a reassertion of central authority.
Mr. Gorbachev appeared to have meant his comments in part as a rebuttal to the senior party conservatives Viktor M. Chebrikov and Yegor K. Ligachev, two Politburo members who have issued dire warnings in the last two weeks about the dangers of nationalist disorder.
In a speech published today in Pravda, the Communist Party daily, Mr. Ligachev said that if ethnic discord and strikes continue, ''the disintegration of the Union of Soviet Republics is inevitable.''
Mr. Gorbachev did not specifically mention the Baltic independence movements that have recently come under fierce Kremlin attack, but they were clearly on his mind.
In the month since Mr. Gorbachev left for his annual vacation in the Crimea, tensions have risen over the Baltic movements, which dispute the legitimacy of Soviet power in their republics and demand the right to decide whether they will remain within the Soviet federation.
The Communist Party has issued a scathing denunciation of the movements, and Mr. Gorbachev interrupted his holiday to telephone the Lithuanian Communist Party leader and say that talk of secession is intolerable.
Rumors circulated in the Baltics that the Kremlin might use military force to restore control. The Lithuanian Communist Party chief, Algirda Brazauskas, warned that the use of force could not be ruled out if the independence movement raced out of control.
 
No Tolerance for Strikes
Russian-speaking minorities angered by restrictive new laws on languages and voting rights have held protest strikes in Estonia and Moldavia, a non-Baltic republic. Strike committees have been organized in Lithuanian factories, with the support of local Communist Party officials.
In Azerbaijan, factories and railroads were idled by nationalists demanding political autonomy and a tougher line in the republic's territorial dispute with its neighbor, Armenia.
Mr. Gorbachev said the country ''cannot tolerate'' such disruptions of the economy.
''If we take this path for solving problems, it can have very dangerous consequences for this soviety,'' he said. ''These problems must be solved by other methods, in a timely way, so that they do not spread and take on a malignant character.''
 
Platform on Ethnic Issues
Mr. Gorbachev's remarks came as the Communist Party Central Committee was preparing for a special plenary meeting later this month to approve a party platform on ethnic issues, offering republics and local governments greater economic and political autonomy.
Popular-front groups in several republics have asserted that the party's proposal keeps too much power in Moscow's hands.
The Soviet leader conceded that measures aimed at reviving the economy had not yet produced results, and predicted that ''unpopular, tough and, to a certain extent, painful measures'' may be required to make the economy more productive.
He did not specify any new measures he had in mind.

HEADLINE: U.S. Sees No Early Accord With Iran on Hostages

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
The Bush Administration has concluded that despite hints that Iran would like a deal for the release of American hostages, Teheran's new leadership has not decided to act, and Government officials say it could be a long time before it does.
Iran is heading in a more pragmatic direction since the death of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini on June 3, the officials say, but there is no indication that its new leaders have decided that helping to free the eight Americans held hostage in Lebanon would have political benefits. And the officials say domestic considerations will be decisive in Iran's handling of the hostage affair.
As a result, since Washington has no military option and since it is unwilling to bargain with Teheran, Administration officials have concluded that the White House can do little but wait for the Iranian leadership to be politically inclined and politically able to work for the hostages' release. 
Israeli officials say they understand that the best favor they can do the Administration - and United States-Israeli relations - is to prevent the issue from becoming contentious by saying as little as possible about the hostage situation or the fate of the captured Lebanese spiritual leader they are holding, Sheik Abdel Karim Obeid.
Alluding to the appointment by Iran's President, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, of a new Government made up largely of American-trained technocrats and individuals committed more to economic development than spreading revolutionary gospel, an Administration policy maker said:
''Things in Iran are changing for the better, but more has to happen. Sometimes one has to be patient, which should not be confused with a lack of interest. Simply because we are not launching 100 high-profile initiatives every day does not mean that we are not involved or concerned. But tactically, one has to be patient and allow things to work themselves out.''
As Administration analysts see it, the core of the problem is that the taking of hostages was not simply an Iranian foreign policy decision, which could easily be reversed. Rather, it was part of the essential theology of Iran's revolution, which was to punish the United States for involvement in Iran.
''The hostages are part of the legacy of Khomeini,'' said Fouad Ajami, an expert on Iran at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies. ''They were taken on his watch. The new Iranian regime has to decide what will be a decent interval between Khomeini's death and a deal for the hostages. It is Iran's call. The Bush Administration cannot speed up the course of Iranian history.''
Even movement toward greater pragmatism in Teheran will not automatically lead to a solution of the hostage crisis, State Department analysts say. For instance, President Rafsanjani may conclude that it will be an asset to hold onto the hostages to keep hard-liners at bay while he tries to revamp his economy with Western aid.
On Monday, Iranian press reports quoted Ali Mohammed Besharati, Iran's Deputy Foreign Minister, as saying that as ''a sign of good will, the United States should denounce the interference in Iranian affairs by previous Administrations and release the Iranian assets with no conditions.''
''They keep requesting that we make the first move,'' a State Department official said. ''And that is just not going to happen.''
Even if Iran makes a strategic decision to work for the release of the American hostages, it would only be the beginning of the process, State Department experts say. The Lebanese families and political organizations holding the hostages derive certain benefits from their captives that will not be easy to compensate for.
For the pro-Iranian Lebanese militia known as the Party of God, its hostages are insurance against a large-scale Israeli strike on its bases in southern Lebanon, Israeli officials say.
For the smaller groups, the hostages are their ticket to political influence in Lebanon. For Syria, the presence of American hostages in areas of Lebanon they control means that Washington can never ignore Damascus when it comes to Middle East peacemaking.

HEADLINE: Birth Control Making Inroads in Populous Kenya

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KAMU THANGA, Kenya

 BODY:
Kenya's birth rate has dropped, the first sign that the rate of population growth, the highest in the world, may be slowing, a Government survey shows.
In the last five years, the average number of children per Kenyan woman of childbearing age has dropped from 7.7 to 6.7, according to the Kenya Demographic and Health Survey of 1989.
''When we see this kind of result, we are very excited,'' said Prof. H. W. O. Okoth-Ogendo, director of the Population Studies Research Institute at Nairobi University, which alerted the nation to the severity of its population problem a decade ago.
 
Hoping for an African Trend
Some specialists heralded the result as good news not only for Kenya but for other African nations where births have been rising beyond the ability of already weak economies to keep pace. 
''This is the first significant decline in fertility in Africa ever. And it may be a precursor for other African countries with high population-growth rates,'' said Steven W. Sinding, director of the United States Agency for International Development's mission in Kenya. The agency financed the survey conducted by the Kenyan Government's Council for Population and Development.
Mr. Sinding said the results should help demonstrate that Africa is not the ''hopeless case'' many demographers suggest it is.
 
More Data Needed
It was hoped that the results of a national census taken last week would confirm that the total population-growth rate had fallen, Professor Okoth-Ogendo said. But it will not be possible to calculate growth until after full census results, due at the end of the year, because population growth involves the number of deaths as well as births.
One of the reasons for Kenya's population increase, specialists say, has been the combination of fewer infant deaths, the result of a better health-care system, with the higher number of births.
The World Bank estimates Kenya's annual population growth rate at 4.1 percent, based on data from the 1979 census. Kenya's Planning Ministry says the growth rate is 3.7 percent, a figure based on indirect measurements taken since the last census. By comparison, the population-growth rate in the United States is 0.7 percent a year, and in France, 0.4 percent.
There are 23.3 million people living in Kenya, according to 1988 official figures. Population experts said the decline in the number of children Kenyan women are having was attributable to several factors.
 
Will and Prosperity
These include the political will of President Daniel arap Moi's Government to promote family planning, a well-developed rural health system that can deliver contraceptive services, and the widening realization that families are financially better off with fewer chldren. Traditionally in Africa, large families have been viewed as a sign of economic well-being and as a way to better insure a secure old age.
''Economic performance has a lot to do with it,'' Professor Okoth-Ogendo said. ''We find women who are working are contracepting at a higher rate. The economy is a powerful stimulus to fertility decline.''
The survey showed that 27 percent of married women are using some method of birth control. Two-thirds were using ''modern methods'' - the pill, intrauterine devices, injections, sterilization or periodic abstinence.
The diaphragm is rarely used, and the condom has been very unpopular until the advent of AIDS, which has caused an increase in its use.
 
Some Things Never Change
Traditional methods of birth control range from prolonged breast-feeding, periodic abstinence due to taboos and herbal remedies.
In 1984, a survey on the prevalence of contraception found that just 18 percent of married women used some form of contraception.
As pleased as he said he was about the decline in births, Professor Ogoth-Okendo struck some warning notes.
''We are worried about the wide differentiation between contraceptive use on a regional level,'' he said.
In the eastern province, 40 percent of married women were using contraceptives. In other areas, contraceptive use was as low as 6 percent.
And the professor noted another disturbing sign. ''We are still dealing with the fact that 60 to 70 percent of the women are in their reproductive stages - aged 15 to 49,'' he said.
 
Bringing Pills to the People
The acceptability of contraceptives was evident at a clinic run by the Family Planning Association of Kenya here in the village of Kamu Thanga, 50 miles east of Nairobi.
Joyce Wambua, 36 years old and the mother of seven children, said she had been convinced four years ago by a family-planning field worker that she would be financially better off if she stopped having children. Noting the beginning of her oldest child's schooling, she recalled:
''Things are very expensive. Our first was in Form 1 at school, and by that stage, I had one child every year after that.'' Her husband was at first reluctant to limit the size of the family. ''He wanted to know how long I wanted to rest from having children. I said just three years. After three years, he told me he didn't want any more.''
There is optimism, as well, from the village leader, Dick Ndunda, 54, who arranged for the clinic to be established six years ago in the local mud-brick, tin-roofed community center. Mr. Ndunda said he was beginning to see clear signs of fewer births here. ''Every year they were admitting 200 girls and boys in the primary school,'' he said. ''Now there are only 80 admissions.''
His own family is also a startling example. ''I have given birth to so many children,'' he said, acknowledging after several questions that he had 12 children. But his 35-year-old son, he said, was different. ''He and his wife have three children, and will have no more,'' he said proudly.
Mr. Sinding, the Agency for International Development official, said he had noticed during visits to rural areas in the last three years that such a dramatic reduction in family size from the 40-to-50 age group to the 20-to-30 group was not unusual.

GRAPHIC: Josephine Wairumu, a nurse, discussing birth-control pills with Joyce Wambua, who has seven children and began practicing birth control in 1985. (NYT/Jane Perlez)

HEADLINE: U.S. Unease on Gorbachev: How Exposed Is He?

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON Sept. 9

 BODY:
In the last few months, a feeling has spread through the upper reaches of the Bush Administration that the policies of the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, have an increasingly poor chance of success over the long term.
While President Bush has repeatedly declared that he wants to see Mr. Gorbachev succeed - and that remains the predominant view within the Government - Administration officials say that events of the last few months have brought into stark relief the extent of the problems unleashed by Mr. Gorbachev's moves to open up Soviet society. In particular, they point to the miners' strike, the sputtering, empty-shelf Soviet economy and nationalist unrest in the Baltic states.
For the first time, officials say, analysts for the Central Intelligence Agency, the National Intelligence Council and the Pentagon have begun looking seriously at the implications for the United States of increasing ethnic turmoil in the Soviet Union, caused by the desire openly expressed by non-Russian nationalities to have more self-rule. These campaigns range from a desire for more local autonomy to outright secession from the Soviet Union. 
 
Provocation and Harsh Reply
The situation in the Baltic republics - Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, all of which were independent between the two world wars - has been the most acute, and prompted an unusually harsh Central Committee warning last month. That warning has led to heightened concerns in the Baltics, where some spokesmen have talked about the possibility of Moscow's using force to quell their nationalism.
A major concern for Administration officials is that Baltic nationalists might ignore the Central Committee warning, to which Mr. Gorbachev subscribes, not to press their separatist demands too far, and thereby force the Soviet leader into a crackdown that would have the same political repercussions in the West as China's suppression of the democracy movement in June in Tiananmen Square.
''It would mean the end of perestroika, at least for a while,'' a Soviet specialist in the Administration said, referring to Mr. Gorbachev's program of economic and political restructuring. ''It would lead to a fight within the Western alliance as to how harshly we should react, and it would destroy whatever confidence that people were starting to have in Gorbachev. We would be back at Square 1. What we would like to say to the Balts, but can't, is, Remember, you got as far as you have today because of Gorbachev.''
 
Grip on Power Likely
Although acknowledging that no one can predict political events in the Soviet Union, most Administration officials believe that because Mr. Gorbachev has shown himself to be such an adroit politician - by the way he co-opted the striking miners, kept a tenuous lid on the Baltic nationalists, and winnowed out opponents from the army command and Communist Party while building an independent power base in the Supreme Soviet and the Presidency - he is likely to remain in power for the next few years, at least.
The effect of these somewhat conflicting perceptions of Mr. Gorbachev and his prospects has been to leave senior Bush Administration policymakers with a continued feeling that they can, and should, exploit the Soviet leader's need for arms-control deals that will better enable him to use resources and energy to address his domestic woes, but to do so in ways that will insure that the United States can reverse any arrangement as fast as the Soviet Union can - should Moscow be gripped by instability, or Mr. Gorbachev swept away.
To the extent that there is a ''vision'' animating the approach of the Bush Administration to the Soviet Union today, it is shaped by these sorts of practical, day-to-day analyses and caluculations, which are constantly being reviewed and changed in light of events. Officials concede that there is no overarching strategy guiding the Administration, and that the President's stated theme of going ''beyond'' a policy of containing the Soviet Union to one of integrating it into ''the community of nations'' is a nice public- relations goal but no road map for daily decisions.
''People are now much more conscious of his difficulties,'' a senior Administration official said of the Soviet leader. ''Gorbachev obviously has problems. He would like to concentrate on his domestic problems and that means that he would at least like stability, if not progress, with the United States. That gives us a real opportunity, and I think we ought to pursue that. But I think the kinds of agreements we make ought to be those made with an eye to the possibility that if the present situation is reversed, we can recover at least as fast as the Soviet Union.''
 
Withdraw, Then Destroy
Citing an example of such an approach, the senior official pointed to the Administration's handling of the conventional-arms negotiations in Vienna, where the United States has continued to insist that both it and the Soviet Union not only withdraw troops and hardware from Europe, but also demobilize the withdrawn soliders and destroy the equipment.
''If troop withdrawals mean just pulling U.S. and Soviet forces out of Europe - say behind the Urals and back to the United States - that's a bad deal,'' this official said. ''Why a bad deal? Because of the geographical and political asymmetry. They are 10 days away. While once we get troops out of Europe, they are not going back, absent some enormous crisis.
''Therefore, how do you make them more symmetrical? You do it by saying that any troops that are withdrawn have to be demobilized. Those are the kinds of things we need to look at as we go through arms control so that we are not left out there naked in the event of a turnaround. Within that framework, I think that we can still do a lot that is in our interest.''
Another Administration analyst said of European affairs said: ''This is no time for grand strategy. There are too many mixed signals and impressions coming from the Soviet Union. The only way is to move step by step and try to respond to a general trend there, and not any single event.''
 
Timing of a Summit
This explains, in large part, why President Bush has been wavering about whether to set a date for a summit meeting with Mr. Gorbachev -something that will be a topic for discussion between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, at their meeting in Jackson Hole, Wyo., on Sept. 22. A summit meeting, by its nature, would require the Administration to make up its mind more clearly how it perceives Mr. Gorbachev and how far it wants to go with him.
When a senior official was asked whether Mr. Baker and Mr. Shevardnadze would set a summit date, he said equivocally, ''I think we would rather let developments determine the time a summit was appropriate, especially a first summit for the Administration, rather than let a date drive the negotiations.''
Interviews with policy makers make it clear that they came into office with a cautious attitude toward Mr. Gorbachev fed largely by their lingering doubts as to whether he was ''for real'' as a reformer. They are still cautious about how to deal with him. But now their caution is being fed by the mounting awareness that he is indeed for real - in fact, as one official put it, ''too real'' - and that his far-reaching policies may have set in motion a centrifugalprocess that could unsettle the entire country.
''When I look at what has been happening in the Soviet Union,'' a top Administration official said, ''I have to say to myself: the reformability of its system is open to serious question. You have a multi-ethnic empire beginning to show that it is still a multi-ethnic empire and was never assimilated into a single state. I see an economy in which you can't reform one part without reforming another. It is like an onion that you keep peeling off one layer of problems and find another layer underneath.
''On top of it all,'' the official added, ''you have given people the right to complain, and plenty to complain about, at the same time. So I ask myself, what are the chances of his pulling this off, and the answer is not much. Any shred of optimism I have left rests on Gorbachev's own personal adroitness.''
 
Dealings Will Continue
This sense of his adroitness is both crucial and widespread within the Government. It explains in part why despite the mounting pessimism about Mr. Gorbachev's prospects for success, no one in the Administration is prepared to argue that there is no use doing any serious business with the Soviet leader in areas like arms control and resolving regional conflicts.
Many Administration officials believe that short of a major upheaval galvanizing broad opposition, Mr. Gorbachev will probably hold onto the reins of power, despite what is bound to be a very bumpy road in the next few years.
Even in the event that Mr. Gorbachev were toppled or forced to become a hard-liner himself to survive, a majority of top Administration officials -including the President, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft - are inclined to believe that the reformist trend he set in motion would eventually have to be continued by his successor because of domestic economic needs.
There is, though, a minority sentiment - represented by Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney and Vice President Dan Quayle, in particular - who believe it is not impossible that instead of Mr. Gorbachev succeeding Mr. Gorbachev, ''Stalin would succeed Gorbachev,'' an Administration official said.

HEADLINE: Opposition Leader From Soviet Union Begins Visit to U.S.

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

 BODY:
Boris N. Yeltsin, the Soviet populist opposition leader, arrived in the United States yesterday and said he had come to learn more about ''the American experience in democracy.''
''You have more than 200 years' experience in democratic government, although bourgeois democracy,'' Mr. Yeltsin said. ''We're just getting out of the egg.''
The silver-haired, former Politburo member was beaming as he arrived at Kennedy International Airport for an eight-day visit of lectures and economic and political contacts. On his blue suit, he proudly wore the red button of a member of the Soviet Congress of People's Deputies.
''I want to see the Washington Monument, museums, libraries and cultural treasures; I also want to see you,'' Mr. Yeltsin said, waving to the large crowd of journalists gathered at the airport. It was Mr. Yeltsin's first visit to this country and it was the first non-official visit by a leading Soviet politician, organizers said.
 
Gorbachev's Popularity
The Soviet opposition leader said that he also had come to talk about the relations between the United States and the Soviet Union and ''how to make major improvements.'' Specifically, he said the Soviet Union wanted ''reduced armaments'' and ''much greater economic cooperation.''
In an exchange with journalists in the Pan Am terminal, Mr. Yeltsin spoke in Russian through an interpreter. He responded without hesitation to delicate questions like whether President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's popularity was slipping. ''It's been falling some lately,'' Mr. Yeltsin said.
When asked about the role of the opposition, Mr. Yeltsin said: ''Our leaders don't like this word; we call it pluralism. We do have a minority group in parliament.''
He declined to comment on the current unrest in the Balkans and in Armenia, saying that he preferred to address those issues at a press conference in the next couple of days.

HEADLINE: New Job for Aide Who Quit Bush Campaign

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9

 BODY:
Frederick V. Malek, who resigned a high-level post in George Bush's Presidential campaign last year while denying charges of anti-Semitism, will soon be appointed by Mr. Bush to a White House post, Administration officials said today.
The officials said Mr. Malek's job would be to coordinate plans for the 1990 economic summit of industrialized nations, to be held in the spring in the United States, at a site to be selected. They said the appointment was awaiting only a security clearance and an examination of Mr. Malek's finances. One of the officials said Mr. Malek would not be paid in the part-time but significant post. 
 
Malek Denies a Bias Act
Mr. Malek resigned last Sept. 11 as a high-level campaign adviser to Mr. Bush and as a top deputy to the chairman of the Republican National Committee after acknowledging that in 1971, at the behest of President Richard M. Nixon, he drew up a list of important Jewish officials at the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Mr. Malek, who was a special assistant to Mr. Nixon, emphatically denied when he resigned from the Bush camaign that he had engaged in an anti-Semitic act.
Mr. Malek said he had prepared the list after Mr. Nixon complained that a ''Jewish cabal'' had tried to undercut his record on the economy. Two months after he sent the list, two of the officials on it were reassigned to less visible jobs within the Labor Department. Mr. Malek said he had nothing to do with those personnel actions and would have refused to have become involved in the matter if he had been asked.
Since then, Mr. Malek has spoken privately to numerous Jewish groups and leaders in New York and Washington, asserting that he is not anti-Semitic and explaining that he provided the list under intense pressure from Mr. Nixon, who asked him five times.
White House officials said they were fairly convinced that Mr. Malek's appointment would not stir widespread opposition by Jewish groups.
Abraham H. Foxman, national director of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, said in a telephone interview: ''I don't think the American Jewish community will object to an appointment. Mr. Malek has in the last several months met members of the Jewish community and in conversations with them and in an article he's written for the Jewish press has apologized for his behavior many years ago and has put it behind him.'' Mr. Malek, who has known Mr. Bush since 1972 and is a member of his kitchen cabinet, is a wealthy businessman in Washington. Currently, the 52-year-old Mr. Malek is co-chairman of Coldwell Banker Commercial Group, co-chairman of Caterair International, the company formed to acquire the Marriott chain's airline catering business, and is on the board of directors of Northwest Airlines.
 
An Earlier Derailment
Adminisration officials said that Mr. Malek was slated to be appointed to a major job in the Administration, possibly even chief of staff, until the controversy broke over his role in the Nixon Administration. When Mr. Malek resigned from the Bush campaign he said it was ''because of my belief that nothing should interfere with the Vice President's victory in November.''
Within recent months Mr. Malek has met privately with the President on social occasions. Officials said that Mr. Malek has been offered at least one high-level job in the Administration, which would not have required Senate approval, but turned it down, partly because he did not want to revive the earlier controversy.
Officials indicated that the new post would involve coordinating with the White House and other Government agenices in arranging the economic summit of seven major indutrialized nations next year to be held in the United States. There has been some speculation that the summit will be held, at Mr. Bush's request, in Texas. This year's summit was held in Paris.

HEADLINE: 1,400 Hairstons Honor Kinship Born of Slavery

BYLINE: By ROBERT E. TOMASSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HIGH POINT, N.C., Sept. 4

 BODY:
The Hairstons held their annual family reunion here this weekend, not far from two of the plantations where their forebears toiled as slaves or ruled as masters.
For Peter W. Hairston, who is white, and Collie Hairston, who is black, their common heritage in the world of the pre-Civil War plantations was not very far away. In the 124 years since the end of the Civil War, some descendants of the white owners retain their elite positions as well as ownership of much of the vast plantations that were the economic and social backbone of the Old South.
And many descendants of the slaves, in a generation-by-generation improvement, have moved into the professions, the clergy, the military, business and the arts. 
In a remarkable celebration by a clan that may be the most extensively documented group of descendants of slaves, 1,400 black Hairstons came from 14 states to their four-day reunion here. Their ancestors, like many slaves, adopted the name of their former masters when slavery ended because they had known no other surname.
 
Handful of Whites Welcomed
While the reunion was overwhelmingly a black affair, a handful of white Hairstons attended and were warmly welcomed, especially Peter Hairston, a 76-year-old retired Superior Court judge, who is the clan's historian.
With the ''Hairston Clan Reunion'' emblazoned on baseball caps, T-shirts and bumper stickers, they poured into the Radisson Hotel for four days of dances, dinners, a barbecue and meetings to promote scholarships and kinship among white and black Hairstons.
The local Hairstons have been meeting every third Sunday for 58 years. Since the early 1930's Jester J. Hairston, a composer, conductor, actor and 88-year-old patriarch, has called every Hairston he could in the telephone books of towns and cities he traveled through. Some were white and some black, and most were curious about the history of the family.
In 1936, he recounted, after he appeared on a radio show in Los Angeles, he received a call from a listener named Hairston who wondered if they were related. He recited the Scottish origins of the white Hairstons and the listener was convinced they were related. ''I told her we must be cousins, but I didn't tell her I was the grandson of a slave,'' he said.
 
Surprised at Dinner Meeting
He met the listener for dinner and her confused surprise at meeting a black Hairston turned to amusement and curiosity. That meeting 53 years ago with Clara Hairston was apparently the start of the black Hairstons' efforts to incorporate the whites into the family gatherings.
That effort continues, organizers of the reunion said, as the family plans to establish state chapters in Georgia and Michigan.
Judge Hairston is the sixth-generation owner of Cooleemee, one of the Hairston plantations 20 miles southwest of High Point along the Yadkin River. With 4,200 acres during its heyday in the early 1800's, Cooleemee retains 2,300 acres of farmland and woods along with a columned house listed in the National Register of Historic Places.
To the north, the judge's brother, Nelson George Hairston, the Philip Keenan Professor of Zoology at the University of North Carolina, is a family owner of Saura Town, with about 6,000 acres.
 
Stories of the Plantations
Judge Hairston noted that his brother was one of four Hairstons listed in an edition of Who's Who a few years ago. The others were black, including Maj. Gen. Guy Edward Hairston Jr. of the Air Force.
Memories of the plantation for many of the Hairston blacks are limited to stories from grandparents or great-grandparents. But others, like Collie Hairston, who lives outside Camden, N.J., have more immediate remembrances.
In a photo from 1922 in ''The Cooleemee Plantation and its People,'' an account written by Judge Hairston in 1986, a young Collie Hairston, another black Hairston youth and a young white Hairston are shown, their arms around each other, laughing in a scene of adolescent playfulness.
''I can't tell you what it means to come here, to have this family,'' Collie Hairston said at one of the many parties during the reunion. The sentiment was echoed by many at the reunion, the 16th held by the National Hairston Clan.
 
Hairstons Marrying Hairstons
''Seeing these people, knowing we have the same background, that we are a family that goes way back is very important to me,'' said Joseph Henry Hairston, a black 67-year-old retired lawyer from Washington. ''But believe me, it can get very complicated.''
The complications arise from the practice of Hairstons' marrying Hairstons, who presumably are not blood relations.
The retired lawyer noted that the maiden name of his wife's half brother is Hairston. And while their fathers were different men, both were named Hairston. The retired judge's great-great-uncle Robert married the mother-in-law of his younger brother, Sam. ''Her name was Hairston also,'' said Peter Hairston.
The founder of the Hairston clan was Peter Hairston, born about 1695 in Dumfriesshire, Scotland, who came to America in 1729 and died in 1780. By 1851, a publication called The Richmond Whig termed a descendant, Samuel H. Hairston, the largest slaveholder in the country. By the Civil War, the Hairston plantations were spread over Virginia, North Carolina and Mississippi. Much of the land is still retained by Hairstons and their relations.
The black and white Hairstons have retained one vocal distinction. The blacks pronounce the name HAIR-ston, while the whites retain a Scottish ring with HOS-tin.

HEADLINE: TOXIC SITE CLEANUP REPORTED LAGGING

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Sept. 9

 BODY:
Only 34 of the 1,175 worst toxic waste dumps in the United States were cleaned in the first eight years of a program intended to solve the problem, and polluters paid less than a tenth of the cost, the Rand Corporation said in a report made public Friday.
In a statement summarizing a study of the Superfund cleanup program, Rand, a nonprofit research organization, said: ''Superfund has been super slow at cleaning up toxic waste sites, spending available funds and recovering its outlays from those who did the polluting.''
The study, which was done by Rand's Institute for Civil Justice, covers the Environmental Protection Agency's accomplishments from 1980, when the program was created, to September 1988.
''The bottom line is that we passed legislation that could have permitted as much as $10 billion of Federal money to start cleaning up hazardous waste sites,'' said the author of the study, Jan Paul Acton. 
''Congress has appropriated only about half that amount, and E.P.A. has only spent a quarter of that amount,'' he added. ''What we've got is a gap between the rhetoric and the reality.''
 
Only 34 Sites Cleaned
Of the 1,175 toxic waste sites that the environmental agency has placed on its National Priority List for immediate attention, only 34 have been declared clean, the study found. As many as 30,000 dumps may have to be cleaned eventually.
The report also said the environmental agency spent only $2.6 billion of the $4.5 billion appropriated by Congress from 1980 to 1988 for cleanup projects. Of the $2.6 billion that was spent, the report said, only $1.6 billion went directly to cleanup work; the rest was spent on management and legal costs.
The agency recovered only $230 million of the $2.6 billion from polluters, who are supposed to pay for the cleanup work, the study found.
''We think improvements are possible, but substantial progress has been made,'' said Walter Kovalick Jr., deputy director of the agency's Office of Emergency and Remedial Response, which administers the cleanup program.
 
Progress at Other Sites
While only 34 dumps had been declared clean by September 1988, Mr. Kovalick said cleanup is under way on more than 170 others. Designs for waste isolation, treatment plants or other cleanup work are being done at 230 other dumps, he added, and studies of the extent of contamination and cleanup options are under way for more than 640 sites.
The $2.6 billion that has been spent does not include formal obligations by the environmental agency to pay for work under way, Mr. Kovalick said in a telephone interview from his office in Washington. He said only a fraction of the cleanup costs had been recovered from polluters because ''it's hard to recover the money until you've finished the project.''
After William K. Reilly was appointed by President Bush as administrator of the agency, an internal review ordered by Mr. Reilly criticized the cleanup program. The administrator pledged in June to toughen the enforcement of toxic waste cleanup laws.
The Rand study said the environmental agency's sluggishness in the Reagan Administration was partly to blame for the cleanup delays. It also attributed the delays to a high staff turnover, confused management and other inefficiencies at the agency.
 
Legal Delays Cited
The study also said the cleanup effort was lagging because of court battles stemming from the requirement that the agency make polluters perform or pay for cleanup work whenever possible. If companies responsible for pollution cannot be identified or no longer exist, the Government pays under the Superfund law.
Mr. Acton, the author of the study, said that when the law comes before Congress for renewal in 1991, lawmakers may want to ask whether the attempt to make polluters pay for the cleanup costs is worth the delay. He suggested that the nation clean up the dumps the way it builds highways, with taxpayers footing the bill.
That possibility was criticized by Linda Greer, technical director of the Hazardous Waste Treatment Council, which represents companies that do cleanup work.
''There is no inherent reason E.P.A. cannot go ahead and aggressively clean up these sites, then go back to the responsible parties and get the money,'' she said. ''There's no reason for the American taxpayer to pay for industrial dumping.''

HEADLINE: Yale and New Haven Become Tennis Partners

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 8

 BODY:
In an unusual marriage of town and gown, New Haven, Yale University and state representatives have cooperated to bring a major tennis tournament to New Haven.
Officials announced Wednesday that in 1990, the Volvo International, a male tournament that is a warm-up for the United States Open, will move from Stratton, Vt., to grounds near the Yale Bowl, more than a mile west of the university's campus.
The plan calls for building a 15,000-seat grandstand and a 3,000-seat stadium on Yale athletic fields, to be paid for with a $15 million state bond issue. Several new courts will be built, and Yale's existing courts will be resurfaced. 
 
City and Yale Will Share Profits
In a complicated revenue sharing plan, the city agreed to forego taxes and Yale agreed to forego ground rental charges. Instead, the city will receive 50 percent of all profits from the tournament, and the university will receive 40 percent. The remaining 10 percent will go to a nonprofit Tennis Foundation.
Hollis Young, New Haven's acting development administrator, said a key part of the city's interest in the project was a commitment of a $100,000 annual donation to the city's youth tennis program.
Over the next 20 years, officials said, the Volvo is expected to attract more than 2.3 million people to New Haven and to generate nearly $450 million.
Officials from city and state govenment and the university and local business leaders developed the proposal in meetings since February.
Steve Heintz, Connecticut Commissioner of Economic Development, said the tournament's move to New Haven showed improved relations between Yale and the city in the last 10 years. Because Yale owns so much property, New Haven's tax base is small, and the university and the city have often had conflicting interests.
Cooperation was ''unprecedented'' to draw the tennis tournament to the city, said Sheila Wellington, the Secretary of the university.
 
'Trust Level Is Growing'
''A group of people over time have kind of gotten used to working together and comfortable with each other,'' she said. ''The trust level is growing. When the city government views Yale as a potential for partnership rather than adversarially, there's a kind of synergy that makes things possible.''
In the last decade, the university has increased its involvement in New Haven's economy, most notably in developing Science Park, where major technological corporations have been drawn. More recently, under Yale's president, Benno C. Schmidt Jr., the university has begun to invest in city development.
But Ms. Young and others who worked on the tennis tournament proposal, which involves Yale in a commercial development, said the university's participation was untraditional.
At Yale, where administrators are grappling with a long list of buildings needing renovation, the athletic department has had to become entrepreneurial, said Forrest Temple, associate director of finance and administration.
''We have a substantial number of assets which we only use very infrequently,'' he said. ''We're trying to do the best we can to better utilize them and realize funds that can be put back into renovation.'' Mr. Temple said Yale also hoped to attract a minor league baseball team to its stadium, which also needs refurbishing.
The tennis tournament's move from the mountains of Vermont to a crowded city will require a new marketing approach, said Jim Westhall, director of the tournament. ''We're trying to create an atmosphere on the campus of Yale that everyone will fall in love with,'' he said.
Mr. Westhall said Yale's prestige and cultural scene made it naturally attractive. ''I think that New Haven and the State of Connecticut, over a period of time, will sell well, as well.''

HEADLINE: MUSIC VIEW;
Notes From Between The Sheets?

BYLINE: By Donal Henahan

 BODY:
The speculation in this space recently about Schubert's underground sexual life, as explored in documentary detail by the musicologist Maynard Solomon, brought two typical, if opposed, reactions from readers.
One view - let us call it the Keatsian Imperative - was summed up in this way by an angry indicter of all such psychobiographical efforts: ''We know from his music that Schubert was a man with an exceptionally rich emotional life which reflects universal emotions of all mankind throughout their entire range. That is all we need to know.'' In other words, beauty is truth, truth beauty, end of discussion. 
An early biographer of Mozart, F. X. Niemetschek, argued similarly in 1808 when he excused himself for deleting from his book some of the composer's self-destructive personality flaws: ''A desire to be fair to a man of such merit demands that we try to wipe out such blemishes from the portraits of the great. If the same fairness is shown to Mozart, as one would wish shown to oneself, even then he could not serve as a model of economy and thrift. It is true, he should have been more careful with his money; but is a genius not allowed any weaknesses or failings?'' Here we see operating not only the Keatsian but the Kantian imperative: the Golden Rule.
Such a blinkered, hands-off approach to biography, although never out of fashion, does not satisfy everyone. Recalcitrant humanists persist in wondering if there may not be vital, discoverable connections between personality and art. They do not avert their eyes when historians speculate about the possible effects of Beethoven's deafness on his music, or of his pretense to nobility. A logical linkage between Schumann's madness and his weaker late works is not automatically rejected as defamation of the dead. ''In fact,'' writes one person of this skeptical persuasion, ''who is to say whether certain psychological 'aberrations' may not actually produce the very climate essential for genius to show itself?''
A different sort of idealism underlies that suggestion. In extreme cases, it takes the form of the mad-genius theory: great art, by definition a deviation from the norm, can only be produced by bohemians, garret inhabitants, the near-insane and other social sports or misfits. (New York City's famous Downtown Imperative follows naturally from this: Art is whatever is produced in lofts.) Implicitly, at least, most artists and estheticians believe that an artist's work, place in society and personality connect somehow, somewhere. Finding and explaining these points of convergence are what musical biography is largely about. It makes little sense to say that Wagner the man and Wagner's works, say, run parallel into infinity, never touching at any point.
In this respect, I have been especially fascinated by ''Mozart in Person: His Character and Health,'' an engrossing collection of articles by Peter J. Davies. Mr. Davies, whose exhaustive investigations of Mozartian fact and myth have been appearing piecemeal in British musical journals for several years, gathered his findings into an invaluable Greenwood Press volume earlier this year. Much of the documentation consists of rounding up and assessing nearly two centuries of medical opinions about Mozart's illnesses and death. I can especially recommend the book to the person who wrote me, regarding Mr. Solomon's attempt to probe into Schubert's medical history: '' . . . Solomon has some nerve attempting to diagnose a dead person he never saw. Not even M. D.'s do that!''
But, as all Mozart idolaters know, M. D.'s by the dozen have been busy at that for nearly two centuries. The Mozart literature overflows with treatises by doctors willing and eager to diagnose a dead composer they never saw. The following ailments have been deduced from what these experts read as the medical evidence: arsenic poisoning, miliary fever, brain tumor, rheumatic fever, neurosyphilis, pulmonary tuberculosis, typhus, grippe, streptococcal infection, infectious polyarthritis, extreme coprolalia (though probably not Tourette's syndrome), dropsy, bacterial endocarditis, hyperthyroidism or Graves' disease, uremic coma, complications from venesections, Schonlein-Henoch syndrome, cerebral hemorrhage and immune-complex disease.
Furthermore, Mr. Davies infers, Mozart suffered from cyclothymic disorder (hypomanic swings of euphoria and melancholy), chronic extradural hematoma (probably from a head injury) and recurrent blackouts (formerly thought, erroneously, to be caused by epilepsy). If all that were not enough to keep any man from productive work, Mozart also was afflicted by what we now recognize as the Pete Rose syndrome. He gambled so compulsively and self-destructively that some of his close friends, unlike the soft-hearted Niemetschek, could not excuse his excesses or the bad effect gambling had on his family and his health. They probably would have thought long about voting him into the Musical Hall of Fame.

PUB-DATE: September 10, 1989

SECTION: Section 2; Page 37, Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2299 words

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
Anthems and Troubadours That Stirred Crowds to Protest

BYLINE: By HEIDI WALESON; Heidi Waleson writes frequently about music.

 BODY:
On May Day 1934, in concert with laborers from around the country and the world, hundreds of workers and their supporters demonstrated in Union Square in New York. Their marching song was a tune just published in the left-wing weekly New Masses, ''Into the Streets May First'' - by Aaron Copland.
Mr. Copland was but one of several conservatory-trained composers who threw their talents into the movement for social change in the 1930's. Their efforts form part of a continuum of protest music that dates back to the earliest years of American history and encompasses folk, popular and art idioms. Merkin Concert Hall is about to celebrate this music with ''Voices of Change,'' a five-concert series that opens Monday evening and continues on Sept. 14, 20, 23 and 24. 
Numerous causes - battles on behalf of abolition, women's suffrage, unionism, civil rights and nuclear disarmament, and against war, poverty and hunger - have had their anthems and troubadours. ''Protest music builds a sense of solidarity, of togetherness, of 'I'm not alone - other people are dreaming these things,' '' says Eric Gordon, a consultant to the Merkin festival and the author of ''Mark the Music, '' a recent biography of Marc Blitzstein (St. Martin's Press). Neely Bruce, a professor at Wesleyan University and also a festival consultant, adds, ''Look at the effect of 'We Shall Overcome' on the civil-rights movement. Who was it who said, 'I don't care who writes a country's laws as long as I can write its songs' ?''
''Voices of Change'' will survey protest music historically and in terms of subject and musical genre. The first three concerts will be preceded by panel discussions on such subjects as ''Roots of Musical Activism'' and ''The Composer and Musician as Political Advocate.''
The opening concert, dubbed ''Free, Equal and Sober,'' presents paeans to abolition, suffrage, temperance and civil rights, and features the folk singer Odetta and the Hutchinson Family Singers, who re-create a 19th-century traveling musical group with period dress, staging and musical arrangements. Thursday's ''War and Peace,'' with the Western Wind Vocal Ensemble and the St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble conducted by Rhonda Kess, documents musical responses to war, from the Revolution to recent decades. Included are patriotic songs like ''When Johnny Comes Marching Home'' and Ives's ''He Is There''; Ron Gold and Allen Ginsberg's antiwar ''Amerika,'' and a concert version of Kurt Weill's first American musical, ''Johnny Johnson.''
The semistaged ''Workers of the World'' on Sept. 20 focuses on 20th-century labor movements. Though mostly from the 30's, the music includes visions of those movements by the contemporary composers Frederic Rzewski and Christian Wolff. On Sept. 23, in a ''Folk Music Showcase,'' the Washington Sisters and Bright Morning Star perform traditional folk music as well as their own songs.
The festival concludes on Sept. 24 with ''An American Songfest,'' which will feature choral songs about labor and civil rights and conclude with Earl Robinson's patriotic cantata ''Ballad for Americans.''
The Hutchinson Family Singers, a Minnesota-based quintet that will present some of the earliest American protest music, take their name from a clan of rabble-rousing New Hampshire Yankees that flourished in the latter half of the 19th century. In various combinations that sometimes included outsiders, family members claimed to have given more than 12,000 performances around the country.
Jesse and Mary Hutchinson first presented their 13 children in concert in 1840. The family's musical activities came to center around a quartet of the children, John, Judson, Asa and Abby (baritone, tenor, bass and alto). Successive generations formed their own versions of the group, and one descendant who performed until 1896 is, at age 104, still living.
The Hutchinsons were fervent abolitionists, great favorites with political candidates and close friends of such activists as Susan B. Anthony and Frederick Douglass. Their songs, many of which they wrote themselves, stirred up crowds. They performed abolitionist songs for General McClellan's troops on the Potomac during the Civil War and caused a riot, according to George Berglund, who leads the Minnesota Hutchinsons and has done extensive research on the family; thereafter they were banned from performing for soldiers. ''They narrowly escaped being killed by anti-abolitionists on several occasions,'' Neely Bruce adds. ''They were often run out of town.''
Mr. Berglund believes that the Hutchinsons had a profound effect on the political causes of their day - abolition, women's suffrage, sweatshops, even women's dress reform. ''They brought focus and public attention to the causes much faster,'' he says. ''Also, this was a period when national pride was really high. People were starting to turn away from European influences, and they went into ecstasies over this home-grown phenomenon.'' Mr. Bruce describes the Hutchinsons' music as ''light classical.'' ''They didn't do big hits,'' he explains. ''They considered themselves morally superior.''
The close harmony of the Hutchinsons gave way to the less complicated, more participatory songs of the labor movements early in this century. The activist Joe Hill (1879-1915) of the Industrial Workers of the World (the ''Wobblies'') was their troubadour, but his songs usually set new words to old tunes. Workers' choruses sprang up, many established along ethnic lines, which rehearsed regularly and rallied the workers. Some still endure: The Workmen's Circle Chorus, which performs in the final Merkin concert, celebrates its 75th anniversary this year.
Then came the Depression, and the heyday of the American Communist Party. Intellectuals - conservatory-trained composers among them - were caught up in the ideals of social reform. Composers such as Charles Seeger, Elie Siegmeister, Alex North, Marc Blitzstein and Aaron Copland, says Mr. Gordon, ''thought that it was criminal, given Depression conditions and the rise of Fascism, to devote their lives to art for art's sake, and turned to more proletarian-type audiences. But they went on using the avant-garde techniques they had learned - 12-tone music, Sprechstimme, advanced harmonies.
''They saw no reason to throw out modernism, but rather sought to retrain the ear of the mass audience. It was a reaction to the folk-type music of Joe Hill.''
The Composers' Collective of New York grew out of such sentiments, as did its 1934-35 ''Worker's Songbook,'' which includes such creations as ''The Scottsboro Boys Will Not Die'' by Elie Siegmeister and ''Song of the Builders'' by Charles Seeger, both of which will be performed in the ''Workers of the World'' concert by Marni Nixon and Mr. Bruce's American Music/Theater Group. Mr. Copland's ''Into the Streets May First'' was the outcome of a New Masses competition, in which Blitzstein also submitted a song.
''If you look at the texts of some of those ''Worker's Songbook'' songs now, they seem naive, even laughable,'' Mr. Gordon says, ''particularly the ones that celebrate Lenin and Stalin. But if you listen to the music, a lot of it sounds very fresh, and it was quite sophisticated. 'Into the Streets' was not an easy song - imagine hundreds of people today singing a contemporary work like that.''
The power of the left permeated high art in the 30's. Marc Blitzstein was teaching ''Social Aspects of Music'' and other courses at the Downtown Music School, intended to be a school for workers, and his scathing pro-labor work, ''The Cradle Will Rock,'' was closed down before its opening by the Works Progress Administration, which had paid for its development. Lan Adomian, whose songs appear in ''The Worker's Songbook,'' went off to fight in Spain. Plays and musicals depended on good notices in the Communist press for business.
Kurt Weill's 1936 ''Johnny Johnson'' excoriated the role of industry and the press in promoting World War I, a switch from the usual patriotic explanations. And in 1939, the socialist composer Earl Robinson played ''Ballad for Americans'' for CBS executives, who hired Paul Robeson for the solo part and broadcast the work across the country. Mr. Robinson recalls, ''I wanted to make the point that the United States had revolutionary traditions. No one objected to the revolutionary context; the only criticism was connected with Robeson, because he was black.'' ''Ballad for Americans'' became extremely popular, and had a healthy 20-year career among choirs throughout the country.
The 1930's saw the last great outpouring of socially conscious work by ''serious'' composers in the United States, and folk musicians took over as the voices of change. ''A lot of the artistic world moved in a more populist direction,'' Mr. Gordon says. ''World conditions were getting more serious, and people started to wonder, 'Can we afford the luxury of teaching the workers 12-tone music?' ''
Mr. Bruce points out that ''concert music has always been establishment music, and the patrons of that music are the church, the aristocracy and the rich, who are not the main proponents of social change. 'Serious' music composers tend not to get into these issues. Think of the Dreyfus affair: All of the French intellectuals - but none of the major French composers - signed the manifesto in support of him.'' Those who do tackle social issues are often ridiculed: Leonard Bernstein's ''Mass'' (1971), which - inspired by the protests of the 60's - dealt with rebellion against authority, was abused in some critical quarters as being sentimental and trendy.
A few living composers have continued to become socially involved, however. Christian Wolff, whose choral ''Wobbly Music,'' based on texts relating to Massachusetts mill strikes in 1912, will be presented in the ''Workers of the World'' program, calls political and social issues ''a major preoccupation'' in his work. ''I feel a responsibility to deal with these issues in my work, since I don't do it in other ways,'' he says. ''Music is the way I relate to large groups of people.''
Mr. Wolff started to bring politics into his music in the early 1970's. He based his ''Changing the System'' on a speech by the antiwar activist Tom Hayden, set songs to texts by Rosa Luxemburg and dedicated a trio to the memory of Emma Goldman. ''It's not direct agitprop,'' Mr. Wolfe says, ''but an occasion to remind people about political issues.''
Not all concert music uses a text, of course, and the extent to which instrumental music can be made overtly political is limited. Frederic Rzewski gets around this problem with melodic references to songs of protest. His ''North American Ballads,'' selections from which will be performed by Ursula Oppens in the ''Workers'' concert, are based on popular songs: ''The Winnsboro Cotton Mill Blues'' is a labor song; ''Down by the Riverside'' is an antiwar gospel tune. Mr. Rzewski's piano work ''The People United Cannot Be Defeated'' comprises 36 variations on a song that was a well-known symbol of democratic resistance in Chile.
Like Mr. Wolff, Miss Oppens sees her performances of these works more as education than as a call to action. ''Memories are very short,'' she says. ''I hope that someday 'The People United' will be merely historical.''
The folk and popular musicians who dominated the social protest scene of the civil-rights and anti-Vietnam movements, however, like the Hutchinsons and the Communists and socialists of the 30's, saw their contributions as something more. Mr. Gordon thinks that today's gay and lesbian choruses, which go beyond civil rights and AIDS-related material to include other calls for social change, are the contemporary heirs of those writers and performers.
Then there is the 79-year-old Earl Robinson, who has written about everything from the founding of the United Nations and civil rights (his songs ''Black and White'' and ''Hurry Sundown'' were made famous by Three Dog Night and Peter, Paul and Mary, respectively), to a recent musical about a mythical continent destroyed by ''misuse of nuclear power.''
After musically chronicling a half-century of movements and upheavals and observing the apathy that confronts the wrenching problems of today, Mr. Robinson says he is still undiscouraged. ''I started off in the 30's writing for the strikers, and I'm still available. I believe we're on the edge of a new age of love.''
'ONCE I BUILT A TOWER TO THE SUN . . . '
So effectively did the song ''Brother, Can You Spare a Dime?'' capture its era that its title became one of the lasting symbols of the Great Depression. It will be sung by Marni Nixon in the concert ''Workers of the World'' on Sept. 24 at Merkin Hall. Here are the lyrics.
 
They used to tell me I was building a dream,
And so I followed the mob.
When there was earth to plough or guns to bear,
I was always there, right there on the job,
They used to tell me I was building a dream, with peace and glory ahead.
Why should I be standing in line just waiting for bread?
 
Once I built a railroad, made it run,
Made it race against time.
Once I built a railroad. Now it's done.
Brother, can you spare a dime?
Once I built a tower, to the sun,
Brick and rivet and lime.
Once I built a tower. Now it's done.
Brother, can you spare a dime?
 
Once in khaki suits, gee, we looked swell,
Full of that Yankee Doodle-de-dum.
Half a million boots went sloggin' thru Hell,
I was the kid with the drum.
Say, don't you remember, they called me Al.
It was Al all the time.
Say, don't you remember, I'm your pal!
Buddy, can you spare a dime?
 
Words by E. Y. Harburg, music by Jay Gorney (1932); printed with permission of the E. Y. Harburg Foundation
