HEADLINE: Rap by the Bay: Oakland Emerges As a Force in Pop

BYLINE: By MICHAEL E. ROSS; Michael E. Ross is a freelance writer living in Manhattan.

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif.

 BODY:
''It's hard times city,'' Dwayne Wiggins said. ''You can't half-step here. Whatever you do, you have to be good at it.'' Mr. Wiggins is one of the three principals of Tony Toni Tone, an Oakland funk group whose debut album has emerged smartly on the national charts. He was speaking of this blue-collar city, which over the last five years has become a veritable mixing board for black American music, a studio whose sounds are thriving on at least three prominent fronts: funk, rhythm and blues, and music from the rap and hip-hop movements.
This mix of styles has made for a concerted assault on the Top 100 charts - and for a music scene as boisterous as a concert at the city's Coliseum, and as diverse as anything the region has experienced in years.
With by some estimates as many as 50 different performers recording either on independent labels or with major recording companies, Oakland - a city of 356,000 that has been viewed as a cultural second-string player beside San Francisco, its sister to the west - is emerging anew. In the parlance of the music, Oakland is ''in effect'' -meaning in vogue or just plain in. 
The re-emergence of Oakland as a musical force comes at a time when the city is suffering from urban ills that include a high crime rate, the presence of crack and cocaine in many neighborhoods, a static economy and a school system facing possible bankruptcy. But there is new construction near downtown. There are moves afoot to bring the Raiders football team back from Los Angeles. And some residents of ''Oaktown'' - as the city is affectionately called by its younger residents - see the new music as reflecting a change in civic attitude, an outlet of pride in again living large on the American stage.
In past decades, the Bay Area has produced some of rock's more celebrated performers. Fantasy Records, a Berkeley-based label, launched Creedence Clearwater Revival in the late 60's. Other groups, such as the Pointer Sisters, the Greg Kihn Band, Graham Central Station and Sly and the Family Stone have roots there. Tower of Power, a funk band whose music was a staple of dance clubs and discos in the early and mid-70's, originated in Oakland.
The city is now home base for a number of musicians; the singer Pebbles and the group Club Nouveau come from the Bay Area, as do Ace Juice and Oaktown's 3-5-7, a trio of female rappers whose new ''Wild and Loose'' album has been on the Billboard pop and black-album charts.
But three groups in particular demonstrate the diversity of the sounds originating in Oakland: M. C. Hammer, whose debut album ''Let's Get It Started'' (Capitol 90924) puts a bluesy West Coast spin on the swaggering, solipsistic style common to rap; Too Short, the rapper considered the godfather of Oakland raps, whose abrasive lyrics and bare-bones delivery have made his latest album a force on the Billboard charts; and Tony Toni Tone, a trio of singers who blend funk, R & B and soul.
Tony Toni Tone may be the most radio-ready of Oakland's young bands. The group - the brothers Dwayne and Raphael Wiggins and a cousin, Timothy Christian - gave its first performance at a wedding in Los Angeles, and continued with stints on tour with such performers as Lionel Richie and Tramaine Hawkins.
The group's 1988 debut album ''Who?'' (Wing/Polygram 835549), produced by Thomas McElroy and Denzil Foster - Oakland-based producers and two of the creative forces behind Club Nouveau - blends several musical influences, including gospel and blues, with a streetwise flavor that could perhaps have only come from Oakland. One of the album's singles, ''Little Walter,'' a cautionary tale of a drug dealer's demise, borrows its chorus from the gospel staple ''Wade in the Water.'' The record stayed on Billboard's black-music album charts for 65 weeks. The record recently went gold, and the group's second album is set for a January release. While the first album is characterized by lush, smooth, three-part harmonies and horn charts, Dwayne Wiggins said the new album will be ''more street,'' using elements of the rap sound.
Perhaps the steady rise of the rapper Too Short (whose real name is Todd Shaw) best illustrates the staying power both of rap music and of Oakland as a haven for the rap sound. The 23-year-old star's recent album ''Life Is . . . Too Short'' (Jive/RCA 1149) has sold more than 850,000 copies. Mr. Shaw started performing rap in 1980, writing his own raps - harsh, scatological ''freaky tales'' of life, real and imagined, in Oakland - and distributing them on homemade tapes he circulated through his neighborhood. After recording three albums on independent labels (one of them a label he started with friends), he caught the attention of Jive Records, which is distributed by RCA.
The newest Too Short record is a departure in style and substance from its predecessors. For one thing, most of the new release is suitable for radio airplay, a status his previous records did not enjoy. But the success of his early records is continuing. After six months, ''Life Is . . . Too Short'' remains on Billboard's chart of top black and pop albums.
If Too Short is the emeritus of Oakland's rap stars, M. C. Hammer may be the Oakland musician most likely to establish a true musical empire. Mr. Hammer parlayed his talents as a choreographer, producer and dancer into a long-term recording and production contract with Capitol Records. ''Let's Get It Started'' was certified platinum in early 1989. Since then, Mr. Hammer has been building a state-of-the-art 24-track recording studio, producing such artists as Marlon Jackson and Tracie Spencer, and - in the best tradition of Berry Gordy and Motown Records - grooming younger bands in matters of choreography, stagecraft and style.
The current creative chaos is seen as a strength, a benefit thought to be the result of the Bay Area's ethnic diversity. Even though Oakland's music scene is in many ways a free-for-all, some see it as a spectrum of flourishing musical possibilities, and evidence of a fierce civic pride.
''In the Bay Area, there's never been a central base, a central entity to set the standards,'' said David Cook, a disk jockey for KPFA in Oakland. ''People have brought their own ideas into the music. The Bay Area's always overshadowed by Los Angeles. It just hasn't been recognized for the talent it's put forth.''
''There's a real division, a schism, between San Francisco and Oakland,'' said Barry Weiss, the vice president for marketing operations for Jive Records. ''There's a real urban feel in Oakland that isn't in San Francisco. Maybe it's more affluent in San Francisco; maybe there's just more money. It's like a nationalistic pride. People in Oakland see the affluence across the bridge. They want a piece of that pie.''
To Dwayne Wiggins, his group - and the musical renaissance of which it is a part - are opportunities to give something back to the community. ''This has given a lot of people the chance to further their careers, and it's given a younger generation a sign that they can go out and make good money without doing bad things. We stand as something of a role model.''
There is already a second wave of talent emerging, regional bands that are one step from their own major followings. Digital Underground, a hip-hop group based in Berkeley, has recently signed with Tommy Boy Records, an urban dance-music label distributed by Warner Brothers Records. The group's single ''Doowutchyalike'' jumped on Billboard's top 100 singles chart in late August and has been climbing ever since. The rapper DJ Slice and Kool Rock J, a Fresno-based rap group, have signed with the Jive label and are completing their album.
The energy of the music sometimes spills over in unexpected ways. Repeated incidents of violence occurred at a July 29 concert at the Oakland Coliseum, a show starring LL Cool J, Slick Rick, Too Short, NWA and De La Soul. Five people were injured and 15 were arrested in what coliseum security officials described in news reports as ''petty skirmishes.''
Despite such rare incidents, the latest wave of music from Oakland suggests a happy blend of circumstances: a period of creativity in which both quality and quantity are abundant.
''There's a lot more going on than what you hear,'' Too Short said. ''There's rappers and singers all over. You got people who actually look up to us. They want to blame so many things on rap music. But today every other kid on every other block in the country is trying to be a rapper. When that happens, you're going to get good music.''

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Tim Robbins, Hanging Out With the Gang

BYLINE: By RICHARD B. WOODWARD; Richard B. Woodward writes frequently about the arts.

 BODY:
At about 6 feet 4, walking with a loose, shambling gait, his face dimpled and wrinkle-free, Tim Robbins looks like the overgrown kid he portrayed in the 1988 movie ''Bull Durham'' - the baby-faced pitcher with unknown potential.
In a lower Manhattan restaurant he is dressed in sweat pants and T-shirt as though he had just come from the gym. A pair of spectacles adds another touch: the bookish jock. But his speech, soft and earnest, and his determination to talk about theater, and not Hollywood business, dispels his popular image as a large, charming goofball. He may look like the pitcher Nuke LaLoosh, but he comes across more like the character he played in last year's ''Five Corners,'' the confident, committed, slightly naive idealist who wants to better the world.
''I try not to do exploitive films,'' he says.when forced to comment on movies. ''I try to avoid those that insult certain kinds of people or that feature roles with gratuitously stupid women. I want to say something positive.'' 
At the age of 31, Mr. Robbins may be on the verge of becoming a genuine movie star. In his new film ''Erik the Viking,'' a comedy directed by Terry Jones and scheduled for release next month, he co-stars with John Cleese, late of Monty Python. He has just finished work on ''Cadillac Man'' with Robin Williams, and this fall shooting will begin for ''Jacob's Ladder,'' a psychological drama about a Vietnam veteran overcome by personal demons, directed by Adrian Lyne . It will be the first film that Mr. Robbins will have to carry by himself without strong co-stars.
But he doesn't want to talk about any of this. For the occasion, he has asked that he be interviewed with Adam Simon, his colleague in the Actors' Gang, a Los Angeles-based theater troupe to which both devote a fair measure of their time. Together they have written three plays, the latest of which, ''Carnage: A Comedy,'' Mr. Robbins is directing for a run that opens next Sunday at the Public Theater; it is now in previews. The Gang is rehearsing a block away, and Mr. Robbins leaves briefly once to check on their progress.
''Taken in the context of L.A., the Gang was an extremely radical thing to do,'' says Mr. Simon, a Harvard graduate who has collaborated with Mr. Robbins since 1985. Founded in 1981 by a group of U.C.L.A. students who met through a softball game, the Actors' Gang was an unlikely venture: an avant-garde theater ensemble in a city not known at the time for either adjective. With the direction and support of Mr. Robbins, who finances the group with money earned from his movie roles, they have performed standard works from the European Dada and Expressionist tradition (Alfred Jarry's ''Ubu Roi'' and Ivan Goll's ''Methusalem: The Eternal Bourgeois'') and, since Mr. Robbins and Mr. Simon teamed up, original plays with a satirical, surreal, political slant.
''What Tim and I want to do is not so much apply European elements to American theater, but find those parts of our culture that are related to them,'' says Mr. Simon. Small, as fast-talking as Mr. Robbins is slow, and wise beyond his 27 years in the lore of pop culture, Mr. Simon functions as, in his words, ''team egghead,'' the partner responsible for hip, historical references. ''We found those elements not in the American avant-garde but in vaudeville, burlesque, the medicine show: forms that have always been mixed, dirty, chaotic. We wanted to ground ourselves in Dada and American popular culture.'' Their first play, ''Slick Slack Griff Graff,'' sponsored by the Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art in 1985, used the confidence game, as practiced by a grifter and his carny, to discuss contemporary life. The next year they wrote and performed ''Violence: The Misadventures of Spike Spangle Farmer'' and adopted material directly from the news: The Challenger shuttle disaster, the plight of Midwest farmers, American hostages in Lebanon and the news media's reporting of these events. The lead role was played by John Cusack, a Gang member and Mr. Robbins's co-star in last year's movie ''Tapeheads.''
In ''Carnage'' the authors have co-opted the language and attitudes of televangelism, where theater, economics, religion and politics intersect. The plot traces the descent into madness of a charismatic minister. The various subsidiary characters, as they seek redemption for themselves or their loved ones, take any number of deluded or dangerous paths.
The play is about the spirit unbound, corrupted, out of control. Written and first performed in 1987, before the PTL scandal, Jimmy Swaggart's confessions and Jerry Falwell's disbandment of the Moral Majority, the play also features para-military characters who sound like Oliver North, and a family of suburbanites obsessed by their credit cards and car phone. With much of this material already cycled through the light-satire mill by stand-up comics, the play may run the risk of seeming dated, even if it anticipated current events.
''We weren't writing about Jim and Tammy Bakker,'' Mr. Robbins insists. ''Both Adam and I had read this book ''Blessed Assurance'' by A. G. Mojtabai. ''She found that a high percentage of the people in charge of assembling nuclear weapons at a plant in Texas were rapturous about the end of the world. That really got under our skin. And then the statements that were coming out of the White House at the time: Reagan talking matter-of-factly about the prophecy of the Final Days. And Oliver North thanking God that people put money into bank accounts. We wanted to talk about the connections between right-wing politics and apocalyptic religion.''
Mr. Simon seems more concerned that liberal, urban theatergoers will sneer at the play's characters. ''It's way too easy to get a sophisticated audience to laugh at a bunch of yahoos,'' he says. ''That's not our point. We're saying that a zealot can be much more dangerous than a confidence man.''
Both authors have impeccable bohemian credentials as the offspring of left-wing parents, a background about which they are proud and slightly sheepish. Mr. Simon's parents were black-listed academics who ended up at the University of Chicago; Mr. Robbins grew up in Greenwich Village, son of the folk singer Gil Robbins.
''Yeah, we were a singing family,'' says Mr. Robbins. ''Car trips, after dinner, we were always singing. My first time on stage I joined Dad in a version of 'Ink Is Black but the Page Is White,' '' a standard of the civil rights movement. Before U.C.L.A. Mr. Robbins trained in New York as a teen-age member of Theater for the New City. ''I was in their street theater program for about seven years. We had a street vaudeville act during Watergate with Ehrlichman, Haldeman and Dean. I did a sort of song and dance as Haldeman. There was something very raw about that training that made me want to take chances in the theater.'' Further deepening his interest in an avant-garde, anti-realist tradition, he also studied in Paris with Georges Bigot and his Theatre de Soleil.
The plays by the team of Robbins and Simon develop out of a first draft that Mr. Robbins takes into a workshop where actors try it out. Improvisations are then incorporated into the script, with Mr. Simon hurriedly writing new scenes that are immediately subjected to a performance test. The rehearsals in New York have forced more rewriting. ''When we first started running through it, I was seeing the same play we had done before'' says Mr. Robbins. ''I said, 'No, no, you've got to rip it apart and get to the blank page. I don't want to re-create what we did in Los Angeles.' ''
Film and theater work have fed each other in both their careers. Mr. Simon, who has written and directed a forthcoming film for Roger Corman (to be callled either ''Paranoia'' or ''Brain Dead''), used as many members of the Gang as the production allowed. Mr. Robbins says he would find it harmful if he ceased work in the theater. ''When I started in L.A. on television shows, I would take four or five months off each year to work with the Gang,'' he says. ''Everyone said I was crazy, how was I going to build momentum, et cetera. As the notoriety increases, I long for this even more. I need this, not only to express certain things in the writing and directing, but to work with friends of mine who helped me. They've helped my acting.''
In his politics, loyalty to his friends and triple-threat career as actor-writer-director, Mr. Robbins resembles a younger John Sayles, another baseball fan who has figured out how to make Hollywood serve his personal needs. Mr. Robbins next wants to write a play about the American labor movement in the 1880's; and he is on his second rewrite of a film script, ''a fake documentary about a neofascist folk singer on the rise in America.''
The team of Robbins and Simon acknowledges the problem of writing populist plays that will be performed for a small, elitist audience in the theater. ''If there is a master plan,'' says Mr. Robbins, ''it's to do one more play and take them all on the road. I would love to play 'Carnage' in the Bible Belt.''
''Tent style,'' says Mr. Simon, excited. ''Set it up, tear it down.'' He enthusiastically describes a television project for a ''post-apocalyptic 'Gunsmoke.' '' He looks at Mr. Robbins, who winces. ''Tim and I have this fight whether or not it's politically correct to do post-apocalyptic stories,'' he says, smiling. ''I say 'yes,' he says 'no.' ''
Both Tim Robbins and Susan Sarandon, who won his heart in the script for ''Bull Durham'' and later off the set, feel strongly about women's issues. They marched together at the abortion rights rally in Washington in April, one month before she gave birth to their son. Mr. Robbins has moved east from Los Angeles and the couple have lived in New York for the last year and a half, inevitably weakening his daily ties to the Gang.
His recent film work with Robin Williams and John Cleese has allowed him to explore on film the anarchic impulses that find outlet in his work for the theater. In ''Erik the Viking'' he plays a Norseman disillusioned with a style of life that emphasizes raping and pillaging. ''He's a Viking seeking a better way,'' says Mr. Robbins. The Monty Python troupe decisively shaped the style of the Actors' Gang. ''Those guys were major influences on my work,'' he says, an opinion seconded by Mr. Simon, who adds, ''If you went back in a time machine and subtracted Monty Python and Mad magazine from history, the sensibility of our generation would be crippled.''
At the rehearsal loft, a guitarist is leading the 11 members of the Actors' Gang in a folk sing-along from the play. Mr. Robbins sits down with his metal briefcase and goes over notes from a previous run-through. Most of his instructions are the usual directorial maxims: ''Go further with your anger there,'' he tells one actor; ''try to inspire as well as admonish in that speech,'' he says to another. But a few phrases sound somewhat unusual. ''Don't dance with the television until the second chorus,'' he says casually to a young actor, who notates her script as if this were normal stage direction.
''Dare to be stupid'' is the motto of the Actors' Gang. As wholesome as he may appear, Tim Robbins is really more of an All-American Radical. What he is attempting to do in his life and work can't be called, by the standards of film or theater, either very normal or too stupid.

LENGTH: 1599 words

HEADLINE: FILM VIEW;
Classics Thrive on Screen Tests

BYLINE: By Vincent Canby

 BODY:
You've watched the video, now see the movie.
''Tom Jones'' is back, or almost. The uproarious 1963 adaptation of the Henry Fielding novel opens Friday at the Paris Theater in a new print, its soundtrack adapted for Dolby, its original 131-minute running time pruned slightly to 124 minutes by Tony Richardson, its director.
''The Wizard of Oz,'' which has been available on television for longer than most readers have been alive, is now showing at two Manhattan theaters to mark the 1939 film's 50th anniversary.
Last month's ''French Currents: The New Wave, Then and Now'' turned out to be the most successful retrospective ever sponsored by the Film Society of Lincoln Center. Though all but several films in the program could be found in any videocassette rental shop, four (Jean-Luc Godard's ''Breathless,'' Francois Truffaut's ''Jules and Jim'' and ''Day for Night'' and the anthology film ''Six in Paris'') were sellouts at the 1,100-seat Alice Tully Hall. 
Fifty years after its original release, William Wyler's ''Wuthering Heights'' is in movie theaters once more. ''Intolerance,'' D. W. Griffith's 1916 classic (prompted, at least in part, by charges that his ''Birth of a Nation'' glorified racism), has been restored yet again and will be screened Oct. 2 at the New York Film Festival.
Both ''Gone With the Wind'' (1939) and Abel Gance's ''Napoleon'' (1926) have had successful public showings this year at Radio City Music Hall, while David Lean's ''Lawrence of Arabia'' (1962), re-edited to include 20 minutes of footage not in the film as it was originally released, has become one of the year's surprise box-office hits, both in this country and abroad.
As movie trends go, this one doesn't mean much in terms of dollars and cents, not when the producers of a ''Batman'' can earn in several weeks what it took David Selznick, the producer of ''Gone With the Wind,'' a lifetime to achieve.
Yet it does suggest that there exists a small but increasingly literate film audience. These are people who are not going to sit by while theatrical movies are shrunk to the dimensions of present television screens (which seem always to be getting hazier as they get bigger) and while television entertainment is inflated to fill movie theater screens (which seem always to be getting smaller).
These audiences recognize and cherish the differences between the experience of watching something at home, at one's own convenience, the lights on, the picture definition not great, and being in a theater where, in theory anyway, one's attention is commanded by the clarity of a larger-than-life image that dominates the enviroment.
The development of the videocassette recorder has been the greatest boon to theatrical films since the refinement of sound - I now find it difficult to imagine ordinary life without it. The videocassette has reclaimed audiences that had stopped going to movie theaters. It creates additional revenues that, in turn, insure further production.
It also provides students, aficionados and critics with virtually instant access to the entire heritage of movies. Until recently, film study and even random browsing were activities limited to the college student, the buff who had his own 16-millimeter projector and those persistent nuts who made it a point to keep up with the screening schedules at museums and at Manhattan's old Regency and other repertory theaters.
Today almost anybody anywhere can have a mini-festival devoted to the work of Greta Garbo, Abbott and Costello, Fritz Lang, John Hughes, Ingmar Bergman or Billy Wilder. There once was a time when movies, having been seen in a theater, could be stored only as memories, often distorted ones.
Today's audiences can rerun movies indefinitely. Anyone with the desire can figure out how a movie has been put together. Movies can be carried around in coat pockets and evening bags and left on the seats of Broadway buses.
We are, however, paying a price that, like some taxes, remains hidden. When we look at a movie on the television screen, even via a videocassette of the first quality, we are seeing only a fraction of what was originally on the theater screen. Sometimes literally. Favorite scenes can be looked at without having to sit through all the guff that connects them. Movies-as-coffeetable-books leave a lot to be desired.
This is made dramatically evident when one goes back to a theater to see an epic on the scale of ''Napoleon'' or ''Gone With the Wind'' or ''Lawrence of Arabia.'' One has to be aggressively dim not to be aware of what's missing when triptychs, huge battle scenes and magnificent wide-angle landscapes are squeezed onto a 21-inch telly screen. In some ways, watching ''Napoleon'' or ''Lawrence'' on the small screen is a little like listening to radio or reading. Either the imagination fills in the details not actually seen, or it tunes out.
Not as apparent are the ways in which the small screen also affects the way in which we respond to less visually spectacular films.
According to my own erratic survey, no more than three people collected around a television set, watching a cassette of, say, ''Grand Hotel,'' will attend the film with anything approximating the same attention that would be given in a theater.
If there are four or more people, at least one is bound to get itchy and start to talk. The surroundings give permission. The screen is small, and the set itself is just one more piece of furniture to be used or ignored at will. Movies at home are disposable.
When I say we don't ''see'' many details on a television screen that we would see in a theater, I don't mean simply visual details but also all of the other information that one absorbs from a movie in a theater without being aware of it. It may be anything from the rhythm of the editing to obvious contortions of plot or just a subliminal sense of esthetic disorder. In the half light of a movie theater, we are sponges.
This is one of the reasons that audiences tend to be more critical in a theater than they are at home, and why (as has happened to all of us) we sometimes upgrade an opinion of a film seen on television after watching it in a theater. It's not that we were overly cranky the first time, but that a lot of the things that worked against the film in the theater are automatically blacked out. The context does it.
When film students today say they have ''seen'' Orson Welles's ''Citizen Kane'' or Howard Hawks's ''Twentieth Century,'' they mean, nine times out of 10, that they have looked at something shown on a television monitor or, with luck, at a 16-millimeter print, which was probably well worn.
As much as ''Lawrence of Arabia'' or ''Napoleon,'' the Welles work is the kind of film whose magnificence can only be guessed at when it is looked at in anything except a 35-millimeter print, preferably unscratched and with a soundtrack in sync. Among other things, there is no other way in which one can appreciate the remarkable gradations between black and white in Gregg Toland's camera work, as well as the equally spectacular deep-focus scenes.
Deep focus, in which characters and objects in the background are seen as clearly as those in the foreground, is apparently one of the prices paid for color photography. Deep focus requires so much light that, I'm told, it either washes out the color or makes it blaze.
Considering the economics of the motion picture business, it is unlikely that many nonspectacular old films are going to receive the sort of re-release treatment afforded ''Lawrence of Arabia'' or ''Gone With the Wind.'' It is too expensive. It is encouraging, though, that ''Jules and Jim'' could sell out at Alice Tully Hall. Its audience, I assume, was composed of the 1,100 New Yorkers who either never had seen it before or never had seen it in 35 millimeter, in the full glory of its original anamorphic wide-screen ratio.
It should also be encouraging, I suppose, that ''The Wizard of Oz,'' after so many years of special television showings and its more recent availability on videocassette, should be back in two theaters. In fact, however, the print I saw at the Festival Theater was not one to astonish any child who had grown up watching it on the small screen.
The colors in the print were not washed out but, instead, sort of fuzzy and inexact, not much different from what they would be on a good cassette.
Still unseen at this writing is ''Tom Jones'' as reconstituted by Mr. Richardson, who received the 1963 Academy Award for his direction of the film. Even without looking at it, purists will object to his re-editing of it to meet the tastes of 1989 audiences.
The distributor quotes Mr. Richardson as saying that the changes were ''necessary and helpful.''
''The humor works as well today as it did in 1963,'' he says, ''but audiences today are so much more sophisticated than they were 26 years ago. They like humor quick and punchy. I think the cuts substantially improve the film and enhance the actors' work.''
That's all very well and good, but, in another 26 years, how would he feel if someone else came along and edited the film again for the audiences of 2015? Mr. Richardson cites the differing directorial approaches to Shakespeare as being analogous. Yet tinkering with a finished movie is not the same thing. In the case of a play, the original text continues to exist. Caretakers of commercial films have a way of tossing out anything not of immediate use.
Most of us probably won't have any idea where Mr. Richardson has made the cuts in ''Tom Jones,'' but we'll see.

HEADLINE: SOUND;
Triplet Speaker Systems State Their Attractions

BYLINE: By Hans Fantel

 BODY:
Loudspeakers usually come in pairs and are normally delivered as identical twins. Lately, however, there has been a surprising incidence of triplets.
Listeners living in small apartments where space is limited might frown on this development. They think two speakers are enough and three are too many. But paradoxically, space economy is the main purpose of the three-speaker setups. These triplets take up less room than a conventional pair, sound just as good and typically cost less. 
The savings in space and cost result from the fact that the three-piece speaker systems use only a single woofer instead of the usual two; and woofers, being fairly massive, are the bulkiest and most expensive part of a speaker. In addition to its single woofer, which handles the lower notes of both left and right channels, the triple system consists of two small satellite units that separately handle the midrange and treble for the left and right stereo channels.
The pooling of the bass between the two stereo channels in a single woofer is done on the theory that low notes are nondirectional. The listener cannot tell where they come from, and therefore it doesn't matter if the left and right channels are combined at the bass end of the audible spectrum. As far as the top is concerned, normal stereo separation is maintained by the two small satellite units.
From a home decorator's viewpoint, there are several advantages to this approach. The satellite units are small enough to nestle discreetly among the books on a shelf, while the single woofer keeps a low profile that lets it serve as a coffee table or a pedestal for a plant. And since the sound emitted by the woofer is nondirectional, it may be placed anywhere in the room or conveniently stashed out of sight.
This cannot be done with conventional loudspeakers containing woofers and upper-range units in a single enclosure, because they have to be in direct line of sight from the listening area for the best acoustic results. The triplets, on the other hand, can be visually unobtrusive.
As for cost, consider that good woofers are inherently expensive. They require a heavy cast-metal frame, a massive magnet and a strong and firmly braced cabinet to reach to the tonal bottom. By pooling the bass of both channels and dispensing with the second woofer, this major cost factor is cut in half.
The saving could be passed on to the buyer; it could be added to the manufacturer's profit, or a bit of both. In some cases, the manufacturer applies the saving to the product, providing a heftier woofer than could otherwise be furnished for the price. As a result, some triplet systems boast better bass than conventional speakers in the same price range.
A notably fine-sounding triplet comes from a California company with the imperative name of Now Hear This - more commonly known by its initials as N.H.T. Called the SubZero system, it consists of two small units measuring 9 x 5 1/2 x 5 inches. The enclosures are black and made of polished fiberboard laminated with a polymer that makes them inherently nonresonant. This nonresonance prevents false timbres arising from undue cabinet vibration. These diminutive units contain the midrange and treble speakers, and their frequency response extends from 85 to 21,000 Hertz.
The third member of the trio is a woofer, measuring 19 x 8 x 12 inches, which extends bass response down to 45 Hertz. This won't impress perfectionists, but it is quite remarkable for so small a unit and sufficient for most kinds of music.
The overall sound is musically pleasing; clarity at the top never veers into shrillness, and the lower range generates an appropriate sense of sonic weight in orchestral passages. Moreover, the smallness of the upper-range speakers contributes to an even sound, spread over wide areas of the listening room, with clearly defined stereo space relations.
The N.H.T. SubZero can handle up to 100 watts per channel, and with a list price of $399 for the entire system, it is an oustanding bargain. Both sonically and fiscally it validates the triplet approach.
Another set of recently arrived triplets is the Design Acoustics Micro-Monitor P S. 3. It differs outwardly from the N.H.T. model by having a wood finish rather than black laminate on all three cabinets - a fact reflected in its higher price of $599. In other respects it is roughly comparable, though the upper range of the P S. 3 appeared a little brighter and more incisive than that of the SubZero. Whether this is an asset or not depends on the listener's personal tonal taste.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS FORUM: THE ADVERTISING SLUMP;
Cure the Industry With More Creativity

BYLINE: By JOHN PHILIP JONES; John Philip Jones is professor and chairman of the advertising department at the Newhouse School of Public Communications, Syracuse University.

 BODY:
The annual estimates of advertising in the United States have been presented for a number of years in rather a misleading way. In addition to main media figures, the estimates cover other less relevant categories of expenditure.
Fortunately, it is easy to isolate the main media - newspapers, television, consumer magazines, radio and outdoor advertising, like billboards. When we do this and express the total main media expenditure as a percentage of the gross national product - the normal way of measuring advertising's progress relative to other industries - it is clear that the proportion accounted for by advertising has shown no appreciable change since 1984, remaining at a little under 1.5 percent of the G.N.P. And there are forces in the market pointing to continued stagnation. 
The figures have plateaued twice before in the last four decades - at levels of about 1.4 percent of the G.N.P. from 1956 to 1960, and 1.3 percent from 1961 to 1966.
These previous plateaus were followed by a gradual decline until 1975. During this time something very interesting happened.
The old concept of the full service agency became unfashionable; it was in fact pushed aside by a remarkable revival of interest in the creative product, a movement spearheaded by David Ogilvy and William Bernbach, but which by the late 1960's was followed by all the important agencies in New York and elsewhere, even those that Mr. Ogilvy had impolitely but graphically described as the ''extinct volcanoes.''
No one has examined the possible cause-and-effect relationship between the stagnation in the total business and the creative revival of the 1960's. But my intuition tells me that the two phenomena were connected. Advertising had to begin working like a rapier because it could no longer wield the bludgeon of increasing appropriations. A number of the agencies leading the creative renaissance became very successful. Each agency's activity was concentrated exclusively on the work it was doing for its existing clients, and growth to clients and agency yielded profit, the reward of success.
The question raised by this brief incursion into history is whether the present stagnation will call forth a similar innovative response from today's agencies - perhaps a shot of creative adrenaline or even some more unexpected reaction, the nature of which we cannot at the moment guess.
I am not in the business of speculating about the topography of terra incognita, but I do feel able to discuss a related question - whether the culture of the agencies of the 1980's is likely to encourage innovation as radical as the action of their predecessors in the 1960's.
Since the late 1970's the billings of many of the leading agency groups have increased rather strikingly, as a result of mergers and acquisitions. This increasing concentration is one of the most interesting events in recent advertising history, and to understand it we must go further than acknowledging the activities of opportunistic entrepreneurs, whose emergence was a necessary but not a sufficient explanation for why the agency conglomerates came into being.
A conglomerate is said to reduce waste and duplication, thus enabling the agency to achieve greater scales of economy. It is also argued that the working systems and financial controls of the best parts of each organization can be applied to the worst parts, leading to more efficient operation, and cost savings over all. There are possibilities of expanding the business both geographically and by cross-selling between the individual business units (''referrals.'') Lastly, there are - or were - assets to be stripped.
These are reasonably plausible although not entirely convincing arguments. In fact, a good case can be made that the conglomerates were a response to a stagnating business. Depressed growth and profits were the causes of low stock prices, which in turn made certain large American advertising agencies vulnerable to hostile acquisitions.
More important, the arguments in favor of the conglomerates concentrate most on how amalgamation will benefit the agencies (or more precisely their stockholders). Not much is said about advantages to the clients. Little is spoken of plans to invest in recruiting and developing the skills of talented individuals with the aim of improving the creative product; nor of plans to invest in research to improve our dismally inadequate knowledge of how advertising works to sell products.
What we are seeing is the growing importance of agencies that have a different credo from those of the 1960's and 1970's - a new credo that has shifted profit from being a reward to being a direct operating objective. This change did not take place suddenly; it began to happen in the 1970's as the hard and unwelcome lessons of public ownership began to be felt by agencies.
Stagnation in the advertising business will mean an even greater concentration on cost-cutting within the conglomerates - organizations that require high and increasing profit both to service bank debt and to maintain their own stock prices (to protect themselves from financial predators!). It is difficult to see how these conditions will lead to an improvement in each agency's creative work or in its ability to produce brilliant recommendations for its clients.
Readers will have no difficulty in guessing my own belief that the nature of the agency business will not lie with the conglomerates. Indeed the professional deficiencies of the conglomerates will create special opportunities for their organizationally more conservative but professionally more daring competitors.
These competitors are not few in number nor uniform in size. In fact they include some agencies that at the moment are little more than fledglings - American advertising has always provided astonishing opportunities for talented newcomers. Agencies marked for success will have a culture entirely bound up with their work for their existing clients. Rather importantly, such agencies will still be, and will remain, privately owned. And they will be managed by people whose driving force is advertising.

HEADLINE: Prospects;
Productivity's Problem

BYLINE: By JOEL KURTZMAN

 BODY:
The Labor Department's second-quarter productivity figures showed a modest overall increase of 0.7 percent, with gains of 2.9 percent in manufacturing accounting for nearly all of the increase. Analysts are increasingly suspicious of the productivity numbers as indicators of economic health. Three economists and a former auto worker discuss them.
 
Sam Nakagama
Chairman and chief economist, Nakagama and Wallace Inc.
 I don't believe in the productivity numbers. I have a lot of questions about the way productivity is measured and so, in the main, I ignore the numbers. There are a lot of debates and quarrels about what the real numbers have been and it becomes a technical argument among specialists. I have long ago lost interest in that debate. Of course, we ought to do our best to measure productivity, and I'm not sure it can't be done. But the quarterly numbers are meaningless. On the other hand, there is not much argument over the long-term trend - 15 to 25 years - and those numbers have shown a sharp fall-off in productivity growth. 
 
Charles McMillion
Associate director, Institute for Policy Studies, Johns Hopkins University and former policy director, Congressional Competitiveness Caucus.
 We don't have very good statistics for the service sector. One of the many problems of the Reagan years was the damage done to data collection. Our overall economic data has deteriorated. We now have estimated numbers instead of survey numbers, and the survey numbers we do have come from smaller samples. For instance, the Federal Reserve gets its capacity utilization figures by making estimates of overall capacity and then making further estimates based on these numbers to arrive at a figure for utilization.
We don't even know how big the manufacturing sector is anymore. One set of numbers says it's about 22 percent of gross national product and another says its only 18 percent.
The last input-output table for the country as a whole was done in 1983. This table tells us about the elements that go into the automobile industry, for example, so we can chart its effect on the rest of the economy. This helps us understand the economic effect of an investment. The last Japanese input-output table was done in 1988. It is very hard to make public policy based on our data.
 
Carl G. Thor
President of the American Productivity and Quality Center, a not-for-profit research and consulting center in Houston.
 The quality of the statistics makes them of not much use. What I do is look back at the statistics for the last 12 months, add the numbers and then divide them by four to get my own rough indicator of quarterly performance. What this shows is a general flatness in productivity over the last 12 months. Behind that is the real story. Manufacturing increased by 2.9 percent while overall productivity increased by 0.7 percent for the quarter.
On the manufacturing side, the United States should get a solid ''B'' grade. But while American manufacturing improved its productivity by 2.9 percent, Italy and Britain grew in the 3 to 4 percent range, the Pacific nations grew in the 4 to 5 percent range and over the last 5 years, Japan grew in the 6 to 7 percent range.
 
Eric Mann
Director of the Labor Community Strategy Center in Los Angeles and a former auto worker.
 When I went to work at the General Motors Van Nuys plant there were about 5,000 workers. Now there are about 3,700 workers producing roughly the same number of cars - so that's an increase in productivity. If you did floor-to-floor interviews and asked the work force if they are working harder and faster, they would say ''yes.'' If you asked them if they will be able to do their jobs at the current pace for 30 years, then they would say ''no.''
We have to take a look at the concept of a continually expanding G.N.P., because it isn't improving the standard of living of the work force.
Labor unions have to address the fact that given the environmental dangers, a society that is based on continuous productivity growth is in trouble.

HEADLINE: WEEK IN BUSINESS;
Central Banks Act Against Rising Dollar

BYLINE: By STEVE DODSON

 BODY:
The dollar surged, bringing intervention by the central banks of several nations, including the United States. They succeeded in halting the advance, but that still left the dollar just below the two-mark level against the West German currency and around 148 against the yen. In both cases that is considerably above what is widely assumed to be the upper limits favored by the United States and its economic partners - 1.90 marks and 140 yen. At the start of 1989, the dollar was at 1.77 marks and 125 yen. The Federal Reserve said last week that it sold a record amount of dollars, $11.9 billion, in the May-July period in an effort to halt the dollar's rise.
 
*
 The largest takeover battle in French history ended. Compagnie Financiere de Suez, the Paris-based banking group, raised its bid to $4 billion and gained control of Groupe Victoire, the second-largest insurer in France. Last year Suez defeated Carlo de Benedetti, the Italian industrialist, in a fight for control of Societe Generale de Belgique, the huge Belgian conglomerate. 
 
*
 A scandal at Italy's largest bank led to the resignation of the chairman of the state-owned institution. Nerio Nesi stepped down from Banca Nazionale del Lavoro after disclosures that the bank's Atlanta branch had issued $2.6 billion in unauthorized export credits to Iraq. Besides raising questions about lax management, the situation caused concern about the bank's large exposure to Iraq. Gimpiero Cantoni, a Milan banker with ties to the Socialist Party, was named to succeed Mr. Nesi.
 
*
 Bloomingdale's is for sale. The Campeau Corporation of Toronto will seek bids for the department store chain as part of a corporate reorganization intended to lighten the heavy debt load it has accumulated through an aggressive acquisition campaign. Last year Campeau bought Federated Department Stores, which included Bloomingdale's, for $6.7 billion. In late 1986 it paid $3.4 billion for the Allied Stores chain. The announcement said that Marvin S. Traub, the chairman of Bloomingdale's, had expressed interest in a management buyout.
 
*
 A takeover of Plessey, the British electronics company, was completed. General Electric P.L.C., which is not related to the American G.E., and Siemens A.G. of West Germany said they had acquired more than 50 percent of Plessey. Their final bid in the nine-month battle priced Plessey at $3.14 billion. The battle was complicated by British Government concerns about a takeover of Plessey, which is a large military contractor.
Bonn approved a merger that would create West Germany's largest military contractor. The Economics Ministry endorsed an $859 million proposal by the auto maker Daimler- Benz to take over the Messerschmitt- Bolkow-Blohm aerospace and armaments conglomerate.
 
*
 Ford and Saab-Scania have talked about a possible linkup, the two companies said. They said that the talks were at an early stage and that they could not speculate about an eventual outcome. Saab of Sweden has had heavy losses in its car business.
 
*
 Stock market sentiment turned somewhat negative, with a few widely followed analysts suggesting it was time to take some profits from the summer rally that sent the Dow Jones industrial average to a record of 2,752.09 on Sept. 1. For the week, the Dow lost 42.55 points, to close at 2,709.54. The bond market had light trading. Prices edged up enough to push the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond down to about 8.10, from about 8.20 the previous week.
 
*
 Domestic auto sales rose more than 22 percent in late August, aided by aggressive discounting as the model year neared its end . . . Americans paid off $280 million more than they borrowed during July, the first reduction in consumer debt since January 1987 . . . Nonfarm productivity was up seven-tenths of a percent in the April-to-June period; it had declined 1.3 percent in the first quarter.
 
*
 Crazy Eddie's founder was accused by the Securities and Exchange Commission of overstating the profits of the retail electronics chain. The S.E.C. complaint said that Eddie Antar and some top executives inflated profits for two years beginning in 1985, a period during which Mr. Antar and two executives sold Crazy Eddie shares. Mr. Antar's attorney said his client denied the accusations. Crazy Eddie, which was taken over in 1987 by outside investors, is under bankruptcy protection.
 
*
 Miscellanea. RJR Nabisco sold its Del Monte fresh fruit and vegetable units for $875 million to Polly Peck International of Britain. Del Monte is the world's top supplier of pineapple and ranks No. 3 in bananas . . . Donald J. Trump received Government clearance to buy more than $15 million of shares in Tiffany, the high- fashion jeweler.

LENGTH: 2109 words

HEADLINE: Who Will Subscribe to the Valdez Principles?

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Environmentalists and socially minded investment fund managers did not have to look far for a model when they began secret meetings last winter aimed at finding ways to pressure businesses to be more aggressive about protecting the environment.
The concept of comparing the performance of a broad range of companies to a standard of responsible behavior - and to each other - had been established with the Sullivan Principles governing conduct by American businesses in South Africa, introduced in 1977 by the Rev. Leon Sullivan, a Philadelphia minister and a member of General Motors' board. That model had been introduced with the backing of G.M., Citibank and other large multinationals as a ''socially responsible'' alternative to the position of protesters who wanted the companies to cut all ties with South Africa.
However, the new coalition of environmentalists and investors may have a far tougher time getting corporate support for its code of conduct, introduced Thursday under the name Valdez Principles to memorialize the Exxon Valdez oil disaster in Alaska.
The Valdez Principles are far more sweeping in their scope and objectives, as well as being more vague in their language. Moreover, they have been drafted without input from any companies, including those the coalition hopes will become its first signatories. 
''It's sort of come out of the blue,'' said Lydia Bohl, head of investor relations for the H. P. Fuller Company, a specialty chemical maker in Arden Hills, Minn., that is generally considered among the most environmentally progressive businesses in the nation by fund managers.
The code calls on companies to address the impact of both products and production processes on employees, communities and the environment. It also includes requirements that companies appoint an environmental expert to their board and conduct and publicize an annual independent audit of their compliance with the code.
 
'No Company Is Pure'
 Ms. Bohl said Fuller was first told of the proposals in July, making it one of only a handful of companies that had a chance to see them before their release. Fuller has concerns about the burdens of the independent audit requirement, which might duplicate the company's internal programs. In addition, it has fears that signatories might receive negative publicity for problems they are working on while non-signatories whose problems are less public would escape notoriety.
''No company is pure,'' said Ms. Bohl. ''We want to see a half dozen other companies involved before signing on.''
The Polaroid Corporation, which also was contacted prior to release of the principles because coalition organizers had been impressed by its waste management program, had similar concerns.
''It's an idea we are sympathetic to but it needs further discussion in the company,'' said Harry Fatkin, Polaroid's director of health, safety and environmental affairs.
One problem is the vagueness of the principles in the current form, which some coalition backers describe as a draft. Executives at several companies to whom a reporter recited the principles said they believed that the code was already embodied in their corporate policies, with minor exceptions.
''The principles are not yet in implementable form,'' said John Lickerman, director of research for the Working Assets Money Fund in San Francisco, one of those who advised the Social Investment Forum, a Boston-based trade group of socially minded investors and money managers, in drafting the code. ''We cannot at this point use them to evaluate the performance of a Dow Chemical, G.E. or I.B.M. I'm very skeptical about how the business community will receive it.'' Nevertheless, industry experts said that few businesses are likely to take the new code of conduct lightly. And many companies, they said, may be interested in the coalition's announced intention to invite them to help formulate more specific guidelines.
''My sense is that a lot of companies are looking for ways to show they are environmentally responsible,'' said Bill Ralston, senior consultant on environmental health affairs at SRI International, a consulting firm based in Menlo Park, Calif.
Moreover, leading organizers of the effort to introduce the code, like Joan Bavaria, president of the Franklin Research and Development Corporation, a Boston investment firm, stress that they are trying to find methods to reward those companies that have what the coalition judges to be progressive programs.
If such acknowledgments generate favorable publicity among consumers and shareholders, some companies may find adoption of the code to be a valuable competitive weapon. In that case, the fact that the code was developed without major business input may lend more credibility to positive ratings.
Those companies that dislike the code or believe that they should focus only on complying with existing laws might nonetheless feel forced to address the principles because of the potential clout of the sponsor, the Coalition for Environmentally Responsible Economies (or Ceres, after the Roman goddess of agriculture).
 
Economic Pressure
 Organizers of the coalition include some of the nation's biggest environmental groups, like the Sierra Club and the National Audubon Society, as well as the Humane Society of America. These groups say they intend to use the Valdez standards as a basis for exerting economic pressure, possibly including consumer boycotts, on companies that fail to address their concerns.
In addition, the Council on Economic Priorities, a New York-based research organization that has published a widely circulated shopper's guide outlining corporate positions on a broad range of social issues, said that it would pass on information generated by Valdez audits to its growing audience.
''This will represent the largest single tool for consumers to express their concern about the environment that we have ever had,'' said Terry Gips, president of the International Alliance for Sustainable Agriculture in Minneapolis, a coalition member.
Such observations raise the prospect that the environmental groups, some of which have conflicting agendas, may use the Valdez principles to reach contradictory conclusions about how a company is performing. Spokesmen for several of the groups said last week that none of the environmental organizations would be adjusting their positions to account for those of other coalition members.
Pressure will also come from those Ceres members who represent the growing social investment community. Investors with assets totaling more than $450 billion have shown a willingness to consider issues such as corporate policy in South Africa in making their investment decisions and in voting at shareholder meetings, according to Marcy Murninghan, head of the Lighthouse Investment Group, a Boston investment research firm.
 
Of Greatest Concern
 Investor interest in pressing companies on environmental concerns is thought to be far higher. A survey last year by the Calvert Social Investment Fund of its 30,000 clients found the environment to be their greatest concern by far, according to John Guffey, co-founder of the Bethesda, Md.-based fund.
The fund, which manages $350 million, has applied numerous environmental tests to screen its investments since its founding in 1982 but is now weighing several others. These include a ban on investments in manufacturers of plastic packaging and in companies that contribute to the destruction of rain forests abroad or old-growth forests in the United States.
One group that has played a major role in introducing shareholder resolutions on various social concerns and that now intends to push for adoption of provisions in the Valdez code is the Interfaith Center on Corporate Responsibility, a New York-based investment adviser for the National Council of Churches. The participation of such groups and major pension funds - California and New York City's pension funds have already announced their backing - is certain to catch corporate attention.
''We want companies to understand and we want owners of companies to impel them to understand,'' said Harrison J. Goldin, who, as Comptroller of New York City, controls investment of its pension funds.
''We will obviously take a look at it,'' said William Winters, a General Motors spokesman. ''These are major investors that we work with regularly.''
 
The Major Unknown
 Perhaps the key uncertainty at this point is what Ceres expects from the code's disclosure and audit provisions.
 Corporate sources said that it would be difficult to agree to any disclosure policy that might lead to increased litigation against their companies or to disclosure promises that might create liability beyond that specified in state and Federal laws. For example, companies are already required to report environmental hazards or problems that could materially affect their financial situation in their annual 10K filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Many will be reluctant to go further than that.
As for the audits, coalition members said at Thursday's news conference introducing the code that they expected Ceres to develop standards for such examinations, as the Financial Accounting Standards Board does for financial audits. They also said that they expected the environmental audits to become as routine and widely followed by investors as financial audits.
However, environmental advisers to the business community say that any audit comparable to such financial reports is unlikely to provide coalition members with as much information as they anticipate.
''Typically, financial audit statements are fairly circumspect and don't say much,'' said S. Noble Robinson, head of the Environmental and Risk Management Group at Arthur D. Little Inc., a consultant based in Cambridge, Mass. ''If they say, 'We have reviewed Company X's environmental performance in accord with generally accepted accounting principles and it is fine,' that doesn't get you into a very exposed state in terms of nitty-gritty details.''
Environmental consultants note that financial problems are often hidden from outside auditors and that environmental audits might suffer from the same failings unless they are extremely detailed, which would make them very expensive. Environmental audits are increasingly common in cases where property is being sold and banks, insurers or purchasers believe that a hazardous waste or asbestos problem may exist. But the kind of audit contemplated by Ceres members appears to be far more sweeping and business executives say there are few if any independent auditors capable of doing such a thorough job.
Ceres backers say such problems reinforce the need for having companies voluntarily disclose information on an ongoing basis. How else, asked Denis Hayes, Ceres co-chairman with Ms. Bavaria and chief executive officer of Earth Day 1990, can environmentalists and investors know if the grounding of the Exxon Valdez is a sign that Exxon is operating in an environmentally unsound way compared with other oil companies or is just unlucky?
''This is the most complicated area of social investing, more complicated even than judging employee relations,'' said Mr. Lickerman of the Working Assets Money Fund. ''But we have an obligation to monitor it for our investors and we hope the Valdez Principles will help.''
 
 A SUMMARY OF THE VALDEZ PRINCIPES
 
Protection of the Biosphere: Signatores will try to eliminate pollutants that damage the air, water or earth.
 
Sustainable Use of Natural Resources: Pledges use of renewable resources, conservation of non-renewable materials and preservation of biological diversity.
 
Reduction and Disposal of Waste: Pledges minimizing and safely disposing of hazardous wastes.
 
Wise Use of Energy: Calls for energy-efficient products and processes.
 
Risk Reduction: Pledges reducing environmental risks and preparing for accidents.
 
Marketing of Safe Products and Services: Pledges disclosure of environmental impact of products and services.
 
 Damage Compensation: Pledges restoration of damaged environments and compensation for human injury.
 
Disclosure: Pledges disclosure of accidents and hazards and protection of employees who report them.
 
 Environment Directors and Managers: Companies agree that at least one board member will be an environmental expert. A senior executive for environmental affairs will also be named.
 
 Assessment and Annual Audit: Pledges annual environmental audit of worldwide operations. Audit is to be made public.

GRAPHIC: Joan Bavaria, co-chairman of the group that is sponsoring the Valdez Principles (NYT/John Sotomayor)

HEADLINE: Struggling for Profits in Electronics

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: RICHMOND

 BODY:
The last several years have been miserable ones for specialty retailers of consumer electronics. After riding the boom in V.C.R. sales through the first half of the 1980's, most electronics chains are now being battered by flattened sales, brutal price wars and ill-conceived expansions.
But there is one striking exception: Circuit City Stores Inc. Profits for the chain, which is based here, have risen every year since 1980, and tripled since 1986 to reach $69.5 million in fiscal 1989, ended in February. The company has a dominant position in almost every city in which it competes, and is expanding its store base by 25 percent a year despite the sluggish retail electronics environment. With 133 stores, and revenues expected to top $2 billion this year, Circuit City has emerged as the undisputed leader among chains of stand-alone electronics stores.
''Without a question, Circuit City is the best-managed consumer electronics retailer in the United States,'' said David A. Bolotsky, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company. ''By every significant measure, including sales per square foot, sales per store and pre-tax margins, Circuit City outperforms its major competitors.'' 
There is a lesson in retailing to be found in the story of how Circuit City has prospered amid the turmoil of a floundering retail industry. Some analysts believe the lesson is applicable not only in consumer electronics, but in other retail areas as well where deep discounting, fierce competition and a fickle public have taken their toll.
In part, Circuit City has excelled for the same reasons that McDonald's has continued to dominate the fast-food industry: execution. Like the hamburger chain, Circuit City has refined a merchandising formula that is more subtle than it appears. And like McDonald's, Circuit City exercises nearly autocratic discipline in carrying it out.
Still, Circuit City faces tougher times. The mass merchandizers and discount warehouses are expected to prove to be more serious competitors. That is largely why its shares are trading at only 24 - a lower multiple of earnings than other top specialty retailers like Toys 'R' Us or the Limited.
''This is going to be a difficult period,'' said Barry Bryant, an analyst for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. ''The markets they are moving into are harder than the ones they are in now, and the markets they are in now are going to get much more competitive. We are entering a period where durable goods sales are not likely to do well. If you combine all those things, you may have a period when Circuit City faces a series of declines in comparable store sales.''
But it is in a stronger position that most other specialty electronics retailers. And the rapid rise of the video cassette recorder are at the root of their current woes. VCR sales exploded in the early 80's, rising to $5.2 billion in 1986, from $389 million in 1979. After the recession of 1981 and 1982, consumers were eager to spend freely on all forms of consumer electronics and appliances.
The craze encouraged specialty retailers to expand like wildfire. Between 1983 and 1986, 14 chains went public, using the proceeds to launch or accelerate their expansions. Detroit-based Highland Superstores, alone, has grown to 84 stores nationwide, from 18 in 1980.
By 1987, however, more than half of all households had already acquired a video cassette recorder. Without a new blockbuster to resurrect the market, sales growth of consumer electronics slowed to a meager 2 percent a year - a trend that analysts expect to continue for several more years.
Competition turned savage, squeezing profit margins, earnings and the stock prices of most chains. Highland, with sales of $1 billion a year, lost $11.2 million in the first half of its current fiscal year. In 1987, it earned $13.9 million. With sales of $506 million, the Best Buy Company of Bloomington, Minn., has seen its profits fall to $2.5 million, from $7.7 million two years ago.
The performance of some chains has been grimmer still. This year, Audio Video Affiliates Inc., a company formed in 1984 by consolidating three smaller retail chains, decided to sell off and lease back its 78 stores to raise $61 million. The company used some of the money to pay down debt incurred when it bought back $40 million worth of its own stock in 1988. (The purchase has not helped the stock, which trades at about 4, down from more than 13 in mid-1986.
 
Flamboyant Flameout
 But Crazy Eddie Inc. of Edison, N.J., has been the most flamboyant flameout. Once one of the hottest names in the field, the company is now in bankruptcy and has shuttered 17 of its 43 stores. The chain's sales peaked at $352 million in 1987, but fell off, precipitating a huge $109 million loss the next year. This week, the Securities and Exchange Commission charged that its founder, Eddie Antar, who sold much of his stake in the company several years ago, had fraudulently overstated the company's assets by $65 million.
In contrast, Circuit City expanded more cautiously during the electronics boom. It avoided helter-skelter expansion and instead has methodically blitzed the cities in which it has chosen to compete, coming to dominate almost all of them. It has invested heavily in infrastructure, such as a satellite-linked computer network, automated distribution facilities and truck fleets.
''It sounds boring, but we are doing a lot of things a little bit better than the competition,'' said Richard L. Sharp, Circuit City's chief executive. ''You know, Vince Lombardi and the Green Bay Packers won a lot of Superbowls running Paul Hornung over tackle. Everyone knew that's where he was going, but they executed the play with enough precision and expertise to succeed.''
Brian Berghuis, an analyst at T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore, gives the company high marks. ''I would put Circuit City up there with the best names in retailing, along with Toys 'R' Us and Wal-Mart,'' he said.
To be sure, Circuit City faces plenty of opportunities to stumble. One problem is the threat of a recession, since most of its products are discretionary purchases that can be put off during hard times.
A second threat is intensified competition. Sears and Montgomery Ward are both upgrading their consumer electronics departments into something analogous to in-house superstores offering brand-name products. Although analysts say their cost structures are higher than Circuit City's, the department stores' formidable marketing clout is expected to increase their market share.
Finally, the chain could run into trouble from the growing importance of membership warehouse chains likePrice Club and Pace Membership Warehouse Inc. Such chains, which have much lower advertising and operating costs, account for up to 4 percent of the nation's consumer electronics sales, but their market share is expected to steadily increase. Should the warehouse stores begin to seriously erode their market share, Circuit City executives say, they have contingency plans for converting affected stores into warehouse operations.
Nevertheless, Circuit City has profited handsomely through what has already been a recession in its industry. And its strong balance sheet, analysts say, should help it extend that record. Circuit City's long-term debt is only 16 percent of total capital, compared with 24 percent at Highland Superstores and 28 percent at Best Buy Company.
 
Slow Evolution
 Although Mr. Sharp gets much of the credit for the company's success, the foundations of Circuit City preceded him. Founded in 1949 by Samuel Wurtzel as the Wards Company, the concern evolved slowly into an operator of television departments inside department stores and then into a small chain of stand-alone retailers in the Middle Atlantic region.
In 1975, Mr. Wurtzel's son, Alan, pioneered the nation's first electronics superstore, a 32,000-square-foot outlet in Richmond that offered about 2,000 product selections. The superstore's high volume made it possible to cut prices and still offer conveniences like home delivery and in-store repairs. The concept proved a hit, and Circuit City has devoted almost all its subsequent expansion to superstores.
Mr. Sharp, previously the owner of a computer software and consulting firm, arrived in 1982, hired to install a computer network that would link the stores with company headquarters. When that task was completed, Mr. Wurtzler hired Mr. Sharp as executive vice president and later promoted him to president and chief executive. (Alan Wurtzel is now Circuit City's chairman.) Mr. Sharp's own discipline has rubbed off on Circuit City. ''He's a systems guy, not a seat-of-the-pants merchant,'' commented Mr. Bolotsky. ''He's not a people person like Sam Walton,'' he said, referring to the head of Wal-Mart.
Mr. Sharp concurs with such assessments. ''I don't claim to be the merchant or even the guru of this business,'' he said. ''My contribution comes not from figuring out which one of those TV's we ought to be selling. What I can do is make sure, in the global sense, that our customers get the kind of service they need.''
At first glance, Circuit City's merchandising strategy seems to rely simply on the discounters' golden rule of high volume and low prices. In reality, however, it is a subtle balance between competitive pricing and customer hand-holding. ''It's very easy to beat Circuit City on price, just by selling televisions out of a garage,'' Mr. Bolotsky said. ''But they have finessed the pricing issue by competing on the basis of superior service and the other components of value.''
This is no small feat, however. Most consumers view TV's, stereos and appliances as ''commodity'' products that should be purchased only on the basis of price. At the same time, however, they want sales representatives who can explain the distinctions between competing products, and they like the conveniences of a full-service department store.
 
An Efficient Warehouse
 In large part, Circuit City straddles these competing demands by being efficient. A central warehouse facility near Richmond, for example, supplies about 50 stores in the Middle Atlantic region. By using computer-controlled routing machines and bar-code readers, the warehouse sorts orders and routes them over several miles of track to the proper loading dock. Only 16 employees receive and load more than $400 million worth of merchandise every year.
Circuit City's store designs are carefully calculated to create the illusion of both warehouse pricing and customer service. First-time customers usually walk in after reading or seeing advertisements about low prices. The stores reinforce that expectation in the lobby, where customers are given a view of the storage area with boxes piled on high. ''The purpose is to give people a little subliminal message, that 'Gosh, there are all these boxes and big volume, so they've got to sell this stuff cheap,' '' explained Mr. Sharp.
Once inside the display area, however, customers are greeted by an orderly, almost cozy, atmosphere. In the television section, for example, some 200 models line the walls, all tuned to the same channel. To make the selection easier, the models are meticulously arranged according to size and complexity. Layout is controlled so carefully that each model is in the same position, relative to its competitors, in Circuit City stores.
Well-groomed sales representatives, dressed in polished shoes and navy blazers (or gray, depending on the day), guide customers to the products in their price range. Salespeople have been schooled intensively on the distinctions between each product, and they specialize in only one category of merchandise at a time. They are assertive, and will always point out advantages of products one level more expensive than a customer has first sought out. But they are trained not to browbeat customers into making more expensive selections or denigrate less sophisticated merchandise.
Customers are reminded that they can return merchandise for any reason within 30 days. If a customer finds the same product selling elsewhere for less than he or she paid, Circuit City says it will refund 110 percent of the difference. The latter point is less helpful than most consumers realize, because appliance manufacturers try to forestall price wars by selling slightly different merchandise to rival retailers. Thus, finding precisely the same model nearby is usually difficult. Nevertheless, much of the inherent anxiety of picking a big-ticket item at more than the lowest available price is relieved.
All these details add to operational costs, and Circuit City's expenses for sales and administration account for about 22 percent of its revenues. They are significantly higher than no-frills warehouse clubs, where expenses average about 11 percent of sales. But 22 percent is still lower than department stores and many other specialty electronic retailers. For instance, those expenses at Highland Superstores have been averaging about 30 percent in recent quarters.
Thus far, Mr. Sharp has managed to stay even on prices with other conventional retailers but avoid bloodbaths. Stores in each market have the authority to lower prices to meet competition, but they are under orders to avoid starting their own price wars.
''This is such an intensely shopped business, and so visible, that essentially what happens is you just bring down the pricing in the market for everyone,'' said Mr. Sharp. ''So, we don't start price wars - but we usually end them. Make no mistake, we have the strength and the ability to respond.''
 
Controlling Expansion
 Unlike many of his rivals, Mr. Sharp has controlled the pace and the breadth of company expansion. Although Circuit City now competes in Los Angeles and San Francisco, all of its other expansion has been into areas contiguous with previously established markets.
As a result, Circuit City has no presence in some of the nation's largest metropolitan areas, including Chicago, Boston or, fortunately enough, any city in Texas. (In one blunder, the company did try to compete in New York. Crushing competition made it impossible for the stores to do much better than break even, however, and the company retreated.) The cautious expansion has produced several benefits. As a practical matter, Circuit City has been able to centralize its entire supply operation in three highly automated warehouses. That has boosted economies of scale, as well as flexibility, in transportation and handling.
On the strategic level, Circuit City has avoided the most brutally competitive markets, while earning comparatively easy profits in a host of smaller cities like Tampa, Fla. ''You can credit them with being brilliant or with being lucky,'' said Mr. Bolotsky of Goldman Sachs. ''But they do not compete against other major chains in most markets.'' Regardless, Mr. Sharp has proved that his company can compete fiercely if it must. Two years ago, Circuit City moved into San Francisco, home of The Good Guys, a highly regarded regional electronics chain and one of the only publicly held companies to increase its profits in recent years.
Consistent with its standard approach, Circuit City did not test the waters with a pilot store. Instead, it launched eight superstores at once to achieve economies of scale for mass-market advertising, distribution and administration. The up-front investment totaled between $40 million and $50 million, not including the initial advertising expenses.
Today, Circuit City is roughly equal in volume with Good Guys. Said Mr. Sharp: ''We move on the assumption that we will do well.''
