HEADLINE: Old Newspapers Hit a Logjam

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

DATELINE: GARFIELD, N.J.

 BODY:
Hour after hour, around the clock, bundles of old newspapers rumble along a conveyor until they drop into a large vat at the Garden State Paper Company's recycling mill here along the Passaic River. In a few hours they will emerge as rolls of blank newsprint, ready to be used again.
The company, a subsidiary of Media General Inc., has been turning old newspapers into new newsprint since 1961 without much fanfare. But now municipalities are vying to sell their newspapers to Garden State. And they are hoping that more mills will follow in the company's footsteps and do so quickly. In response to the shortage of landfill space and pressure from environmentalists, municipalities across the nation have mandated newspaper recycling programs. The trouble is, there is a dearth of recyclers.
Paper makers have been slow to face the facts: Recycling is the way of the future and is already shrinking the market for their traditional product. But switching to recycling is no easy task. The industry, encumbered by huge and costly plants, has never been one to react quickly. Paper makers face other obstacles, too, like remote locations and depressed prices. 
It remains to be seen whether these manufacturers will wake up and catch the recycling trend - by building recycling mills or converting existing ones that use trees - or whether recyclers like Garden State will move in to fill the gap.
 
A Common Challenge
 But other industries are no doubt watching the drama unfold. After all, the challenge to recycle is sure to be repeated throughout American business as the public demands stronger conservation measures. In the aluminum industry, which has been struggling with the issue for some time, there already is a range of recyclers.
For now, supply of old newspapers has simply overwhelmed the capacity of recyclers, paper industry officials say. The eight mills in this country capable of recycling newspapers are already running at full capacity and sell all they produce. ''There are a million tons of old newspapers in warehouses, mills and waste paper packing plants now,'' said J. Rodney Edwards, a vice president of the American Paper Institute, a trade group. ''In July the industry said 'we're full.' ''
Some communities have started recycling programs only to find that they still have to truck newspapers to distant landfills. Each ton of newspapers not recycled uses three cubic feet of landfill space and incurs as much as $100 in disposal costs.
Meanwhile, the demand for recycled newsprint is growing. Some states have passed laws encouraging, even mandating, its use. Florida imposed a 10-cent-a-ton tax on non-recycled newsprint, which costs about the same amount as the recycled variety. A Connecticut law requires that newspapers published or circulated in the state use increasing amounts of recycled paper, starting at 20 percent in 1993 and rising to 90 percent. Legislators in New York and New Jersey have also discussed ways to increase the use of recycled newsprint.
If only to stave off more such legislation, newspaper publishers are showing more interest in recycled paper. ''I am very confident that publishers will make a significant commitment to buy recycled newsprint,'' said William M. Ferretti, director of energy conservation services for the New York State Department of Economic Development. He heads a committee on newsprint usage that is to release a report next month.
Executives at The New York Times said they are interested in using more recycled newsprint. ''We would favor another recycled newsprint mill in this area,'' said Walter E. Mattson, president of The New York Times Company. He said The Times would ''seek to be involved'' in attracting such a mill.
The Times currently buys about 30,000 short tons of recycled newsprint a year from Garden State, or about 8 percent of its total usage of 360,000 tons. Most of the remainder comes from mills in Canada using virgin fiber.
Other publishers have been paying more attention to recycled newsprint as well. ''There has been a lot of interest in the last few months,'' said James L. Hutchinson, another vice president of the American Paper Institute. ''There are a lot of discussions going on between publishers and their suppliers.''
The following publishers use varying amounts of recycled paper.
* The Gannett Company, whose 84 daily newspapers consume 962,000 short tons of newsprint a year, has a policy to use more recycled newsprint as it becomes available. ''We are in the 8 to 10 percent range now,'' said Shelia Gibbons, director of public affairs for Gannett.
* Jon Melkerson, director of newsprint operations for The Los Angeles Times, said 83 percent of its newsprint, or 380,000 short tons a year, contains some recycled fiber. The majority is from two mills in Oregon that produce a blend of 50 percent recycled paper with virgin wood.
* Knight-Ridder Inc., with 29 daily newspapers, uses 11 percent recycled newsprint, said Homer Taylor, vice president of supply. ''We will shortly be sending a letter to all our suppliers telling them we intend to be at 25 percent by 1992,'' he said.
 
Publishers Are Key
 Paper makers say the interest of publishers is crucial if they are to make the transition to recycling. ''From a producer's standpoint, if you are going to make newsprint, you would like to know where you are going to sell it,'' said John H. Veidt Jr., a vice president of the Jefferson Smurfit Corporation, which has two mills in Oregon. ''In most mill start-ups lately a user was involved, either financially or contractually.''
The paper companies are under added pressure because newsprint prices have been depressed since the beginning of the year. With newspaper advertising linage down this year, newsprint is being sold at a 25 percent discount from the $650 a metric ton stated price, according to trade journals. (A metric ton is 2,205 pounds; a short ton is 2,000 pounds.) Under these conditions, paper makers are reluctant to invest as much as $400 million in a recycling mill - unless they have a financial safety net, either long-term purchase contracts or equity investments from publishers. With the increasing governmental pressure on publishers to buy recycled paper, these kinds of deals may not be far off, industry and government insiders say.
Even now, there are preliminary signs that recycling capacity will grow. Garden State and Jefferson Smurfit, the largest recyclers in North America, are studying the possibility of building mills in the Northeast. Officials ofseveral Northeastern states say most paper producers are considering adding de-inking equipment, at a cost of $20 million to $30 million a mill, to blend in some recycled material.
For the traditional paper companies this push to recycle comes at an inauspicious time. Many are just completing a building phase, started in the mid-80's when paper prices were rising steadily. About a dozen new mills and enlargements are scheduled to go into operation in the next few years, but almost all are based on trees.
And this new capacity is to produce an extra two million tons of newsprint a year, and will flood a market already having trouble absorbing 15 million. Industry analysts say these conditions - overproduction and depressed prices, on top of pressure to produce recycled paper - make the business ripe for a shakeout.
''Political incentives could create demand for recycled newsprint, which would cause problems in the forest products industry,'' said Jon G. Udell, a professor at the University of Wisconsin Business School. ''The impact could be the harshest on the Canadian industry.'' Nearly 60 percent of the newsprint consumed in the United States comes from Canada, where mills tend to be in remote locations, with an abundance of trees and a minimum of people. But recycling mills need to be close to the source of their raw material: large urban areas. Three of the five mills in the United States using 100 percent recycled material have such sites, in the suburbs of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles.
 
The Geography Problem
 For the traditional paper companies, geography will be one of the stickiest obstacles to recycling. The economics of gathering up old newspapers from urban areas like New York, shipping them to distant mills in Canada and then shipping the finished product back are still being evaluated, industry executives say.
''The problem is that it has been difficult to persuade manufacturers with mills in a forest to invest in recycling equipment and go through all the travail involved in collection,'' said John Morton, a newspaper industry analyst at Lynch, Jones & Ryan. ''But it is the manufacturers that will have to solve it.''
Recycling presents another sticky problem: paper quality. Publishers have been reluctant to use recycled paper in the past because it has been more likely to tear, disrupting high-speed pressrooms that operate on tight production schedules.
Recyclers want old newspapers but little else. Yellow-page telephone directories and brown bags, for example, color the paper, making it less desirable to publishers who want a bright white sheet for a more readable newspaper. Coated papers and slick magazines are equally undesirable. If the contaminants they contain get through filters, they can make sheets of rolled paper stick together, causing tears during printing.
Garden State pre-sorts newspapers at the warehouses of its subsidiary, Bruno & D'Elia Inc. Workers say the loads of papers have included everything from hand tools to a cement block. ''People have tried mechanizing the process, but nothing other than hand labor has worked so far,'' said Clare Mullett, manager of procurement services.
Incoming material has a big impact on the economics of recycling. Bruno & D'Elia pays $12 a ton for a ''clean'' load - newspapers tied with cotton string and nothing else. For a ''dirty'' load - one filled with shopping bags, junk mail and other unsuitable materials - it charges $20 a ton.
''Newspapers are teaching us a lesson on the importance of quality in the marketing of materials,'' said Mr. Ferretti, the New York State official.
Paper makers have learned another lesson: recycled paper must coexist with, not replace, paper from virgin fiber. Recycling breaks some fibers in newsprint to lengths too short to make strong paper, so they are filtered out. Ten to 15 percent of what goes into a mill is lost in processing, said James L. Burke, executive vice president of Garden State. And the percentage could rise if paper is repeatedly reused. For this reason, paper industry executives and analysts say Connecticut's demand that publishers use 90 percent recycled paper is unrealistic.
They also note that newspapers can be turned into other materials like like egg cartons and insulation. ''If there is legislation in this area,'' said Professor Udell, ''it should aim for the most economic use.''

HEADLINE: No New Taxes, But Plenty Of New Plans

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AS the Bush Presidency unfolds, it is becoming clear that the Administration's most ambitious goals, like the war on drugs that the President proclaimed last week, are hostage to his campaign promise not to raise taxes. Even many of the President's strongest supporters agree that the drug initiative and some other Presidential proposals are constrained by inadequate financing, and nobody has proposed a politically feasible way to squeeze the needed funds out of the Federal budget.
In his speech Tuesday night, the President called drugs ''the gravest domestic threat facing our nation,'' but he proposed to spend only $716 million more than had already been budgeted in the next year for drug control programs. That is less than one-hundredth of 1 percent of the $1.1 trillion Federal budget. 
Other Bush initiatives have followed the same pattern.
* The President went to Poland in July to cheer on the cataclysmic political and economic changes under way there. But he pledged only $100 million to underwrite the transition to Polish democracy, 1 percent of the $10 billion in Western assistance that the Solidarity leader, Lech Walesa, maintained was necessary.
* Mr. Bush promised in his election campaign last year to be the ''education President,'' but the budget he submitted in February included less money for education than Congress had appropriated the previous year.
* On the 20th anniversary of the American astronauts' first moon landing, Mr. Bush announced the new goal of sending people to Mars. But he never addressed how such a huge project would be paid for.
Mr. Bush maintains that more money is not necessarily the solution to all problems. Richard G. Darman, the President's budget director, has argued all year that the secret is to reallocate funds from less worthy Government activities. But as was the case with the President's previous budget submissions, the cuts Mr. Darman suggested to pay for the modest drug program were all but guaranteed to be rejected by Congress. For example, the Economic Development Administration, which Mr. Darman recommended abolishing, is a particular favorite of Congressional Republicans. The agency gives loan guarantees to developers and other business owners who tend to be strong Republicans.
Mr. Bush's habit of speaking loudly but carrying a small fiscal stick has begun to grate even on some of his friends in Congress. Representative Mickey Edwards, an Oklahoma Republican, said of the drug fight, ''If it's not worth spending everything it takes, it's not a war.''
Among Democrats, the irritation was more intense. George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Senate majority leader, spoke of ''the gap between rhetoric and reality, word and deed.''
 
Paying the Check
Representative Leon E. Panetta of California, chairman of the Budget Committee, said he sensed ''a growing concern'' among his fellow Democrats, and among Republicans as well, ''that all these promises are being made and nothing is said about who's going to pick up the check.''
Michael J. Boskin, an economist who is chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, told the United States Chamber of Commerce in a speech last week that a ''basic principle'' of the Administration was to reduce the budget deficit by slowing the growth of Government spending.
But the consensus of economists outside the Government is that savings big enough to provide funds to finance the war on drugs, improve public education or make ambitious advances in space exploration can be made only in two areas: the military and social insurance programs.
For example, the single step of canceling the Navy's plans to overhaul the aircraft carrier Enterprise would save nearly $2 billion. Eliminating for one year the cost-of-living increase paid Social Security beneficiaries would save $9 billion in the first year and, because of compounding, much more in subsequent years.
But Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has proved to be a vigorous advocate of the Pentagon's budget, and President Bush has been unwilling to make sharp reductions there. Both the President and Congress have forsworn reductions in Social Security payments.
''When you have to play off a program that doesn't exist against a program that exists and has strong interests behind it, it makes for very tough sledding,'' said a senior staff economist in Congress.
That leaves higher taxes as the only practical way to meet the President's goals, and most Democrats and many Republicans are hoping Mr. Bush will relax his no-tax stance somewhat to generate more money for the drug program. For instance, Representative Edwards, normally a forceful opponent of higher taxes, said he would support a higher tax on alcohol and tobacco if the money were dedicated to the drug fight. Public opinion polls indicate that this is a popular position.
Doubling the Federal tax on cigarettes to 32 cents a pack would raise about $3 billion a year. Raising the tax on beer and wine, which has been unchanged since 1951, to the same rate (based on alcohol content) as the tax on distilled spirits would raise about $5 billion a year while increasing the price of a six-pack of beer by less than 50 cents.
 
No Change on Taxes
But Mr. Bush has shown no inclination to relent on his tax pledge. In his speech he cautioned Congress against ''a partisan bidding war'' and said, ''We can pay for this fight against drugs without raising taxes or adding to the budget deficit.''
Moreover, Mr. Darman, in his countless meetings with Congressional leaders over the last nine months, has given not the slightest hint that the Administration would accept anything that could be construed as a tax increase.
Democrats in Congress say they cannot afford to move toward higher taxes without the President's assent. ''We're not going to have a light-cavalry charge in the face of a certain veto,'' Senator Mitchell said.
The drug program aside, a revenue shortage remains. The law requires the President and Congress to find a way to reduce the budget deficit by at least $36 billion next year. Meantime, in the years ahead, the cost of cleaning up and modernizing nuclear weapons plants will cost more than $100 billion, Government accountants say. Eliminating hazardous waste at military bases will cost more than $10 billion.
Updating air traffic control systems will cost $25 billion in the next decade. And most experts believe the savings and loan rescue plan adopted this year will cost billions more than was budgeted. Furthermore, the demands for Federal help to young families for child-care expenses and to the elderly for long-term health care are mounting.
President Bush has not begun to address those problems in a comprehensive way. William J. Bennett, who devised the President's drug control policy, said last week that he had not been given a budgetary ceiling. ''But I'm a grown-up,'' he added. ''I'm part of the Administration. I live in the real world.''

HEADLINE: COLOMBIA'S VIRGILIO BARCO VARGAS;
The President With the Biggest War on Drugs

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia

 BODY:
PRESIDENT VIRGILIO BARCO VARGAS, who has vowed to crush the drug lords who have turned his country into a killing ground, seems an unlikely field commander. Uninspiring at the microphone and uncomfortable with the grand gestures of leadership, Mr. Barco might be better cast as a university researcher.
Before the current war on Colombia's cocaine traffickers began, his distaste for publicity and reluctance to make public appearances had left many people calling him the ''ghost president.'' But now, confronted by powerful and vicious hoodlums, the 67-year-old scion of a wealthy land-owning family has surprised his enemies and his colleagues by ferociously striking back. Earlier this year, under pressure from Washington to cut the flow of cocaine to the United States, he began ordering raids on processing laboratories and jungle airfields. Three weeks ago, he began to wage all-out war. In the battle, Mr. Barco has to worry about the reliability of his security forces and some elected officials. He is also wary of the potentially undermining effects of a tempting but probably disingenuous offer of a truce by the drug lords. At the same time he and his centrist party have all the typical political pressures of an election year. Many Colombians oppose his decision to send the so-called extraditables to the United States on the ground that it looks like an admission that Colombia's judicial institutions are inferior. As a former executive director of the World Bank in Washington and Ambassador to the United States, he faces criticism at home for seeming too willing to follow Washington's lead. 
But senior Government officials and Western diplomats here said that President Barco had become convinced that the powerful drug traffickers were striving to supplant Colombia's traditional politicians and, through intimidation, bribes and the creation of their own political party, seize control of the country. ''The traffickers are not only criminal, but politically oriented to the extreme right, and he believes they are mortal enemies of our democracy,'' said a senior Government official.
Mr. Barco, who holds a degree in civil engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, gave no indication in his lackluster campaign in 1986 that he planned to take on the private armies of the drug barons, who are among the wealthiest men in the world. His toughest hurdle on the way to the presidency was in gaining the nomination of his Liberal Party, which has invariably won office when it has avoided internal warfare.
In his fight against the traffickers, Mr. Barco has the backing of the United States. But he also has more than a few handicaps. His army and police force are ridden with corruption. There are serious questions about whether the Colombian people will be willing to endure an almost certainly long and bloody war.
Furthermore, congressional elections are coming up in seven months with presidential elections two months later. Constitutionally, Mr. Barco cannot succeed himself, but he is being undercut by partisan politics as members of both his party and the opposition Conservative Party, which share a nearly indistinguishable centrist ideology, jockey for personal advantage.
 
Fighting Guerrillas
In his first three years in office, Mr. Barco concentrated on pacifying Colombia's half-dozen leftist guerrilla organizations. His advisers said he focused on the rebels rather than on the traffickers simply because he could not do everything at once and because in the beginning he regarded the leftists as the greater threat. As he progressed toward a deal with the guerrillas, he shifted attention to the drug lords.
The traffickers had long cowed the Colombian judiciary with guns and bribes. In early August a new political party called the National Restoration Movement was born in the Magdalena River Valley, a region of cattle ranchers and peasant farmers. The party says it is for democracy, a better life for Colombia's poor and an end to leftist guerrillas, but the Government warns that it is dominated by the drug barons.
For months, in his methodical, plodding manner, Mr. Barco worked to build a consensus for the plan he announced on Aug. 19 calling for confiscation of property and extradition. That week the traffickers' assassins had gunned down a provincial police chief and a magistrate. Hours before the President announced the campaign, Senator Carlos Luis Galan, the most popular presidential candidate, was killed.
Swept along by the candidate's murder, initial support for a war on the drug lords was overwhelming. An independent poll published Friday showed that more than 75 percent of Colombians were still behind him. But there have been expressions of disenchantment from leaders in both parties. American officials say the latest raids have severely disrupted cocaine production and shipping, but not a single kingpin has yet been captured.
 
Living With Violence
Colombians have been living with violence for decades, and before the latest surge, many of them seemed willing to quietly coexist with the traffickers. In the late 1940's and early 1950's the two main political parties, the Liberals and the Conservatives, fought a civil war known as La Violencia that cost 300,000 lives. These days, in addition to the leftist guerrillas, more than 130 rightist paramilitary units are operating in Colombia, many linked to the drug traffickers. There are also legions of criminals who make a living as hired killers and robbers.
Signs of how difficult a task President Barco faces, even in rallying the other leaders of Colombia for the fight, was evident last week. When his Cabinet tried to address the House of Representatives to gain support for converting decrees by Mr. Barco on extradition and confiscation into laws, the acting speaker from the Conservative Party abruptly called for adjournment.
Mr. Barco had angered the Conservatives by abruptly declaring that some civilian mayors in areas dominated by the cocaine traffickers would be replaced by military officers of his chosing. The mayors are considered a key to grass-roots political support and Mr. Barco's Liberal colleagues were as angry as the Conservatives. They fumed about dictatorial tactics and refused to concede that an appointed military officer might prove a more formidable and less corruptible foe of the traffickers than an elected civilian. Within 24 hours Mr. Barco abandoned what he had reckoned to be an important weapon against the traffickers.

HEADLINE: Seoul Is Opening Up, But Its Jails Are Still Full

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea

 BODY:
EVEN before the end of the Seoul Olympics last year, which raised Koreans' hopes for progress and stability, leaders here fretted about a potential post-Games letdown. Today the euphoria of that time is long gone, and South Korea is struggling with the shadows of its authoritarian past and lurching fitfully in its transition to democracy after decades of military rule.
As in the past, the challenges facing South Korea are epitomized by the state of its jails. This spring and summer, less than 18 months after President Roh Tae Woo released hundreds of political prisoners in his first gesture toward a more open society, the country faced a wave of sometimes violent strikes, student protests and anti-Government actions, including unauthorized trips to North Korea by leftist dissidents.
Despite the widespread view that this opposition posed only a mild threat to stability, Mr. Roh responded with a crackdown on militant dissent that has filled jails with as many political detainees as were imprisoned before he took office in early 1988. The jailings, in turn, have created new concern about Mr. Roh's commitment to due process and free institutions. 
Mr. Roh's crackdown culminated last month with the indictment of Kim Dae Jung, the most prominent opposition leader, on charges of violating national security laws. Mr. Kim, who was one of Mr. Roh's opponents in the 1987 election, remains free and his frequent denunciations of the Government are widely publicized. But human rights groups say that perhaps 800 dissidents, some of them avowedly radical leftists, are waiting in prison for their day in court.
''There has been a true conservative backlash that makes everyone a little nervous about the future,'' a Western diplomat said.
Mr. Roh's advisers dismiss the concern that democracy is endangered. They assert that the National Assembly is functioning vigorously with Mr. Kim's party in the dominant position, and that freedom of the press and the independence of the judiciary are respected. ''Seoul Plaza is not Tiananmen Square,'' an aide to Mr. Roh said. ''To return to the old ways is impossible.'' Nevertheless, Mr. Roh's actions were a reminder that although a democratically elected government is in place, many trappings of democracy have yet to be institutionalized. A free press prints criticism of the Government, but many Korean oppositionists feel that newspapers still reflect the conservatism of their owners.
 
Showcasing Progress
This autumn was supposed to have been a season in which South Korea would showcase its recent progress. Vice President Dan Quayle is due for a visit later this month, followed by Pope John Paul II in October. Then, Mr. Roh is to visit Washington. United States officials say recent events in South Korea are unlikely to disrupt the exchanges, but they are worried that the situation could deteriorate. Political stability is essential if there is to be any serious discussion of possible reductions in the 44,000 American troops stationed here. Sentiment is rising in Washington for such decreases, or at least for demands that Seoul pay more of their expenses.
Only six months ago, the atmosphere was far less contentious, as opposition leaders urged their supporters to give Mr. Roh time to fulfill his campaign promises. There was even talk, unthinkable a year or two ago, of a possible political alliance between Mr. Roh and the opposition.
But in the spring, an impasse developed over disagreements on several matters, such as how to handle the legacy of South Korea's authoritarian past. An especially delicate subject was the placement of blame for the 1980 massacre in Kwangju, in which hundreds were said to have died as the army and security police suppressed a student rebellion. The opposition demanded that Mr. Roh purge his Government of several people involved in the Kwangju action, but the President apparently felt he could not do so without angering his right-wing backers.
Even some Roh supporters concede that he may indeed have overstepped himself in the crackdown. But they also argue that the success or failure of the Roh Government will rest on other issues. Some say that South Korea's booming economy and rapid industrialization are creating wider and wider disparities, and they maintain that economic deprivation ought to be their most important concern.
''In the past 30 years, we have moved from absolute poverty to unevenly distributed prosperity,'' said Jei Jeong Gu, chairman of the Progressive Political Movement, an independent group. Thus, organized labor is becoming more militant, land prices are soaring, housing is in short supply, and slums are spreading.
Both the Government and the opposition have proposals to deal with such things, and at one point it seemed that the National Assembly would agree on sweeping reforms this year. But for now, all bets for cooperation are off. Political experts say that that South Koreans will have to move beyond their fixation with protests and arrests and get down to providing economic benefits as the best means to assure stability.

HEADLINE: Flight and Futility Are Rountine in the Horn of Africa

BYLINE: By Jane Perlez

 BODY:
THE Horn of Africa, which includes the waters of the Nile and the fertile lands of southern Ethiopia, is rich in the basic requirements for agriculture. Without war, it could easily be self-sufficient in food. But the last two decades have proved a time of hunger and dislocation on an enormous scale throughout the region. In an attempt to resolve one cause of that misery - the civil war between Eritrean rebels and the Ethiopian Government - preliminary peace talks began in Atlanta last week under the auspices of former President Jimmy Carter.
Wars in the Sudan, Somalia and Ethiopia have thrown nearly two million refugees across the map of the Horn, and both the Sudan and Ethiopia have come to rely on huge supplies of world humanitarian aid to help reduce hunger. 
The people of the Sudan, Ethiopia and Somalia have intermingled for centuries, giving them a shared cultural, social and historical legacy. Today, what they share most is the despair of civil war, refugee encampments, economic decline and recurring famine.
 
Absolutist Leaders
Throughout the region, absolutist regimes have been waging fruitless wars that threadbare economies cannot withstand. Perhaps most tragic of all has been the tension between Ethiopia and the Sudan; each has helped a long-running insurgency in the other's territory, and each conflict has produced a flood of refugees with which the two countries must cope.
Until recently, much of the misery was being worsened by East-West competition; the Horn was a hotbed of rivalry between the United States and the Soviet Union, and in 1977, the superpowers even traded client states. Ethiopia became an ally of the Soviets after having had a long allegiance to the United States; Somalia, previously backed by Moscow, was furnished with American weaponry.
But with the end of the war in the Persian Gulf, the Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan and an easing of tensions in the Indian Ocean, superpower competition for bases in the region has decreased.
 
Superpower Retrenchment
The Soviet Union, which United States officials say has spent $11 billion on supplying the Ethiopian armed forces, has lost its enthusiasm for that civil war. Last week, the State Department said Washington had suspended new military aid and some economic assistance to Somalia because of abuses that included killings by the Somali Army of hundreds of unarmed civilians in rebel areas. And in the Sudan, the United States has urged its ally, the Government in Khartoum, to talk to the rebel southerners, with whom Washington has also been in touch.
While the talks in Atlanta represented a step toward perhaps resolving one conflict, both the Eritrean rebels and the Ethiopian Government said it would be a long and tedious process before a de facto cease-fire now in place could be turned into a firm peace. In Ethiopia, as in the rest of the Horn of Africa, even lasting peace would leave immense problems, particularly the fate of the vast numbers of refugees displaced by war and war-related famine.
 
Civil War
Southern rebels, largely Christian and animist, have fought on and off for 21 years against Muslim Governments in the north. A de facto cease-fire has prevailed since May, but the Sudan's leader, Lieut. Gen. Omar Hassan Ahmed al-Bashir, was quoted recently as saying he was prepared to renew fighting. The war and resulting famine have caused the flight of more than one million southern Sudanese to northern Sudan and the area around Juba. Some 367,000 Sudanese, many of them teen-age boys whose parents were killed, have fled into Ethiopia.
 
Hunger
The United Nations estimates that 250,000 people died of hunger last year in the Sudan, mainly in three southern provinces. Large-scale starvation appears to have been averted this year, in part because fighting has abated and a United Nations relief effort has delivered tens of thousands of tons of food.
 
Flight From Chad
Some 20,000 refugees from the civil war in Chad fled into western Sudan in the late 1970's and 1980's and, in the absence of a permanent settlement there, have not returned home even though the battle fronts are quiet.
 
War on Two Fronts
Eritrean rebels have been fighting for 28 years for independence from Ethiopia. Other rebels in the region of Tigre have been fighting since 1977 for greater autonomy. As the preliminary peace talks in the Eritrean conflict began last Thursday, the Government and the Tigrean rebels renewed fighting. The fighting in Eritrea and attendant starvation have caused an exodus of 625,000 refugees into the Sudan in the last 20 years.
 
Specter of Starvation
Two years of adequate rain have spared Ethiopia from famine on the horrifying scale of 1984-85, but agricultural production continues to decline and the population is increasing, keeping the Ethiopians in jeopardy.
 
Rebellion
Northern rebels seek the ouster of Somalia's leader, Gen. Mohammed Siad Barre. In 1988 they retaliated against his forces for abuses that included executions of suspected rebels; the Somali Army then inflicted heavy civilian casualties and damage on Hargeisa and Burao. Recent fighting has been reported in Mogadishu and Kismayu. The Government has armed Ethiopian refugees who fled in 1977 during a Somali-Ethiopian war. Last week the United Nations said it was suspending supplies to these refugees because they are used as combatants in Somalia's civil war. The Government reports 837,000 Ethiopian refugees in Somalia, but United Nations officials say privately that the number may be half that. The civil war has sent 324,000 refugees to Ethiopia and 30,000 to Djibouti.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 880 words

HEADLINE: Congress Gets Serious On the Capital Gains Tax

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
ONE of President Bush's favorite ideas, to cut the capital gains tax, has been transformed this summer from long shot to near certainty. But what form it will take is not at all certain as Congress sets out to decide how to restore a tax preference that was abolished in the tax overhaul legislation of 1986.
To do this, legislators will have to overcome a lingering reluctance to tamper with the rewritten tax code - in the process undermining the goal of eliminating loopholes - and resist the temptation to reduce a fiendishly complex subject to rhetorical oversimplification grounded in class warfare.
The 1986 legislation was itself a compromise. Along with abolishing the special rate on profits from the sale of stock and other assets - which for 65 years had been lower than the rate on other income - the new law cut overall tax rates, to the current maximum of 33 percent. 
But now the Republicans argue that restoring the capital gains preference would stimulate the economy by encouraging investment and raising revenue. Those who oppose the cut say that it amounts to tax relief for the wealthy, and that in any event it would cause a revenue drain in the long term.
Little is known about the impact of changing the levy on capital gains. The budget, the economy and various groups of taxpayers would all be affected in largely unpredictable ways, various analysts say.
One reason is that taxpayers can exercise a large degree of control over when, if ever, they pay a capital gains tax. The sale of assets that have risen in value can in most cases be accelerated or postponed at will, and tax liability can be avoided entirely if the assets are passed along at death to the next generation.
Another reason for uncertainty is the volume of potential sales. At the end of 1987, Americans held an estimated $4 trillion of unrealized capital gains, about half in stocks and bonds and half in real estate. Securities values have since risen an additional $750 billion.
 
On Verge of Victory
Nonetheless, President Bush, whose campaign pitch for capital gains reduction seemed so unrealistic at the time, is on the verge of a victory that the Administration asserts will provide broad economic gains.
''It's likely to lead to increased entrepreneurial activity, investment, risk-taking and long-range economic growth,'' Michael J. Boskin, the President's chief economic adviser, said last week. He sees these putative benefits as ''swamping'' any loss of revenue or other possible disadvantages.
The political breakthrough came in late July, when six of the 23 Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee joined the 13 Republicans to form a majority favoring a rate cut. This forced the chairman, Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, to devise his own relief plan.
Most Democrats still say capital-gains reduction is ''effectively a tax break for the wealthy paid for by the middle class,'' as the Senate Majority Leader, George J. Mitchell, put it last week.
Republicans say everybody benefits from a strengthened economy and insist that taxation of the rich and taxation of a certain form of income are different issues.
It has become clear, in fact, that many ordinary people do have sizable, though perhaps occasional, capital gains. This may help account for the liberal Democrats' inability to bury the idea.
Yet Republicans cannot offer much proof that a rate cut is good policy. It is generally agreed that a straightforward tax-rate cut will raise money for the treasury in the first year or two as people rush to take profits, but nobody can predict what it would do to revenue over the longer term, as the stock market, inflation and other factors would affect decisions about cashing in gains.
There is also little evidence - as opposed to textbook faith - that a cut in the capital gains rate would invigorate the overall economy. Some economists do not accept the assumption that the country needs more risk-taking entrepreneurs, most of whom, after all, wind up failing and wasting resources.
Moreover, capital gains already enjoy preferential status not only because taxes are avoided in the case of inheritance but because for each year the gains are deferred, investors avoid taxes that would have to be paid if they were receiving the interest instead. Thus, the conservative economist Herbert Stein contends, policies that tend to favor long-held assets are exactly backward.
In addition to sliding scales based on the holding period, the score of capital gains plans now before Congress include such possibilities as helping small businesses or other groups, aiming for maximum short-term revenue by making the rate cut temporary, and indexing so gains due to inflation would not be taxed.
The winning combination remains anybody's guess, but the betting in Washington is that the idea of making the rate cut temporary - however clever a budgetary gimmick it may be -will fail while some kind of adjustment for inflation will succeed.
Indexation is the main feature of Representative Rostenkowski's proposal, but this will likely not be enough for his six breakaway Democrats, five of them from the entrepreneurial Sun Belt, or for a White House that sees the center of gravity on the capital gains issue finally moving its way.

HEADLINE: While History Is Conflict, the End Is Not Yet

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your excerpt from ''The End of History?'' by Francis Fukuyama in The National Interest for summer 1989, with its prediction of a coming ''end of history'' and of the ''sad time'' to follow (Week in Review, Aug. 27), is reminiscent of the worries that once led John Stuart Mill to the emotional brink. As recounted in his autobiography, he asked himself: '' 'Suppose that all your objects in life were realized; that all the changes in institutions and opinions which you are looking forward to, could be completely effected at this very instant: would this be a great joy and happiness to you?' And an irrepressible self-consciousness distinctly answered, 'No!' At this my heart sank within me: the whole foundation on which my life was constructed fell down.''
Mill found his way out in considerable measure through appreciation of poetry and a new ''theory of life''; happiness, still a goal, ''was only to be obtained by not making it the direct end.'' He continued: ''Those only are happy . . . who have their minds fixed on some object other than their own happiness; on the happiness of others, on the improvement of mankind, even on some art or pursuit followed . . . Ask yourself whether you are happy, and you cease to be so.'' 
Yet no more than all Mill's desired ''changes in institutions and opinions'' (perhaps notably woman suffrage) were ever attained in Victorian England, does there seem to be any end in sight in the United States to the conflict we are told is the true stuff of history. Ironically, the focus for the coming victory of the West in Mr. Fukuyama's analysis seems to be an implicit opposition between ''Western liberalism'' and a presumably non-Western Communism or socialism.
Let us not forget that Marxism is also a product of the West (the Soviet Union notwithstanding). Marx himself was a German: not from the outer reaches of East Prussia, but from that outpost of the Roman Empire, Trier. Much of Western liberalism's longevity and strength, especially in Europe, is due to its relationship with socialist-Marxist movements, producing such syntheses as the welfare state and social democracy.
It is an American aberration that we remain outside this synthesis to the extent that we do, even as the inequalities in our society grow. If history is conflict, the United States, with its racial and economic divisions (as well as the sexism that is by no means unique to this country), should provide plenty of grist for historians' mills for some time to come.
 
AMY HACKETT
 Brooklyn, Aug. 28, 1989

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
The Phony War

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
A President who was serious in declaring a new war on drugs would do at least these things:
* Make a commitment to provide treatment for addicts who want to give up the habit - millions of whom cannot now get into treatment programs.
* Propose plans, and money, to reduce demand by getting at the causes of Americans' lust for drugs.
* Recognize candidly that expensive efforts to stop the flow of drugs into this country have been worthless, and that interdiction can never be very successful.
* Make no promises without committing the funds to pay for them. 
Those are the tests applied by drug experts right across this country, the men and women fighting the menace on the ground. They know the kind of commitment needed to deal with it.
President Bush met none of those tests last week. The ''strategy'' he announced for the war on drugs was virtually empty of new money, realism or candor. What it was long on was politics.
The President put overwhelming emphasis on interdiction and law enforcement, which have been the main U.S. answers to the drug problem over the last decade. In that time supplies of cocaine entering the country have increased so much that the street price has fallen from $60,000 a kilogram to $10,000.
Every decent person wants to see the drug lords broken; everyone applauds the courage of the Colombian Government in fighting the Medellin cartel. But no one who has dealt with the problem really believes that supplies can be cut off. Cocaine is too easy to produce and to transport. New suppliers will arise in new places before long.
Moreover, all-out military action of the kind Mr. Bush has hinted at to stop coca production in South America would risk bringing the coca-growing peasants into revolutionary movements like Peru's Shining Path. William Bennett's draft of the drug plan recognized that eradication of coca crops could sometimes ''be self-defeating, driving farmers into the ranks of anti-Government insurgency.'' But that passage was deleted.
Law-abiding Americans are angry at drug dealers and users. They naturally like politicians who talk about ruthless war on drug barons, about more prisons and tough law enforcement. That is what President Bush did.
At the American Legion convention the President said some who criticized his drug program as insufficient were ''the very people who oppose the death penalty. It's that kind of thinking that's lost too many battles already. So let's not let these critics lose the war.''
The trouble is that the military rhetoric does not actually solve the American drug problem. The words in the White House have just about nothing to do with the reality on the ground. That was made powerfully clear by a New York Times reporter, John Kifner, who visited the South Bronx after the President's speech last week and reported what he saw and heard.
Crack and heroin were on sale almost openly. The police saw what was happening but felt from experience that arresting even significant numbers would have no effect. ''There's so much money in drugs,'' a detective said.
One of the drug men told Mr. Kifner: ''Hey, there's no work. You go looking for a job, they want to pay you $3.50 an hour. New York's expensive, man. You can't live on the breeze. That's why we're selling drugs.'' The conservatives who have been in power under Ronald Reagan and George Bush preach a good deal about the power of economic motivation. But somehow they do not see it when it comes to drugs. They do not recognize that social and economic measures to reduce the appeal of drugs may work better than a ''war.'' Or perhaps they are afraid to say so. The Economist of London, which knows the United States better than any other foreign journal, is not afraid. In its issue of Sept. 2 it analyzed at length America's ''national curse of drugs and drug-financed crime.'' It concluded that the attempt to prohibit drugs should be replaced by a regime of regulation and taxation.
Cheap gin ravaged Britain in the 18th century, the magazine noted. The answer was not to prohibit it but to control the sale and tax it to raise the price. America tried prohibition, and it was a disaster.
''Repression, however vigorous, cannot win the war against drugs,'' The Economist said. ''Legalizing the trade would be risky. Prohibition is worse than risky.''
That kind of talk is too dangerous for American politicians now. But at least they could stop talking cynically about winning a war on drugs.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 34, Column 3; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 1200 words

HEADLINE: ON LANGUAGE;
Diplomatese

BYLINE: By ALVARO DE SOTO; Alvaro de Soto, a Peruvian career diplomat, is executive assistant to Javier Perez de Cuellar, Secretary General of the United Nations. William Safire is on vacation.

 BODY:
DIPLOMATS, LIKE all practitioners of a specialized craft, have their own parlance, and in diplomacy, as elsewhere, things are not always what they seem.
The Secretary General's good offices is not a reference to the physical trappings of the United Nations chief's working quarters. (In fact, his office on the 38th floor of the Secretariat building is rather spartan, with a drab view of the East River and Long Island City.) A person entrusted with good offices, or a good officer, is a channel of communication between parties to a dispute who are not on speaking terms.
It is a catchall term, the functions of a good officer ranging from passing messages from one party to another to brokering a ceasefire to negotiating a comprehensive peace agreement. As a rule, the officer does not make proposals to the parties in the formal sense, and operates largely out of the limelight. 
Good offices involve meetings with high-level interlocutors, usually foreign ministers. They are often held, wholly or in part, tete-a-tete- literally, in the language of Talleyrand, head-to-head or, according to current usage in the United States, one-on-one. At the United Nations, tete-a-tete means just that: no one present but the principals. We are, however, increasingly faced with the baffling question: ''Who will join the S.G. as note-taker during the tete-a-tete meeting?''
As a professional diplomat, the S.G. (as the Secretary General is frequently referred to) is perfectly capable of jotting down or dictating an accurate note to the file, known to my American colleagues as a memcon (memorandum of conversation). So a note-taker is not a must for him. Besides, total recall is practically a requirement for effective good officers. However, a note-taker at meetings can be helpful to the principals, and sometimes an interpreter is a note-taker in disguise.
But does a tete-a-tete remain one when note-takers are present? I won't quibble on this point; after all, according to the Oxford English Dictionary, in 16th-century France, tete-a-tete didn't even have a friendly connotation - it referred to single combat. For meetings solely between the principals, I offer this suggestion, also from the French, a quatre yeux, which translates roughly as ''four eyes only.''
In a set-piece meeting, on the other hand, the principals will be accompanied by aides, who are referred to in the S.G.'s office as insiders. An insider is not necessarily ''someone in the know.'' The word insiders, as we use it, refers to people actually inside the room where a meeting is held. Hence, insiders may know far less than outsiders in the know.
At the United Nations, diplomats and their assistants increasingly use a tool borrowed from the world of multilateral diplomacy: the nonpaper. This is an exploratory paper whose author wishes to remain anonymous or at least retain deniability until the chances of success of the proposal outlined within it have been ascertained. Nonpapers are not circulated; they are gingerly floated, falling into the hands of fellow delegates as though by chance, deus ex machina. (''I just happen to have with me a nonpaper which attempts to reflect the idea which Your Excellency has so aptly expressed.'') Without interviewing the many batches of United Nations professionals who have served since the organization was established in 1945 - a daunting, if not hopeless, task - I venture an educated guess as to the word's origins. Having sat in on countless tete-a-tetes and other meetings at the United Nations for more than 20 years, I would say that the expression was most probably coined by a United States diplomat. My no-nonsense American colleagues seem partial to an economy of expression.
Confronted with an unpalatable formal proposal, not preceded by a nonpaper, a diplomat can reject it in a number of ways. He can address the issues raised. He can ignore it. Or he can give it fin de non recevoir - that is, deem it as having not been received.
When an agreement between parties to a conflict has been reached, however, the binding terms need to be recorded. Lest lightning strike one of the negotiators and the understandings go up in smoke, ultimately all aspects of a deal should be committed to some form of record, at least a final act, perhaps an exchange of notes, ideally a sacrosanct treaty.
True diplomats set great store by the written word. Those with classical training quote the Latin verba volant, scripta manent - ''words fly away, writing stays.'' Talleyrand, a stickler for thoroughness, is said to have been told by an exasperated aide about a fine point that the prince insisted on having reflected in a text: ''Mais Sire, cela va sans dire'' (''But Sire, it goes without saying''). To this, the prince replied: ''Cela va encore mieux en le disant'' (''It is even better to say it'').
In addition to impartiality and honesty, people engaged in good offices must have the gift of good timing and a flawless sense of balance, if they are to avoid diving into an empty pool. In the S.G.'s office, we have, since the early 1980's, been consigning certain situations to the empty pool category - shorthand for cases in which it would not be advisable, or might be counterproductive, to attempt to assist in resolving a given dispute or conflict.
Again, it is difficult to pinpoint first usage, let alone the uncontested author, but the expression made its first appearance in print in 1983. The occasion was the bicentennial of the Treaty of Paris, when Sir Brian Urquhart, the United Nations' peacekeeper extraordinaire, gave an address at the Smithsonian Institution.
In a list of ''some don'ts for workers for peace,'' he cited this: ''Don't dive into an empty pool. This may create a temporary sensation, but it will leave you stunned and incapable of further action. It is equally inadvisable to dive into a pool of boiling water.''
If it has been determined that there is sufficient water in the pool, and that its temperature is acceptable, shuttle diplomacy may at some point be warranted. The S.G. does a fair share of traveling. By White House or Fortune 500 standards, his journeys - often hastily arranged -are made on a shoestring budget. So I find it particularly apt that members of his entourage are referred to, regardless of rank, as straphangers.
In 1984, in Timbuktu, I first happened on the word straphanger, as applied to a member of the S.G.'s party. It was used by the personnel responsible for getting the principal and everyone in his party from point A to point B safely, at the appointed hour and with their baggage.
When I first overheard the term, I thought I detected a touch of sarcasm. As a straphanger in the S.G.'s party, I felt more curious than insulted, however. The word is obviously borrowed from the world of mass transportation. The Concise Oxford Dictionary of Current English defines a straphanger as ''a bus or train passenger who has to stand and hold strap for lack of sitting space.''
Straphanger is far preferable to hangers-on, and in its allusion to the New York subway can be said to be part of the United Nations' homespun tribute to the city that hosts it in its inimitable way.

LENGTH: 1843 words

HEADLINE: FOOD;
FREE-TRADE CUISINE

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER and PIERRE FRANEY

 BODY:
A RESTAURANT WRITER'S LIFE HAS BECOME exasperatingly complicated in recent years, what with all the cross-pollination of cuisines and internationalization of kitchen staffs. Dining out used to be fairly straightforward: you went to a French restaurant and ate French food; Italian restaurants served Italian food, and the Japanese respected their gastronomic borders, as did the Spanish, Mexicans and Greeks. American food was a little trickier, melting pot that we are, but our cooking was still regionally identifiable.
A recent call to a Manhattan restaurant that was about to open inquired what kind of food would be served. ''We're sort of an American-bistro-style trattoria,'' the manager explained, which is like describing a puppy as a cocker-spaniel-poodle-Great Dane. He went on to say that the chef was American and that the menu included everything from sandwiches, hamburgers and stews to bistro fare (terrines, cassoulet, choucroute), pastas and pizzas. 
How does one categorize such a gastronomic mongrel? Years ago, restaurants that had multiple passports were dubbed continental, a term that seems dated today, reminiscent of overupholstered hotel dining rooms that served boiled potatoes and creamed spinach with every entree. Some restaurant guides resort to descriptions like nouvelle, international and eclectic - none of which conveys much useful information. But, then, how does one characterize a restaurant like Huberts, in New York, where the appetizer list might include soft-shell crabs marinated in ponzu (a Japanese citrus vinegar), grilled shrimp in a spicy Cajun sauce and rabbit sausage with Mexican mole sauce?
Or how about Jane's Bar and Grill, on East 60th Street in Manhattan. There, the chef, Daniel Baylis (who has worked at two other ''eclectic'' spots, Aurora and the Odeon) serves traditional French fare (duck sausage and lentils) next to such cosmopolitan creations as lobster-filled cannelloni seasoned with coriander and presented over fresh tomato sauce and fava beans.
The liberal borrowing from different national pantries is often traced to so-called California cuisine (another label that has grown a layer of mold), though in fact it began in a big way with French nouvelle cuisine in the early 1970's. Leading chefs like Paul Bocuse and Michel Guerard traveled extensively and were influenced by what they saw, particularly in the Orient. A later generation of American chefs has done the same. Len Allison of Huberts and Barry Wine of the Quilted Giraffe are typical. Both started with essentially French cuisine, yet they later became enamored of Japanese food and esthetics, and as a result nudged their menus toward the East.
And it works both ways. Restaurants with Japanese and Chinese chefs, such as Sino and Duane Park Cafe in New York and Chinois on Main in Santa Monica, Calif., turn out food that is Western-influenced.
Manhattan's Union Square Cafe, which has turned a chronic identity crisis between France and Italy into a culinary triumph, arises from the same circumstances: Danny Meyer, the owner, studied and worked in France and Italy before opening his restaurant. Both of his chefs, first Ali Barker (currently at the supertrendy 150 Wooster Street) and now Michael Romano, came from classical French backgrounds. Yet more than half the menu at Union Square Cafe is Italian or Italian-French.
The internationalization of cuisine is also encouraged by the ready availability of ingredients from around the world in specialty shops and, increasingly, supermarkets. Morels, shiitake mushrooms, sun-dried tomatoes, fresh game, arborio rice, goat cheese, filo dough, couscous - all are easy to find in major cities. ''It's incredible,'' says Ludger Szmania, the German-born executive chef at the Four Seasons Olympic Hotel, in Seattle. ''Out here we can get everything year-round. You get spoiled.''
Some traditionalists, particularly overseas, have been heard grumbling that, ultimately, cuisine without national borders could have the same deleterious effect as the impending unification of the European Economic Community: one big homogenized stew. While that is unlikely -national tastes and pride are not so fickle - it is true that cooking has entered a daring and potentially exciting new era of experimentation. Like most cooking revolutions, it is pioneered by restaurant chefs before trickling down to the home cook.
We have had the opportunity to sample some of the best cross-cultural (sounds anthropological, doesn't it?) cooking around the country in the past year. The common denominator for success is universal: harmony of ingredients, attention to texture and visual enticement. We have come up with a few of our own recipes, which, to our taste, meet these criteria. One is a ravioli dish that is made with Chinese won-ton skins, which are available in Oriental groceries. These are much lighter and uniform that most home cooks can produce at home, and they are simple to use. They can be filled with all sorts of ingredients - shrimp, pork, seafood mousses - and served with all kinds of sauces - in a light shellfish broth, a beurre blanc, fresh tomato sauce, pesto.
Veal shank, which the Italians customarily make with carrots, celery, onions and tomato, can be given a colorful, light twist by cooking it with Oriental vegetables: Chinese cabbage, snow peas, sprouts, coriander. And for a bright summer dish, we have devised a poached skate with pesto sauce over orzo, the Greek pasta shaped like rice.
And what shall we call these dishes? We'll settle for tasty.
 
SHRIMP AND GINGER RAVIOLI WITH BEURRE BLANC
 
1 1/4 pounds medium-sized shrimp
Salt and freshly ground white pepper to taste
 1/4 cup finely chopped water chestnuts
2 tablespoons grated fresh ginger
2 tablespoons olive oil
2 tablespoons chopped fresh coriander
 1/4 teaspoon hot red-pepper flakes
2 tablespoons light soy sauce
 About 60 Chinese won-ton wrappers (include extras in case some break)
1 large egg, beaten
1 quart shrimp broth (see recipe)
 Beurre blanc (see recipe).
1. Peel and devein the shrimp. Reserve the shells for shrimp broth.
2. Chop the shrimp into small cubes. In a mixing bowl, combine the shrimp, salt and pepper, water chestnuts, ginger, olive oil, coriander, pepper flakes and soy sauce. Blend well and let sit for about 10 minutes.
3. Lay one won-ton wrapper on a lightly floured dry surface. Brush it with some of the beaten egg. Place three-quarters of a teaspoon of the shrimp mixture on the center of the won ton. Top the won ton with another skin, pressing the edges firmly around the perimeter to seal thoroughly. Trim the won-ton skin edges with a cookie cutter to remove excess dough. Repeat the procedure with the rest of the ingredients. Cover the finished uncooked ravioli with a moistened towel to keep them from drying out.
4. Poach the ravioli, five or six at a time, in simmering shrimp broth for about one minute or until they rise to the surface. Drain and place four to six ravioli on warm serving plates. Drizzle some beurre blanc over and serve immediately.
Yield: About 24 ravioli.
 
SHRIMP BROTH
 
Shells from raw shrimp
5 cups water
6 black peppercorns
 1/4 cup coarsely chopped onions
2 ribs celery coarsely chopped
1 bay leaf.
Put all the ingredients in a saucepan and bring to a boil. Simmer for 20 minutes and strain.
Yield: About four cups.
 
BEURRE BLANC
 
4 tablespoons finely chopped shallots
1 cup dry white wine
2 tablespoons white-wine vinegar
2 tablespoons heavy cream
8 tablespoons cold, unsalted butter cut into pats
1 tablespoon finely chopped fresh tarragon, or any fresh herb of choice
 Salt and freshly ground white pepper to taste.
1. Put the shallots, wine and vinegar into a small, heavy saucepan. Cook over medium heat until the mixture is reduced to four tablespoons.
2. Add the cream. When it reaches a boil, reduce the heat to low and whisk in the butter one pat at a time. Add the tarragon, season with salt and pepper, and keep warm.
Yield: One cup.
 
POACHED SKATE WITH PESTO SAUCE
 
4 boneless, skinless skate wings, about 1 1/2 pounds
4 tablespoons white-wine vinegar
4 sprigs fresh thyme, or 1 teaspoon dried
1 large bay leaf
4 sprigs fresh parsley
 Salt to taste
8 whole peppercorns
 Orzo with fresh tomato (see recipe)
 Pesto sauce (see recipe).
1. Arrange the skate wings in a skillet large enough to hold all the fish in one layer. Cover with water and add the vinegar, thyme, bay leaf, parsley, salt and peppercorns. Bring to a gentle rolling boil and turn off the heat. Let sit for four to five minutes.
2. Drain the fish and transfer them to warm serving plates on top of the orzo. Drizzle some pesto sauce over all and serve immediately.
Yield: Four servings.
 
PESTO SAUCE
 
2 cups fresh basil
 1/2 cup olive oil
3 tablespoons pine nuts
3 medium-sized garlic cloves, peeled
 Salt and freshly ground pepper to taste
 1/2 cup grated Parmesan.
Remove all tough stems from the basil. Place the basil in the container of a food processor or blender. Add the oil, pine nuts, garlic, salt and pepper. Blend to a fine texture. Add the Parmesan and blend quickly. If you make it in advance, serve at room temperature.
Yield: About one cup.
 
ORZO WITH FRESH TOMATO
 
4 cups water
 Salt to taste
3 cups fresh orzo
2 tablespoons olive oil
4 tablespoons finely chopped onions
 3/4 pound ripe fresh tomatoes, peeled and cut into 1/2-inch cubes
 Freshly ground pepper to taste
 1/4 teaspoon hot red-pepper flakes.
1. Bring the water to a boil in a saucepan. Add salt. Cook the orzo for about 10 minutes, or until tender. Drain.
2. Meanwhile, heat the oil in a saucepan. Cook the onions until they are wilted. Add the tomatoes, sprinkle with salt and pepper and the pepper flakes. Stir gently and bring the pan juices to a boil.
3. Add the orzo and stir gently to blend.
Yield: Four servings.
 
VEAL SHANKS WITH ORIENTAL VEGETABLES
 
1 veal shank, about 3 pounds
4 cloves garlic, cut lengthwise into 3 strips
 Freshly ground pepper to taste
4 cups fresh or canned chicken broth
2 cups water
 1/4 cup dark soy sauce
2 whole cloves
1 teaspoon anise seed
1 cup dry white wine
1 1/2 cups scallions cut into 1-inch lengths
5 cups coarsely chopped kale
 1/2 head Chinese cabbage, coarsely chopped (about 5 cups)
12 baby carrots, peeled
 1/2 cup chopped fresh coriander
 1/2 pound snow peas
1 1/2 cups bean sprouts.
1. Make small incisions around the veal shank and insert the strips of garlic. Rub the shank with pepper.
2. In a large kettle, combine the veal shank, broth, water, soy sauce, cloves, anise seed and wine. Bring to a boil, cover and simmer for one hour and 15 minutes, or until tender. Add the scallions, kale, Chinese cabbage and carrots. Cook for 15 minutes. Add the coriander, snow peas and bean sprouts. Cook for five minutes. Taste for seasonings and serve.
Yield: Six servings.
