The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 10, 1989

SECTION: Section 6; Page 58, Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 3330 words

HEADLINE: A KILLING IN MAINE

BYLINE: By James Howard Kunstler; James Howard Kunstler is a novelist who writes about environmental issues.

 BODY:
LAST YEAR, OUTSIDE Bangor, Me., on a November afternoon that could not have been more beautiful, Karen Ann Wood was shot in her own backyard by Donald Rogerson, a deer hunter. The 37-year-old mother of twin baby girls died minutes later. The incident aroused a furor in a state where the traditions of the great outdoors are more and more at odds with the realities of suburban sprawl. It grew even more bitter when a Bangor grand jury refused to indict the hunter, a homegrown son of Maine, on manslaughter charges, fueling an ''us-versus-them'' quarrel between natives and newer arrivals from ''away,'' as the rest of the world is called. Karen Ann Wood was from away. Wood and her husband, Kevin, had come to the Bangor area with their infant twin girls in July 1988 from Davenport, Iowa, where he had been in graduate school. The Woods had both grown up in the small, upstate city of Binghamton, N.Y., met in high school and married a few years later. They had postponed having children until Kevin Wood was settled in his profession as a child psychologist. The move to Maine also represented the fulfillment of a long-postponed desire: to resettle in the East. 
A month after they arrived in Maine, the Woods moved into a new house, a slate-blue Cape Cod home, the last dwelling near the dead end of a one-street subdivision called Treadwell Acres in the town of Hermon, a few miles west of the Bangor city line. What had been forest and puckerbrush only 10 years before - prime deer-hunting territory - had lately burgeoned into a mixed suburb of industrial parks and new homes. The new house, the new children - a new life in Maine was the Woods' reward for the years of struggle in Iowa.
DON ROGERSON, 45, IS THE PRODUCE manager of a neighborhood supermarket in Bangor, a Boy Scout leader and a lifelong hunter. Neither he nor his hunting companion that day, Peter Anderson, a Bangor lawyer, would comment for this article, but in the days after the shooting Rogerson gave an account of the incident to local reporters.
At about 2:45 that Tuesday afternoon, the two hunters parked Rogerson's pickup in a dusty turnaround at the dead end of Treadwell Acres Drive, 200 yards or so past the Woods' house. There is no way they could have failed to notice that they were close to a residential neighborhood when they entered their hunting ground. The weather was perfectly clear, the temperature about 50 degrees.
One of the Woods' neighbors across the street, Cheryl Hamlin, 40, had gone out shopping in the morning and returned home at noon, well before Rogerson and Anderson arrived on the scene. She recalled hearing no gunshots that afternoon until the two that killed Karen Wood.
Treadwell Acres is about five miles from Bangor International Airport. Jet airliners often fly directly over the development at very low altitude, under 1,500 feet. If airplanes were flying low overhead - as they very often did - when Karen Wood stepped out of her house, then she might not have heard the hunters. And they might not have heard her. The absence of other gunshots and the constant airplane noise suggests that she went out there because she saw the hunters near her property. On her way out, she grabbed her dark blue coat and white mittens.
Despite the veil of official secrecy drawn over the case, a few crucial facts slipped out in the days directly after the shooting, when Kevin Wood's backyard was full of wardens searching for bullet fragments, footprints and other clues. Wood fell into casual conversation with the searchers, so it is possible to reconstruct the critical moments when the bullets were fired.
Behind the Wood house is a thin scrim of saplings. Behind these are two connected clearings, just beyond the Woods' property line, 135 feet from the house. Between the two clearings stood two saplings. One was cut down after the incident and taken into the lab because it contained one of Don Rogerson's two discharged bullets. On the basis of it, and of fragments from the second bullet, the investigators placed Karen Wood 130 feet from the house when she was struck down, five feet inside her own property line.
What prompted her to go out there? She'd left her year-old twins inside the house, which suggests that she had meant to stay outside a very short time. Possibly, she went outside to warn hunters that they were too close to her house. But how did she know they were back there? Most likely, she saw the hunters or had seen their truck.
The wardens placed Don Rogerson 189 feet from Karen Wood when he shot her. Thus, Rogerson was 319 feet from the Woods' house. Under Maine law, a hunter can discharge a firearm no closer to a house than 300 feet.
The sun, at that hour (3:30 P.M.) of the cloudless day at that time of year (Nov. 15), would have been behind him, slightly to his left, and low on the horizon (it was an hour until sunset). The trees had shed their leaves by this date, and in that low, clear light, the Woods' next-door-neighbor's house, which was white, must have blazed like a torch.
Rogerson's rifle was a .30-06 mounted with a 4X power Weaver scope. Rogerson told The Bangor Daily News that he had had a deer in his scope when he fired two shots in succession. Since he did not have a doe permit, Rogerson was obliged to correctly identify his target not only as a deer, but as a deer with antlers: a buck. One of the wardens told Kevin Wood that there was not one bit of evidence indicating that a deer had been in the area around the house, let alone in the line of fire. No deer body, no blood, no hair, no droppings and no tracks.
Rogerson told The Bangor Daily News, ''I can honestly say that I do not now recollect anything after the first shot, after I fired at the deer, at the same instant the two white flags appeared.''
These would be Karen Wood's white mittens. Does this mean he fired his second shot at the white flags? The white-tailed deer is called that because the underside of its tail is white. Would he have fired at a deer's rump? This is considered bad hunting practice, because it does not insure a clean, quick kill and it also rips the best meat to shreds. After the second shot, Rogerson hurried across the clearing where he discovered Karen Wood crumpled on the ground.
He said he then lost his motor functions and soiled his pants. He bent down to Karen Wood. At first, he was relieved to see only a little spot of blood on her shoulder. But then he discovered the wound in her upper right chest. Karen Wood was still breathing, but with difficulty. Rogerson put some kind of ''compress'' on her wound and screamed for an ambulance, no doubt in a state of panic. He picked her up, then put her down a few steps later. Meanwhile, his hunting partner, Peter Anderson, ran to Cheryl Hamlin's house for help.
Around 3:30 P.M., Cheryl Hamlin had heard the two shots followed by shouts for help. Thinking that a hunter had been hurt, she had called the Penobscot County sheriff's office in Bangor. Shortly afterward, Anderson came to her door. Then another hunter who had also been in the area emerged from the woods and said that ''a young girl'' had been shot and that it was ''very bad.'' Hamlin called the sheriff's department a second time. The sheriff's cars and the ambulance arrived about 12 minutes later.
At the time, Kevin Wood, 36, was at the Eastern Maine Medical Center in Bangor, the new man on the pediatric psychology staff. That day, in addition to his regular duties, he was on call for the emergency room. He had just interviewed a suicidal teen-age girl when the Bangor police called with a garbled, bewildering message: ''Dr. Wood, your son has been in a hunting accident.''
The police were vague about details, and while Wood insisted he did not have a son, they persuaded him to go home at once anyway, offering a police escort, which he declined. The drive took Wood 20 minutes.
''The whole way out,'' he told me, ''I was thinking, Did someone shoot my dog? Did a shot go through the babies' upstairs bedroom and splinter glass and hurt them or something?''
Wood painfully recalled the day. As he approached Treadwell Acres Drive, a news report came over the car radio saying that a hunter had been shot and killed in Hermon. How terrible! he remembered thinking. There were so many vehicles on the street - sheriff's cars, television vans, an ambulance - Wood had to park in front of a neighbor's house.
''It was a big circus,'' he said. ''I was halfway up my driveway and two big officers asked me who I was. They walked me into the garage and told me that Karen had been killed. My first reaction - I'll never forget it - was that this was some kind of cruel joke. Then, as I walked into the house, the reality of what I was seeing hit me. It was the worst nightmare you can imagine.''
The hunter, Rogerson, remained at the scene. Distraught, he admitted pulling the trigger. He was taken in handcuffs to the Penobscot County jail in downtown Bangor and booked on a manslaughter charge. There he remained until the following morning, when he was released on $20,000 bail. Karen Wood's body was not removed from the scene until 8:30 P.M., long after darkness fell.
In the days following the incident, much was made of Rogerson's good character in the local newspapers and on television news shows. He was a solid citizen, ''a most wonderful kind of person,'' a neighbor was quoted as saying. He had been named employee of the year at the Doug's Shop 'n' Save supermarket where he was produce manager. As a scoutmaster, he had led boys up Mount Katahdin. What's more, he voiced remorse for his deed. In an editorial, The Bangor Daily News labeled the death of Karen Wood and the arrest of Donald Rogerson ''a double tragedy.'' Few details about Karen Wood emerged, aside from the fact that she was the mother of year-old twins, and that the family was from out of state, and that when she was shot, she had been wearing white mittens, which might have made it easy to mistake her for a white-tailed deer.
ON DEC. 5, THE CASE WAS PRESENTED to a grand jury, which did not indict Rogerson. An out-of-court settlement of Kevin Wood's wrongful-death civil action, amounting to $122,000, was quickly reached. Rogerson's homeowner's insurance company paid his policy limit of $100,000 plus $2,000 in medical benefits. Rogerson himself paid $20,000 out of pocket, even though court records show that his savings account contained only $200, and he owned little besides two 20-year-old snowmobiles and an even more ancient 15-foot power boat. Had a lawsuit gone to trial, Rogerson would have had the option of declaring bankruptcy, Kevin Wood's lawyer told his client, and the whole thing might easily take years to resolve, so Wood was advised to settle quickly.
By an unfortunate coincidence, Kevin Wood had decided to try to return to work on Dec. 5, the same day the grand jury refused to indict Rogerson. The news was ''the final straw for Kevin,'' according to his friend Dr. Tim Rogers, who was also Wood's boss at the Eastern Maine Medical Center. Before the end of the month, Kevin Wood put his house in Hermon on the market, packed up and temporarily moved to Binghamton, his hometown, where he had buried Karen.
The death of Karen Wood proved to have a strange persistence in the public imagination. For one thing, it had stirred up a lot of debate about hunting, in particular the question of the sport's place in a region where a lot of new homes were being built on traditional hunting grounds. Hunting in Maine is fondly described by outdoor enthusiasts as ''a tradition older than voting.'' In 1988, 227,751 licenses were issued in a state whose population is a shade over one million. The income from hunting generates more than $150 million a year for the Maine economy.
''The bullet that killed Karen Wood killed any rational debate about hunting safety,'' said one Bangor newspaperman who asked not to be identified. ''The thing that shocked me was this spontaneous effort to air every justification, every mitigation of the tragedy, and every reason why the victim might be to blame.''
The Bangor Daily News's outdoors columnist, Tom Hennessey, wrote that if Karen Wood ''had been wearing one piece of blaze-orange clothing, she'd be alive today.'' Hennessey still defends his position. ''If she'd been killed out in her backyard by a limb falling out of a tree, people would have said, 'Isn't that a terrible thing!' '' he told me, ''But there would have been nowhere near the response because of it being hunting-related.''
''I don't think he was callous and uncaring,'' said V. Paul Reynolds, the paper's managing editor, referring to Hennessey. ''I think he was trying to point out that the woman - even though she might have been on the edge of her woods - put herself at risk by going into the woods dressed the way she was dressed.''
Many letters to the editor echoed Hennessey's theme, along with assertions that out-of-staters ought to learn a thing or two about Maine's traditional way of life, which one correspondent said includes ''not going into the woods in November.'' These, in turn, prompted an uproar among citizens disgusted with the hunting fraternity.
''I'm stunned that there could be so much public equivocation about what happened that afternoon, and I'm especially disturbed by oblique references to Mrs. Wood's 'out-of-stater' roots,'' wrote one unhappy Bangorite. ''As a native old-family Mainer, I am ashamed,'' wrote another.
Months after the shooting, feelings on both sides still ran high.
''One guy goes out and makes a very bad mistake, he shoots a woman who waves white gloves. She made a mistake! He never should have shot at her, and she never should have had on white gloves to wave. And the whole ruckus starts!'' said Gene Letourneau of Waterville, who writes a column seven days a week for Maine's Guy Gannett newspaper chain, which includes The Portland Press Herald and The Kennebec Journal.
Some feel the incident sullies Maine's record of hunter safety, which has been improving. ''Had this death not occurred, there would have been no hunting fatalities in Maine this past season,'' asserted Jon A. Lund, publisher of The Maine Sportsman magazine and a former state Attorney General.
''You're safer in the woods during hunting season than you are on the streets of Portland,'' declared Harry Vanderweide, editor of The Maine Sportsman magazine, on ''MaineWatch,'' a public television show aired less than a week before Karen Wood was shot in her backyard.
THE CITY OF BANGOR (pop. 32,000), once the timber capital of the world, now the financial center for eastern and northern Maine, is still the gateway to the big woods. Its roller-coaster main street drops steeply into a downtown of neatly rehabilitated commercial blocks. On a hilly street above the center of town is Doug's Shop 'n' Save, where, one evening after Karen Wood's shooting, produce manager Don Rogerson was greeting a crowd of sympathetic well-wishers just as Kevin Wood's friend and colleague Tim Rogers came into the store to pick up a few groceries.
''There was a line of people standing there, all patting (Continued on Page 119) him on the back, telling him it was O.K., that it wasn't his fault,'' Rogers recalled. ''I waited on line and shook his hand and said I was a friend of Kevin's, and that I held him totally responsible, and said the thing he should do is admit publicly that it was his fault. He said, no, I couldn't understand it because I wasn't there.''
From the very first, Rogerson had admitted that a bullet from his rifle killed Karen Wood. He said he was deeply sorry, many times. But he maintained all along that it was pure accident, that the moment he squeezed the trigger, he held a deer in his sights.
Under Maine law, manslaughter is defined as the reckless or criminally negligent killing of another human being. It can be the result of either disregarding a known risk, or failing to be aware of a risk.
''Criminal negligence exists whenever the hunter is not absolutely certain what he's shooting at,'' said Jeffrey L. Hjelm, 33, the Assistant Attorney General in charge of the case. ''People are not charged with these crimes because they're bad people, but because they make errors in judgment.''
''Unless you know you're shooting at a deer, then as far as I'm concerned that presents us with a case that we're going to take to the grand jury,'' said Fernand LaRochelle, Deputy Attorney General in charge of the criminal division.
To date, however, all the facts about the Karen Wood case, as established by the state authorities, have remained officially secret. Under Maine's statutes, not only are the grand-jury proceedings sealed, so is every shred of evidence collected in the case. Not even Kevin Wood has ever been officially informed as to the details of his wife's killing. And legally, the files may remain sealed forever. So secret is the grand jury process, that it can only be assumed that the case was even presented to them.
''I can tell you that the case was dismissed on the day that the grand jury sat,'' said prosecutor Hjelm. ''I can tell you that of the cases the grand jury considered that day, there was one case in which they elected not to return an indictment. And I can also tell you that when Mr. Rogerson was first charged in the district court, I expressed publicly my intention to present the case to the next grand jury. But I cannot go the extra step, because of the rule of secrecy, and tell you that I did in fact present it.''
Many people were shocked when Donald Rogerson was not indicted for shooting Karen Wood, not because he was a bad man, but because there was probable cause to believe that he had made a reckless error in judgment.
''I've been around here since '72, and I've never known of a hunter death when there hasn't been an indictment,'' said Wood's attorney, Frederick J. Badger Jr. ''Somewhere, the process broke down in the grand jury.''
Of three hunting deaths dating from the previous season, 1987-1988, in which human beings were mistaken for animals, two of them resulted in convictions and jail terms.
The detail about the white mittens - ''which at a distance could have looked like the white tail of a deer'' - was prominently played up in the very first news account of the shooting. The fact that the wardens found no evidence of deer at the scene was scarcely mentioned in the press.
According to the state prosecutor Jeffrey Hjelm, the case is still open. The statute of limitations extends six years from the date of the incident.
AFTER SPENDING the winter in his hometown of Binghamton, N.Y., Kevin Wood resettled in Iowa, where his wife had received her bachelors' degree in business administration and given birth to the daughters who will always wonder who she was and what happened to her in the faraway state of Maine.
''I've settled out of court,'' Wood told me. ''The investigation is essentially in limbo. They want this thing to go away. At the very least, I want access to the evidence, so I can make it known that my wife was not the least bit responsible for her own death.''
Back in Hermon, a town councilwoman named Peggy Elmer proposed that the community devise some sort of memorial to Karen Wood, perhaps a contribution to the education fund then being set up for the twin girls, Laura and Lindsey. The town council brought up her proposal on a night when Mrs. Elmer was not present, and instead of tabling it for discussion at a time when she could be there, they voted it down.
As the year turned, and another hunting season approached, the office of the Maine Attorney General said that it would seek to suspend the hunting license of Donald Rogerson. The Hermon town council voted to spend $500 on fluorescent orange plastic disks for homeowners to nail on trees around their property so that hunters will know that they are in a place where human beings live.

PUB-DATE: September 10, 1989

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2, Page 45, Column 5; The New Season Magazine

LENGTH: 2324 words

HEADLINE: ART: SEASON PREVIEW;
Demanding exhibitions that capture decisive moments in modern art

BYLINE: By Michael Brenson

 BODY:
THIS SEASON IS distinguished by a kind of museum show that is very welcome at a time when more and more members of the art community know how to generalize and theorize about painting and fewer and fewer know how to look at it.
If you are not willing to enter the worlds of ''Picasso and Braque: Pioneering Cubism'' (opening Sept. 24 at the Museum of Modern Art), ''Monet in the 90's: The Series Paintings''(Feb. 7 at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston) and ''Matisse in Morocco'' (March 18 at the National Gallery of Art in Washington), you will miss artistic feasts that do not come along every year. These shows engage artists for whom painting was the highest calling and pleasure. They present decisive moments not only in their careers but also in the history of modern art.
''Picasso and Braque'' will be the most demanding and polemical. It is the first attempt to establish, point by point, the artistic exchange that gave birth to Cubism. How great will Cubism, which has been so crucial to MOMA's esthetic, seem now? Will new generations of art viewers, raised on alternatives to the Western pictorial tradition, even be able to see what is going on in a Cubist painting? 
The Monet exhibition will bring together for the first time almost 100 paintings of cliffs, cathedrals and the Creuse Valley. By considering the pictorial developments within the works, as well as to whom Monet was responding and why he seemed so obsessed with the idea of the series in the 1890's, the exhibition will clarify the ambition and nationalism of this quintessentially French painter.
The Matisse exhibition is focused after Matisse's Fauve period and before his years of hard analysis and experimentation. In the air and light of Morocco, which had left such a mark on Delacroix, one of his heroes, Matisse found a harmony and ease that he would henceforth be able to integrate with his Cartesian rigor. Even here, in paintings with the floating softness of dream, there is more to the jolting radiance of this great artist than meets the eye.

ART: A SELECTIVE GUIDE
 
September
 
Exploring Rome: Piranesi and His Contemporaries. An exhibition placing the fabulous drawings by Venice-born Giovanni Battista Piranesi in the context of the 18th-century European fascination with Rome. Sept. 12-Nov. 6, Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, 685-0008.
 
Jeff Wall. A Canadian artist whose staged color photopanels using minorities as stars and mixing art history and politics have been a staple of recent international exhibitions. Sept. 12-Oct. 7, Marian Goodman Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, 977-7160.
 
Strange Attractors: Signs of Chaos. An examination of the relationship between contemporary art and the emerging science of chaos, at a time when many followers of the contemporary art scene believe chaos rules. Sept. 14-Nov. 26, New Museum of Contemporary Art.
 
The Blues Aesthetic: Black Culture and Modernism. This traveling exhibition may be the first to explore the effect of the blues aesthetic - and the music of black Americans - on American modernist art. Sept. 14-Dec. 9, Washington Project for the Arts, 400 Seventh Street, N.W., Washington, 202 347-8304.
 
Masterworks of Minq and Qing Painting from the Forbidden City. Eighty paintings from the Palace Museum in Beijing -most of them never before seen outside of China - spanning more than 500 years. Sept. 15-Oct. 29, Metropolitan Museum of Art.
 
Richard Serra. A two-gallery show for one of America's great sculptors. Sept. 15-Oct. 14, Pace Gallery (sculpture), 32 E. 57th Street, 421-3292; Sept. 23-Oct. 14, Leo Castelli Gallery (new drawings), 420 West Broadway, 941-9855.
 
Gardens and Ghettos: The Art of Jewish Life in Italy. A survey of images of and by Italian Jews, from ancient Roman architectural fragments and gold glass to illuminated manuscripts and printed books from the Renaissance to 19th- and 20th- century sculptures and paintings by Amedeo Modigliani and others. Sept. 17-Feb. 1, Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92d Street, 860-1889.
 
Picasso and Braque: Pioneering Cubism. An exhibition piecing together one of the greatest modernist adventures, the formation of Cubism, that may turn out to be the museum adventure of the year. Sept. 24-Jan. 16, Museum of Modern Art.
 
Mario Merz: A Retrospective. The first American retrospective of one of the most important Arte Povera figures, whose ''igloos'' in all shapes, colors and sizes are far better known in Europe than in the United States. Sept. 28-Nov. 26, Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum.
 
Robert Gober. A sculptor who gets lumped in with Neo-Geo painters and the new object-makers, but whose beds, cribs and sinks - inspired by the joys and deceptions of childhood - have a nightmarish warmth very much his own. Sept. 30-Oct. 28, Paula Cooper Gallery, 155 Wooster Street, 674-0766.
 
October
 
Frans Hals. More than 60 paintings and oil sketches by the Dutch painter, whose portraits and genre scenes are both representations of a particular staid 17th-century society and artistic monuments of verve and freshness that continue to belong to the present. Oct. 1-Dec. 31, National Gallery of Art.
 
Velazquez. Nearly half the oeuvre of the 17th-century Spaniard believed by more than a few artists and scholars to be the greatest of all painters. Oct. 3-Jan. 7, Metropolitan Museum of Art.
 
The Paintings of Jakuchu. A rarity among Oriental art exhibitions - a solo show, devoted to the meticulous color paintings and the expressionist ink paintings of the 18th-century artist Ito Jakuchu, the son of a greengrocer who rose to become one the towering figures of Japanese art. Part I, Oct. 5-31; Part II, Nov. 4-Dec. 6, Asia Society.
 
Projects and Portfolios: The 25th National Print Exhibition. A survey of contemporary American printmaking, with work by 50 artists from across the country, including entire portfolios by Francesco Clemente, Donald Judd, Brice Marden and others. Oct. 6-Dec. 31, Brooklyn Museum.
 
Nancy Graves. A show that may answer questions about whether this fanciful, prolific and well-known sculptor is now overproductive and overexposed. Oct. 7-28, Knoedler Gallery, 19 East 70th Street, 794-0550.
 
Frederic Edwin Church. A needed overview of one of the best-loved American landscape painters, who can seem mesmerizing when his works are viewed in small numbers, but limited when many are seen together; all his major paintings will be here. Oct. 8-Jan. 28, National Gallery of Art.
 
Francis Bacon. The virtuosity of this British master - now 80 years old - has rarely been questioned, but doubts about his ability to develop the vision of human deformity that was already starkly defined in his work of the 1940's has left his reputation up for grabs. Oct. 12-Jan. 7, Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, Independence Avenue at Eighth Street, S.W., Washington, 202 357-2700 (at the Museum of Modern Art from May 24-Aug. 28, 1990).
 
Tim Rollins + K.O.S. The complete series of paintings inspired by Kafka's ''Amerika'' by word-and-image artists who have generated considerable debate about the future of socially concerned art. Oct. 13-June 17, Dia Art Foundation, 548 West 22d Street, 431-9232.
 
Three Contemporary French Artists: Catherine Beaugrand, Andre Cadere and Raymond Hains. A typical P.S. 1 show, in that it brings together artists largely unknown in New York, argues for the importance of outsiders and calls attention to a large subject - in this case, French art of the last three decades. Oct. 15-Dec. 10, P.S. 1 Museum, 46-01 21st Street, Long Island City, 718 784-2084.
 
The Intimate World of Alexander Calder. A special show of over 300 diminutive works that focuses on the ability of this bear of a man to invent and design all sorts of whimsical and functional objects, many of them bestowed on family and friends. Oct. 17-March 11, Cooper-Hewitt Museum, 2 East 91st Street, 860-6868.
 
Magdalena Abakanowicz. A Polish artist whose fabric figures - some only shells of bodies, others only heads - have made an impression on sculptors throughout Eastern Europe and the United States. Oct. 20-Nov. 25, Marlborough Gallery, 40 West 57th Street, 541-4900.
 
Ashley Bickerton. One of the most intelligent, obsessive and glibly malicious artists to enter the mainstream in the last three years. Oct. 21-Nov. 11, Sonnabend Gallery, 420 West Broadway, 966-6160.
 
Icons: Ideals and Power in the Art of Africa. A selection of 120 works, spanning 1,000 years, suggesting the long continuum of African history and the many contexts in which emblematic and cult objects can be understood. Oct. 25-Sept. 3, 1990, National Museum of African Art, 950 Independence Avenue, S.W., Washington, 202 357-4600.
 
November
 
Canaletto. This first-ever Canaletto retrospective includes not only Venetian views that have affected the way generations of people have perceived the city, but also the artist's views of England, home of some of his important patrons. Nov. 2-Jan. 21, Metropolitan Museum of Art.
 
Houston Conwill. The Museum of Modern Art's Projects series has invited a sculptor of quiet eloquence who has been known for a while to followers of the sculpture scene. Nov. 3-Jan. 2, Museum of Modern Art.
 
Thomas Hart Benton: An American Original. Organized by the Nelson-Atkins Museum in Kansas City, Mo., this traveling retrospective includes around 85 works by an American regionalist best known for his baroque rhythms, strong opinions on art and influence on Jackson Pollock. Nov. 17-Feb. 11, Whitney Museum of American Art.
 
December
 
Jenny Holzer. The Guggenheim collaborates with probably the most visible American artist during the last three years, whose aphorisms and narratives provoke an awareness of the way in which the mass media has been defining the American self. Dec. 12-Feb. 11, Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum.
 
January
 
Facing History: The Image of the Black in American Art. A brave theme show that will challenge everyone who sees it. Jan. 13-Mar. 26, Corcoran Gallery of Art, 17th Street and New York Avenue, N.W., Washington, 202 638-3211 (at the Brooklyn Museum, April 20-June 25).
 
Contemporary African Artists: Changing Traditions. With more than 75 works by 9 artists, this is one of the first attempts in the United States to consider not only the situation of contemporary art in black Africa but also the appropriate way of presenting it in a foreign context. Jan. 14-May 6, Studio Museum in Harlem.
 
February
 
Monet in the 90's: The Series Paintings. A study of the serial works Monet painted in the 1890's, including the Grainstacks, Poplars and Rouen Cathedral, that will try to answer all the big questions, including why Monet painted in series during these years and how these paintings alter our understanding of Impressionism. Feb. 7-April 29, Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, 465 Huntington Avenue, 617 267-9300.
 
Robert Moskowitz. A retrospective of a lush and economical painter who came in with the ''new image'' artists of the 1970's and who has remained committed both to familiar artistic and architectural imagery and a rigorous analysis of form. Feb. 10-April 24, Museum of Modern Art.
 
March
 
Post-Minimalism: American Sculpture 1965-1975. An exhibition devoted to the crucial years when American sculpture rooted in Minimalism began sprouting limbs in many directions. March 2-May 20, Whitney Museum of American Art.
 
Renaissance Into Baroque: Italian Master Drawings by the Zuccari, 1550-1600. The work of Federico and his older brother, Taddeo, Zuccaro clarifies the shift from the 16th to the 17th century, from Mannerism to Baroque. March 13-April 30, National Academy of Design.
 
Matisse in Morocco. A collaboration among four great museums, the National Gallery of Art, the Museum of Modern Art, the Pushkin Museum and the Hermitage, this concise show will illuminate the effects of Moroccan space and light on an artist searching for a balance between intellect and sensuality, nature and theory. March 18-June 3, National Gallery of Art (at the MOMA, June 21-Sept. 4).
 
April
 
Albert Pinkham Ryder. The most complete show yet of a fierce intimist (1847-1917) whose compact, brooding, almost abstract landscapes hit a note of courageous melancholy in American culture that no painter had hit before. April 6-July 29, National Museum of American Art, Eighth and G Streets, N.W., Washington, 202 357-2700.
 
May
 
The Decade Show. A cross-cultural exhibition, spread over three institutions, that may argue that the struggle against conventional notions of identity has been this decade's most pressing artistic theme. May 10-July 15, New Museum of Contemporary Art; May 12-July 15, Museum of Contemporary Hispanic Art, 584 Broadway, 966-6699; May 20-Aug. 19, Studio Museum in Harlem.
 
The Intimate Interiors of Edouard Vuillard. A sustained look at a master of the impressionistic and the claustrophobic, whose paintings may be particularly welcome now, when there is so much interest in psychoanalysis and art. May 18-July 30, Brooklyn Museum.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 10, 1989

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2, Page 18, Column 1; The New Season Magazine

LENGTH: 2027 words

HEADLINE: Fine-Tuning 'The Piano Lesson'

 BODY:
AUGUST WILSON AND LLOYD RICH-ards have been collaborating as playwright and director since 1982, when Mr. Wilson's ''Ma Rainey's Black Bottom'' was given a staged reading at the National Playwrights Conference at the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn. Mr. Richards, who is artistic director of the O'Neill conference as well as dean of the Yale School of Drama, subsequently staged the play at the Yale Repertory Theater and on Broadway. Mr. Wilson's next two plays, ''Fences'' (1987) and ''Joe Turner's Come and Gone'' (1988) followed even longer tryout routes, which included stops at several regional theaters. Each of Mr. Wilson's three plays won a New York Drama Critics Circle Award; ''Fences'' also won Tony Awards for best play and best director and the 1987 Pulitzer Prize for drama.
Mr. Wilson's latest play, ''The Piano Lesson,'' is now making its way to New York via a similar regional route. As is the case with his earlier plays, ''The Piano Lesson'' deals with a specific decade of black American life. Focusing on the 1930's, it is a story about the Charles family, Southern blacks who have moved to the urban North. At the heart of the play is a 135-year-old, richly carved piano that represents something different to both of its owners: Berniece, who wants to keep the piano as a symbol of her heritage, and her brother, Boy Willie, who wants to sell it to buy a farm in the South. 
''The Piano Lesson'' has already been presented in Boston, Chicago and San Diego and is scheduled to play at the Kennedy Center in Washington as well as in Los Angeles before it arrives in New York this spring. Shortly after its San Diego run, Mr. Wilson and Mr. Richards met with Mel Gussow, a New York Times theater critic, to discuss the creative process that will bring ''The Piano Lesson'' to Broadway. Mr. Wilson began by talking about the first version of the play at the O'Neill Center.
 
WILSON. At the pre-conference, a playwright reads the play aloud to the other playwrights. There are always parts that you don't want to read - and those are generally where the problems are. Other parts you're anxious to read, because you feel that they're good. I was assigned a director -Steve Robman. At that point in the writing of the script, the play opened with the brother already in his sister's house. Steve suggested that I show him coming in - to get more action into the play. I did a complete rewrite.
 
Q. From that you move into a staged reading?
 
WILSON. You see how it plays in front of an audience. I make notes, and I get critiques from other participants in the conference. I study them very carefully and then do another draft. It was at the O'Neill that I actually learned to rewrite a play, and that's the part of the process that I enjoy -the rewriting and problem solving, what Borges calls the problematic practice of literature.
 
Q. You don't realize the problems until you see the play on its feet?
 
WILSON. Then, and later, when you've sat with an audience for 30 performances and you suddenly begin to see something that should have been very obvious from the beginning. At one point, people did not believe that Boy Willie was responsible enough to go back to the South and buy land. Some of the work was to make him a more responsible character - and we've continued to work on the ending. But the same things still happen at the end of the play that happened in the first draft, more or less.
 
Q. Was the through-line of the play clear to you from the beginning?
 
RICHARDS. Most plays define themselves as they go along. The difference in this play is that we started at an earlier stage. When ''Fences'' came to the O'Neill, it was four-and-a-half hours' worth of material, from which you begin to pull out the threads of the fabric. With ''The Piano Lesson'' we really started with a first draft, and the work has been to flesh it out and make sure that every idea that is expressed is a part of the fabric. Berniece's justification for having the piano had to be fleshed out, so that you have two very strong and valid reasons for that piano going one way or the other.
 
Q. There are a number of set pieces in the play - monologues, dreams. Were they in the first draft?
 
WILSON. Yes. Some of them were cut down and a couple were taken out. I have a tendency to write long.
 
Q. I hope none of the good ones were taken out.
 
WILSON. One of my favorite ones was.
 
Q. Did he [Mr. Richards] do it?
 
WILSON. No, no, Lloyd has this way of suggesting things. He said, ''I think you have one too many stories there. See what you can do with that.'' I came back the next day and Lloyd said, ''Did you make any changes?'' I said no, I couldn't find anything to cut. He said, ''I think you need to look at that again.'' I saw I had one monologue, or story, after the other, and I picked the one that I thought that I could live without - and cut it. And then there were times when I would cut something and Lloyd would say, ''You don't mind losing that?'' I'd say no. He'd say, ''Well, I do.'' And we'd go back and cut something else.
 
Q. Do the two of you ever argue?
 
WILSON. No, we never have an argument. I don't even recall a disagreement.
 
Q. Not even about casting or some scenic effect?
 
RICHARDS. August might say, that wall looks too yellow. That's the only thing I can remember him saying.
 
Q. Was the wall too yellow?
 
RICHARDS. It wasn't because of the wall. It was because of the light from the gel. The lighting was not right yet and he was steamed. August was not familiar with the visual aspect of it. He has become a much more knowledgeable technical theater person about sets, costumes, lights and so on.
 
WILSON. I remember the first audition for ''Ma Rainey.'' I was ready to hire anybody who could read. Lloyd said, ''No, I don't think he's right.'' I learned how to pick a good actor, to discern what's there beyond the way they read.
 
Q. As director, you [Mr. Richards] encourage the actors to create more of a life for their characters than they see in the script.
 
RICHARDS. I try to permit the actor to arrive where I want him to arrive, without telling him where I want him to be. You feed them the right things, and keep stimulating them to the point where they make choices. I would rather an actor discover it for himself than me tell him - it's his then.
 
WILSON. When I would want a particular actor to do a certain thing, I would tell Lloyd, and two weeks later the guy would say, ''Lloyd, would it be O.K. if I do this?''
 
Q. Charles Dutton joined the cast after the first production, didn't he? [Mr. Dutton played in ''Ma Rainey'' on Broadway and ''Joe Turner'' at the O'Neill and the Yale Repertory.]
 
RICHARDS. Charles came into the play as Boy Willie in Boston, with one week's rehearsal. Then we moved to Chicago. It wasn't until San Diego that I got a chance to have a full rehearsal with him. We've had a chance to dig into things that he had only been addressing. The last scene is a tough, tough scene, and in San Diego we tended to get the keys to that.
 
Q. At the end of the play, we hear a violent struggle upstairs, but we don't know whether or not Boy Willie is wrestling with a ghost.
 
WILSON. There are ghosts whether we can hear them or see them. What was important to me was Boy Willie's willingness to do battle. He's not running out the door, he's not relying on Jesus, he's not relying on anything outside of himself.
 
Q. What does the piano represent?
 
WILSON. The legacy. The sister has a self-imposed taboo about playing the piano. The brother is willing to embrace it, and at the same time he's also willing to sell it in order to provide himself with a future. It's also important that he's building on what his father left him. Which is what Americans do, except for blacks who very seldom have anything to pass along to their kids. The only thing his father had to give them was the piano, and he died over giving them that. Boy Willie takes this legacy, and wants to use it to provide for himself a better life, even if that means selling the piano in order to get some land. He feels his father would have done that if he had the opportunity.
 
Q. One of the images you had for the play was a Romare Bearden painting of a piano.
 
WILSON. A Bearden painting called ''The Piano Lesson.'' It's of a little girl at the piano with her piano teacher standing over her. And in my mind I saw Maretha [Berniece's daughter] and Berniece.
 
Q. Following ''Joe Turner,'' this is the second play that a Bearden painting has inspired. Are there more to come?
 
WILSON. That's very interesting; I need to look at some more Bearden. I think he's a tremendous artist.
 
Q. Do you generally start with an image like that or with an idea?
 
WILSON. Well, usually it's an idea. With ''The Piano Lesson'' I started with the idea, can one acquire a sense of self-worth by denying one's past, which is what I felt that Berniece was trying to do. I wanted the past to come in the person of her brother, and I wanted him to come to the house like a tornado and force her to confront the thing she was trying to deny. Then it became, what do you do with your legacy and how best do you put it to use?
 
Q. Do you respond to criticism?
 
WILSON. Not only published criticism. I respond to people walking out of the theater, to my brother, my daughter. I listen to all of that. And critics, of course, have an informed point of view. I don't necessarily change the script because a review said this or that. But I take it all very seriously, and I examine why the person said the thing, and then I go back through and try to see how they arrived at that particular statement and then make a decision based on what I feel is necessary.
 
RICHARDS: It's very important for a playwright and a director to learn what to listen to and what not to listen to. I'm interested in the point that the theatergoer loses interest or becomes confused. I sit in the theater with an audience and live through it with them. Attention brings people forward. When they begin to sit back, then you're on your way to losing them.
 
Q. Do you travel with the play?
 
WILSON. I wouldn't miss it. I enjoy watching the show with the audience - I enjoy the audience. Generally, I go to every show for the entire three weeks.
 
RICHARDS. August is there from the very beginning to the very end. He's even there after I've gone.
 
Q. The tryout process is not the same as it was when you brought Lorraine Hansberry's ''Raisin in the Sun'' to Broadway.
 
RICHARDS. There's an important difference. My concept of the American national theater is all of these companies in all of these regions. Artists circulating among them form in their composite the American national theater. But it does have regional aspects, and my hope is that the unique in each region can be transferred to other regions.
I want the nation to experience August's work. At the same time, it gives us an opportunity to continue to work on a play. It used to be when you went to Philadelphia with a show, you lived or you died. That's why you were only booked for a week - you were hoping to be able to sell a week's worth of tickets. Here we go into a theater for three or four weeks. It's a subscription audience, so you can focus on the work without the economic pressures.
 
Q. Where does the play go now?
 
RICHARDS. We have plans to open it at the Kennedy Center and Los Angeles. We're running out of cities! By the time it gets to New York, it will be nationally known.
 
Q. Is there a possibility that the rest of America will see these plays, but not New York?
 
RICHARDS. I think of New York as a major region in America, and I would not want to even consider denying that region the work.
 
Q. But we will have to wait until spring.
 
RICHARDS. You can come out to see it in one of its other guises. It'll be a little different from the play that comes into New York. We haven't finished yet.

PUB-DATE: September 10, 1989

SECTION: Section 8; Page 10, Column 2; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 1309 words

HEADLINE: VIEWS OF SPORT;
Football's Muzzled Masses Unleash a Call of the Wild

BYLINE: By W. C. HEINZ; W. C. Heinz was the sports columnist of The New York Sun and since then has been the author of numerous magazine articles and six books.

 BODY:
Last March, in all their might assembled in Palm Desert, Calif., the National Football League owners made a momentous decision. They voted to impose penalties against home teams for crowd noise that continually disrupts the offenses of their opponents, and if they thought they heard noise, the indications are that they ain't heard nothin' yet. After all, you can't smoke in elevators, spit on the sidewalk or shoot off a machine gun in church. Now this.
The vote was 21-7, and proponents of the rule, which allows referees to deduct timeouts from the team whose fans are doing the dinning, and impose yardage penalties if that doesn't impress them, said it was necessary because the crowds were becoming bigger factors than the players. That came as no surprise to anyone who has been watching these past few seasons as the gladiators stood around while the hometown hooters exercised their freedom of expression, their lungs and their vocal chords, the referee having suspended play because the opposing quarterback couldn't hear himself.
Those red-blooded Americans aren't going to take this sitting down, something they seldom do anyway during the height of their hysteria. Already in preseason we have heard their clamors and seen their banners, an army of freedom fighters in training for the season that starts today and - who knows? - may end with William Kunstler quarterbacking them up the courthouse steps. 
To cast light on how this has come about, a little history is called for. Once within living memory the game was played by 22 men -currently the number of some college coaching staffs - and attended by audiences of admirers who came to cheer, providing a sort of operatic chorus to the drama at hand.
Now it is played by an ever-changing cast of characters who commute in and out -sometimes to their own confusion - and attended by crowds who come not to cheer but to jeer and, as noted, hold up the proceedings until the question is not who will win but will they let the game continue before the team trainers and water boys are asked to bring out the mail from home.
A college football game was televised for the first time on Sept. 30, 1939, when Fordham beat Waynesburg, 34-7. Next we settle in on Dec. 22, 1952, when from Balboa Stadium in San Diego NBC prepared to telecast coast to coast something called the Poinsettia Bowl. It pitted the San Diego Naval Training Station against Bolling Field, for the championship of the armed services.
According to Lindsey Nelson, the retired sportscaster, on the morning of the game the rain was hitting the skylight of the hotel coffee shop with such intensity that it was impossible to tell the waitress how you wanted your eggs done. ''As kickoff time approached,'' Nelson wrote of the Poinsettia Affair in his 1985 autobiography, ''we became aware of another interesting development. There were no spectators. I do not mean that it was a small crowd. I mean there did not appear to be one single paid admission. We were about to televise from coast to coast on NBC a football game to which nobody had come.''
Tom Gallery, the director of NBC sports, convened a quick conference of Navy brass. He explained that you could no more televise a game without an audience than you could christen a battleship in secrecy.
''Gentlemen,'' he said, ''we have to have a crowd of some sort.''
Those were the words, the dictum from which all that would follow would derive. Within the hour the Shore Patrol, having made clean sweepdowns fore and aft in every movie house and ale house, paraded in some 200 soggy, sullen and shanghaied sailors -Hayden Fry, now the coach of Iowa, among them. When Bill Bennington, the director, punched in the crowd shot of them sitting in a sodden and unsmiling square, wondering what they were doing there under Niagara Falls, it was established, apparently forevermore, that the crowd shot is an indispensable part of the televised game.
Since then, successive creative directors have embellished and embroidererd the basic principle that you can't enjoy anything, whether it be a football game, a painting or a sunset, without company, the more and more raucous the merrier. To the obligatory long shot of partisans cheering a gain or a score -and what else would they be doing? - was added the close-up. The sideline camera, initially installed to capture play at ground level, was swung up toward the stands, inviting every closet clown in the area out into the open, his face and torso often painted in team colors, raising the question at college games of the benefits of higher education and, at pro games, of the wisdom of universal suffrage.
It was in Cleveland's Municipal Stadium on Jan. 11, 1987, when, by my calculations, the Poinsettia Principle, as formulated in San Diego more than three decades before, finally came to full flower. While the Denver Broncos defeated the Cleveland Browns in overtime, 23-20, there were, by official count, 143 plays on the field and, by my count, 69 crowd shots on NBC. This not only entitled the Broncos to meet the New York Giants in the Super Bowl - a dubious honor as it turned out - but crowds anywhere to assume that, if they were that indispensable to the game on the tube, they might now be similarly important to the play on the field.
This was a concept that had not escaped the keen and inventive minds of a number of coaches who had already begun to include it in their game plans. Some weeks before, Don James, the foresighted head man at the University of Washington, had implored Huskie fans to come to the home game with Arizona State and scream their brains, or whatever, out. A record gathering of 73,883 packed the place, and set up such a clamor whenever Arizona State had the ball that, not only were the visitors unable to hear their snap count, but a member of the gendarmerie became concerned that the sportsmanship might get out of hand. He requested of Mike Lude, the Washington athletic director, that Lude make an announcement asking for calm. ''I told him,'' Lude said, ''to go to hell.'' More recently - last Dec. 31, in fact - the NBC commentators at the Cincinnati-Seattle contest reported that Sam Wyche, the Bengals' resident conductor, had been leading the home crowd in the manner, I judged, of Arturo Toscanini. You'll recall that the Maestro regularly not only conducted the New York Philharmonic but also the NBC Symphony, so that was keeping the old baton in the house.
''Crowds,'' Merlin Olsen, the network's leading musicologist, informed us in seeming admiration that day, ''have become so much more sophisticated in knowing when they can make so much noise that the other team can't hear.''
So the games, repeatedly interrupted by the a capella concerts, dragged on - on Sundays on the East Coast into TV prime time, and on Monday nights into Tuesdays. And the viewers began to drop off or doze off. This left the owners faced with an economic reality. Few things stir these sportsmen like an economic reality, so when they realized that for every TV rating dip there would be a comparable dollar drop, their decree to muffle the huddled masses yearning to be free was as inevitable as it may be vulnerable.
It seems to this observer that, while you can't get away with hollering ''Fire!'' in a crowded theater, there's a constitutional question here that the American Civil Liberties Union will pounce upon as on a fumble on the 5-yard line. The right peaceably to assemble and of freedom of speech are guaranteed by the First Amendment of the Constitution. Should the National Collegiate Athletic Association follow in step, I can hear now the cheers change from ''U.C.L.A.! U.C.L.A.!'' to ''A.C.L.U.! A.C.L.U.!'' and foresee the first N.F.L. draft pick coming, not as this year out of that eminent California institution, but out of Harvard Law.

HEADLINE: Talking Condo Funds;
Managing Capital Reserves

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
THE roof shingles will deteriorate, the driveway will need a new surface and even the corridor carpeting will wear thin. But unlike a co-op corporation, which can easily borrow funds for capital outlays to repair such conditions, the condominium is not so fortunate; banks are still wary since the condominium association has no collateral to pledge. And a special assessment creates too much individual hardship and internal strife.
''Raising the possibility of a special assessment is the best way I know to get lynched,'' said Bob Kirkland, president of Professional Property Managers Inc. of Virginia Beach, Va., which manages 72 associations. 
No wonder more and more condo associations are beginning to place greater emphasis on establishing and financing a well- thought-out capital reserves program.
A recent survey by the Commmunity Associations Institute of Alexandria, Va., a national network of condominium officers and their advisers, showed that in 1989 the need to build up reserves was the major cause of an increase in monthly common charges. The use of the special assessment fell from 25 to 16 percent of the 230 associations surveyed in a nationwide random sampling.
A planned program of capital reserves is essential today for other reasons, too, said Douglas Kleine, director of research for the institute. The secondary mortgage market - investor pools that buy individual mortgages - now insists on assurances that such a program is in place. This means a local mortgage officer will require the same verification before approving a loan on an individual unit.
Further, California, Florida and other states have passed laws requiring an association to provide unit owners with details of its capital reserve program on an annual basis. More states may follow. And the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants is creating new guidelines that will require the inclusion of a capital reserve program in any audit of an association.
The basic tool to set up a program that will be acceptable to lenders and regulators is the reserve study - a blueprint for action that takes into account engineering factors, like the anticipated life of a roof or heating system, plus financial projections that compensate for inflation and the fluctuating rate of return on invested reserves.
A handful of companies, among them Association Reserves of Calabasas, Calif., and Erickson Associates of Orlando, Fla., and San Diego, are beginning to specialize in this burgeoning field, combining engineering and actuarial expertise to arrive at an accurate figure for the amount of money needed and a timetable for expenditures. If such a company takes over the job, expect to pay around $600 for under 40 units and up to $10,000 for 500 units or more, said Robert M. Norlund, president of Association Reserves.
Most condominiums, however, will begin by simply getting an engineer's report. Mr. Kirkland recommends using only a licensed professional engineer, since specialized knowledge will be needed. Ideally, he said, the person will also have had experience compiling reports for buildings or developments that were being converted from rental status, since the work closely parallels the kind needed for a reserve study.
Condo officers should not rely solely on the cost estimates for replacement provided by such a study, say managers. It is wiser, they say, to get a more precise figure by putting the items out for local bids.
''Each contractor usually knows his particular job and specialized local conditions much better,'' explained Rhonda Major, senior manager with Bay Area Property Management of Clear Lake City, Tex. By contrast, many engineering companies, she maintained, base their projections on national or regional averages. Thus their figures do not necessarily reflect the views of the local contractors who will be doing the work.
THE rule-of-thumb is to have such a report updated every three years. After this, if the association does not have a management company accustomed to making up the funding and expenditures projections, the officers could use a computer program. The Community Associations Institute favors one written by Craig Gilbert, an accountant in Atlanta. Called ''Community Reserves,'' it costs $195 (call 404-231-0349 or write: Front Row Systems, P.O. Box 550346 Atlanta, Ga. 30355).
Some cautions should be observed when making the projections. For example, Mr. Kirkland said that if a roof would cost $100,000 to replace this year and still has a useful life of 10 years, the association would need to set aside far more than $10,000 a year. Assuming only a 5 percent yearly inflation, the cost 10 years hence would reach $163,889, due to compounding.
Further, it is normally assumed that the interest earned on the money as it accumulates will make up the difference. But if $10,000 were set aside each year at an interest rate of say, 8 percent, only $134,805 would be available at the end of the 10th year, Mr. Kirkland warned.
Ms. Major, like others, also favors an unallocated amount of around 3 percent of the total to cover such variables as a shorter-than-anticipated life of a particular system, or perhaps an upgrade to a product that is technically or esthetically more appealing.
''One time I remember we planned for one coat of paint,'' she said. ''But when the painting came due there was so much flaking and rot we needed two coats.'' Thus, in addition to that unallocated amount, she favors maintaining a contingency fund of around 5 percent of the total.
Making certain ongoing maintenance chores become part of the capital reserve progam also helps. ''A generous amount allocated to the regular budget for maintenance can do a great deal to avoid sudden and unplanned capital expenditures,'' Ms. Major said.
Do not forget to amend that reserve plan to factor in sudden and unanticipated changes in costs, Mr. Kleine added, like new regulations that can add hundreds of dollars to any replacement project.
More detailed planning information is available in ''Reserve Study Guidelines'' a 120-page book costing $32.95, and ''Reserve to Preserve,'' a booklet costing $9.50; both are from Community Associations Institute. Write: 1423 Powhatan Street, Alexandria, Va. 22314, or call (800) 342-5224.
Good investment management of the funds is a further complex topic. C.A.I. has a new newsletter for this purpose, called The Ledger Quarterly. The annual subscription for members is $36, for nonmembers, $48.

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles

 BODY:

 
VICTORIAN FAIR
The Justin Morgan Bicentennial Victorian Fair and Carriage Rally in Old Lyme on Saturday and next Sunday is also being called Stick It to the Tick Festival. Proceeds from the two-day event will benefit the University of Connecticut's research on Lyme disease.
It starts with a parade at 10 A.M. Saturday from downtown to the pre-Revolutionary War McCulloch Farm on Whipporwill Road. The farm's house was built from plans in Christopher Wren's ''Designs for the Colonies.''
Leading off on the three-mile route will be the Governor's Horse Guard, followed by the UConn equestrian team, a collection of antique automobiles, several high-wheeled bicycles and a group of antique carriages drawn by Morgan horses bred at the farm. Justin Morgan was the name of the original Morgan horse, known for its stamina, versatility and economical appetite. It was also the name of the horse's owner, a choirmaster and tavernkeeper when he was not breeding horses. 
The other events take place on the farm. An auction of collectibles at noon Saturday features a 26-foot used powerboat, a quilt made for the occasion, a three-generation-old handmade bedspread and an original Katzenjammer Kids cartoon. A square dance will be held Saturday night, and a horse-drawn carriage rally begins at 10 A.M. Sunday, followed by hayrides in the afternoon and a chamber music concert titled ''Victorian Women in Song'' to be held in the parlor of the house on Sunday evening.
Throughout the two days, there will be Morgan horse demonstrations, a petting zoo, children's games, puppets, songs by the Sweet Adelines as well as information about Lyme disease. Admission is $10; the chamber music concert costs an additional $5. Call 434-7355 for tickets.
 
LYME IMPRESSIONISM
More than 400 paintings, drawings and watercolors were destroyed when Everett L. Warner's studio burned down after his death in 1963. As a result his work is extremely rare, but a representative collection of his paintings goes on exhibition at the Connecticut Gallery in Marlborough today; it remains through Oct. 22.
Best known as a Lyme Impressionist because of the many exhibitions of his work displayed there, and because of the frequency of his stays at Florence Griswold's boardinghouse for artists, he was a native Midwesterner. Born in Iowa, he lived and studied in New York and Paris, taught at the Carnegie Institute in Pittsburgh, served as a camouflage artist for the Navy in World War I and II, and finally settled down in New Hampshire in 1947.
His work was reqarded with most of his generation's prestigeous prizes, including ones from the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts, the Washington Water Color Club, the National Academy of Design the Art Institute of Chicago and the Panama-Pacific Exposition of 1915 in San Francisco.
In the Marlborough show are paintings of New York City wharfs, Connecticut landscapes and depictions of Pittsburgh's industrial day in the 1920's and 30's. A reception will be held from 2 to 5 P.M. today. The gallery is open from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesday to Saturday and by appointment on Sundays and Mondays by calling 295-9543.
 
LIBERATION OF MARSEILLES
''The Resistance and Liberation of Marseilles, 1941-1945'' is the photographic record kept by a Polish photojournalist during her flight from the Nazis and her years as a resistance fighter in France. The exhibition may be seen from Thursday through Sept. 28 in the Art School Gallery of the University of Hartford. It is being sponsored by the University's Maurice Greenberg Center for Judaic Studies.
The photojournalist, Julie Pirotte, took pictures at underground meetings, among starving children, in camps for German-Jewish mothers who were later killed in the gas chambers of Auschwitz, and with the French Guerillas fighting German soldiers. She is the only surviving member of her family. Her sister, also a member of the Resistance, was killed by the Nazis.
After the war she returned to Poland with her negatives, but most of her prints were missing until the 1970's when they began turning up in museums and in documentary films in Europe and the United States. Ms. Pirotte will give a talk with slides at 8 P.M. on Sept. 21 in the gallery, followed by a public reception. The exhibition is open from 9 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. weekdays and from noon to 4 P.M. Sundays.
 
MUSIC FROM THE '30s
''Wobbly Music,'' composed in the cause of the International Workers of the World (whose members were called wobbles), is to be performed in three concerts by the American Music-Theater Group, the Wesleyan Singers alumni and Marni Nixon, a soprano soloist.
Christian Wolff, a professor of music at Dartmouth, was commissioned by Wesleyan in 1975 to compose a cantata of settings for labor songs of the 1930's and music by the Composers' Collective, a group of young musicians in New York City that included Aaron Copland, Mark Blitzstein, Elie Seigmeister and Earl Robinson. ''Wobbly Music'' has been performed 18 times throughout the Northeast since the mid-70's.
The first of three upcoming performances will take place at 8 P.M. Saturday in the Charter Oak Temple Cultural Center, 21 Charter Oak Avenue, Hartford. It will be repeated at Wesleyan's Crowell Concert Hall in Middletown at 8 P.M. next Sunday, and at 8:30 P.M on Sept. 20 at Merkin Concert Hall in Manhattan.
Ms. Nixon will be featured in the first half of the program in songs by Blitzstein from ''The Cradle Will Rock,'' in Harold Rome's ''Pins and Needles,'' and in labor-related music of the Composer's Collective members.
The Wolff cantata, called ''Wobbly Music,'' will fill the second half of the program with settings from the Workers Collective Songbook, many of them written during the textile strike in Larence, Mas., in 1912. Mr. Wolff has also composed original material based on documents, letters, and the preamble to the constitution of the Internal Workers of the World. The work will be performed by a four-part chorus and various instruments including guitars and piano. Neely Bruce, the chairman of the music department at Wesleyan, has organized the program and will conduct.
Tickets in Hartford are $8, students $4. Details are at 249-1207. At Wesleyan they are $3, students and the elderly $2. Information is available at 347-9411.
 
VENISON AND CIDER
The Renaissance Deer Farm in Woodbury will supply the venison for a cooking workshop by the connecticut Culinary Institute on Tuesday. The workshop, ''Connecticut Venison,'' is part of a series being led by the school's master chefs and cosponsored by the State Department of Agriculture and Connecticut-based companies. The dishes include juniper bery and red wine roast of venison, ragout of fallow deer and venison chili.
Apples and sider supplied by the Old Cider Mill in Glastonbury will be used for appplesauce, chicken with apples and cider cream sauce, and apple and cider cinnamon pie on Wednesday. Both workshops are to be held from 6:30 to 9:30 P.M. and cost $25.
Beth Hillson, author and chef, will conduct the ''Open Hearth Cooking and Wine Tour'' on Saturday with a cooking workshop at the Open Fireplace in Randall's Ordinary, the historic tavern in Stonington, followed by a tour and tasting session at Stonington Vineyard with Nick and Happy Smith, the owners. Details are at 677-7869.

LENGTH: 398 words

HEADLINE: False Economy: Cutting School Costs

 BODY:
I read with great interest your article on the changing Long Island economy [''L.I. Growth Years Over, Looking Beyond Defense,'' Aug. 13]. All of us who have made our lives and careers here have much at stake. A significant increase in unemployment and the subsequent impact on property values would certainly affect us all. I was concerned, however, about the comments made by Lee E. Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board. 
His first suggestion for improvement is to cut the cost of public education. Once again, the schools are the scapegoat for a much broader problem. For most homeowners, school taxes account for less than half the total real estate tax burden. Real estate taxes themselves are not the major factor in the high cost of living on Long Island. The cost of everyday necessities such as power, transportation, clothing, food and even garbage disposal are much more of a hindrance in making ends meet.
I was also surprised to read that Mr. Koppelman suggests consolidating school districts as a way of saving money. New York City is desperately trying to find a better way to localize control of their school system as a means to salvage a once-great institution.
He then mentions the cost of duplication of effort by town and county governments. Is consolidation what he has in mind here as well? While duplication may be costly, I can't imagine the expense required to establish and run a bureaucratic structure that would govern all of Nassau and Suffolk Counties as one.
We should keep in mind that the fine quality of our schools and the distinct nature and personality of each Long Island town are major reasons Long Island is considered one of the 10 best places to live in the United States. Radical changes in either could do more harm to the Long Island economy than any Pentagon cutbacks.
While it may be difficult for young professionals starting their careers, perhaps an economic slowdown would not be so bad. Because we are an island, we have a limit to our resources and a finite amount of room for expansion. Let's not turn Long Island into a blivit.
 
ROBERT A. WIGGINS
 Smithtown
Letters for publication should include the writer's name, address and telephone number for verification. Send letters to The Editor, Long Island Weekly, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

LENGTH: 901 words

HEADLINE: ART;
Looking at an Unkept Promise

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
ALJIRA'S ''Promise of Progress: Present Conditions'' is the third sociopolitical show to be staged by this Newark gallery since it moved to 2 Washington Place. It was organized by Carl Hazlewood, the gallery's artistic director, and its six participants, a press release says, ''have shed the disengaged 'cool' of much mainstream art.''
This is to assume that they have the cool to shed, which is inconceivable where the expressionistic Jacob Landau and Luis Cruz Azaceta are concerned, and improbable in the cases of Willie Birch, a naif, and Cliff Joseph, who owes a little something to Ben Shahn. Nor are cool pasts easily imagined for Scott Dedecker, a commentator on international immorality, and Mo Bahc, a Korean-born painter who attempts the reconciliation of Eastern and Western cultural traditions. 
As political statements, Mr. Bahc's images will be meaningless to Western viewers, since the writing in them is Korean. Taken at face value, though, they are blends of abstract shapes in paint and collage ornamented with ''braids'' of black pigment, oversized characters and faint allusions to Buddhist art, and as such seem grandiose. The founder of a politically oriented gallery (in Brooklyn), Mr. Bahc has talent and conviction, but he may have to choose between politics and art if he is to make himself understood.
His subject the violence in Lebanon, Mr. Dedecker bases his enameled-looking images on news photographs, which leads him to paint tonally and in what are essentially blacks, grays and whites tinted with such colors as sepia, reds, blues, yellows and so forth. The results are impressions - of a dark wasteland illuminated by puffs of creamy white smoke, figures picking through the wreckage of a building and, in some watercolors, landscapes dotted with groups of Muslim soldiers.
Of all the artists, Mr. Dedecker is said in the press release to be closest to the avant-garde, in terms of ''ironic/critical stance.'' But to the reviewer he seems as literal (if not as grand) as Meissonier is in his 1870 rendering of the Tuileries in ruins.
The violence that Mr. Birch reports in ''Johnny Make the Nightly News'' is strictly home-grown. A bloody corpse lies in the street, cordoned off by red tape; the police are at hand; people stand on the sidewalk watching. Decorating the picture's dark wood frame is a painted relief of crack vials and daggers - shades of Gauguin and the motifs he carved on the frames of his Polynesian works.
Mr. Birch may lack technical sophistication, but he is a shrewd observer, particularly in ''Season's Greetings.'' The scene is a room attractively furnished in a middle-class, arty style; the chief figures are a black boy and a black girl (the boy in a Yale sweatshirt), on the floor studying economics by way of a Monopoly game. A man sits nearby reading The New York Times Magazine; an orange cat cleans itself on a divan. All is brightly colored domestic bliss, except for the acrimonious atmosphere around the game and the overall implications that, sooner or later, penalties must be paid for this or any other kind of prosperity.
Mostly, it is in ''Freedom,'' a small painting of black, green and yellow balloons held aloft by a disembodied black hand, that Mr. Joseph conveys his attachment to Shahn. Otherwise, he is his own man - an odd mixture of reticence, militancy and humor. The painting of a black family bivouacked on the sidewalk outside a waterbed store, ''Have More Fun in a Waterbed,'' is not the average comment on homelessness. But then the family isn't exactly typical either.
Cradling an adolescent boy in her lap, the woman sits staring into the store that is advertising the fun, while her man lies sleeping with one hand on the back of a bright-eyed white terrier. The color is drab; the drawing is sometimes good (the man's shoes), sometimes inept (the figure of the boy), and the whole spectacle is tinged with improbability.
But as a statement about poverty, it is far superior to ''Oh Say Can You See,'' where Mr. Joseph hauls in props from the dissidents' warehouse - the flag, skyscrapers, dollar signs and other symbols of capitalism - juxtaposing them with a garbage basket containing cutouts of African sculpture.
A goblin with large eyes and a hooked nose, Mr. Azaceta's alter ego continues to play Everyman. In one of these large, crusty canvases, he squats, seeming unable to decide which of the open manholes around him to scuttle into; in the other he is but a head bobbing on a choppy sea in a small boat. He is a character that everyone, regardless of political affiliation, can identify with.
Mr. Landau gives the show perspective, as a resident of Roosevelt, the community that Shahn lived in, and as the one artist in the show to be inspired by the Bible. His pencil and pastel drawings of torsos, heads and limbs speak, variously, of Christ's ''wars and rumors of wars''; the ladder full of angels that Jacob dreamt about, and the fragmentation prophesied by the Book of Revelation.
Though none are demagogues, these artists make it plain that ''present conditions'' don't begin to fulfill the ''promise of progress'' forever being made by political leaders. A gallery that was originally oriented to minority artists, Aljira is setting an example with art that generally transcends minority issues. The show, through Sept. 30, is open Wednesday through Sunday from noon to 6 P.M.

GRAPHIC: Photo of work by Cliff Joseph; work by Luis Cruz Azaceta

HEADLINE: Being Taxed Out of One's Town

 BODY:
Re: ''West Milford Journal: Angered by Tax Increases, Residents Seek an Investigation'' (Aug. 13):
Any political candidate for office in the State of New Jersey should read this article and understand that every community in our state is also West Milford. The issue is not if our present methods of establishing the priorities for the people's business work, but whether their continued functioning can be rationalized quickly enough to prevent the destruction of the state's basic unit, the family. 
The effects of taxation are absorbing the disposable income of average citizens at a rate that families find impossible to replace. Who should be identified as these average citizens? They are the nondominant political culture people (retired, aged, single-parent, fixed-income, lower middle class, the non-upwardly-mobile middle class and the documented poor). And those in ''dominant political and socioeconomic culture'' are finding that they can reconstruct their once stable and ethnically and economically mixed communities (regardless of the Mount Laurel decision) into isolated and insulated reflections of themselves and their values through the use of creative capital projects and related increases in local property taxes.
Is your town using the coercive power of local property ordinances and taxation to gentrify you and your neighbors out of town? Do you now understand why there are no low-income homes for families in New Jersey communities except the huddled masses' ghettos of Camden, Newark et al?
We are a new statewide coalition. We are not associated with either political party, but we are the reason your town or the state exists, to create equity from chaos.
 
BARRY S. PERLMAN
 Secretary
 
Coalition for Affordable Taxes for All
 
Palmyra
