HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
First-Time Buyers Face Some Agonizing Choices

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
WHEN it came time to buy their first home, Jeff and Kelly Bonser of suburban Los Angeles matched the experience of many young couples setting out to buy into the American dream. They paid more than they had expected to, and settled for less than they had hoped for.
But it was a home, and it was theirs. So last December they joined the ranks of American homeowners, achieving a goal that is becoming more and more elusive for other young couples like them. Over the last decade, relatively high interest rates, housing prices that outpaced the rise in wages, and high rents that limited the opportunities of young families to save - all have seriously eroded the proportion of owners among people in their mid-20's to mid-30's, traditionally the prime ages for first-home buyers.
The Bonsers - he is 27 years old and she is 25 - increased their expenses and lowered their expectations in buying a 2,000-square-foot badly deteriorated house in Rancho Cucamonga in San Bernardino County, and Mr. Bonser set to work with hammer and saw to make it livable. Their dream, to live higher up in the foothills of the San Bernardino Mountains, will have to wait, they said. 
In becoming homeowners, the Bonsers joined Alex, 27, and Betsy Sosa, 24, who gave up on finding something they could afford in their first choice, Irvington, N.J., and camped out for three days before the builder's trailer to sign up for a new state-subsidized brick-and-frame town house in a redevelopment area of Newark.
At about the same time in North Carolina, Charles and Elizabeth Tysinger, both 24, decided against spending more money for less in their first choice location - Chapel Hill - and ''got lucky,'' spending $20,000 more than they had planned for two acres and a big house in the town of Elon College, outside Burlington.
Each of these couples is typical of two-income middle-class home buyers in their new towns. The men have special skills - one is a pharmacist, another a carpenter, and the third a telephone technician - and their wives are office workers. What they discovered in looking for their first houses, and the choices they were faced with, say much about the difficulties a young family faces in acquiring a home these days. They needed patience and some luck. Two of the couples got help from their parents and the third took advantage of a state program that helps first-time home buyers.
AND despite wide differences in the relative cost of housing among the American regions they represent, the young home buyers agreed that one element above all others was crucial to clearing the first hurdle to buying a home: an iron determination to scrimp and save, even while friends were buying new cars and leaving on expensive vacations, to amass a big enough down payment.
Having a baby on the way helps on the inspirational side. ''When I found out I was pregnant, it was no more 'wait 'til next year,' '' said Mrs. Bonser. ''I said, 'Jeff, we've got to find a house!' ''
Federal officials, social planners and demographers are expressing a growing distress that fewer and fewer Americans in the 25-to-35 age group are willing or able to achieve the goals of these young couples. After rising steadily since home-ownership percentages were first being tracked by the Bureau of the Census after World War II, the percentages of first-time buyers becoming homeowners began to drop after 1980, from 43.3 percent to 36.2 percent in 1988 for 25-to-29-year-olds, and from 62.4 percent to 52.6 percent for 30-to-35-year-olds.
If ownership participation by those groups had remained at the pre-1980 levels, said a recent report from the Joint Center for Housing Studies at Harvard, two million more home-owning households would now dot the country.
The decline in home ownership among young people is not simply a matter of a different lifestyle for the coming generation, the experts warn. The country's retirement system assumes that a certain number of citizens will have acquired substantial savings in their homes by the time they leave work, and the Harvard study warns of the consequences of a generation of renters coming to retirement.
''THE growing poverty population and the decline in homeownership rates among the young are likely to contribute to further increases in the inequality in income and wealth,'' it concluded. Unless reversed, it said, this trend ''threatens to produce a permanent underclass of disadvantaged renters and jeopardize the long-term financial security of future generations.''
For Mr. and Mrs. Sosa of Newark, the connection between home ownership and future security hardly needed an academic explanation.
''My whole idea is, number one, if you really want to save money and make money for the future, real estate is the only way to go,'' said Mr. Sosa, a telephone-line technician for New Jersey Bell. ''So you have to think what you would rather do, drive a new car every year or keep the one you have for three or four years and own your own home. That's the choice you have to make.'' Mr. Tysinger, a pharmacist with the Super X chain in Burlington, N.C., and his wife, a production scheduler at the A. T. & T. plant there, took the most drastic steps to get their $24,000 down payment together.
After their marriage in January 1988, they moved deep into the country to a little farmhouse that rented for only $235 a month and lived on Mrs. Tysinger's salary while banking his.
''Basically we didn't go out like a lot of people and look for a nice expensive condo with a pool and everything that rents for $800 a month,'' Mr. Tysinger said. ''We found this nice little farmhouse and put my salary in the bank, and that gave us the idea that, hey, we could make the house payments because in a sense we were doing it by putting that money in the bank.
''You say in your mind that you have to do this thing, and if it means you have to scrimp a little bit, you do it.''
Indeed, while studies bemoan the loss of the savings ethic among Americans, the Tysingers were eager to explain that looking years instead of days ahead is something they learned growing up.
''We're both owe a great deal to our parents,'' Mr. Tysinger went on. ''They did give us some money to help buy the house, but what they also did was work hard all their lives to be able to send us to school and to send us through college. They have had to work hard all their lives, and we feel very strongly about how important that has been for us.''
The Tysingers have a combined income of about $70,000, compared with the statewide median household income of $30,200. They are also childless, increasing their disposable income.
So when they decided they were ready to start looking in earnest last October, they were confident that their $100,000 upper limit for the purchase price would give them their pick of houses.''
''We were incredibly unrealistic about it,'' Mrs. Tysinger said with a laugh. ''We thought that if we were spending $100,000 for a house, we would end up with a mansion. Well, we found some very nice residential sections but they were very expensive, and they still didn't have the privacy and the room we were looking for.''
AFTER looking since last October, the Tysingers found their three-bedroom, three-bath home on two acres of oak, hickory and walnut trees. Best of all, from Mr. Tysinger's point of view, it overlooks a neighbor's pond. Ponds feature prominently in his plans for a small ranch later one.
''We got lucky,'' Mr. Tysinger said of the $120,000 purchase. They closed on the house June 21.
For the Bonsers of Rancho Cucamonga, an $80,000 home was the original upper limit. He is a finish-grade carpenter, and his wife, who handles billing for Pomona Valley Hospital Medical Center according to the National Association of Realtors.
For a while, they rented a home in Ontario, the adjoining community, and found several houses there in their price range.
''BUT we also heard gunshots in the night, our neighbor had a bullet go through his wall, the whole nine yards,'' Mr. Bonser said. ''We have kids and we want them to be able to play outdoors, so our goal went up to $100,000 in a real hurry.''
Even that price put their first dream of a house in the foothills out of reach, and Mr. Bonser was half hoping his family would wait a few years, until they could move over the San Bernardino mountains to the high desert around Victorville, where land was cheaper and he would be able to build a house of their own.
But with a second baby on the way, and Mrs. Bonser insistent that she remain close to her parents, they eventually found their home at the outer edge of Rancho Cucamonga, just inside the right side of the railroad tracks from Ontario, for $102,000. The house had been vacant for some time, and had been badly vandalized. Not a closet door was hanging, the stove was a mess, there were holes in the wall, and most electric fixtures needed replacing.
''I went to look at it with a girlfriend and she kept saying, 'Oh, Kelly, you can't live in here,' and I kept saying 'Yes, but Jeff can do this and Jeff can do that, and it's going to be O.K.' ''
So it has. Mrs. Bonser traded in her beloved Thunderbird on a compact to save on gas, and they rearranged other parts of their budget to swing the deal.
Since moving in just before last Christmas, Mr. Bonser has repaired the interior, and only a pile of cinderblocks in the driveway, awaiting Mr. Bonser's plans to level the front yard with a retaining wall, remain to recall the house's former state.
''I never thought I'd be paying a thousand dollars a month for house payments,'' Mr. Bonser remarked. ''But it sure feels good.''
Mr. and Mrs. Sosa - she is a supervisor at Citibank in New York City - were faced with the problem many first-time buyers confront in the New York area. Their combined income of about $50,000 is close to the New York metropolitan area median of $54,300, but in that same region, the median house price is $178,000, according to the National Association of Realtors.
''We've been trying to find a home like any young couple, and we've been looking for two and a half years.'' Mr. Sosa declared. ''It always turns out to be a little harder than you expect.''
Their bid of $99,900 for an older house in Irvington, a suburb of Newark, was accepted, and the Sosas spent $1,300 on engineering reports and other services before being turned down by the bank. At a 10.5 percent interest rate, the bank decided, they could not qualify for the loan.
THEN, just a year ago, the Sosas saw an ad for new town homes being built in Newark by the Inner City Division of K. Hovnanian Enterprises of Red Bank, N.J., a leading builder of modestly priced housing in New Jersey and Florida. The project was rising in a redevelopment area of Newark that had been bulldozed clear of the slums that once stood on the site.
The City of Newark donated part of the land for the project in exchange for a pledge from the developer to include low-cost rental units in the condominium project.
Society Hill Newark, as it is known, offered brand new homes for under $100,000, and the Sosas showed up at the builder's sales office three days before it opened, sleeping bags and pillows in hand. They were 30th in line. They took turns standing, and sleeping, in line, and when the office opened, they signed up for a two-bedroom, two-bath corner unit on Howard Street, with cabinets and carpets they picked out and equipped right down to the washer and the dryer, for $97,600.
BUYING a house even at that price required the help of the New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency, a state office that lends the proceeds of tax-free bonds as reduced-interest mortgages for first-time home buyers in the state.
The Sosas were just under the upper-income limits set by the program, and qualified for an 8.5 percent, 30-year fixed-rate mortgage, 2 percentage points below the prevailing bank rate. They closed on the house May 19.
Their total monthly charges for mortgage, taxes and insurance come to $888. At that price, the choice of a condominium townhouse in one of the least fashionable cities of the Northeast was easy, because in the case of Newark, Mr. Sosa said, fashion lags behind reality.
''Many people would say we must be crazy to move from Woodbridge to Newark,'' Mr. Sosa said. ''It's the typical New Jersey attitude - you just mention Newark and people assume its all bombed out and terrible. But this city is coming back, and because we are owners now, we are a part of it.''

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Demographics Hold Key To Home Appreciation

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
AS vice president and chief housing analyst for the Chicago Title and Trust Company, John Pfister is among the legion of real estate professionals who consider home ownership one of the most solid long-term investments available to American families.
But ask Mr. Pfister about his own parents, who bought a three-bedroom home on Chicago's North Side in 1929, the year of the stock market collapse, and sold it in 1945 after a decade of deflation, a global depression and a World War. The house they bought for $11,000 sold 16 years later for $9,200.
''There are never any guarantees that a housing investment will pay off,'' he said. ''Things go sideways, and even downwards for a while, and sometimes people get hurt.'' Like Mr. Pfister, experts across the nation now are reassessing the prospects for home value appreciation with a newfound sense of caution. Most continue to believe that home prices will continue to rise over the long term. But they point to factors already responsible for downturns in some markets, and that could spread to others. 
Never mind wars or depressions, the housing analysts say. Many expect the most potent force in the nation's housing markets to be the demographic reality of the baby-boom generation, which created a huge new population of first-time home buyers from the late 70's to the mid-80s, and which is now growing into middle age.
Between this year and the year 2000, according to the Bureau of the Census, there will be no increase in the number of Americans between 25 and 44 years old, the group that traditionally has included most of the first time home buyers. By contrast, the population of those 45 to 60 years old will grow by 18 million, according to the government projections.
''The group with real problems are those born in the middle 60's, people at the lagging edge of the baby boom and leading edge of the baby bust,'' said John Tucillo, chief economist for the National Association of Realtors.
People in this age group - now 20 to 25 years old - will buy their first homes at prices that have been pushed up by a larger population of slightly older buyers. And when they decide to sell, the analysts caution, they may find the market has weakened because of a dwindling population of first-time buyers younger than themselves.
Nor are demographics the only reason for skittishness in some parts of the country, the experts say. One clear characteristic of the housing market dur-ing the late 70's and the 80's was a volatility rarely experienced in the past, bringing periods of soaring price escalation in some areas that inevitably have led to downward adjustments.
''We have seen - and will continue to see - an actual price decline in places that overshot the market,'' said Kenneth Rosen, director of the Center for Real Estate and Urban Economics at the University of California in Berkeley and chief real estate analyst for Salomon Brothers. He added that he sees no immediate signs of a turnaround in two large markets currently experiencing a downward adjustment - the New York City region and New England.
DESPITE their warnings of caution, however, experts say that over the long term a home is a safe - some say essential - investment for people looking forward over decades toward retirement. Shortages of land suitable for development, the rising cost of construction, and the fact that Americans are living longer and are healthier in their old age are all factors that should serve to buttress demand for homes and push prices higher, the experts say.
Some have concluded that home ownership is the most important means of accumulating wealth, and that having complete or partial equity in a home will be crucial to planning a secure retirement.
''As households continue to delay or forgo becoming homeowners, their economic security at retirement is threatened,'' said a report issued in June by the Joint Center for Housing Studies at Harvard University.
Nonetheless, few expect the surging pace of price escalation that took place in many parts of the country between 1970 and the mid-1980's to be repeated. Some experts are urging young home buyers to consider not only the soaring prices of recent memory, but conditions in the housing market in several preceeding decades.
One rough measure of home prices over 50 years is provided by the Census Bureau, which has asked homeowners across the nation every 10 years what they think their homes would sell for. On that basis, it has reported a median home value once each decade.
Beginning with 1930, when the median home value was $4,800, the census data show clearly that prices move down, as well as up. By 1940, the median value had dropped more than 50 percent to $3,000. It shot back up to $7,400 by 1950, then climbed at a more gradual pace to $11,900 in 1960 and to $17,000 in 1970.
That is when prices began to soar. By 1980, the census data show that the median price had almost tripled, to $47,200. Data obtained by census using the same techique show that the median price had climbed to $73,536 by 1985.
And the volatility of prices has been much greater in some areas, particularly California, New England and the New York metropolitan region. The price swings around New York are reflected in research by the Housing Information Committee, a group of New Jersey realtors that commissioned a title search on a large four-bedroom house in Westfield, 20 miles southwest of Manhattan.
The group said the Westfield house was typical of homes in affluent suburban neighborhoods that are within easy commuting distance of New York City.
The search found that that title to the house was transferred in 1932, when a savings bank foreclosed on a $12,000 mortgage outstanding on the property. Later the same year, the savings bank sold it to another real estate concern for $11,500. In 1937, with its value still sinking, the house was sold to a family for $10,900.
That family kept the house for 12 years, selling it in 1949 at a time of rapid suburban growth after World War II. It was sold twice in 1949 - for $18,000 in January and for $22,500 in June.
IN 1953, a family bought the house and kept it for 28 years, profiting handsomely when it ultimately put it on the market. The family paid $32,000 in June 1953 and sold it for $166,500 in March, 1981. But while the value of the house rose rapidly in three decades, its price surged even faster in the 1980s. It sold in February 1987 for $390,000, more than double the price six years earlier. Its current owners paid $530,000 in August 1988.
But analysts say the values of the Westfield house and others like it in the New York suburbs have leveled off and in many cases declined slightly over the last year. Thus, recent buyers who now have to sell may have to accept losses. The decline, however, has been far less severe than in some other regions -home values plummeted over 20 percent Houston and Dallas during the early 80's - but it is having a painful impact on the plans of some suburbanites around New York.
The National Board of Realtors estimated that home prices have dropped three percent in the last year in the New York suburbs. If the owners of the Westfield house had to sell at a 3 percent loss, they would forfeit $16,000, plus thousands of dollars more in bank finance charges, legal fees and other costs associated with buying and selling real estate.
They would also have to suffer through the emotional ordeal of selling in a weak market in which buyers are holding out for unrealistically steep discounts and homes are languishing on the market for months.
''There is a tendency to think the housing market is going to collapse,'' said Mr. Tuccilo. ''It won't, but just as there always have been in the past, there are going to be shakeouts in individual markets.''

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION: CHICAGO;
A Residential Flying Community With Streets Called Taxiways

BYLINE: By JODY BROTT

 BODY:
GOLFERS and boaters long have known the advantages of living along the fairway or at a marina. Now pilots are carving out their own niche in the residential real estate market. The latest in this area is Meadow Creek, a 212-acre airport community under construction near Monee 35 miles southwest of the Loop, where pilots will be able to taxi their private planes up to their front doors.
Roads will not be called roads, but ''taxiways'' named after World War II aviation heroes such as Jimmy Doolittle and Butch O'Hare. Houses will have airplane hangars with direct access to a 3,400-foot runway, this area's longest residential airstrip. And closed-circuit television will carry information about runway and weather conditions. 
''The ideal situation is for the pilot to store his plane in his attached hangar, just like you would park your car in an attached garage,'' said William W. Pradelski, codeveloper with Edward Rachanski.
''We buy aircraft for pleasure and convenience,'' said Terrence Kunes, one of Chicago's largest car dealers, who bought a Meadow Creek lot and owns a Beech Baron, a Cessna Skylane and a Piper Lance. ''And usually the distance between home and the airport dictates whether it's convenient or not.''
The Meadow Creek Corporation already has spent $6 million on land, improvements and the runway. Most of the houses on the 150 one-acre lots will be under construction within two years and completed within four years, Mr. Pradelski said. Since some buyers plan to build on more than one lot, about 135 houses will go up at $310,000 to $1 million, including lot, hangar and house. As of mid-August all but 38 lots had been sold and most purchasers have chosen to have a hangar at home.
The first residential airport community in the Chicago area was Brookeridge, built in 1956 in southwest suburban Downers Grove. A handful more were built in the 60's and 70's throughout the metropolitan area - the aviation hub of the nation, with six airport communities including Meadow Creek.
Richard M. Ware, chief of the Illinois Bureau of Aviation Education and Safety for the Division of Aeronautics, estimated that there are a dozen airport communities in Illinois, adding that Western Flyer Aviation, a biweekly newspaper, reports 250 across the nation.
Meadow Creek, is situated in the 25-square-mile area known as unincorporated Will County, still predominantly farmland. Mr. Pradelski, a pilot and former airport community resident, bought the land in 1983 for about $1.5 million.
The project is expected to appeal to private pilots who want the convenience and economy of keeping their airplane, or airplanes, in their backyards. Its homeowners' association - the projected maintenance charge is $40 per month - will own the runway and will sell fuel to residents at cost.
CONSTRUCTION of a one-plane hangar costs $40,000 to $80,000 depending on design and extras, such as a turntable or special plumbing system for washing the aircraft. Typically, they are 50 feet wide, about as wide as a four-car garage and about 15 feet deeper. Some homes will have three-plane hangars.
Meadow Creek will also offer 270 condominium hangars, basically to accommodate residents of its second phase - 225 town houses and 50 single-family homes on an adjacent 139-acre site with smaller lots that afford no room for hangars. The hangars, which will also start at $40,000, will be available to residents of the first phase of construction who do not choose to house their planes at home.
Residents may take off and land at any hour, with no noise problems anticipated by Mr. Pradelski who described an airplane as ''quieter than a truck going down a highway.'' There will be no control tower, but there will be runway lights and markings, a wind tee and a windsock. The subdivision will be private and will have extensive security, including a guardhouse, an electronic entrance, individual alarm systems and a 24-hour television monitor of the runway. The acre to an acre-and-a-half lots cost $60,000 to $140,000, with ''premium'' parcels on the runway.
HOUSES must be at least 2,000 square feet, not including garage or hangar. However, plans that have already been filed show that one will be 8,000 square feet and Mr. Pradelski said that he expects others to be as large. He added that an architectural review committee must pass on all plans. Buyers may use Meadow Creek's builder or hire their own.
Once built, Meadow Creek will help meet a growing demand for residential airports, said Mr. Ware, noting that at least four privately owned Chicago area airports open to the public have closed since 1980.
In addition to providing much needed space, airport communities separate smaller general aviation aircraft from commuter airplanes, and thereby help alleviate traffic delays at larger municipal airports, where monthly hangar fees of $300 to $400 are common.
As a result, the state is encouraging airport-home developments. The Illinois Department of Transportation is drawing up guidelines for such communities. In 1985, the state created a special classification of residential airport, making it easier for airport communities to gain approval from local zoning boards which previously were uncertain how to classify such developments. Mr. Ware believes Illinois is the only state to recognize the classification of residential airport.
Developers have been slow to enter the residential airport market because of its high cost, including leveling land for the runway, Mr. Pradelski said. Other deterrents are special zoning requirements, Federal Aviation Administration approval and the scarcity of locations that cause no conflict with existing traffic patterns.
Who will live at Meadow Creek?
FIFTY percent of the buyers will use their aircraft for business. Among the buyers are an automobile dealer, a real estate developer, a physician, an aircraft insurer, and a retired Air Force colonel. Some now hold breakfast club meetings at airport restaurants. Some collect antique Stearmans and aircraft from World Wars I and II. Some are stunt fliers. Some build experimental aircraft.
Their airplanes cost between $20,000 for a four-seat single-engine airplane and $300,000 for a twin-engine eight-passenger craft.
For them, moving to Meadow Creek will mean the hours of washing, polishing and repairing their aircraft will be hours spent at home.
''It's fulfilling a lifelong dream,'' said Dean Del Bene, who insures aircraft. He calls his four-seat single-engine Mooney and 1937 Stinson Reliant his ''magic carpets.''

HEADLINE: IN THE NEW YORK REGION;
A Soft Market Is Chilling Apartment Construction

BYLINE: By MARK McCAIN

 BODY:
SOMETIMES when he answers his phone, Robert Ginsberg gets the feeling that home buyers in New York City today are a band of marauders driven by a thirst for rock-bottom bargains.
''People haven't been shy about negotiating over the phone - to see how far they can whittle down the price before they even look at my apartment,'' said Mr. Ginsberg, who is asking $167,000 for a studio apartment on East 56th Street that he believes was worth more than $200,000 before the stock market crash of 1987.
''Nonserious shoppers are looking for the steal of century,'' he said. ''And unfortunately, some owners are panicking and selling their apartments for less than they're worth - which hurts all the rest of us.''
Whether the motivation is panic or simply realism, successful sellers today are often resigning themselves to break-even deals. And sellers who bought nondescript apartments at the peak of the bidding frenzy four years ago are looking at losses that sometimes exceed $50,000. Buyers have become choosy and cautious, amid fears that prices have not bottomed out yet. Deals are still being struck, but hot spots in the market are few. 
''It's much harder to make a sale because buyers have tremendous choices, and in some segments of the market - like postwar apartments east of Lexington Avenue - there have been lots of price reductions,'' said Eva Fabry, a broker on the Upper East Side with Albert B. Ashforth, a realty company.
''But when someone is matched with an apartment that fits their needs to perfection, they'll readily buy it for the right price. I made three sales last month, all with serious sellers who weren't playing games and who had attractive prewar apartments.''
Clearly, the market is feeling the aftereffects of a major boom in housing construction and resale activity during the mid-80's. ''Lots of people are sitting in homes they've only owned for short periods of time, so we've really zapped the trade-up activity,'' said John Savacool, who tracks residential real estate in the New York metropolitan area for WEFA Group, an economic consulting firm in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa.
Moreover, as fears of a recession waft through the air, and homes appear to be uncertain investments, it takes more courage to trade up for a home.
''Everyone wonders,'' Mr. Savacool said, '' 'Will I survive if I happen to be caught in the midst of an economic constriction?' Nobody wants to be in a new trade-up home with a fat mortgage, trying to make ends meet on unemployment compensation.''
Developers, too, have grown cautious. In Manhattan, about 3,500 market-rate condominium and rental apartments will be erected this year, according to Yale Robbins, a Manhattan publisher who tracks the real estate industry. That is less than half the annual volume of 1987 and 1988, when an expiring tax-abatement program spurred builders into action.
But on the other end of the affordability spectrum, New York City began a $5 billion program last year aimed at producing more than 250,000 units of low- and moderate-income housing over the next decade. The central focus is on new construction and rehabilitation projects in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx.
In the suburbs, 1989 has been a year of bloodletting, with builders reducing their volume or shutting down completely. Yet even though buyers appear to be an endangered species, they are not extinct.
''This project indicates that even in a bad market, and you'd have to call this a bad market, there's still demand for well-designed, low-priced product,'' said Martin Berger, developer of the largest condominium tower ever built in Westchester County - a 17-story, 316-unit project in White Plains called the Seasons Club and Spa. Prices start around $150,000 for one-bedrooms with about 700 square feet of space. The building will be completed next spring and so far there are about 90 buyers.
''IF we were in a brisk market, I think we would have sold double that number by now,'' said Mr. Berger, president of Robert Martin Company, based in Elmsford, N.Y. ''Even a slow market you can find niches to move into - and that's what we've done.'' But a good niche is hard to find. Every developer, when mapping out strategy for a project one or two years before construction begins, attempts to guess what buyers will find attractive. As the market grows weaker, that becomes more difficult.
''Buyers today are looking for apartments that they know aren't being duplicated elsewhere,'' said Steven G. Rockmore, chairman of Gilbert Charles Beylen, a Manhattan marketing firm that assists developers. ''It's a very difficult time for any building that has cookie-cutter boxes.''
Two of the projects that Mr. Rockmore is handling have exceptional views. A 21-story building at 222 Riverside Drive overlooks the Hudson River, while a slightly taller building at 279 Central Park West offers views of the park. Prices there average $800 a square foot, more than double the price of plain-vanilla condominiums in Manhattan.
But $800 is not the peak of the market. Last year, the top square-foot price in a condominium transaction was $1,840 - for an eight-room, $3.6 million apartment $3.6 million at St. James Tower, a building east of First Avenue on 54th Street that opened in 1983.
WITH prices like that, no one can say the Manhattan housing market is moribund. Yet many sellers are frustrated. They believe they have attractive, well-priced homes. But no one seems interested in buying.
''It's a great apartment and I think it's a great buy,'' said Denise Lipman, who has been trying to sell a 1,300-square-foot duplex in a renovated armory near the Hudson River on 42d Street for almost a year. ''A lot of people are shopping around, but no one wants to commit themselves.''
Two months ago Ms. Lipman, her husband and their two children moved to a house in suburban New Jersey. As a sweetener, the Lipmans now are offering to pay the first year of maintenance fees - totaling more than $13,000 - on their apartment, which is priced at $279,000.
''We've been really anxious,'' Ms. Lipman said, ''but now I guess we've resigned ourselves to the idea that we'll probably have to rent it out for a couple of years.'' Decisions like that are putting downward pressure on rents in Manhattan. Individual owners and condominium developers alike are shifting apartments into the rental market temporarily, intending to sell them when prices move up again.
Most owners are renting their apartments for less than their attempted sale prices might seem to warrant. That is forcing landlords to become more aggressive, too. In July, a new 1,107-unit rental project on Roosevelt Island, across from the Upper East Side, began offering free rent through November to anyone signing a two-year lease.
''At this point, I can get a better quality apartment by renting rather than purchasing,'' said Mr. Ginsberg, who is selling his small apartment and looking with his fiancee for a two-bedroom apartment. ''Comparing total costs after taxes, I figure a rental will be about 70 or 80 percent of what I'd just be throwing to the wind by owning a place in this soft market.''
But once he began looking around, Mr. Ginsberg discovered to his dismay that two-bedroom apartments have continued to hold their value in the resale market. According to the Halstead Property Company, a Manhattan firm, average asking prices in virtually every size category of co-op and condominium apartments dropped during the 12-month period ended in June - except two-bedroom units.
''A few years ago baby boomers like me paid a lot for studio and one-bedroom apartments,'' Mr. Ginsberg said. ''Now we're all looking for family-sized apartments and so those are the ones that are selling for top dollar.'' Usually a home seller waits no longer than two years to reinvest in another home, thereby deferring taxes on capital gains. But for people like Mr. Ginsberg, who expects to only break even on his apartment, capital gains are absent, so tax liabilities are absent, too.
Other hopeful sellers have decided now would be a good time to buy -if only they could find a buyer.
''I think it's a bad market,'' said Alan Solarz, who is asking $165,000 for a one-bedroom apartment at 245 East 54th Street. ''People come through our apartment and look in two seconds, so there must be a lot of supply on the market.''
Many brokers report that sales activity has been improving since a nearly comatose stretch last winter, but buyers are still hestitant.
''FIVE years ago buyers would walk into in an apartment and feel they had to take it immediately,'' said Betsy Dean, a senior vice president of Douglas Elliman-Haldenstein, a major co-op brokerage on the Upper West Side. ''Now they no longer feel under the gun psychologically. There's lots more out there.'' In July, New York State extended a 0.4 percent transfer tax on houses and condominium apartments to co-op apartments as well - sparking a surge in co-op sales during April, May and June as owners raced to beat the new tax liability.
Apartment sales within about 200 co-op buildings surveyed by Douglas Elliman increased from 83 during the first quarter of 1989 to 173 in the second quarter. Many brokers are predicting that third-quarter activity will fall somewhere between the first-quarter stupor and the second-quarter frenzy.
Both Douglas Elliman and the Corcoran Group, another Manhattan brokerage that tracks the high end of the resale market, showed declining sale prices during the first six months of this year. The average price per room in both surveys, tabluated from different samples, was down by about 2.5 percent from 1988. Before this year, the average price in Elliman surveys had been climbing every year since a slight dip in 1976, while the Corcoran survey had its last price drop in 1982.
''For years, we'd laugh if a prospective buyer asked, 'Where can I find a good deal,' '' Ms. Dean said. ''But now, for the first time in a long time, we can say, 'There are some good deals out there.' ''

HEADLINE: Focus: Belmont, N.C.;
Old Mill Town Revived, With a New Twist

BYLINE: By PHOEBE ZERWICK

 BODY:
RUSSELL AND DEBORAH WRIGHT, both workers at R. L. Stowe Mills in this textile town just south of Charlotte, live in a frame house built about 70 years ago by a man who made his fortune in spinning mills.
Like other mill owners in the Carolinas in the early years of this century, R. L. Stowe knew that if he wanted to lure farmers from the Catawba River Valley and beyond to run his spinning machines, he had to provide inexpensive places for them to live.
Now his grandsons are renovating those same mill houses as rentals to recruit workers like the Wrights, much the way the grandfather did years ago. In the next five years they plan to spend $7 million to $8 million to turn drafty frame houses into modern homes with central air-conditioning, dishwashers, double-pane windows and vinyl siding.
Richmond Stowe, 27 years old, the youngest of the three brothers who now run the mill, said of the project, ''It got to the point where they were in such bad shape and the work force around here got so tight, we felt it would solidify our employee base.'' 
In some ways the Stowes are just following the advice that their father, R. L. Stowe Jr., always gave them about the 350 rundown houses they owned and rented to mill workers around town. ''He always said they were an asset, that he would never sell them off,'' Richmond Stowe said.
Housing experts say the Stowes are reviving an employee benefit that other companies are just now discovering. Assemblyman David C. Schwartz of New Jersey, a professor of political science at Rutgers University and director of its American Affordable Housing Institute, said he believes that employer-assisted housing in general will be an important new personnel benefit in the 90's.
In Princeton, N.J., for example, Church & Dwight Company, which makes Arm & Hammer baking soda, lends its employees up to 15 percent of the purchase price on a condominium town house in the Griggs Farm development in Princeton Township. If the employee remains for five years - during which time no payments are required - the loan is forgiven.
In Santa Barbara, Calif., a dozen companies have agreed to do business with the Santa Barbara Bank & Trust in exchange for low-interest second mortgages to help their employees make down payments.
And on the northwest side of Chicago, seven companies have agreed to invest in a revolving loan fund, called the Walk Home Program, for down payments for employees who buy houses in the surrounding neighborhood. Elizabeth Lockwood, one of the directors of the program there, said that the businesses - mostly manufacturing companies - started the fund because they were losing employees to the suburbs and losing the neighborhood to crime.
''It keeps people in the city and industry in the city,'' she said. With a cost of about $5 a year per employee, ''it's a real low-cost, high-visibility fringe.''
In Belmont, the approach is different, and perhaps fitting, in a town where working for a mill and living in mill-owned housing has always been a way of life. Rather than help employees buy their own homes, the Stowes are repairing the broken-down homes their employees have always rented from them.
RENTS have been low - 10 years ago, for example, an employee got a three-bedroom house for $25 a week - but there were few amenities. Most houses did not have heat and the tenants used space heaters; indoor plumbing was something of an afterthought, with toilets tacked onto back porches.
''Most of the companies around the country who have chosen to get into employer- assisted housing,'' said Mr. Schwartz, ''have avoided rental housing precisely because it reminds them of the company town of the late 19th and early 20th century.'' But times have changed, he said. ''After all,'' he said, ''the workers are not being brought in by bayonet. People who come in and rent these houses presumably know what their housing needs are and presumably could get a job somewhere else. I think the fear of the company town is really a yesteryear story.'' Nelson J. Bradshaw, who has sold appliances and groceries to mill workers for more than 40 years and cashed their paychecks, said: ''It's going to give them an edge. A man's going to think twice about leaving when he doesn't have a house to go to.''
In North Carolina, most other textile makers say that mill villages are a throwback to a time of company control that they would rather forget. Most of the big companies - Hanes, Cone, Burlington - bowed to public pressure and sold off their houses years ago.
''To the extent that there was a great deal of competition, it was a benefit,'' said Dennis M. Julian, a spokesman for the North Carolina Textile Manufacturing Association. ''A company could say, 'You work for me and you'll get an inexpensive house.' The reason they got out of it was because it was a bit of paternalism and an administrative burden.''
The Stowe brothers, however, are willing to bear the burden. With an unemployment rate in the surrounding county at 2.2 percent, the lowest in North Carolina, Stowe Mills often cannot find and keep the 1,300 workers it needs to run its spinning machines. And often as many as 20 percent only stay a few months before moving on to one of the dozens of other mills in Belmont and nearby.
Repairs on the first of six villages, near Stowe's National Plant and the new automated Helms Plant, are nearly done. On the advice of a public relations concern, the Stowes changed the village's name from National Mill Hill, as it had been known for decades, to Cottonwood, and published a brochure that looks like any other subdivision leaflet.
THE tongue-and-groove board walls are gone, as are the wild shades of green, blue and purple that mill workers had used to brighten their neglected homes. In their place are white sheet rock, country print wallpaper and wall-to-wall carpeting.
The houses have small back and front yards, but no basements or garages.
The Wrights, in their mid-30's, live with their three sons at the end of a row of gleaming white houses in Cottonwood. They both work in the winding room at National; Mr. Wright working the second shift during the week, and Mrs. Wright two 12-hour shifts during the weekend for 30 hours of pay.
Like the other houses on the street, theirs was gutted before they moved in. The wiring and plumbing were redone; central air-conditioning and heat were added, and the makeshift bathrooms off the back porch were replaced with modern ones. The total cost was about $20,000.
The Wrights' rent of $50 a week comes out of their paycheck, ''so you never miss it,'' Mrs. Wright said.
Cheap housing in the area for a family with three boys is scarce, so they will probably stay on at the mill to keep their home, they said. Nevertheless, they wonder if they will ever be able to save enough money to buy a house for their retirement.
When a spinner or winder stops working at the mill, he loses his house. ''If we didn't do that, we'd have a retirement community,'' Richmond Stowe said. A younger couple with an infant that took advantage of the availability of housing at Stowe Mills are Angie D. Roark, 21, and her husband, Richard, 26. They moved to Belmont from depressed West Virginia to find work, and Mrs. Roark said her husband had taken a job with the mill just to be able to rent a home for his family.
''This was the only way we could afford it,'' she said.

HEADLINE: More Prisoners Serving Time Outside Jail

BYLINE: By NANCY KENNEDY

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
A STATE program that allows people convicted of nonviolent crimes to serve the bulk of their sentences outside prison has prompted three counties to create similar programs and three other counties to consider establishing them.
To date, the majority of the participants in what is known as the Intermediate Sentencing Program have been first offenders convicted of drug-related crimes. They are required to find sponsors in the communities where they work, undergo counseling and perform community service. They must also submit to drug testing and observe strictly enforced curfews.
Advocates of the program dismiss criticism that the program's participants are let off with lighter sentences than warranted. They say that it has shown impressive results in rehabilitating its participants, frees up much needed space in overcrowded prisons and is far less costly than incarceration. Critics maintain that the program gives officers who supervise participants far too much influence over their lives. 
In this decade, largely because of the rise in drug use, lawmakers have taken a tougher stand on crime, instituting a range of measures like mandatory sentences for illegal gun possession. Such actions resulted in a rapid increase in the prison population. With 18,500 inmates, state instutitions today, on average, are at 125 percent capacity.
The idea for the Intermediate Sentencing Program grew out of a 1982 seminar on correction issues sponsored by the State Supreme Court. With $1 million in state money, the program was set up in September 1983 with six participants and placed under the jurisdiction of the Administrative Office of the Courts.
The program in New Jersey was the second in the nation; the first was in Georgia. Today there are 28 similiar programs across the country.
Harvey M. Goldstein, the Administrative Office of the Courts assistant director in charge of probation, said that similar programs had been set up in Essex, Middlesex and Union Counties. He said Hudson, Camden and Gloucester Counties were considering such programs.
''We are taking what we have learned from the intensive supervision program and attempting to apply it to the entire probation system,'' he said. ''We are very pleased with the inroads we have made. With reasonable safety, we can provide the support needed to enable an individual to act in a manner that society demands we act.''
Richard Talty, the program director, said state support for the program had grown steadily. In the 1988 fiscal year, the Legislature approved $2.4 million for the program and $2.9 million for the next fiscal year. Last year's appropriation, he said, was increased by $300,000 at midyear to allow for 75 additional participants.
Mr. Talty said the program has had about 500 participants a year since its inception six years ago. ''It's not the answer to overcrowding in the prisons,'' he said. ''But we think it makes a lot of difference in people who are ready to make a change in their lives.''
George Biddulph, 33 years old, of Hamilton, who completed the program in June, said he was looking for a way to redirect his life. ''I felt like I fell behind in life,'' he said. ''I needed somebody watching over me.''
The program imposes a grueling regimen that far exceeds the reach of most standard parole or probation programs. About one in four ''outmates,'' as some have dubbed program participants, ultimately returns to prison after violations of program regulations.
Those seeking to take part in the program are not eligible to apply until they have served at least part of their sentences in prison. Applications are reviewed by a panel made up of officials of the program and residents of the community in which a participant will reside after release from prison.
Those accepted into the program are released into the care of sponsors - a spouse, a parent or a graduate of the program, for example - who serve as the primary contact for a participant's officer. Completing the supervision circle are so-called network team members: employers, family members, ministers or friends who also agree to help a participant comply with program regulations. The extensive support network is intended to reinforce the efforts of program officers.
To remain in the program, a participant must be employed, meet at least three times a week with an officer, participate in individual counseling sessions, attend fellowship meetings like those of Alcoholic Anonymous or Narcotics Anonymous, and perform community service work. Officers from the program randomly test the participants for drug or alcohol use and strictly enforce curfews.
Participants spend from 16 months to five years in the program. The length of stay is determined by the length of the prison sentence.
 
'Pretty Rough at First'
''It was pretty rough at first,'' Mr. Biddulph said. ''After 9 or 10 months, it was wearing thin. The curfew checks bummed us out; the phone would ring at 11 o'clock at night and you're sound asleep.''
But because participants were imprisoned while their applications for the program were under review, vivid memories of incarceration provided most of them with the motivation to succeed.
Antonio Santos, 28, of Trenton, who spent eight months in prison after his conviction on drug charges, said: ''What kept me going? The thought of being where I was before. The thought of being incarcerated and knowing I don't want to be there again.'' He entered the program in December 1988.
The intense supervision by program officers makes some participants uncomfortable.
''They sometimes are apprehensive whether an officer is really there to help them,'' said Damery Bonilla, a New Brunswick-based program officer. ''They know I can recommend to the judge if a person is not making it they should be returned to jail.''
Most, however, gradually come not only to accept but also appreciate their officer's guidance. ''Joe's wonderful - he really encourages you,'' Mr. Santos said of his officer, Joseph Grinkevich, another New Brunswick officer.
 
Appealing to Women
The program is especially attractive for women whose prison sentences might otherwise separate them from their children. ''All the women in the program work, just as any other woman might,'' Ms. Bonilla said. ''But they'd rather be on I.S.P. with their families than be incarcerated in the state prison and have no contact at all.''
Statistics on recidivism bear out the success of the support-based program. Participants have a low probability of further illegal behavior. Fewer than 2 percent of about the program participants studied have later been convicted of felony offenses, while 6 percent have been convicted of misdemeanors, Mr. Talty said. None of the offenses involved violence. The program has graduated about 670 participants.
Those figures, Mr. Talty said, compare favorably with probation and parole results in which about 50 to 60 percent of those completing probation or parole go on to commit further acts of crime.
''We don't recycle people,'' Mr. Talty said. ''In that, we have really achieved something.''
Mr. Talty also points out that while the state spends about $19,000 a year on every prison inmate, the program costs $6,000 a year for each participant. In addition, he says, participants contribute an average of $3,500 a year to the economy through taxes, fines and restitution payments, community service work, child support and supervision fees.
''Judges originally were totally in opposition,'' Mr. Talty said. ''I guess they were thinking, 'I sent this person to prison and this other person is taking him out.' That has since changed. But prosecutors do not like the program. They feel it interferes with their prerogatives.''
 
Reaction of Prosecutors
Prosecutors, while generally favoring the program, oppose the participation of those convicted of dealing drugs. ''We have been resisting anyone with a violent background or drug dealing, and have not been totally successful in the latter,'' said Alan A. Rockoff, the Middlesex County Prosecutor. ''We can argue at the hearings although we have no veto power, and we have successfully argued in a few instances.''
Acceptance of the program by prosecutors was slow. At the program's inception, Mr. Rockoff said, he and his colleagues made their protests known to the Administrative Office of the Courts, describing their ''war stories'' in detailed letters.
''Prosecutors reluctantly accepted the program because it doesn't seem to be adequate punishment for a person sent to prison after diversionary and probation programs have failed to be released into the care of a sponsor to enjoy his conjugal rights, his refrigerator and his own bed,'' Mr. Rockoff said. ''But rehabilitation is the name of the game. There is such intensive supervision in this program that their statistics of success, if correct, are good ones.''
Diana Gordon, a professor of political science at the City College of New York who is writing a book on such programs, said the programs might not be as beneficial as expected. ''These programs are very intrusive on family life,'' she said. ''If it becomes a major option, we will see ghetto communities and the poor under benevolent supervision by the justice system, and I'm not convinced that's an appropriate role.''
 
Middle-Class Values
While granting that most participants embrace the structure imposed by the program on their lives, Ms. Gordon also questions the appropriateness of the perceived middle-class values imputed by the program.
''There are many requirements - written and communicated - concerned not so much with prevention of crime as with fitting people into an image of life which values hard work, not complaining, not asserting one's rights,'' she said.
Officer Grinkevich said, ''If requiring someone to have steady employment, to bring in a regular income, to support one's family or pay child support, to live up to his responsibilities - if that's considered middle class, then so be it.''
Both Mr. Santos and Mr. Biddulph are making plans for the future. Mr. Biddulph is starting night school this fall, working on a civil engineering degree to further his opportunities in the heating and air-conditioning trade. He and his companion have an infant son, are planning marriage and are hoping to buy a house.
Mr. Santos is headed for night classes at Mercer County Vocational School, hoping in two years to have a welder's certificate. He and his companion and their 8-year-old son also are looking to leave their drug-infested neighborhood behind.
''This program gives you a second chance,'' Mr. Santos said. ''It's tough, but it's fair. I feel like I've gained a little confidence in myself now.''

CORRECTION-DATE: September 17, 1989, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about a state program that allows sentences mainly outside prison for people convicted of nonviolent crimes misidentified the program. It is the Intensive Supervision Program, not the Intermediate Sentencing Program.

LENGTH: 1129 words

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION: WELLINGTON, FLA.;
Just Next Door to the Polo Club, Island Homes With Riding Trails

BYLINE: By TODD WOODY

 BODY:
FOR those who prefer their horse near home and hearth, equestrian residential communities have become the latest option in a state that offers planned communities for everyone from baby-boom tennis players to golf-playing retirees.
The developers of one such new community, the Equestrian Club Estates in western Palm Beach County, hope to lure the horse set with 200 homes - 34 villas attached in pairs, 39 detached patio homes and 127 detached single-family homes - surrounded on three sides by riding trails and adjacent to the Palm Beach Polo and Country Club's new $12 million equestrian center. Home to the Winter Equestrian Festival, the center will be host to more than 1,500 horses and their riders in the annual national jumping competition. The next one is in February. 
''There were about 200 acres next to a world-class facility, and it occurred to me that there definitely would be a market for a residential community featuring an equestrian theme,'' said Larry Throneburg, president of Equestrian Club Ltd., the partnership that purchased the land in April from his former employer, the Landmark Land Company.
The key to the future of Equestrian Club Estates is the equestrian center next door. But Jim Corbin, a horseman and manager of the Merrill Lynch Realty office here, said horse-oriented communities in Palm Beach County had not been unqualified successes.
''Mallett Hill was a sleeper for a long time,'' Mr. Corbin said of an equestrian community near Mr. Throneburg's project. ''It didn't really start selling until the equestrian center came along.''
And fewer than half the lots at White Fences, a similar community in western Palm Beach County, have been sold after seven years, other brokers say. Part of the reason, they explained, was legal problems between the developer and its lender that delayed sales for two and a half years.
MR. THRONEBURG is launching his project into a soft South Florida housing market, analysts say. Sales of single-family homes in Palm Beach County declined 4.5 percent in the first half of this year, compared to the first half of last year, said R. Thomas Powers, an economist with the Goodkin Research Corporation in Lauderdale-by-the-Sea.
''Palm Beach County is the only market in South Florida experiencing a downturn,'' he said, noting that the market in the rest of the area is relatively flat. ''The county is particularly dependent on the second-home market and when you have a softness in the Northeast market, people are going to think twice about buying a second home down here.'
Landmark sold the tract to Mr. Throneburg and his partnner Denis Quinlan for $5.9 million. Until this year, Mr. Throneburg was Landmark's sales and marketing director for the Palm Beach Polo and Country Club. Mr. Quinlan is a former vice president of contruction and development for the club.
Equestirian Club Estates will consist of six islands set in artificial lakes, with a moat along its perimeter. It will have a clubhouse, four tennis courts and a pool, and riding trails around the community and leading the equestrian center, where resident can board their horses.
The project's first phase - the first homes will be started by the middle of next year, and all are to complete by 1991 - will offer 34 two-unit villas on one island and 39 Mediterranean-style patio homes on another.
The patio homes will be built around a central courtyard and will share common yards. Twenty-six single-family homes will rise on half acre lots on the third island, to complete the first phase.
The remaining islands will be reserved for single-family homes to be built on half-acre to three-acre lots. Although barns will not be permitted, residents will be able to build training rings on the larger lots, Mr. Throneburg said.
He said the single-family home lots will be priced from $140,000 to $175,000 when sales begin in the fall. The town homes will sell for around $240,000 and the patio homes will be priced around $350,000, he said. He added that he expected the single-family homes to range in price from $500,000 to more than $1 million.
The villas and patio homes will be designed by a firm hired by Equestrian Club Ltd. Mr. Throneburg said the company will offer buyers of the single-family lots the choice of six builders. Buyers may choose their own architects for the custom homes. The project is scheduled to be completed in 1994.
Know in the past for horse racing, Florida now increasingly attracts enthusiasts of polo and equestrian events. 'When people used to think of polo, they thought of Beverly Hill,' said Deborah Clark, manager of the Merrill Lynch Realty office in Palm Beach. 'But Prince Charles changed that.'
The polo-playing Prince's visits to South Florida helped popularize equestrian events and have attracted second-home buyers, brokers say.
Mr. Throneburg said that although polo and the Prince of Wales - a photo of Prince Charles is displayed on an office desk - helps popularize a number of horse-related properties, he said the proximity of the new equestrian center will distinguish Equestrian Club Estates from the competition.
The 125-acre equestrian center at the Palm Beach Country and Polo Club features five show rings, including a 160,000-square foot Grand Prix ring with seating for 5,000 spectators, Four rental barns have been built, and plans call for building 12 more barns to house 1,024 horses.
As the equestrian center adds more year-round events like the Arabic Horse Classic scheduled for next spring, Mr. Corbin said, he expects that more people not involved with horses will choose equestrian communities for their year-round homes.
But the popularity of such communities poses some problems for the local government. 'We didn't anticipate so much horse traffic and, of course, there's the manure,' said Ed Lowder, cheif administrator for the Acme Improvement District, which governs Wellington.
Mr. Throneburg said he intended to market Equestrian Club Estates as a year-round residence for full-time equestrians and armchair horse enthusiasts.
'We're offering large lots that should appeal to those who want a permanent home,' he said. 'But I want this to be a place to come home to for those people out on the equestrain circuit, as well as people who just like to look out their window and see horses riding down the lane.'
Mr. Throneburg said he hoped that at least half of his project's owners will be year-round residents, adding that the new equestrian center should guarantee the success of his equestrian community. But brokers with experience in the equestrian market such as Mr. Corbin are cautious.
'Anything in Florida real estate can be dicey,' he said. 'But they're smart guys and there's a market out there to be captured.'

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 10, 1989

SECTION: Section 7; Page 13, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1204 words

HEADLINE: PRESNT AT THE SUPPRESSION

BYLINE: By SUSAN SHAPIRO;Susan Shapiro is a freelance critic and novelist.

 BODY:

TIANANMEN DIARY
Thirteen Days in June.
By Harrison E. Salisbury.
176 pp. Boston:
Little, Brown & Company. Cloth, $18.95. Paper, $10.95.
On June 1, 1989, Harrison E. Salisbury went to Beijing to make a television documentary for Japan's NHK network about the first 40 years of the People's Republic of China. The Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist for The New York Times, the author of ''The Long March'' and many other books on both China and Russia, stayed at the Beijing Hotel with his television crew. In the last five years Mr. Salisbury had spent almost a third of his time in China, and he knew the country well. But he did not know that from his window in Room 735, overlooking Tiananmen Square, he was about to witness and chronicle one of the most violent and mysterious upheavals in Chinese history. 
''Tiananmen Diary'' is, as its title suggests, written in a day-to-day format, beginning with the author's flight from the United States to Tokyo. On June 2, he arrived in Beijing, where Chinese students were demonstrating and calling for democracy, an end to official corruption and an honest dialogue with their leaders. The students were occupying Tiananmen Square, which, at a hundred acres, is the largest public square in the world. The Government had taken a hard line, proclaiming martial law on May 20. Troops were maneuvering on the outskirts of the city and deeper and deeper into the city itself. From news reports and personal communications, Mr. Salisbury learned that Beijing had been issuing warnings to correspondents, and that several aides to the ousted party secretary Zhao Ziyang, the leading liberal, had been arrested. Optimistic Chinese friends, however, assured him that the army would not kill students.
Mr. Salisbury searched for signs of unrest, but saw none. Instead, he found ''a lot of new planting along the highway, lovely flowers blazing in new beds. No troops hiding in the bushes.'' He saw, as the world did, the Goddess of Freedom, the symbol of liberty that the Chinese students had erected on May 30 in the center of Tiananmen Square. There were soda and Popsicle vendors, creating the atmosphere of ''a small-town summer festival.'' At that point ''there was nothing tense about the mood at Tiananmen as darkness began to thicken; instead, it seemed to me rather a holiday atmosphere. Young people hanging out, aimless sightseeing. Going to Tiananmen is the in thing.''
On June 3, he learned from friends, colleagues and foreign radio broadcasts that armed and unarmed troops had entered Tiananmen during the night. An army truck had accidently hit and killed civilians. Fighting between troops and students had erupted, with tear gas and clubs. Still, Mr. Salisbury was optimistic about the students' camp, with its cluster of olive-drab ''nylon half-moon tents'' neatly placed in horizontal patterns. The next day his admittedly sanguine perspective was shattered when he was awakened at 4 A.M. by heavy gunfire. In almost hourly entries, he records the bloody events of the day: the continuous barrages from automatic weapons, the explosions and screams. On June 5, as the cannonading and machine-gun fire continued, Mr. Salisbury was shocked to hear a foreign radio broadcast announce that the death toll had reached thousands.
For reasons of safety and work, Mr. Salisbury then left Beijing. Although he was frightened, he says, he did not go back to the United States. Instead, for the next eight days he toured provincial cities and towns in China and Hong Kong, filming his television documentary and preserving in his diary the enraged and confused voices of the Chinese people he encountered, while trying to make sense of the Chinese Government's cover-up and propaganda.
In the final section of the book, he offers a complicated analysis of what had taken place and why, noting the impact of the regime's economic problems and corruption. He cites China's ''geriatric leadership'' and 85-year-old Deng Xiaoping's failing physical health, mental decline and mistrust of the students. According to Mr. Salisbury, Mr. Deng thought the students were ''uppity, rambunctious, ungrateful,'' that ''they didn't know their place.'' Having let thousands go abroad to study and work, and having spent more money than any previous Chinese Government had on their education, he felt let down and betrayed. His temper overcame his reason. He believed ''that a plot threatening not only to overthrow the party but also to take his life and those of other leaders was developing under cover of the student protests.''
Mr. Salisbury traces the origin of the events of May and June back to the autumn of 1986 and the vicious campaign that forced Hu Yaobang to resign as party secretary in January 1987. This campaign against ''spiritual pollution'' was designed to combat the Western ideas that Hu had permitted to flourish. The army and the Public Security Administration then began, for the first time, to prepare for riot control. There had been rumors in March and April of 1989 of a possible comeback for Hu. His death on April 15 touched off immediate demonstrations at Beijing and other universities that rapidly evolved into the marches at Tiananmen Square. When the demonstrations escalated, the decision was made on April 26 to use force, but to delay any confrontation until after the Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev's visit of May 15-17.
Mr. Salisbury's firsthand account is written in a fast-paced, chaotic and colloquial style, which often feels confused and hastily set down. He interweaves maps, history, rumors, interviews, news reports, descriptions of what he eats for lunch and accounts of phone calls home to his wife in Connecticut. Rushed into print, the book lacks coherence, an overarching synthesis, yet in the end the material is so fascinating and so important that the rush seems justified.
The specific details lend the volume a particular flavor and authority, best shown by Mr. Salisbury's recital of Chinese graffiti. Slogans chalked up on walls included ''Good news: Deng Xiaoping's death is near!'' and ''Against Violence by Fascists!'' Spray-painted on the side of a bus was the slogan ''White Cat, Black Cat, Any Cat Is a Bad Cat!'' - a play on Mr. Deng's famous statement, ''It doesn't matter whether the cat is black or white so long as it catches the mouse.'' The author's idiosyncrasies, such as having Chinese friends autograph his old pacemaker and using a 1942 Remington portable typewriter, add to the human side of the story, as do his expressions of guilt: ''My presence may have encouraged them to stay and be mowed down. Was I just a Judas goat? The idea haunts me.''
Mr. Salisbury's political insights and informed theories provide the motivation and historical reference that were missing in the news media's extensive coverage of the Tiananmen Square massacre, while his intense and angry reactions make the events gripping and real. In a story that exemplifies the book's emotional tone, he tells of a young Chinese woman who, a day after the violence in Tiananmen, asked a supporter of democracy, ''What's the news today?'' The man replied, ''The news is that one point one billion hearts are dead.''
