PUB-DATE: September 10, 1989

SECTION: Section 12NJ; Page 1, Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1793 words

HEADLINE: Developer's Monorail Plan Scrutinized

BYLINE: By JEFFREY HOFF

 BODY:
WHEN Gov. Thomas H. Kean proposed a multibillion-dollar transportation system for the Hudson River waterfront in June, state officials acknowledged that the announcement followed months of lobbying by the Hartz Mountain Development Corporation to promote a monorail that would link its projects in the Meadowlands and the waterfront.
While no one questions the need for a comprehensive transportation system along the waterfront, no consensus has emerged among planners and officials on what is the best approach. Notwithstanding, the Hartz plan has raised questions about the feasibility of a monorail system and the role the developer has played in the formulation of the transportation plan.
An improved transportation system for the waterfront area has significant implications for Hudson County and the thousands of New Jerseyans who commute daily into Manhattan.
From 7 to 10 A.M. every workday, 1,000 commuters a minute cross the Hudson River into New York. Planners fear that the 80,000 workers and 50,000 homes in proposed developments along New Jersey's Hudson River waterfront will further tax the area's already overburdened transportation systems. Officials and developers are concerned that the lack of mass transit and highway access to the waterfront will threaten the viability of office complexes needed to improve the area's economy. 
The Governor's proposal, called the Circle of Mobility, is a collection of earlier suggestions by private developers and state agencies to link bus, car and rail transport to ease clogged traffic arteries through Hudson County to Manhattan. Determinations about which of the plan's elements will receive state or Federal funds await the findings of a series of studies to be completed over the next two years.
In addition to engineering and demographic factors, political disagreements remain between the State Department of Transportation and the New Jersey Turnpike Authority over which portions of the plan are most important and which should benefit from hundreds of millions of dollars at the authority's disposal.
The monorail proposal promoted by Hartz has won strong support from the authority's chairman and 11 members of Congress. The monorail would run from Hartz properties in the Meadowlands through a new tunnel that Hartz argues should be dug under the Palisades to its properties on the waterfront and south to Hoboken.
Hartz's plan, however, has been coldly received by State Department of Transportation officials who say other elements of the transportation ''circle'' would benefit more commuters at lower costs while the Hartz plan would principally benefit Hartz developments.
The transportation agency wants to use an existing tunnel under the Palisades linking the Meadowlands and the waterfront and operate a light-rail, not a monorail, system. The agency has pushed to establish mass transit in southern Hudson County, Jersey City and Hoboken, where there is more development, than in northern Hudson County, where Hartz has properties. The agency, however, has frustrated developers by showing no results after announcing such plans in 1985.
Because of that frustration, Hartz lobbied state officials to develop a transportation plan and as an incentive proposed a monorail. Officials say the Hartz proposal spurred the Governor to take action. ''I think the Hartz plan was one of the key things that started a lot of creative thinking,'' said Brenda S. Davis, the director of the Governor's Office of Policy and Planning.
Some, like Representative Frank J. Guarini, Democrat of Jersey City, see Hartz's monorail plan as ''visionary.'' Others, like David Phraner, supervising planner for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, caution that monorails have never really worked as a commuting vehicle in any American city.
Detroit is the only American city with a long monorail. The Detroit monorail, which makes a loop in its business district, was never intended as a vehicle for commuting. Still, the $200 million, 2.9-mile system was $65 million over budget and two years late. In support of its proposal, Hartz points to a monorail system, built by a Swiss company, being used in Sydney, Australia.
Hartz officials argue that it would be faster and cheaper to build a monorail because one can run on supports above ground and does not need expensive rights of way and environmental permits. Light-rail advocates say their system can run above ground or on street level, can carry more people and is more flexible because vehicles running on a rail could also run on the street.
Ralph A. Loveys, chairman of the Turnpike Authority, has sought to broaden the authority's mandate beyond highways to mass transit, which would allow his agency to build the tunnel and monorail proposed by Hartz. Mr. Lovey has offered to support the Hartz plan with $500 million initially earmarked for widening of the turnpike in northern New Jersey.
The offer comes as questions have been raised about the authorit's contract with a licensed lobbyist who also works for Hartz.
Dolores T. Prideaux, a member of the Turnpike Authority, voted against the extension of a $40,000 contract to the Marcus Group, a Secaucus public-relations and lobbying concern, at the authority's August meeting. Alan Marcus, the owner of the concern, is one of the state's most active lobbyists, with about 50 private clients.
Ms. Prideaux suggested that the Marcus company's work for the Turnpike Authority as it considered spending millions to aid Hartz was a potential conflict of interest. ''My problem with the Marcus people is that they also represent Hartz Mountain,'' she said.
Mr. Loveys said that Mr. Marcus, as the authority's lobbyist would seek support for legislation that would allow the authority to spend hundreds of millions on the monorail and tunnel desired by Hartz. Mr. Loveys and Mr. Marcus said that Mr. Marcus was not in a decision-making role in the authority and thus no conflict of interest existed.
Mr. Marcus strongly supports the monorail plan and said he had promoted it to the members and staff of the authority. But he said he stayed out of negotations over the Circle of Mobility plan.
Mr. Lovey added that while he had liked the idea of a monorail after hearing the proposal from Gene Heller, the Hartz president, he would not make a final decision on supporting it until further studies were completed.
The authority's bond counsel, Hawkins, Delafield & Wood, a Manhattan law firm, however, has cautioned that the authority may not be able to spend $2 billion originally earmarked for turnpike widening on the mass transit plan even with new legislation. Availability of those funds is crucial to the progress of any plan because other state agencies do not have money available and Federal support is low.
 
Allied Junction Plan Backed
Mr. Lovey is also supporting plans to build a new turnpike exit in southern Secaucus to link a proposed commuter rail station where four train lines would be brought together, easing traffic to the Jersey City and Hoboken waterfronts as well as Manhattan.
Yet that plan, known as the Allied Junction Transfer Station, which is being backed by a contribution of $100 million from another private developer, the Allied Junction Corporation has been given far less attention by Mr. Loveys and local members of Congress. Mr. Lovey said the Allied Junction plan, which could include a rail link to the Meadowlands sports complex, would cost some $190 million for a new turnpike exit and another $110 million for road links to Jersey City. It has not been determined where $200 million for track improvements will come from.
The Turnpike Authority is prepared to spend $750 million to $800 million on the Circle of Mobility effort to speed traffic into Manhattan and the Hudson waterfront, Mr. Loveys said.
Mr. Heller has retreated from initial reports that Hartz would absorb up to $100 million in expenses for the monorail and tunnel above the first $150 million from state sources. Mr. Heller now says Hartz would contribute land, services and cash worth about $10 million for a monorail system that may run beyond Hartz property in Secaucus west to the sports complex and south from Hartz property in Weehawken to Hoboken. The tunnel Hartz proposes would run under the Palisades, linking the Meadowlands to Weehawken or West New York.
 
'120 Reporters Listening'
 
Representative Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of Englewood, and Representative Guarini both support the Hartz plan. They said their interest was piqued after Hartz offered to build a baseball stadium in the Meadowlands. At a widely covered news conference last spring, Hartz officials pointed out that a tunnel would be needed under the Palisades to get people to the stadium from the Hudson River waterfront.
Mr. Torricelli now says he believes that Hartz never really wanted a baseball stadium but wanted to draw attention to the transportation plan.
Mr. Heller acknowledged that the ''stadium idea came about because we were talking about transportation,'' adding, ''All of a sudden we had 120 reporters listening.''
Both Representatives Guarini and Torricelli sent letters to the Governor seeking his support for the Hartz plan in June before Mr. Kean and Mr. Lovey announced the Circle of Mobility plan. Nine other members of Congress from the state signed Mr. Guarini's letter.
Mr. Guarini sent another letter to the Governor in July, again pushing the monorail concept, but received a heated response. In an Aug. 9 letter, Mr. Kean cautioned Mr. Guarini that ''Hartz Mountain has never prepared a complete written proposal for the construction or financing of this project.''
 
Light-Rail Plan Criticized
Moreover, Mr. Kean said that in a meeting with officials of the Transportation Department ''Hartz expressed reluctance to pursue the monorail proposal in favor of maximizing automobile access to their property on the waterfront.''
The Governor concluded: ''It is wholly inappropriate to describe the Hartz idea as the Hartz/Turnpike plan for the northern waterfront. Neither the engineering nor the funding is in place for their proposal.''
Criticizing Mr. Kean for not moving more quickly on plans to improve transportation along the waterfront, Mr. Torricelli has also dismissed the light-rail plan first announced by Mr. Kean in 1985 as too expensive.
Mr. Torricelli and Mr. Heller say that a light-rail system may be able to carry more people than a monorail, but that a monorail could be built more quickly.
''I don't have to worry about the year 2030 I am worried about 1990,'' Mr. Heller said. ''If the Circle of Mobility gets a light rail done in 1996, wonderful. Just attach it to the monorail.''

GRAPHIC: Photo of the monorail system in Sydney, Australia

LENGTH: 1647 words

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT Q&A: THOMAS A. AQUILA;
'Education Is a People-Intensive Business'

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
THOMAS A. AQUILA has been a member of the State Board of Governors for Higher Education since 1983 and this year he became its chairman. The board oversees a $433 million budget and it licenses and approves all academic programs at the public and private colleges and universities in the state. It also administers student financial aid programs.
Dr. Aquila, a resident of Weston, was schools superintendent in Weston from 1961 to until his retirement in 1982. He has been president of the Connecticut Association of School Administrators and now runs Educational Counseling Associates in Westport. Through the counseling service, he interviews students and recommends colleges based on their needs, interests and personalities. He also helps students file their college applications.
In an interview at his office in Westport, Dr. Aquila talked about the state's higher education system. Here are some excerpts from the conversation:
Q. About two-thirds of Connecticut's high school graduates go on to college. Are you satisfied with that? 
A. Yes, but I think what has concern for me is the large percentage of Connecticut kids who don't go to our educational facilities. About 66 percent of our kids go on to college, but of them 45 percent go out of state. That's quite a brain drain.
If you go after the reason, you hear that kids want to really get away from home. I think that's a little bit of a cop out. I'm not at all sure that the average Connecticut resident holds his state university system in as high in esteem as some residents of other states hold their university system.
It would be very interesting to find out what the attitudes are now and what the attitudes will be five years from now. Because of the low tuition rates, more and more families who would have normally gone out of state are now saying, ''What's wrong with UConn?'' We have a commitment to turn our university system into one of the top 15 or 20 in the nation by the year 2000.
Q. How are you going to do that, given your budget problems?
A. We're very concerned about that. Last year our budget went up about two-tenths of a percent, which didn't even keep up with inflation. The six years before that we spent catching up on maintenance and equipment and the book situation; we had generous budget allotments. Last year it hurt, and I expect it's going to hurt even more this coming year. We asked for a 6.5 percent increase, and got a two-tenths of a percent increase, whereas elementary-secondary education got pretty close to 20 percent. We have to have a higher priority than we have at the moment.
Q. How well has your minority-enrollment program worked?
A. That's one thing we can take considerable pride in. More minority students are taking advantage of the educational system. Since 1980, the minority enrollment surged to 17,000 students, up 38 percent. In addition, more minority students are earning degrees. The number of minority student graduates is up 36 percent.
Q. Why is racism on the rise on campuses?
A. I think it's a cyclical thing. I think you maybe see some concern, some envy, by the nonminority student saying: ''Well, they're getting admission breaks. They're getting tuition breaks. And my brother or sister can't make it.'' Their education has been limited in seeing there is an obligation, and it's not too surprising. Here we have the minorities living in our four largest cities primarily, not in the suburbs, yet when it comes time for college, we mix them up on our campuses. They've never learned to live together; suddenly, differences are obvious.
Q. What can schools do about it?
A. Just wringing our hands or being punitive is not enough. Education is the key. The earlier it starts in our lives, the better. What we're trying to do on the university campuses is to set parameters to show we won't tolerate it. By beginning there and by trying to bring right into the curriculum what this is all about, we will make progress.
Q. With 23 public and 25 private colleges and universities in the state, does Connecticut have too many institutions of higher learning?
A. In my judgment the answer would be an unqualified no, but I would say it's close. What we have to keep in mind is that most of the colleges are placed where they are for geographic representation. The enrollment is high at all of them, except at one private institution, the University of Bridgeport, with 10,000 seats and 5,000 kids. I certainly wouldn't be recommending we add any more universities. We don't need them, but what we do have seems to be functioning well, at least until you get to the technical colleges, where the enrollment is down.
Q. Enrollment decline was one of the reasons for merging the technical and community colleges. How is that working out?
A. We have now a single board of trustees. That group has met once, and there's a single-mindedness to strengthen technical education in this state. That's going to mean more funding for the system. And with the merger we have reduced the size of the central office, which was getting to be huge.
But underlying it all, we have to persuade families that it's O.K. for their children to get a technical education, that it's not only rewarding financially, but that it may be the way to go. You have to get into the high schools and inform the guidance counselors so they see this as a viable alternative.
Q. One question on parents' minds is why have college costs risen so much and how long can it go on? M
A. What we have to remember is that education is a people-intensive business: nearly 75 to 80 percent of its costs are salaries, and you can't ask those people to live on a lower standard of living than the rest of the nation or you lose them. So as a consequence, costs go up. And what we have is tuition moving ahead of inflation because it didn't for a number of years.
I have no clear vision how we're going to stop it. I see for the short term it will continue, almost at its current rate, although I see a decreasing incline. I think we have to look at our marketing a little harder to find ways to improve our revenues.
For instance, business spends almost as much as higher education does in training their own people, simply because many of the colleges are not responsive to their needs. It would be wonderful if we could find ways to tap part of that, to do the job for them.
Q. A couple of public schools have made it a requirement for undergraduates to volunteer for community service. Do you predict an expansion of that?
A. There is much to gain by having students realize as early as possible in life that it's not all ''what can I get?'' It's that ''I owe, and what can I give?'' And from that, everyone gains.
I think volunteerism is becoming a major plank in our lives. That's something the world has always admired about this country, and it's a more positive direction than I've seen over the last 10 or 15 years, when the drive was ''I'm out to get what I can and what I give in return may be a little bit to get the tax write-off.''
Q. For a long time college presidents moved up through the academic ranks, but now, a lot of schools are picking business leaders. What should the background of a college president be?
A. You should have a heavy concentration in the academics, be a scholar in some discipline. She would have published in her field. The individual would have vision, high energy, be people-oriented with superb communication skills, be practiced in collegiate management, which is far different from trying to manage a business. Someone who understands fund-raising and economic management theory. Someone who can work effectively with a very diverse constituency: trustees, alumni, faculty, students.
Given what's happening on a college campus, an individual with corporate training only is not enough. If the college is in financial trouble, there's a tendancy to want to go for a business type. Dartmouth did it. Trinity did it. Wesleyan did it. After that cycle's over and people have had it up to here with business management, they want the academic type. So they get the academic type, who is not raising enough money. It's cyclical. But the college president, unlike the corporate executive, has no real power. Whatever he gets done, he gets done by persuasion.
Q. A common complaint among public college presidents is it is hard to foster the kind of identification with alumni that the private colleges get, especially when it comes to fund-raising. Why is that?
A. The alumni I talk with have pride in their school, but there's a loose connection. They're not involved in any of the planning, any of the programs. Some may do some loose recruiting, if it's sports. They don't necessarily put any influence on their children to attend their school. But they do contribute. Not as much as you would find or expect to find at the private schools.
There's not a long, rich tradition yet within our public institutions. I would say, however, that the trend that I see - now that there is a major effort on the part of the public universities in new marketing techniques, actually having people in charge of development - is that their contribution rate is moving upward. The pride will increase.
At a great university, the loyalty is to what that school has done for me as a person, and as we get a larger and larger movement and we begin to really believe that school has done that for me and that I didn't get it in spite of, I think you will see the connection. At the moment it's loose, but it is better now than it ever was.
Q. If you could give one message to the students coming in as freshmen this month, what would it be?
A. I would advise them to leave their self-centeredness behind and to reach out and be of service to anyone in need. I would ask that they dream and accept no limits.

GRAPHIC: Photo of Thomas A. Aquila at his office in Westport (NYT/Stephen Castagneto)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (95%); 

STATE: CONNECTICUT, USA (95%); 

ORGANIZATION: BOARD OF GOVERNORS, CONNECTICUT

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 19, Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 561 words

HEADLINE: Where Addiction Is the Subject Matter

BYLINE: By SHARON L. BASS

 BODY:
IT carries titles like ''Fat Is a Family Affair,'' ''Is It Love or Is It Addiction?'' and ''If Only I Could Quit.'' And in less than a year, the Meridian Shoppe in Stamford, a bookstore that specializes in literature on addiction and recovery, has already turned a profit, its organizers say.
Most likely, they agree, it is because it is the only one in the state and one of just a few in the country. 
''When I learned there were 6,000 publications that come out every year which deal with addictions, the number just jumped out at me,'' said Manuel P. Fonseca, the executive director of the Alcohol and Drug Abuse Council in Stamford. The Meridian Shoppe, which opened last December, is a program of the council.
Typically, bookstores stock 6 to 10 titles that deal with addiction, said Joyce Hall, the manager of the shop, which has more than 300 books displayed by category in glass and wood cases. The shop is at 159 Colonial Road, in the same building as the council's outpatient rehabilitation program.
Mr. Fonseca said the store was conceived to raise money for the council's residential halfway house for recovering alcoholics, called the Meridian House. In addition to the halfway house and the outpatient center, the council also runs a community drug and alcohol prevention program.
 
Funds for Halfway Houses
''Halfway houses are economic nightmares,'' Mr. Fonseca said. Meridian House, he said, operates on a $350,000 annual budget, and much of its funds come from United Way campaigns in the area and the Connecticut Alcohol and Drug Abuse Council. He said he hoped the bookstore would supply the halfway house with 10 percent to 20 percent of its budget.
The books are geared to people with addictions to alcohol, drugs, sex and love, overeating, smoking and gambling. Ms. Hall said most customers previously ordered books through the mail or went to a bookstore out of state. Books on healing and meditation are also in stock.
Dena L. Anderson, a resident of New York City, was shopping at the store during her second visit there one recent afternoon. ''When I first came in, I loved it,'' she said. ''The literature keeps the recovery going. I spent $80 during my first trip here.''
In addition to books, the store keeps a modest selection of T-shirts, sweatshirts, license plate frames that say ''One Day at a Time,'' jewelry, bumper stickers that say, ''Honk! If You're a Friend of Bill W.'' (Bill W. was one of the founding members of Alcoholics Anonymous), and one slightly controversial item: cigarette lighters. ''They say to concentrate on one addiction at a time,'' Ms. Hall said.
While most books focus on addictive behavior, others deal with emotional healing and healthful living. There is an assortment of meditation books, a different one for nearly every type of addiction.
Ms. Hall, who used to be a night manager at the Meridian House, set up the bookstore. A recovering addict herself, she said she finds the store and the interactions with the customers to be healing.
Although the store draws people with addictions, many of whom are involved in the council's recovery program based on Alcoholics Anonymous, Ms. Hall said she does not find the atmosphere depressing or discouraging. To the contrary, she said, ''most of the people who come into the shop are looking for help and to make their lives better.''

STATE: CONNECTICUT, USA (91%); NEW YORK, USA (79%); 

CITY: NEW YORK, NY, USA (79%); 

ORGANIZATION: MERIDIAN SHOPPE (STAMFORD, CONN)

HEADLINE: Where Addiction Is the Subject Matter

HEADLINE: Farms, Food and Chemicals: Seeds of a Revolt

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept 10

 BODY:
Although the transition to natural cultivation has begun in several regions, the National Academy of Sciences' proposal to shift most of American agriculture from a heavy dependence on synthetic chemicals would take decades and require profound changes in attitudes and public policy,farmers and agricultural experts say.
The transformation, if it occurs in both farming techniques and agricultural policies, could also mean regional shifts in crop and livestock production in the United States.
For instance, Florida, which supplies half of all vegetables eaten in the United States in the winter, could be forced to grow crops less vulnerable to insects and diseases unless new pest control methods are developed.
And the intensive cultivation of irrigated corn on the delicate, erosion-prone soils of western Nebraska might be replaced by the growing of dry land wheat if Congress eliminates tax and crop subsidies that promote the use and development of irrigation systems, the experts say.
Jim Hightower, Commissioner of Agriculture in Texas, is a strong proponent of natural farming and says its time has come. ''What we've had here, and what we found elsewhere, is that farmers doing this kind of agriculture make money,'' he said. ''They pay off their notes; they pay for tractors and they do it without crop subsidies. There is a conversion coming.'' At Mr. Hightower's urging, Texas has established programs to help farmers practice organic farming and use techniques relying on fewer chemicals. 
Congress, which has historically considered natural farm practices to be whimsical and incapable of satisfying the food demands of the nation and export customers, also appears inclined to consider changes in farm policies that have encouraged farmers to rely on fertilizers and pesticides.
Lawmakers face pressures for a shift, ranging from the cost of farm programs - more than $136 billion since 1980 - to consumer concerns about pesticides in their food and pollution caused by agricultural chemicals to chronic food surpluses throughout most of the decade.
''I would hope that our colleagues will pay attention to some of these issues,'' said Senator Patrick J. Leahy, the Vermont Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee. ''Everybody is aware that we have to make some changes. It can't be business as usual as we go into the next century.''
''We have the responsibility to give these ideas a fair assessment and we haven't done that yet,'' said Representative Pat Roberts, Republican of Kansas who is an influential member of the House Agriculture Committee. ''Our responsiblity is to get the facts out and say, 'Look, we have the studies and this is worth a try.' ''
But there remain strong concerns in the agricultural community about natural farming. One concern is that the quantity and quality of food could be sharply reduced; another is that the cost of food could rise. Even supporters of natural farming concede this last fear could turn out to be accurate.
 
Step Toward Mainstream
Farm practices that use fewer chemicals took a step toward the mainstream of American agriculture last week when the National Academy of Sciences issued a report concluding that carefully managed farms growing diverse crops with little or no chemicals are as productive and often more profitable than those using pesticides and synthetic fertilizers.
In a lengthy study, the nation's pre-eminent scientific body urged changes in Federal policy and in research to encourage farmers to switch to natural farming techniques.
''Alternative farming practices hold promise for many other farmers and potentially significant benefits for the nation,'' the report said. ''How fast and how far this transformation of U.S. agriculture will go depends on economic opportunities and incentives, which are shaped by farm policies, market forces, research priorities and the importance society places on achieving environmental goals.''
 
Use of Biological Controls
Natural farm practices involve an array of techniques that use natural biological controls to do the same things chemicals do now.
For instance, instead of planting corn on a flat field, some farmers in the upper Middle West grow their corn in beds six to eight inches above the field, allowing mechanical cultivators to get to the ground around the plants to control weeds.
In Massachusetts, the State Agriculture Department has helped farmers learn techniques to reduce pesticide applications. And apple farmers have begun to control coddling moths, a voracious pest, with one application of diluted insecticide at the crucial moment when the insects are most vulnerable instead of 5 to 10 applications at predetermined times as was the common practice in New England until recently.
In California, the nation's largest agricultural producer, the transition to natural cultivation practices, especially in the fruit and vegetable industries, has been moving swiftly. Some of California's largest farms began to grow crops this year without any synthetic pesticides, joining hundreds of smaller growers. In the Salinas Valley, Tanimura and Antle, the nation's second largest lettuce grower, developed new vaccuum equipment to suck insects from the plants instead of killing them with toxic sprays.
 
Skepticism in Midwest
Fruit growers are using wasps and other beneficial insects to kill destructive ones. Across California, farmers are counting bugs in the field and spraying insecticides only when insect populations reach threatening levels.
''Given intelligent farming practices and given proper information, yes, in fact, we can greatly lower our reliance on pesticides,'' said Dr. Steven S. Balling, manager of entomology and pesticide control for Del Monte Foods, USA.
Grain growers in the Middle West and Great Plains are more skeptical. Over the last four decades, Grain Belt farmers were encouraged by researchers and policy makers to change from diverse small farms that also raised livestock into large, specialized farms that grow the same two or three crops year after year. Such farming would not be feasible without expensive equipment, generous amounts of fertilizers to boost yields and pesticides to protect the enormous harvests.
More than half the 430 million pounds of pesticides used each year on the United States cropland is applied on corn, wheat and soybeans in the Grain Belt, the Academy of Sciences study found.
Many grain farmers see a shift from industrialized practices to systems that use crop rotations and other natural farm methods as a step backward to an era when the work was more backbreaking and the profits not nearly as substantial.
 
'I'd Go Broke'
''What they're talking about is doing what we did in the 1950's with the cover crops and animals and spreading manure,'' said John K. Pellet, who farms 750 acres of corn, wheat and soybeans in Maryland Heights, Mo., 25 miles west of St. Louis. ''But if I did it now I'd go broke. My yields weren't near what they are today. My neighbors would outproduce me. We need the fertilizers and the herbicides very bad. I know what happens out here if we don't use them. The yields won't be the 150 bushels an acre I'm used to, and the weeds will be so thick out there you can't see the corn.''
Yet the Academy of Sciences argued in its report that switching to systems that involve planting more crops in rotation to build the soil's fertility and reduce pest pressures could yield the same size harvests while reducing operating costs.
One of the 14 farms studied by the Academy was Glen and Rex Spray's 720-acre farm in Knox County, Ohio.
Without using commercial fertilizers or chemicals since 1971, the Sprays had built their farm into one of the largest and most profitable in the region, the Academy said. The Sprays raise corn, soybeans, wheat and oats, along with red clover, white clover, blue grass and other pasture and cover crops. Their beef and dairy herd supplied manure, which was spread on 100 acres each year. Yields for corn and soybeans were substantially above the county average, and the cost of production was less, the Academy said.
 
More Research Urged
In the report, the Academy urged Congress and the Agriculture Department to play a more decisve role in encouraging the transition to natural practices. The report said the Agriculture Department should increase financing for research on natural farm methods from $4.45 million in 1990, to $40 million.
Dr. Charles E. Hess, Assistant Secretary of Agriculture for Science and Education, said the Bush Administration was preparing to ask Congress to increase the department's overall research budget from $1.2 billion annually to $1.7 billion to provide more money for research on natural farm practices and other scientific studies.
In the meantime, the study's authors urged Congress to enact changes in farm policies that now discourage farmers from trying the new techniques. Farmers participating in subsidy programs for grains, soybeans and cotton are now encouraged to maximize their yields to gain maximum benefits from the Government. The policy of paying higher prices encourages overuse of fertilizer and pesticides and chronic surpluses because producers strive for maximum yield for each acre instead of maxmimum return in the marketplace, the Academy said. The farm policy also discourages diversification into other crops not covered by the Government's farm program, the Academy said.

HEADLINE: Arkansas Spa Pushes Quest For Retirees

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Sept. 10

 BODY:
Hot Springs has an army of people who love to boast about mineral springs, pure air and cheap living in the Ouachita Mountains.
When a prospective settler calls the city-run Retiree Recruitment Office, the coordinator, Gail Ezelle, unleashes a force of 150 silver-haired volunteers whose bubbly enthusiasm matches this resort's hot spring water.
Dapper in matching blue blazers, breast pockets adorned with their names and the city logo, the volunteers court potential new neighbors with information about health care, expenses and recreation.
They escort guests up the 216-foot Hot Springs Mountain Tower for a panoramic view, then head downtown for a look at Bathhouse Row, which has been restored. The tour may end with a meal or a sunset cruise aboard a party barge on Lake Hamilton. 
 
Economic Effect on Community
The personal approaches have been potent. The Retiree Recruitment Office has handled more than 6,500 inquiries since it started advertising nationally last summer; it takes credit for 75 moves.
Part of its success stems from a 1987 Rand-McNally study listing Hot Springs as the nation's third most desirable retirement spot after the areas of Murray-Kentucky Lake in Kentucky and Clayton-Clarksville in Georgia.
To Mrs. Ezelle, 55 years old, who moved here from Texas, recruiting the retired is just like recruiting an industry. ''They have such a tremendous economic impact on the community, and they give us expertise and enthusiasm,'' she said.
But they do not bring some of industry's pollution, clogged highways and fluctuating work forces. The retired people arrive with average assets of $215,000 and average annual incomes of $33,000 a year, along with taxes and spare time to devote to community activities.
 
It's an Arkansas Tradition
Mrs. Ezelle praises her volunteers, who buy their own jackets, pay for their own gasoline and provide any extras like lake cruises or meals. The coordinator offers a toll-free telephone line and complimentary passes to the mountain tower.
Hot Springs is innovating on aggressive recruiting of retired people by applying the concept to an existing city rather of a carefully planned development for the elderly, said Charles F. Longino Jr., an expert on aging.
''Arkansas has been a nice place for people to retire for a long time, so they have a tradition up there,'' said Mr. Longino, who is the associate director of the Center for Adult Development and Aging at the University of Miami. ''But the difference with Hot Springs is they are really going after the retirees, instead of letting the retirees come to them. States have to kind of compete for retirees.
 
The Commuting Got Too Long
''They bring expendable income and lots of advantages. And older people rarely move someplace where they don't know anybody.''
Dick and Marge Bingham moved to Hot Springs in 1987 from Covina, Calif., their home for more than three decades. Mr. Bingham, who is 57, said he knew it was time to retire when he found his daily commutation to a securities office stretch from its average of 28 minutes to one and a half hours.
The Binghams were familiar with Arkansas because their daughter and grandchildren live in Mena, on the state's western edge. A deal on a lake house cemented their the decision. Once Mr. Bingham had lost his tensions after three months of relaxation, he decided to tell others about Hot Springs.
 
Everybody Knows Everybody
Marge Bingham, who is 52, says she was floored by friendliness. ''Out in California, it was so huge and impersonal,'' she said.
''We maybe knew our neighbors across the street and on either side of us. But here, we've already got 50 to 100 close friends, and 500 speaking acquaintances. I love it.''
Mr. Bingham says he likes to end a recruiting session by inviting guests onto his party barge, which is docked a few yards behind his home on Lake Hamilton. He doffs his blazer, takes the controls and steers the barge toward the setting sun.
His wife waves to a passing dinner cruise boat. Two dozen strangers wave back. ''See what I mean?'' she said. ''Everybody's friendly. Heck, in California, if a guy raises his hand like that, he may have a gun in it.''
The office generally refrains from criticizing other states, but it proudly displays a map shading in blue the states generating the most inquiries this year. In descending order, they are California (400 calls); Illinois (314); New York (291); Texas (265); and Florida (221).

HEADLINE: Medicaid Rationing Will Cost More in the End

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The proposal of New York State to limit the number of physician visits by Medicaid recipients (news story, Aug. 17) is yet another quick fix for a complex problem. Certainly, medical costs of all sorts are soaring, and certainly there are people who visit doctors needlessly. It is even possible that some of these unnecessary visits would not be made if patients were forced to pay out of their own pockets. 
Limiting the number of doctor visits is not, however, economical. People who are cautious (and I would wager that the majority of Medicaid recipients are) would ration their visits against a real crisis, thus neglecting ailments that, promptly treated, could be remedied easily and economically. Fearing to use up their allowed visits, they would, in the long run, cost the system more when those ailments reached an acute stage.
And those who cannot see beyond the immediate and save visits for the rainy day will continue to use the system as at present, knowing that in a real crisis they cannot be turned away from the emergency room. There would be no savings on them either. Of course, hospital emergency rooms might end up swallowing those costs, but that is merely a bookkeeping shift.
The blithe assertion by a spokesman for New York's Social Services Department that in real need, ''it's simply doubtful in most cases that we would overrule a doctor's decision,'' is not persuasive to someone who has seen a private health insurance carrier overrule two competent neurologists to avoid paying a legitimate claim for brain surgery. When people plan social policy that looks good on paper, they may comfort themselves with the thought that ''in most cases'' no one will be hurt. How much pain, injury and human cost is encompassed in the exclusions?
While we must, as a society, find ways to provide health care to everyone without bankrupting ourselves in the process, we must avoid solutions that are neither cost-effective nor workable. Until we find a reasonable solution, it seems to me, we are better off staying with the imperfect system we have.
 
HANNAH S. HESS
New York, Aug. 24, 1989

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Federal Reserve Doesn't Need Fixing

 BODY:
To the Editor:
One of the reforms Marriner Eccles achieved in the 1935 Bank Act was to remove the Administration from direct involvement in the central bank. He did this by removing the Comptroller of the Currency and the Secretary of the Treasury from the Federal Reserve Board. Eccles believed that the automatic majority of the seven governors (all political appointees) in the Open Market Committee, together with the President's right to appoint his own chairman, constituted sufficient politicization of the system. 
Representative Lee H. Hamilton's scheme to readmit the Administration by putting the Treasury Secretary back on the Federal Reserve Board (front page, Aug. 24) has less than nothing to recommend it. We have developed the childish custom of blaming the Fed chairman for economic slowdowns and crediting the reigning President for ensuing upturns. This curious rite has been accepted by the news media and, apparently, by the electorate.
The Federal Reserve System is one of the regulatory agencies that has survived the last decade without corruption, political or financial. The board does its job with few public defenders. It must accept in silence obloquy heaped upon it by self-serving politicians.
Even so, monetary policy has been managed with admirable objectivity and without overt guile. There are few enough Federal agencies with such a record of service. Our governments since the 1960's have reduced fiscal policy to annual deficit targets and the comedy of agonizing over the (ever-increasing) debt limit.
No public purpose can be served by immersing our best Federal agency in this morass. The Treasury interest will always be easier terms (lower interest rates) to finance future deficits. This should not be made easier, but Mr. Hamilton's proposal would assure just that.
 
JONATHAN HUGHES
Evanston, Ill., Aug. 24, 1989
 The writer is a professor of economics at Northwestern University.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Five Reasons to Transform 42d Street

 BODY:
A giant cylindrical sign, 27 stories high, gyrates on one corner. The Great White Way dazzles with the brilliance of 20,000 new bulbs. Late-night strollers wander through concourses of shops and food stands.
That's what Times Square could look like and it's no pipe dream. The developer George Klein and the architect John Burgee have now offered their revised plan for the transformation of 42d Street's most squalid and dangerous block. 
The plan, once sensible but lifeless, is now imbued with a vitality that answers any lingering doubts. The design can still be improved, but it shows how staid office structures can become, at night, colorful backdrops for the city's prime entertainment district.
The 42d Street plan has already won unanimous support from the Board of Estimate and survived 41 court challenges. There are five powerful reasons for it to move forward, as soon as the 42d challenge is heard and appeals are concluded: (1) To disinfect the dangerous Deuce; (2) to reclaim nine magnificent old theaters; (3) to produce millions in new city revenue; (4) to rehabilitate the seedy, sprawling Times Square subway stations; (5) to conquer, finally, the sour obstructionism that has come so often to strangle visions and to stifle growth.
The first reason is the most important. ''The Deuce'' is police slang for one of America's most dangerous blocks, 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. It was the scene of 2,246 reported crimes in 1988, of which 462 were murders, rapes, robberies and assaults. Another 468 felonies were committed in the subway passages.
Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch agreed long ago on an Urban Development Corporation plan for restoring the street's grand old theaters, now decaying movie houses whose sex and violence films mirror what goes on outside. Even so, no plan for restoring the block would have won Board of Estimate approval if the city had to pay. The 42d Street plan it approved not only spares the city any expense; it would bring in extensive revenue.
The idea is to consolidate the rights for potential high-rise buildings on the theater sites and concentrate development in four office towers in Times Square. In return, the developer must pay to rebuild two of the nine legitimate theaters and purchase six others. The city will receive more taxes from the finished office buildings alone than it now collects from the whole area. And the developer will pay more than half the $120 million cost of rebuilding the vast subway station.
Critics raise one objection after another. Some charge that the office buildings would deaden the theatrical district. That's hard to understand because there have been office buildings in the theater district for years. Theaters and office buildings require convenient transit, but at different hours; the combination seems desirable.
A more common objection is bulk and density. The new plan improves notably on the four gray towers previously proposed but even it includes a truly formidable hulk on the northeast site - which might still be moderated in size and appearance. In any case, any alternative will need to meet the plan's basic economic need: office floors large enough to attract tenants and to generate enough income to subsidize the public benefits.
Other critics claim that, as West Side development flowers, the block would be redone without government condemnation. Yet not one investor has sought to assemble the whole site, nor could any single developer make a move on one part of 42d Street without knowing the adjacent dilapidation and crime would be removed.
Litigation and criticism have brought improvements, like the enlivened new plan. Even it may serve merely as the beginning of further imaginative detailing. But the plan is sound. After eight years, the courts can be rightly impatient with arguments that could have been advanced long ago. It's time to proceed in Times Square.

HEADLINE: Judges Anguish Over Medical Issues

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RENO, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Saying they increasingly face anguishing decisions about medical cases, judges debated this weekend whether the courtroom is the place to resolve them.
''I don't think anyone here would ever say we enjoy this sort of decision,'' said Judge Gladys Kessler of the District of Columbia Superior Court, who was an organizer of the conference.
More than 90 judges from 47 states attended the meeting, and many said they were haunted by the prospect of a late-night phone call that, for medical reasons, required an immediate decision on highly complex legal issues.
Indeed the judges repeatedly asked themselves if they were being confronted with issues that courts were unequipped to resolve. Many complained that state legislatures were passing their responsibilities to make difficult choices in the biomedical area to the courts. 
 
Urged to Refuse Arbiter's Role
Alexander Morgan Capron, a professor of law at the University of Southern California, said in a keynote talk Thursday that a judge should refuse the role of society's ''bioethical arbiter'' or ''physician surrogate.''
Mr. Capron, who directed a Presidential commission on ethical problems in medicine, praised the courts for returning to patients the power to make decisions and warned that society could push the courts to take back those powers.
But Justice Stewart G. Pollock of the New Jersey Supreme Court said that judicial initiatives were frequently needed to stir debate and to open the way for legislative action.
Robert L. Schwartz, a law professor at the University of New Mexico, said, ''I've been distressed by suggestions that you should be timid. Social policy is made in large part through the common law.''
Also defending ''judge-made law'' as inevitable and useful, Justice Linda K. Neuman of the Iowa Supreme Court said, ''You don't have to be an activist judge to be concerned with social policy; it comes with the territory.''
While Mr. Schwartz encouraged judges to take an active role, he concluded they would find legal fields like constitutional law, criminal law, property law or family law inadequate for handling the fundamental problems raised by biomedical developments, as well as contradictory.
 
Conflicting Legal Approaches
Frequent groping among these legal approaches marked the judges' discussions. The judges were told of disputes like the Baby M case in New Jersey pitting a biological mother against the couple who had paid her to be artificially inseminated and bear a child for them and the case involving the conflicting claims of a divorced couple in Tennessee about control over previously frozen embryos. While some judges favored turning to contract law or property law for those cases, others argued that family law, custody principles and adoption practices were more appropriate.
Judges here considered those cases as well as hypothetical ones, including who should decide if a comatose woman should be disconnected from a respirator keeping her alive and whether a pregnant teen-ager who abuses drugs should be put in jail to protect her fetus.
Many judges acknowledged that their choices of legal approaches were guided by their initial intuitions of what outcomes they would consider just. But one judge, Addeliar D. Guy 3d of Nevada Circuit Court, provoked a sharp rection when he said during a heated debate on the withdrawal of life support systems from a permanently comatose woman was a foregone conclusion. ''The problem is not what to do with her but to find some way to do it and make it look good,'' he said.
Judge George L. Stigler of the District Court in Waterloo, Iowa, said a judge like him could not ignore that rural hospitals were being sentenced to bankruptcy ''if you allow individuals like this to languish.''
But for Judge Janine P. Geske, a Circuit Court judge in Wisconsin, such economic considerations were ''totally inappropriate'' in a specific case about suspending medical treatment.
 
Questions Involving Pregnancy
An equally sharp debate came when the judges discussed restraint or punishment of women whose behavior during pregnancy is likely to harm their fetuses.
All participants agreed that education and access to prenatal care ought to play the chief role in preventing harm to children before birth. But John A. Robertson, a professor at the University of Texas School of Law, compared extreme cases of harmful behavior by pregnant women to parental abuse of children already born and said parents should be held legally responsible in both cases.
Other participants objected that efforts to control the behavior of pregnant women legally rather than by persuasion threatened their right to control their own bodies.
Patricia King of the Georgetown University Law Center said courts would use sanctions more readily for poor women or those with criminal records , ''and we will talk next about their right to be parents at all'' and confront proposals for forced sterilization.
The conference was held at the National Judicial College on the campus of the University of Nevada at Reno and ran from Thursday through today. The college provides training for many of the country's trial court judges. The chief justice of each state was invited to send two judges to the conference, where they were joined by other court officials and representatives of major legal and medical organizations.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Reaction to China Reopens Old Battle

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
China has disappeared for the moment from the headlines and the newscasts, to be replaced by Poland and South Africa and Colombia, but the constriction of freedom in China continues, by all accounts, and so does the argument here about how the United States should respond.
''There is no clear road map as we feel our way through an ambiguous passage,'' writes Winston Lord, the former United States Ambassador to China, in the current issue of Foreign Affairs quarterly. ''We cannot practice business as usual; nor do we wish to destroy all the structures in place. We do not seek to hurt the Chinese people, but we also do not want to hand the leaders photo opportunities depicting normalcy.'' 
Both sides in the argument - to oversimplfy, the White House and Congress - agree with that. What they disagree on is what measures the United States should take to express its outrage at the crackdown in Tiananmen Square in June and what the Government has done since then, most recently in purging the culture minister, Wang Meng.
''The situation has been steadily worsening, with the hard-liners consolidating their power,'' said one of the Bush Administration's top China analysts. ''We don't question that. But China is difficult to deal with in the best of circumstances, and now more than ever, the executive branch requires the maximum latitude to make the relationship work.''
In other words, Congress should lay off and leave such delicate and important work to the professionals.
When President Bush visited China earlier this year, one of the senior aides who traveled with him recalled last week, Deng Xiaoping lectured his guests on his country's history for more than an hour. The main point being made by China's senior leader was that China had only two permanent adversaries, the Soviet Union because it occupied territory that China claimed, and Japan because it killed millions of Chinese in World War II.
The President drew two lessons, the adviser said: that the Chinese harbor grudges for a long time, that the United States must take care not to become the third country on the list, as it once was.
Thus the Administration is considering softening its opposition to Chinese membership in GATT, the organization that manages world trade, and it still hopes to soften or eliminate the sanctions against China voted by Congress this summer despite their relative mildness.
The House approved the sanctions 418-0, and the Senate followed with only a slightly less decisive margin. The two packages are attached to different bills and they contain some differences that will have to be taken up by conference committees.
''We would prefer nothing,'' said a White House strategist, ''but being realistic, it's obvious that Congress wants to express its disapproval. So we'll push as hard as we can for the greatest possible Presidential latitude. The House bill, for instance, bans some of our programs indefinitely and the Senate bill bans them for only six months. Obviously we prefer the Senate version.''
It is an old fight, this struggle for control of foreign policy, and it has a partisan and philosophical subtext, too. One of Mr. Bush's main foreign policy advisers argues privately, as do most other Republicans, that ''it's time that human rights stop driving our foreign policy, whether you're talking about China or South Africa.''
Most Democrats, like Representative Steven J. Solarz of Brooklyn, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Asian and Pacific affairs, still advocate giving as much weight to human rights as to realpolitik in foreign policy.
The contrast was drawn unusually starkly last month when former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger wrote in a syndicated newspaper article that ''no government in the world would have tolerated'' the students' occupation of Tiananmen Square, defending Mr. Deng as ''a reformer and a good friend of the United States'' and attacking Congress.
Mr. Solarz wrote in reply in The Washington Post that ''when the Chinese Government resorts to the wanton violation of human rights, it will inevitably pay a price with the American public and its elected representatives,'' and he denounced Mr. Kissinger's views as ''amoral.''
As Mr. Lord says, Washington faces a difficult period as it struggles to get the balance right.

HEADLINE: COLOMBIANS FEAR FOR THE ECONOMY

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 10

 BODY:
As Colombia's stepped-up campaign against drug trafficking goes into its fourth week, many Colombians are divided over the wisdom of trying to abruptly shut down the country's most lucrative industry.
Both Government and independent economists say that a sudden halt to the drug trade, which last year yielded $4 billion, would throw the country into a deep recession that might run four or five years.
''It should be reduced gradually over five or six years,'' said a leading economist, who requested anonymity.
The Government's anti-narcotics campaign has slowed dramatically since the first few days of raids and none of the major traffickers have been caught, although an economist accused of helping the Medellin cartel launder $1.2 billion was extradited to face Federal charges in Atlanta last week. But Government officials deny that economic concerns are a factor. 
 
'Committed to This Fight'
''President Barco is committed to this fight,'' a senior Government official said. ''I've never heard any Government ministers or important pressure groups argue that we should soften the effort for economic reasons.''
''On the other hand,'' he added, ''there are decent people who would prefer to keep things as they were.''
Immediately after President Virgilio Barco Vargas declared war on the drug traffickers on Aug. 19, 11,000 people were arrested and hundreds of planes, boats, cars and weapons were seized. But since then the traffickers have had the Government on the defensive with almost nightly bombings in Medellin, the country's drug trafficking hub, and sporadic attacks in the capital.
Today, the Associated Press reported that the Government had signed extradition orders for three more imprisoned Colombians. They were identified as Ana Helena Rodriguez, jailed in Bogota on drug trafficking charges, Bernardo Londono Quintana, 47, jailed in Bogota on money-laundering charges, and Alberto Orlando Gamboa, 37, held in Medellin on money-laundering charges.
The income from cocaine last year was more than three times the $1.2 billion expected this year from coffee, Colombia's leading legal export. Eighty percent of the cocaine consumed in the United States is processed in Colombia.
The Colombian Government, which insists that it is not dependent on cocaine and not influenced in its policy-making by cocaine dollars, says that most of the traffickers' earnings are stashed in banks and investments outside the country.
 
'It Could Be Disastrous'
Even so, Government and independent economists estimate that as much as $1.5 billion in drug trafficking profits circulated in the Colombian economy last year, accounting for 20 percent of the country's total export earnings. By some estimates, as many as 300,000 of Colombia's 32 million people may be directly or indirectly employed in the cocaine business and as many as 1.2 million may benefit from the proceeds.
''If the narcotics trafficking stopped suddenly,'' said Fernando Tenjo Galarza of the Department of National Planning. ''it would be like having a coffee crisis and oil crisis at the same time.'' A university economist said: ''I think we would see a very deep recession. It could be disastrous if you don't manage it properly.''
In recovering from a cocaine-induced recession, the economists said, Colombia would need substantial aid from the United States and other countries. Colombia would probably not ask for money, they said, but would expect American support for an agreement guaranteeing favorable prices for Colombian coffee as well as a reduction in import restrictions.
Colombia might also ask for leniency in repaying its $16 billion foreign debt, which is now devouring 42 percent of its export earnings.
 
Where Drug Barons Invest
Narcotics trafficking is an embarrassment to the Government and it refuses to acknowledge that tens or hundreds of thousands of Colombians are living better because of it. It makes no effort to track the flow of narcotics dollars and omits the income from official reports and calculations.
The drug barons have amassed fortunes that exceed anything previously known in Colombia. Often using ficticious names and dummy corporations, they have invested extensively in Colombian business and industry. But most economists say they doubt reports that the traffickers also own large blocks of corporate shares traded on the Colombian stock market.
The traffickers have bought millions of acres of prime farm and ranch lands and invested heavily in construction.
Jorge Enrique Vargas, the deputy director of the Department of National Planning, portrays the cocaine money as an unwelcome factor that distorts the Colombian economy.
In the last three years, he said, it has caused the price of real estate and houses to double. The finance industry has suffered, he said, because ''these people pay cash'' and food production has declined because workers have been lured away from farms and ranches by higher paying jobs in the drug trade.
The Government does not appear to expect a quick end to the cocaine business. It has developed no plan for coping with the loss of cocaine dollars, Government economists say, and no one is working on such a plan.

HEADLINE: Housing Plan Is Central Issue In Yonkers Primary Contests

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: YONKERS, Sept. 8

 BODY:
Local officials who favor compliance with a court-ordered housing desegregation plan have long felt that a majority in this city of 190,000 agreed that continued opposition to the plan was pointless.
That theory will be tested in Tuesday's primary elections, where candidates on opposite sides of the long-running housing dispute face each other.
The Democratic Party has primary contests for the mayoral nomination and for City Council seats in three of the six Council districts. The Republicans have Council contests in two districts; the Conservatives have a Council race in one district. 
In 1986, the city was ordered by Judge Leonard B. Sand in Federal District Court in Manhattan to build 1,000 units of low- and middle-income housing in mostly white neighborhoods to help remedy what the judge said was nearly 40 years of ''intentional segregation.''
Opponents have argued that the city was unfairly singled out and that forced integration will depress real-estate values. Those who favor compliance say that legal appeals have been all but exhausted.
 
Clear Test in November
Until now, the debate has been conducted almost entirely in the seven-member Council - six councilmen and the Mayor - where four members have been able to delay carrying out the judge's order.
For the clearest test of voter sentiment on the housing issue, observers will have to wait until the November mayoral election. If he wins the Democratic primary, Mayor Nicholas C. Wasicsko, the major proponent of compliance, will facethe housing plan's most outspoken opponent, Councilman Henry Spallone.
Mr. Spallone, the vice mayor, has used his Council seat to press for resistance to the housing plan. He abandoned a re-election campaign a few months ago to run for mayor, switching to the Republican Party. The switch allows him to avoid a primary contest with Mr. Wasicsko.
The results of Tuesday's primary will be studied for hints of support or opposition to the plan. Observers will have to interpret the results carefully because other factors, including a struggle among Democrats, may have a bearing on the primary contests.
 
Challenge to Mayor
Mr. Wasicsko, for example, faces a Democratic primary challenge from a former four-term councilman, Dominick Iannacone, who has the support of the city's Democratic leader, Ralph Arred. Mr. Iannacone's entry in the race was inspired by Mr. Arred, the Mayor said, ''to derail my candidacy.''
Mr. Iannacone ''has been silent on the housing issue,'' Mr. Wasicsko said., But Mr. Iannacone said carefully that he would ''not break the law,'' which means complying with the judge's order.
Mr. Iannacone, 61 years old, says the 30-year-old one-term Mayor not only lacks experience, but, with Mr. Spallone, has ''polarized the city'' on the housing issue.
In the Third Council District, where the incumbent Democrat, Charles A. Cola, died in June, there are two primaries. On the Republican side, John N. D'Agnillo, who says the plan will place a social and economic burden on the city, faces John L. Spencer, who has his party's endorsement and favors compliance with the court order.
The two Democratic candidates favor compliance with the housing order. They are Thomas G. Meier, who has Mr. Arred's support, and Barbara C. Cola, the former Councilman's widow, who played an active role in her husband's political life.
 
Outspoken Newcomer
The Fifth District offers another faceoff on the housing issue, but it also pits an experienced Republican incumbent, Nicholas V. Longo, against an outspoken newcomer, Thomas A. Dickerson. Mr. Longo, who has Conservative Party support, also faces a primary challenge on that line, from Alyssa A. Scelza, also a newcomer.
Mr. Longo is firmly opposed to compliance and has fashioned much of the strategy used by the Council majority in seeking to overturn or delay implementation. Mr. Dickerson is in favor of the housing plan. If Mr. Longo, an eight-term Councilman, wins his primaries, he will face George Oswald, the Democratic candidate, who opposes compliance, as well as Mr. Dickerson, who is also running as an Independent, in the general election.
In the Sixth District, two Democrats are seeking the nomination against the incumbent, Edward J. Fagan Jr., a Conservative-Republican candidate. The challengers, like Mr. Fagan, oppose compliance but differ in degree. Ralph Ferraioli, the party's choice, would limit opposition to court appeals, while Mel Ellen, a fervent opponent of the housing plan, would challenge construction at every stage.
In the First District, which has a 65 percent minority voter enrollment, a seven-term incumbent Democrat, Harry Oxman, is seeking re-election without Mr. Wasicsko's endorsement and without the support of a majority of local leaders in his district, although he has Mr. Arred's backing.
Mr. Wasicsko has said that while Mr. Oxman, who is white, has long favored compliance, he has not been vocal on the subject. The district leaders and Mr. Wasicsko are supporting Joe L. Farmer, an administrator in the Yonkers school system, who is black.

HEADLINE: Despite Skew Rates, Few Fear Recession

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
In the opinion of some analysts, tight monetary policies in the United States and other major industrial nations are at best likely to produce a slowdown in growth next year while increasing the possibility of a global recession.
For the first time since the early 1980's, the major central banks' desire to fight inflation has pushed yields on short-term debt securities in countries like West Germany and Japan, as well in the United States, Canada and Britain, above those offered on long-term bonds. In the past, this inversion of the ''yield curve'' has often been a harbinger of economic downturns.
But at the moment, the chances of a recession appear remote, the analysts said, in part because the inversion is slight in most countries and current conditions are far different than they were at the start of the decade. 
 
Inflation Difference
''The difference between now and then is that inflation was running rampant back in the early 1980's, and in order to brake inflation and regain credibility, central banks were forced to drive real interest rates to record levels,'' said Nicholas Sargen, a director in bond market research at Salomon Brothers Inc.
''Real interest rates around the globe are not as high now as they were then, and central banks won't have to push them up as high or keep them up as long,'' Mr. Sargen continued. ''There won't be a global meltdown. We think there will be a slowing of growth in the United States and the world economy.''
While bond-equivalent yields on short-term Treasury bills are currently below those offered on 30-year bonds, investors in instruments with maturities from two years and up can capture a higher yield than on the Government's bellwether 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019.
At the end of last week, the 8 1/4 percent two-year notes were offered at a price to yield 8.25 percent; the 30-year bond was offered late Friday at a price to yield 8.07 percent. Three-month Treasury bills were offered on a bond-equivalent basis to yield 8.01 percent.
The Treasury yield curve has been inverted or flat for much of this year, but outside of a slowdown in the goods-producing sector, there are few signs of economic weakness. Yet the fact that short-term interest rates have risen above long-term rates around the world is a reason to be optimistic about bonds, some market participants maintain.
''We are in a period of wonder right now,'' said James M. Benham, chairman of Benham Capital Management in Palo Alto, Calif., which has more than $5 billion in assets. ''But the fact that yield curves in all of the Group of Seven countries are inverted is bullish, because it is likely to create a slowdown in the world economy.''
 
A Warning
Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Company, said the inverted yield curves in major countries are a warning.
''They mean a slowdown in growth, which has already materialized here, will spread to Europe in the months ahead,'' he said, noting that the most prudent course would be less caution by the Group of Seven, which comprises the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy, and Canada. ''I think the Fed will move to ease rates very soon, probably within the next month.''
A slew of economic reports, many to be released Friday, could produce swift action by the Fed, though most analysts said the chances of that occurring are slight.
The figures include August retail sales figures, which should be strong because of healthy auto purchases, and a report on changes in producer prices last month. Analysts at Merrill Lynch & Company predict that the producer price index will register a drop of two-tenths of a percent, in large part, because of softness in energy prices.
An August decline in the index would mark the first time since early 1986 that producer prices have declined in more than two consecutive months. The index fell by four-tenths of a percent in July and by one-tenth of a percent in June.
 
Washington Public Power Issue
Elsewhere, new-issue activity in the tax-exempt municipal bond market is almost certain to pick up sharply this week after a slack summer.
Roughly $3 billion in new municipal issues could be offered to investors this week. The list includes a $450 million issue of refinancing bonds from the Washington Public Power Supply System, the utility's first offering since 1982, when it defaulted on $2.25 billion of bonds issued to finance two nuclear power plants.
Participants in the municipal bond market said they expected the sales to go well.
''When interest rates fell through the first half of the summer, municipals underperformed Treasuries, and as a consequence our rates didn't go down as fast,'' said Neal Atterman, a vice president and manager of municipal bond research at Kidder, Peabody & Company. ''That means that retail investors are likely to be back. This sort of supply will get their juices going.''

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Lag Expected For German Chemicals

BYLINE: By FERDINAND PROTZMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Facing an uncertain global economy, currency swings and new health-care regulations, West Germany's chemical industry, the fourth largest in the world, may be nearing the end of its six-year boom.
In the last few weeks, the nation's three largest chemical companies -BASF A.G., Hoechst A.G. and Bayer A.G. - reported quarterly results that signal another record year for an industry that had sales of about $90 billion in 1988, of which $17 billion, or 19 percent, was earned in the United States. But there are signs of weakening.
The results of Hoechst, for example, were below analysts' expectations, a performance attributed to weakness in its plastic division. The company did not release details of its plastic division's earnings, but said: ''The competition with polyproplylene increased. Sales stagnated at a high level.'' 
 
Revamping and Lower Costs
Stagnation at a high level could well describe what lies ahead for the German chemical industry, whose success can be largely attributed to far-reaching cost reductions and management reorganizations undertaken in the early 1980's, comparable to a phase that the American chemical industry has also undergone.
Profits in the industry as a whole are likely to decline by 1.8 percent in 1990, in the view of Peter Dietelmaier, an economist at Commerzbank A.G. in Frankfurt. ''But one must consider that profits are at their highest levels to date,'' he added. ''I wouldn't sound any alarm bells. They are stabilizing at a very high level. These high rates of growth just can't continue indefinitely.''
Like the global chemical industry, one area of concern for the German companies is overcapacity. Buoyed by surging profits in recent years, they have invested heavily in new plant and equipment.
 
Pressure on Prices Seen
''There will be massive new capacity coming into the chemicals market between 1991 and 1994,'' said Huber Gunter of Bank in Liechtenstein A.G. ''That is going to put a lot of pressure on prices, particularly if demand weakens for any reason.''
Some of the expansion was to prepare for the unified European market envisioned for 1992, but analysts said that may have been unnecessary.
''The West German chemical industry is already very international,'' said Jackie Ashurst, who follows the industry for James Capel & Company in London. Exports were up 10.5 percent from the year before and accounted for 53 percent of the value of the industry's sales in 1988, according to the West German Chemical Industry Association.
Unlike Japanese and American chemical producers, the German companies are more dependent on exports to other nations, including the United States, where they had a 7 percent share of the market in 1988. Much of its growing foreign presence, built through acquisitions in the current boom, is concentrated in a few product areas, like paints, plastic and fibers.
 
Mexican Paint-Maker Bought
On Aug. 29, BASF bought Aurolin, a family-owned Mexican paint producer for an undisclosed price. But BASF's most important North American acquisition to date was its $1 billion purchase in 1985 of the Inmont Corporation, the second-largest producer of paints and lacquers for the United States automobile industry.
In late 1986 Hoechst followed BASF's lead by making the biggest United States acquisition to date by a West German company with the $2.8 billion takeover of the Celanese Corporation, putting it in the thick of the commodity fiber market.
Bayer has chosen not to make any spectacular acquisitions in the American market, choosing instead to expand gradually its Mobay Corporation and Miles Inc. subsidiaries. Its rivals say that Bayer is not likely to make major foreign deals for the next few years while consolidating past acquisitions.
Their United States business activities have made the German companies more vulnerable to swings in the dollar-mark exchange rate, analysts said. If the dollar rises sharply, this can be a boon, but if it falls dramatically, it cuts into earnings.
 
Changes in Health System
Changes in the German national health system, aimed at cutting Government health spending, also loom as a threat. Some industry executives say they fear the changes could also erode earnings by pushing consumers toward generic producers and reducing demand for the products of the chemical companies.
Hermann J. Strenger, Bayer's managing board chairman, said generic producers cut the company's drug earnings by 30 percent in 1988 and he expected a further erosion this year.
