HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Latin America Records Some Economic Gains

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Despite a sharp contraction in economic growth last year, Latin American countries increased both exports and imports and managed for the first time since 1982 to reduce foreign debt, the Inter-American Development Bank said Friday.
In its annual report, Economic and Social Progress in Latin America, the bank found ''reasons for hope as well as disillusionment.''
Overall growth of the international economy was nearly 4 percent last year, mainly reflecting strength in the industrialized economies, but the growth in Latin America was just six-tenths of 1 percent, markedly below the 3 percent in 1987.
The Latin economies, the report said, were battered by a three-percentage-point surge in international interest rates between the first quarter of 1988 and the first quarter of 1989, which restrained growth and added $10 billion to debt service. 
 
Pressure to Export
With debt in Latin America totaling about four times the size of exports, every percentage point increase in rates requires a 4 percent increase in export earnings to keep even.
Yet in spite of the higher interest payments, the Latin debt fell to $426 billion at the end of 1988, from $441 billion a year earlier. Much of the decline occurred in Brazil, Mexico, Chile and Venezuela, whose lenders agreed to swap large amounts of debt for equity in various enterprises in those countries.
Bank economists project further declines this year as a result of Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady's plan to reduce debt by offering banks incentives to forgive a portion of their loans. An agreement reached between Mexico and its foreign creditors in July, for example, could lead to reducing the $54 billion of commercial bank debt of that country by as much as 35 percent.
For the average citizen in Latin American, the region's weak economic performance has meant a declining standard of living.
 
Measure of Decline
One measure of this is per-capita gross domestic product, representing total economic output divided by population. As populations were rising throughout the region, the per-capita measure fell by 1.5 percent last year.
Between 1980 and 1988, output per capita fell by 7 percent, or $176, after rising almost 40 percent, or more than $700, between 1970 and 1980.
The region also continued to be buffeted by a sharp decline in capital inflows and investment rates, a drop in foreign exchange reserves, continued high unemployment and rampant inflation in some countries.
''This has been a lost decade for Latin America,'' Enrique Iglesias, president of the bank and a former foreign minister of Uruguay, said at a news conference in presenting the report. He added, however, that the future looked better, citing the region's expanding exports and policy changes that focused on a market orientation.
The bank, a major source of financing for Latin America, recently was granted increased funds. It gets its money from the United States and other industrial countries.
 
Some Progress
Some nations, the report said, have made progress. Chile is the most dramatic example. In 1980 it owed $21 billion and exported $3.5 billion. By 1988 its debt shrank to $17 billion with exports up to $8 billion.
The region's exports in 1988 came to a record $102.6 billion, up 14 percent from 1987, surpassing the previous record $100.7 billion in 1981. Nearly all of the increase for the region was accounted for by gains by Brazil, Argentina and Chile.
Imports, at $78.2 billion, were the highest since 1982, though still nearly $25 billion lower than their peak in 1981. Imports were held down by the need for foreign exchange to pay interest on the debt.
Imports had also strengthened in 1987. The combined increase of $16 billion in the two years represented the first clear evidence of a much delayed recovery in Latin imports, the report said.
Many economists say the Latin import contraction accounts for a large part of the United States' trade deficit. Latin America is a traditional market for many American capital goods and other suppliers.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Argentina Faces Fight on Oil Plans

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Facing labor opposition, Argentina's new Government is pushing ahead with efforts to reorganize the deficit-ridden state oil company and increase private participation in oil and gas exploration and production.
The policy of opening up the oil business was begun under President Raul Alfonsin in 1985. Since Carlos Saul Menem took office two months ago, his Government has awarded 24 exploration contracts to private concerns, many of them foreign, including several American companies.
But as it moves closer to the promised sale of pieces of the state oil company, Yacimientos Petroliferos Fiscales, the Government expects a conflict with the strongly nationalistic views of the oil workers union. 
 
Rampant Inflation
The company, known as Y.P.F., is an example of the problems the Menem Government faces in trying to reduce the state's role in the Argentine economy. The effort will require bringing fiscal order and better management to more than a dozen state companies that account for most of the immense fiscal deficit, which, in turn, is blamed for the country's vulnerability to rampant inflation.
Octavio Frigerio, who was named by Mr. Menem to head Y.P.F., inherited a company with an operating deficit running at an annual rate of more than $1 billion. He said that much of the deficit was the result of selling gasoline at the pump far below international prices and that the situation had been corrected by raising them to about $1.50 for a gallon of premium-grade gas, more than three times what they were two months ago.
Mr. Frigerio said the basic requirement for reorganization of the state companies was ''mostly political.''
 
Against the Heritage
In deciding to turn the Argentine economy more toward free enterprise, President Menem is going against the heritage of his Justicialist Party and the political movement founded four decades ago by Juan D. Peron. Until now, its basic tenets had been economic nationalism and a big role for the state in the economy.
The choice of Mr. Frigerio to run Y.P.F. reflects the drastic shift that Mr. Menem has led in his party. Mr. Frigerio is an economist known for free-market thinking, and not a Peronist. His father, Rogelio, was a leading adviser to President Arturo Frondizi, whose 1958-62 Government unsuccessfully attempted a similar opening of the economy.
Many in Peronism, including the labor movement, the traditional backbone of the party, still differ with Mr. Menem. The union representing the 36,000 state oil workers has been in the forefront of opposition.
Diego Ibanez, secretary general of the oil workers union, declined to be interviewed, but his public statements suggest that he wants Argentine oil production to be used mainly to assist the nation's industrial growth, without the country trying to become an exporter, and that he does not want Y.P.F. broken up.
 
'Mix of Distinct Interests'
Mr. Frigerio said he considered the labor opposition to his plans to be based on ''a complex mix of distinct interests, part ideological and partly an attempt to protect old corporativist privileges.''
The term corporativism is used in Argentina to describe the custom of interests, like labor and private enterprise, negotiating shares of power and income without concern for productivity, quality or competition.
Mr. Frigerio said he believed that the oil workers would be better off in the long run ''if Y.P.F. becomes professional, modern and internationally competitive.''
Before the end of the year, Mr. Frigerio said, he expects to come up with a plan to sell pieces of the firm as private operations. Possibilities include the shipping fleet, the drilling activity and the gas stations. Then, he said, the production section would remain as a much smaller firm or would disappear as private companies took on its functions.
He said the Government was not making any plans to dismiss oil workers, even though he said that their salaries were double the national average for industrial wages and that he thought it took ''about four people in Y.P.F. to do what one person does in a private firm.'' He said he had found Y.P.F. to be ''organically inefficient.''
 
No Confrontation
Despite this, he said he was not going to confront the union over the size of the work force because salaries account for only 6 percent of the Y.P.F. budget. Argentina has no unemployment insurance system, another reason the Menem Government is trying to avoid dismissals.
Until the Alfonsin Government initiated the change in oil policy, the oil business in Argentina was dominated by the state. The private companies here either worked on drilling contracts for Y.P.F. or exploited fields after Y.P.F. abandoned them. Now, the emphasis is on private exploration, with production itself to be either by Y.P.F. or the private companies.
The exploration contracts signed in the last two months constituted the fourth round in the series of auctions of exploration rights begun in 1986. The companies that signed those contracts are expected to invest $266 million.
The extent of Argentina's oil and gas reserves is unknown because only a small percentage of the sedimentary basins, both on land and offshore, has been explored. The country is considered self-sufficient in oil.
Many Argentine oil experts contend that the country would never be an important oil producer, but Mr. Frigerio said that is a premature judgment.
''I think we could have a lot of oil,'' he said, ''and, above all, a lot of gas.''

LENGTH: 1502 words

HEADLINE: Yeltsin, the Moscow Populist, Takes Manhattan (in Stride)

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN

 BODY:
When he spotted the Statue of Liberty yesterday from the window of a circling helicopter, Boris N. Yeltsin smiled broadly and applauded. Then, in a spontaneous gesture of delight, he gave a lusty thumbs-up sign - as if he, the maverick prince of the Soviet Communist Party, and she, the symbol of American freedom, have a special thing going.
Mr. Yeltsin, 58 years old, a leader of the Soviet Union's first independent parliamentary caucus, spent the first full day of his first trip to the United States embracing much of the American way of life - even as he sounded notes of warning about the difficult times faced by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev back home.
''All my impressions of capitalism, of the United States, of Americans that have been pounded into me over the years, including by the Short History of the Communist Party - all of them have changed 180 degrees in the day and a half I have been here,'' said Mr. Yeltsin, whose populist politics have won him a large following in Moscow.
He said he hoped for a meeting with President Bush in Washington at which he would outline in detail how the United States could help Mr. Gorbachev's program of restructuring. 
 
Criticizes 'Half-Measures'
As for Soviet society, Mr. Yeltsin told reporters yesterday that it is facing its worst crisis of several decades - economically, socially and politically. He voiced criticism of the ''half-measures'' and ''compromises'' taken by his former ally, President Gorbachev, but discounted some of the more alarming predictions being made about the Soviet Union.
''A coup d'etat is pretty unrealistic,'' said Mr. Yeltsin, who lost his seat on the ruling Politburo and then his job as Moscow party leader after making a particularly frank speech at a party meeting in 1987. He dismissed talk of a civil war - raised by Mr. Gorbachev in a television address to the Soviet people on Saturday night - as a ''useful scarecrow to scare people with.''
Mr. Yeltsin made it clear that he intends this eight-day trip - sponsored by the Esalen Institute's Soviet-American Exchange Program - to be as much a chance to learn how to propel Soviet restructuring forward, as to lecture about it.
 
Learning From America
''We have to learn lessons from America - how to work, how to learn, how to enjoy life,'' he said as he took his entourage on a brisk walking tour around the southern rim of the Central Park Reservoir in the hot sun, alternatively damping his brow with a handkerchief and gulping down a Pepsi-Cola.
A native Siberian known for his physical strength, Mr. Yelstin turned his energy loose on Manhattan almost as soon as he and his small entourage arrived on Saturday afternoon. By midnight they had managed a walking tour of Fifth Avenue, a dinner at a Chinese restaurant, a close examination of the fresh fruit and working habits of a Korean grocery, a quick trip to the 102d floor of the Empire State building and a brief chat with a group of homeless people protesting outside the United Nations.
''They were complaining the Government does not give a place to live,'' Mr. Yeltsin said, ''but while they were protesting, they seemed quite good-natured.'' Aides said the conversation, joined by a dozen people who seemed to recognize the tall, broad-shouldered man with a shock of white hair, turned quite jocular as people suggested an exchange between the homeless of New York and Moscow.
The next morning, before brunch with a small group of business leaders and economists, Mr. Yeltsin, an engineer and chairman of a parliamentary committee on architecture and construction, went on a tour of Trump Tower on Fifth Avenue, casting an expert eye on the brass-and-glass atrium.
His host in New York, Robert Schwartz, a former journalist who has worked closely with Esalen's East-West exhange programs, then took him on a helicopter tour of the city and to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. There, he made a direct line for the Flemish painters and the Impressionists, giving short shrift to modern art, except for one short, stunned look at the giant poster of Mao by Andy Warhol.
 
Department Store Skipped
The original schedule had included a visit to Bloomingdale's, but Mr. Schwartz said Mr. Yeltsin had quickly vetoed the idea. ''He said forget it,'' Mr. Schwartz said. ''He said if he didn't go to the Metropolitan, New Yorkers would never forgive him, and neither would Muscovites.''
When he was named Moscow party leader in 1985, Mr. Yeltsin soon made his mark as a streetwise politician, sending out the message that he had traded his Zil limousine for the city's crowded buses, publicly attacking the privileges reserved for the party elite.
Yesterday in New York - where six candidates are winding up real mayoral campaigns before Tuesday's primary elections - Mr. Yeltsin gave passers-by a hearty Russian version, with handshaking at every turn, quick quips and even one episode of baby-kissing on Central Park West.
''He doesn't come out of the tradition of Marx or Jefferson,'' said an American member of his entourage, perhaps thinking more in terms of Harry S. Truman. ''He comes out of the Pendergast machine in Missouri.''
 
Gives U.S. Benefit of Doubt
But wherever comparisons could be made, Mr. Yeltsin seemed to give the benefit of the doubt to the American way of doing things - listing ability to govern with a two-party system, protection of individual rights, direct elections, antitrust laws and religious tolerance. ''I think you have a very healthy society,'' he told reporters.
Besides such theoretical advantages, Mr. Yeltsin had good reviews based on his own observations. The Chinese dinner was ''10 times better'' than the fare at the average cooperative restaurant in Moscow, he declared, and not that expensive on an average American salary.
Looking out the window of the helicopter at the Alfred E. Smith public housing complex along the East River, he declared the apartments to be ''Khrushchevki,'' or Soviet housing units built during the Khrushchev era, now mostly rundown. ''In our terms, your buildings look more comfortable,'' he told reporters later.
But perhaps the most impressive sight so far was the Korean grocery, where, he said afterwards, ''everything was so clean, so tidied up, with only one man serving all those people.'' He had taken careful note of the variety of fruits and vegetables - one of the most painful shortages facing Soviet consumers - and their prices, declaring that they, too, were ''not bad for an average American salary.''
 
'It Can't Get Any Worse'
The day when Soviet shoppers will see such an array is still far off, he said in an interview during a walk through Central Park. ''The situation is so bad, it can't get any worse,'' he said. ''There are even lines for bread now in some parts of the Soviet Union. But we will not be able to decide this problem with half-measures and compromises.''
''Compromise should be a temporary policy,'' he said. ''But Gorbachev has pursued a policy of continual compromise.'' Mr. Yeltsin is a leader of an inter-regional group, made up of several hundred deputies to the Supreme Soviet, or Parliament, that seeks to offer alternatives to Government policy. He said no real change in strategy is possible until ''one-half of the Central Committee and one-half of the Politburo are changed at the upcoming 28th Party Congress. Until then, it will be impossible to carry out perestroika to its conclusion.''
Both privately and publicly, Mr. Yeltsin reserved his harshest comments for his longtime opponent, Yegor K. Ligachev, a member of the Politburo now in charge of agriculture. At an afternoon news conference, Mr. Yeltsin accused Mr. Ligachev of ''spewing venomous saliva,'' and during the visit to the Korean grocery he privately mocked Mr. Ligachev's efforts at reforming Soviet agriculture.
He waved toward the stands stacked with fresh produce, one aide reported, and said contemptuously, ''And Ligachev is still holding seminars.''
 
Calls Restructuring Necessary
Although he said the Soviet Union needed someone ''more decisive'' than Mr. Gorbachev, Mr. Yeltsin said at the news conference that his criticisms should not be seen as undercutting Mr. Gorbachev's position. The collapse of the Soviet President's efforts to restructure society would be ''a tragedy, and not only for our country,'' he said.
But changes in Soviet politics have only just begun, he said. With crucial local elections due before the end of the year, he called for a greater separation between the Communist Party and the Government. ''Things are not as they should be in the future,'' he said. With greater political decentralization, he said, some of the national problems that are now plaguing Moscow will recede.
He said that if a meeting with Mr. Bush took place, he would outline proposals on how the United States could help the process, including a proposal that would allow direct investment by American businesses in the Soviet Union.

LENGTH: 715 words

HEADLINE: Is Bush Repeating Rockefeller's Folly?

BYLINE: By Stephen Gillers; Stephen Gillers is professor of law at New York University Law School.

 BODY:
If Miguel Ruiz were alive today, he might tell George Bush a thing or two about getting tough on casual drug users, one objective of the President's new drug plan.
Fifteen years ago, as a young court-appointed lawyer, I represented Mr. Ruiz (this is a pseudonym) following his arrest under Gov. Nelson Rockefeller's tough new drug law. As Mr. Ruiz and hundreds like him were herded daily before new judges and prosecutors in bright new courtrooms, they were living proof of the gulf between political rhetoric and what toughness can actually deliver.
Mr. Ruiz, in his mid-30's and employed, lived alone in a rented room. He had no criminal record. He spent evenings with friends in a Manhattan bar, where they talked, drank beer and took trips to the bathroom to ingest cocaine. They had no trouble buying the drug, which had not yet achieved notoriety. 
In Mr. Ruiz's group, whoever bought the cocaine shared it and got reimbursed. On a day that Mr. Ruiz happened to be the supplier, one of his newer ''friends'' turned out to be a police officer, who paid him for a portion then busted him for selling it.
Under the new law, Mr. Ruiz faced life in prison with no parole for seven and a half years. The prosecutor offered to let him plead to a crime that carried a life sentence, with eligibility for parole after one year. This was the best deal the law allowed.
Mr. Ruiz's cocaine habit made it hard to discuss the offer. He could be enraged one minute, docile the next. He had trouble concentrating. But most of all, he could not understand why anyone would want to lock him up even for a day just because he shared cocaine with his friends.
Most Rockefeller defendants took the deal. It would be the officer's word, supported by a tape recording and the actual drug, against theirs. And many defendants, like Mr. Ruiz, could not even tell their story. The act of attempting to testify would reveal to the jury unmistakable symptoms of prolonged drug use.
But Mr. Ruiz didn't want to plead guilty. If he went to prison, he said, he would lose his job and his room. He wanted a trial to explain this to the judge. My effort to tell him that he faced a sentence seven times longer if he was convicted caused him to suspect me. He seemed to believe that imprisonment was my idea, that the judge would be more reasonable.
Eventually, he accepted a sentence of one year to life. I heard later that he died in prison. Had he lived, he would have left prison homeless and unemployed.
New York, like other states and the Federal Government, has responded to people like Mr. Ruiz in three ways. At times, it has been generally content to ignore them. Occasionally, it has offered treatment. Under the Rockefeller drug law, it designated them a grave danger to the social fabric, people who had to be stopped through tough law enforcement.
Echoing the former Governor, the President has made ''getting tough on drug criminals'' the first ''element of our strategy.'' Miguel Ruiz might have told the President that broad get-tough strategies mainly catch people like him, people for whom drugs are part of a social subculture, not a criminal enterprise.
A year from now, the White House will cite numbers to prove the success of the President's plan. So many thousands arrested, convicted and sentenced to so many millennia in prison; so many tons of this or that drug seized, having a street value of so many millions of dollars; so many new prison cells, police officers and prosecutors built or employed.
To impress, these numbers have to be big. The surest way to get big numbers is to arrest people like Miguel Ruiz. There are lots of them and they are easy to catch.
Governor Rockefeller also relied on numbers. He didn't identify the people behind them, but we in the bright new courtrooms knew who they were. The millions spent to imprison Mr. Ruiz and others had no effect on the drug trade.
After Rockefeller left office, New York overhauled his law, silently acknowledging what Miguel Ruiz, his brain addled from cocaine use, already knew, although Mr. Bush may not. Prosecuting adults because they casually use and share drugs, however unfortunate that may be for them and those who love and depend on them, costs a lot, makes hard lives worse and accomplishes nothing.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: The Dream Of Reunion;
Idea of One Germany Gains New Currency

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
As thousands of East Germans seeking freedom streamed across the Hungarian border to Austria and West Germany today, the ''German question,'' the dream, or fear, of German reunification, also came alive with them.
''It's still not going to happen any time soon, but there's beginning to be serious thought about it,'' a senior American diplomat said. ''It's not just a pious platitude anymore. You have to think about what it really means.'' 
West Germany's European allies gave lip service to the idea for years, precisely because it was out of the question. Today, it is being debated again publicly not only in Britain and France, which have always been afraid of it, but also in West Germany, where for the first time in years it is not taboo.
 
Guilt, Shame and Debate
As a headline on the front page of the weekly Die Zeit this month described the ''guilt and shame'' felt by Germans on the 50th anniversary of the start of World War II, interviews and articles inside discussed how best to overcome the main consequence of it for Germany, the division of the country.
Fritz J. Raddatz, an author not given to romanticizing in the past, wrote a nostalgic ''brief for German unity,'' arguing that the idea was unthinkable only for people who were unimaginative, but should not be for the visionaries who make history.
And, he asked, ''where is it written in stone that both Germanys have to maintain armies?''
The implication of that question -that the two remnants of Germany could become one again, neutralized instead of firmly in the clutches of their respective alliances - is precisely what many in Britain and France fear most, despite constant reassurances from governments of whatever political party in Bonn.
 
Disintegrating Forces
''What we are envisaging is the gradual emptying of NATO's content and a growing divergence in political direction between Germany on the one hand, and Britain and France on the other,'' Peregrine Worsthorne wrote in the conservative Sunday Telegraph over the weekend.
''And this in turn would mean an end to all dream of a 'political Europe.' Disintegrating forces are at work not only within the Russian empire.''
Francois Heisbourg, director of the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London, said in an interview: ''Most of what has been happening is attributable to Mikhail S. Gorbachev. When he visited Bonn in April, what I saw was that the West Germans really considered the cold war was over, and that other items could come to the fore.''
Perceptions of President Gorbachev, and of the meaning of the changes unleashed in the Soviet Union, Poland and Hungary since he came to power, differ significantly between Bonn, Paris and London. What the others often overlook is that West Germany feels the effects of changes in the East sooner, and more directly, than they do, whether the change involves arms or emigration.
''We've always operated on the assumption that the Russians would never agree to reunification of Germany, but I'm not so sure any more,'' a high-ranking British official said. ''Recently they've hinted that they might accept it, under the right conditions.''
Those are generally believed to require the neutrality of any united Germany, something that would shake the European Community and NATO as fundamentally as it would the Warsaw Pact.
 
Bonn's Growing Role in East
No responsible West German political leader has even raised the possibility of leaving NATO and declaring neutrality. West Germany has sought its destiny up to now in the context of a firm commitment to the process of Western European integration, coming to terms with its eastern neighbors in hopes of easing economic and political pressures there.
Most of the Germans' neighbors, east and west, hoped they really meant it, but their belief is still easily shaken as Bonn's economic role in Eastern Europe grows.
Lech Walesa, leader of the Solidarity movement that dominates the new Polish Government formed after free elections there, spent last week visiting West Germany, though Polish officials have also been pleading with other Western countries for economic aid to help avert collapse.
Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who is to see Mr. Gorbachev in Moscow on Sept. 23, recently wrote to President Bush and President Francois Mitterrand suggesting discussions on how to better concert help to Hungary and Poland to encourage them to move toward democratization and freer economic conditions.
 
Idea Gaining Validity
East Germany's refusal to do so is causing many Germans to take up Bonn's offer of citizenship to oppressed Germans everywhere, and giving the idea of German unity a validity in other European countries that it has not had since the height of Soviet repression in the 1950's.
''The time for hypocrisy is past,'' Peter Millar wrote in The Sunday Times over the weekend.''For 40 years Western politicians have sympathetically clucked when their colleagues from Bonn made lachrymose speeches about their 'divided fatherland,' while privately congratulating each other on letting the Russians keep the Hun in place.''
Luc Rosenzweig, the Bonn correspondent of Le Monde, told a German television audience the same day, ''The Germans could gain a lot more sympathy if they would end the absurd pretension that reunification would take place within the prewar borders of 1939.''
Mr. Heisbourg said: ''The notion of returning to a previously existing Bismarckian state, which the word 'reunification' implies, is something that nobody wants, including most Germans. The Germans sometimes use the expression 'new unification' to describe what is more plausible. But it cannot happen without the involvement of the great powers, because of their status in the division of Berlin.''
An adviser to Mrs. Thatcher said: ''One of the reasons why all this is happening in Eastern Europe is the success of the Western alliance. But it's definitely fasten-your-seat-belts time.''

HEADLINE: CAR MAKERS WEIGH GASOLINE CHANGES TO CUT POLLUTION

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 11

 BODY:
The Big Three auto makers are close to joining leading oil companies in testing the feasability of using reformulated gasoline instead of methanol or other alternative fuels to meet stricter clean-air standards proposed by the Bush Administration.
The Administration proposal, submitted to Congress in June, calls for the auto industry to begin producing up to a million vehicles annually by the mid-1990's that would burn an unspecified ''alternative fuel.''
Officials of the Environmental Protection Agency, as well as some officials in Southern California, are thought by the oil and auto industries to favor methanol, but those industries have serious reservations.
 
Pilot Models Being Tested
The Ford Motor Company, the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation have all expressed confidence that they can build methanol-burning vehicles in quantity, if required to do so, by the mid-1990's; Ford and G.M. are now testing pilot models in California. 
But auto executives also worry that short of a law requiring the purchase of such vehicles, consumers may ultimately reject methanol vehicles, leaving the companies to bear the financial brunt of the law.
The research project under discussion would examine various reformulations of gasoline, as well as fuels like methanol, ethanol, natural gas and perhaps others. Tests would provide data on the nature of emissions and performance characteristics of the fuel when burned by engines now built by Detroit, said Helen O. Petrauskas, a Ford vice president.
 
Vote by Early 1990 Seen
Mrs. Petrauskas said she hoped the project could begin ''within a few months'' so a great deal of data would be accumulated in advance of rule-making hearings that would start 18 months after the passage of a bill. Many in the industry and the Government believe a bill could be put to a vote by early 1990. ''The sooner we get started, the more data we'll have when rule-making starts,'' she added.
In the past, the auto makers and the oil companies have conducted joint research on other issues of mutual interest, like motor oils and lubricants, through committees of the Motor Vehicles Manufacturers Association. But few projects have held as much potential for making an impact on the way cars are designed - of the way fuel is processed and delivered - as the project under discussion.
Oil companies have billions of dollars invested in gasoline refineries in the United States and abroad, and industry officials say they prefer to comply with provisions of any new law by providing a reformulated gasoline.
''What we're looking for is a level playing field so that every fuel that might be a cost-effective solution to the problem might have a chance to compete,'' said Keith McHenry, a senior vice president of the Amoco Corporation, a major oil refiner. ''We want to find the truth. We'd prefer to sell reformulated gasoline, but if the research shows that methanol is the best solution, we'll sell methanol.''
Privately, Federal environmental officials insist that oil industry lobbyists are waging a behind-the-scenes political battle to remove methanol and other non-gasoline alternatives from consideration.
 
Many Issues Not Resolved
Conversely, auto and oil industry officials believe E.P.A. officials are predisposed in favor of methanol, even though many technical and other issues have not been resolved, like how to inhibit emission of formaldehyde from methanol-burning engines. Another serious drawback of methanol is that it contains less energy than gasoline, and thus vehicles would have to be redesigned to carry a significantly bigger tank of fuel to equal the range of current models.
''The oil companies are working hard to get the alternate fuels provisions killed,'' said Richard D. Wilson, director of the E.P.A.'s office of mobile sources. ''We know for sure that ethanol, methanol and compressed natural gas can meet the emissions targets we've set. If the oil industry can come up with a reformulated gasoline that can meet the standards, it's fine with us.''
Gasoline is a combination of many hydrocarbons, sometimes more than 100, that can be varied in amount to affect the fuel's properties, like volatility or how easily the fuel evaporates in the atmosphere.
 
Statement by Sununu
One Big Three lobbyist in Washington, who preferred to remain anonymous, said the companies had been told by John Sununu, the President's chief of staff, that the Government has not already decided the case in favor of methanol. ''Sununu has told us it's a level playing field and may the best and most economical fuel win,'' the lobbyist added.
Although the specific emissions standards would be set in the rule-making phase of the legislative procedure, the President's bill would generally lower the amount of hydrocarbons, carbon monoxide, oxides of nitrogen and other particles that could be emitted legally from a car's tailpipe. Auto makers have said they are not sure whether such reductions will do much to clean up the air, but they have said they will support the legislation.
Auto makers have suggested for some time, however, that reformulation of gasoline could reduce so-called running losses, or gasoline evaporation, which contributes to air pollution. Recently the oil industry has begun to respond. The Atlantic Richfield Company, a major gasoline marketer, last month announced a lower-polluting formulation of a new fuel for cars that still burn leaded gasoline; the company said it was working on a version for cars that burn unleaded fuel, too.
Denying a report in the automotive trade press that the purpose of joint research was to kill methanol as an alternative fuel, Arthur E. Wiese, a spokesman for the American Petroleum Institute, said: ''We're not against methanol per se. We're against doing it before we can answer the various technical and environmental questions.''
Several major oil companies are testing reformulated gasolines -sometimes referred to as ''designer'' gasolines, while others, including ARCO and the Sun Company, are test-marketing methanol in areas where experimental vehicles are being studied.

HEADLINE: Harar Journal;
Ethiopia Drives Its Peasants Off the Good Earth

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARAR, Ethiopia

 BODY:
With rows of Marx and Lenin volumes in his bookcase and piles of tracts on his desk, Ali Youssef, the head of the ideology department here, explained the alacrity with which the process being called ''villagization'' had been accomplished in his region.
In seven months, he said, half a million houses for more than two million people were built. ''There is systemization; there is mobilization,'' he said, lifting some of the argot from his desktop literature. ''They used to construct at midnight.'' 
It is precisely the speed and authoritarianism of the Government's villagization program - the relocation of peasants from their traditionally scattered homes in nearby areas to new villages established in gridlike patterns - that have caused many of its problems, Ethiopian and Western agricultural experts say.
Villagization was heralded by President Mengistu Haile Mariam in 1984 as the answer to many of the difficulties of the impoverished, drought-stricken Ethiopian peasantry, who make up 90 percent of the country's population. By being grouped together, the argument went, peasants would be able to produce more and have easier access to such services as schools and health clinics.
 
Resettlement Also Introduced
Unspoken, but more to the point, in the view of many Ethiopian and Western researchers, villagization was an effort to increase the power of the state by marshaling people in more easily controlled groups.
Experiments in consolidation and forced resettlement have been tried elsewhere in Africa, most notably under President Julius K. Nyerere in Tanzania, with results that are debated widely.
Along with villagization, which now affects about 40 percent of Ethiopia's population, the Government also introduced resettlement, a program under which thousands of people were moved long distances from one arid region of the country to a more fertile one. This program, smaller in scale and often carried out forcibly, has largely been halted, not because of second thoughts but because of its expense for the war-ravaged and virtually bankrupt economy, Ethiopian officials said.
Both villagization and resettlement have been criticized by many Western countries. The two policies are among the reasons that the United States gives for refusing economic aid to Ethiopia, as distinct from humanitarian aid.
This year, the Swedish Government's aid agency, the Swedish International Development Agency, traditionally one of the most generous donors to Ethiopia, withdrew its support of a major agricultural project in Arsi Province because it concluded ''the actual purpose of villagization was political.''
 
A 'Frightening' Development
President Mengistu himself acknowledged in an address to the congress of the Workers Party of Ethiopia last November that his agricultural policies were not working.
He said agricultural production had declined by an average of 0.4 percent annually. ''It is frightening to see that agricultural productivity is steadily decreasing in this manner at a time when the population is increasing at an annual rate of 3 percent,'' he said.
Visits to villagization projects by most foreigners are circumscribed affairs, conducted in the company of local party officials who unfailingly show model sites. The first stop on such a visit is usually to the local ideology boss, like Mr. Ali, who presides over politics in eastern Harar Province.
Recently Mr. Ali arranged a tour of two villagization projects with three party officials and an agricultural expert, who usually deferred to the party officials. The projects, Dire Tayara and Rare Chillalo, are in the countryside around the town of Harar.
At the first, it was proudly stated that about half the peasants belonged to the producers' cooperative. As an inducement to join the cooperative, priority was given to members for fertilizer and better seeds, the officials said.
At the second, a ''mobilization campaign'' was in progress. A long line of peasants, swinging hoes, were digging up old bushes to plant grain.
''Once every 15 days, everyone does a campaign,'' a party guide said. ''If necessary, every week.'' A Long Way to Walk A more revealing explanation of villagization is provided by Ethiopian agricultural researchers. But they, too, complain that party officials in the villages are loath to talk frankly about the problems and create barriers that make it difficult to speak to the peasants.
One of the new villages that have been studied by the University of Addis Ababa lies in a fertile valley surrounded by high peaks 50 miles outside the capital.
For the most part, the land in the villagization projects is not collectivized. Peasants keep their land but have long distances to walk to their farms from the new villages.
As a result, peasants have told the researchers, they have been unable to protect their crops from the hyenas, monkeys and porcupines that pervade the hillsides.
Their new houses were often built with the materials from their old places - a strategy used by party officials to force the peasants to move - and were put up so hastily that they were beginning to crumble and leak, researchers found. Moreover, the houses were built so close together that peasants had little room to grow vegetables, which previously provided valuable income.
''There are some social gains: greater access to schools in some areas and to water and electricity in some of the villages,'' a researcher said. ''But they do not outweigh the economic difficulties. People have been brought closer to the roads but it's questionable how much the road is being used. If the farmer doesn't have cash, what does it mean being closer to the asphalt road for transport?''

HEADLINE: WASHINGTON TALK;
Behind the No-Tax Talk, The Drug War's Bill

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
Like Capt. Louis Renault, the police chief in ''Casablanca'' who professed to be ''shocked, shocked,'' that gambling was going on under his nose, the White House is shocked, shocked at the notion of new taxes to pay for the $7.9 billion war on drugs.
Unthinkable! Read our lips! No new taxes!
But behind the protestations, there are hints that the devastation of the drug epidemic and the Administration's efforts to cope with it may serve as a wedge for a tax increase.
The White House is reluctant to give up the public advantage of its no-tax stand. Even some Democrats say that many in their party erred in saying the only way to pay for the drug war was to raise taxes. Republicans were plainly delighted that Democrats were casting themselves once more in the role of the party that wants new taxes. 
But some senior Republican officials have indicated, though more by innuendo than actual deed, that paying for the emergency on drugs, dealing with the education problem, helping Poland out of its economic morass and starting a new program to send astronauts to Mars will inevitably mean a tax increase.
''There's the possibility of an increase, but it's very complicated because of the atmospherics on Capitol Hill,'' said Stephen E. Bell, managing director of Salomon Brothers here and former staff director of the Senate Budget Committee.
''Once the President says drugs are a national emergency, and he's willing to raise taxes for that purpose, then he'll be confronted with a new national emergency on, say, education or health care. People will say these are just as important as fighting the drug war.''
Mr. Bell said an increase in taxes on alcohol or tobacco - was possible. ''You can say these should be taxed higher for the greater public good and we'll use the revenues for a greater public good,'' he said. ''Sort of like killing two birds with one stone.''
A senior White House aide said, ''The attitude has perhaps hardened on the anti-tax thing because the Democrats almost always have a Pavlovian response to a new program, saying, 'Let's raise taxes,' and that sets off a counter-Pavlovian response of no tax increases in the Bush Adminstration.''
Robert Teeter, the President's poll taker, said: ''The public mind is absolutely that you don't have to raise taxes to do these things. They believe you can reduce spending in enough other areas. And you can accommodate these things without a tax increase.''
Others close to Mr. Bush, as well as academics and lawmakers, say new taxes are probable down the line. ''The funny thing about all this,'' said Erwin C. Hargrove, a professor of political science at Vanderbilt University, ''is the surveys show people are willing to pay more taxes to meet severe national problems, so I don't think there are political dangers here. But Presidents always worry about their credibility. Bush has himself to blame for the bind he created for himself. Probably he'll have to resort to an artifice of some kind to pay for this.''
''The failure to mention taxes in the drug speech is a clue to the fiscal and I would say intellectual bankruptcy of his proposals.'' said James MacGregor Burns, author of books on the Presidencies of Franklin D. Roosevelt and John F. Kennedy. ''It's obvious that when you're concentrating people's attention on the problem and fail to ask people generally to be responsible for financing that program, it raises questions of how sincere the President is about the program. I don't take seriously a speech that would not raise the question of mobilizing fiscal resources.''
But White House officials say that money can be siphoned from other programs. They say Democratic and academic critics miss the point. The Government, in the words of William J. Bennett, the head of the anti-drug initiative, ''is not a sugar daddy.''

HEADLINE: Dr. Axelrod's Potent Health Plan

 BODY:
Roughly 37 million Americans lack basic health insurance, including 2.5 million who live in New York State. In the absence of any serious Federal attempt to address this need, Dr. David Axelrod, the State Health Commissioner, proposes his own plan. It includes a stunningly bold strategy for controlling medical expenses and thereby protecting the taxpayers as well as the uninsured. 
The medical profession will recoil, but Dr. Axelrod has the right idea.
An obvious way to create universal coverage would be to replace existing medical insurance with a single health plan paid for entirely with tax revenues - Medicare for everyone. But that would cost a fortune to administer. Dr. Axelrod therefore would follow the example of Massachusetts and build upon existing coverage.
Most New York residents receive medical insurance through their employers. The 2.5 million who remain uninsured either are not employed or work for firms that do not provide insurance. Under the Axelrod plan, all employers would be encouraged to extend medical insurance to their workers.
As in Massachusetts, those who refuse would be required to pay into a fund financing medical insurance for any uninsured state resident. Individuals covered by the state insurance would have to pay a premium, but it would be set according to the individual's income.
So far so good. Dr. Axelrod's proposal then departs from the Massachusetts approach by recognizing that universal insurance coverage solves only half the problem. Without some limits on costs, the price tag for such a taxpayer-supported benefit could doom the program.
Dr. Axelrod would establish the state as the sole payer of hospitals, physicians and other health providers. Only the state would pay the doctors and hospitals; then Albany would collect reimbursement from the insurers. The state alone would negotiate fees that doctors, hospitals and clinics would be allowed to charge. New York has already laid the groundwork for this ''one-payer'' system with the program it established in 1983 for setting reimbursement rates that hospitals may charge for inpatient care. Extending this program to physicians would likely evoke passionate resistance from the health providers.
In one bold stroke, the state would become a monopolistic buyer of all medical services, with the power to control costs. And because the state would be negotiating the fees that apply to every resident, health providers would not be able to shift costs onto uncovered patients.
Dr. Axelrod has wisely outlined several different versions of his plan. The least expensive, which could be implemented relatively quickly, would cost taxpayers as little as $100 million a year.
Imposing medical insurance on employers is often criticized as a hidden tax. And so it is - some effects on prices and wages are inevitable. But the whole community benefits from broader health coverage, and the state would be spared the cost of administering a huge program of its own. Employers can be expected to come up with a wide array of different plans - a healthy experimentation that might eventually yield an ideal plan.
No such bold initiative is without danger. By saddling New York companies with additional costs, the plan could unintentionally encourage employers to locate in neighboring states. Still, the health economist Karen Davis of Johns Hopkins University, who applauds the Axelrod plan, estimates that the cost increases to business would be small.
So far, the plan is no more than a proposal; Governor Cuomo has yet to endorse it. Given the inevitable opposition of organized medicine, and perhaps some business groups, implementation is hardly guaranteed. But at very least, Dr. Axelrod deserves credit for stirring the health insurance debate with a powerful idea.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Salvador's Troubles, in Salvador's Hands

 BODY:
Washington no longer focuses much attention on the political future of El Salvador. Its once-dramatic concern has dissipated in the wake of frustration with a seemingly endless military struggle, the election of an extreme rightist Government and progress toward a political settlement in neighboring Nicaragua.
Yet with 70,000 of their countrymen already dead and 1 in 10 uprooted from their homes, Salvadorans cannot afford to resign themselves to the status quo. Peace talks open tomorrow in Mexico City between representatives of President Alfredo Cristiani and leaders of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front. These may be a first step toward a better future. Finally, Salvador's future is in Salvadoran hands. 
In recent days the leftist guerrillas of the F.M.L.N. eased their conditions for negotiations, accepting that the meetings be held outside El Salvador and that Government representation be at less than the highest levels. The insurgents have also announced a unilateral 11-day cease-fire and have called on the Government to take similar conciliatory steps.
It would be unrealistic to expect too much from these discussions. Mr. Cristiani's Arena party contains many people who regard the fight against the guerrillas as a holy crusade. And it is far from certain how much further the guerrillas are willing to compromise. Earlier this year, after the outgoing Government of Jose Napoleon Duarte rejected the guerrillas' proposal to delay elections in exchange for a cease-fire, they launched a bloody offensive that helped cement Arena's electoral victory.
An earlier round of talks, begun amid much hope in 1984 with the then-new Duarte Government, was fruitless. But presumably Mr. Cristiani won't have to worry as much as Mr. Duarte did about Arena's possible reaction to any concessions he might make for peace.
And both sides are now less able to count on outside support. American military aid will not flow indefinitely for a Government that rejects reasonable peace offers while turning its back on economic and social reforms. And Nicaragua's commitments to the Central American peace process limit its ability to support the Salvadoran guerrilla forces.
A decade of U.S. involvement, including $3 billion of military and economic aid, may well have prevented an early guerrilla triumph. But the days of passionate debate in Washington over El Salvador are an increasingly distant memory. That country now faces a deadly stalemate. It's up to Salvadorans themselves to take the next step.

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
Main St. Ponders An Innovation From Fifth Ave.

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT

DATELINE: PORT JEFFERSON, L.I.

 BODY:
Don't get Edvin Stromsten wrong. He'd love to see planter boxes full of pansies and petunias in the Main Street business district in this waterfront Suffolk County village.
More trees along the sidewalk to the harbor would be nice, too. And while you're at it, how about some new storefront facades that hark back to when this was a 19th-century shipbuilding port? 
''Who could object to improvement?'' asked Mr. Stromsten, a 58-year-old architect who has lived here on and off for 25 years.
But if improvement means losing control of Main Street, the heart and soul of this village of 7,600 people, Mr. Stromsten and dozens of his neighbors want no part of it. What has them worried is a proposal to create something called a business improvement district that could include several blocks of Main Street, East Main Street and West Broadway.
''It's another layer of government that we don't need,'' said Mr. Stromsten, who is president of the newly formed Port Jefferson Civic Association, a group of about 60 homeowners.
For years, property owners and business groups in specially designated sections of New York City have voluntarily agreed to pay additional property taxes for amenities and extra services like Christmas decorations or increased security. The New York State Legislature broadened the law this summer to allow such districts in suburban towns and villages that want them.
Village officials and many business leaders here think that would be a great idea. The business district would, essentially, impose a user's tax on merchants within its boundaries. Residents would not be affected. ''With business on Long Island not great, this could bolster the economy here,'' said Harold Sheprow, the Mayor of Port Jefferson.
It would help preserve a vibrant Main Street at a time when ''we don't have a lot of Main Streets on Long Island anymore,'' said Lois Brager, a village trustee and an owner of Mac Snyder's Army and Navy Store. ''They're all shopping malls now,'' she said. 'Doug Norton, president of the Port Jefferson Chamber of Commerce, said merchants in the new district might pay as little as $35 a year in additional taxes to help pay for promotional campaigns, new street lights, street signs, benches or whatever else the leaders of the district decided. ''We could control our own destiny,'' he said.
Residents are hard-pressed to give a strict definition of where the business district as it now exists here begins and ends, so closely do private homes nestle up to shops. Creating meaningless geographic boundaries would drive a wedge between the commercial and residential areas, they say. ''Having business on one side and residents on another side would break down the traditional community here,'' said Mr. Stromsten.
''The commercial districts are not just commercial,'' he added. ''They are the core and the essence of the village and the public places that belong to all villagers.''
Many residents - and some merchants -fear that essence could ebb away. ''The village would abdicate responsibility for maintaining downtown,'' said Michael Mart, an owner of the Good Times Book Shop, who has lived here since 1970. ''I really don't think it's for this community.''
A business improvement district would be governed by a management association whose members would be mainly merchants appointed by the village. ''We're not sure what type of power this group would have or how far it would go,'' said Jacqueline Lewis, a junior high school teacher and 28-year resident.
There are fears that outsiders could alter the character of the village. ''The people it will help are real-estate developers,'' said Charles Kohn, a silversmith with a shop on East Main Street who has lived in town 15 years. ''The residents will lose their say over what goes on in that district.''
''The people who've spoken against it are negative about anything in the community that's positive,'' said Joan Elliott, a florist on Main Street. She is chairwoman of a committee that will present the proposal's pros and cons at a village meeting on Oct. 2.
Until then questions will abound. For both residents and merchants, the predominant feeling about the proposal is one of uncertainty. Who would be in a district? How much would it cost? Exactly who would benefit from the district?
''I want to see a total picture,'' Phil Mishuck, the owner of P&J's Harbour Sound, a record store. ''No one really knows what we're getting.''
''We're at the very beginning stages here and have a lot to learn,'' Mrs. Elliott said.

HEADLINE: Camden's Contradictions Connect Florio's Images

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
For 20 years, James J. Florio has projected a series of seemingly contradictory images: the city street fighter, the suburban Congressman; the political boss, the idealistic reformer.
These images in many ways reflect the divided society in which Mr. Florio rose to power - a Camden County cleanly severed into two separate worlds of city and suburb, poverty and wealth, black and white.
Since his election as a Democratic Congressman in 1974, he has had unusual success in appealing to both, holding together a coalition of white ethnic suburbanites and urban minorities that Republicans elsewhere have torn apart.
''What people in the city and the suburbs still had in common was that they all wanted to climb to the next rung,'' said State Senator Daniel J. Dalton, who worked in Mr. Florio's first campaign for Congress, in 1972. ''Jim portrayed government's function as to help people climb that ladder. The thing that rang true was when he used himself and his work ethic as an example.'' Now, as the Democratic candidate for governor, Mr. Florio says New Jersey must overcome problems of soaring tax and insurance costs, threats to the environment and urban decline. The state's future, he says, depends on resolving the contradictions between its thriving suburbs and the cities they left behind. 
 
Focus on Camden
If Mr. Florio wants to focus on urban issues, his critics are happy to oblige. They note the continued decay of Camden into one of the nation's poorest cities during the 14 years he has represented it in Congress. They say he merely replaced the old Camden Democratic machine with one of his own.
His Republican opponent, Representative Jim Courter, and Gov. Thomas H. Kean have called the conduct of Mr. Florio's associates in Camden the premier issue in the campaign.
''Camden is a political culture reminiscent of the old New Jersey,'' said a Courter spokesman, Gordon Hensley. ''It sticks out in dramatic contrast to where Tom Kean and Jim Courter seek to lead the state.''
In a recent interview in his campaign headquarters in West Orange, Mr. Florio described a New Jersey in which self-interest would turn the suburbs back toward their central cities.
With the social costs of urban blight raising property taxes in the suburbs, and with businesses hungry for workers that only the city's unemployed can provide, he said, the forces of the marketplace, together with government, can begin to address long-ignored ills.
 
Self-Interest, Public Interest
''You are going to have to harmonize self-interest with the public interest,'' Mr. Florio said. ''If you are concerned about drugs in your nice suburban schools, you better be concerned about the market that is operating in an urban community. Because that is where it all comes from.
''You, business person, are going to have to try to help with the drug rehabilitation problem that we have,'' he continued. ''Not because it is the nice thing to do, but because evidence is that 14 percent of the work force has a drug- or alcohol-related problem.''
Businesses must be encouraged to provide child care for the mothers they need to attract in a tight labor market, Mr. Florio said, and suburbs must be encouraged to invest in the cities to help reduce the cost of government and ease their own congestion.
 
One Pair of Shoes
Mr. Florio was born in Brooklyn in 1937 and raised on East Seventh Street in Flatbush, a Jewish, Italian and Irish neighborhood much like the Camden districts he later represented. People there equated government with the New Deal and considered government jobs the most dependable kind.
Like many people in Camden, Mr. Florio's father lost his shipbuilding job after World War II, and Mr. Florio recalls a painful struggle to keep the family afloat. Starting at age 12, he developed an almost fanatical work schedule and a spartan sensibility.
''My philosophy has always been, I have one pair of shoes because I have one pair of feet,'' he said. ''My father always worked, always worked very hard. It is just beyond comprehension that anyone would not.''
At age 17 Mr. Florio dropped out of high school to join the Navy, where he fought as an amateur boxer and received blows that crushed his left cheekbone, leaving that half of his face permanently sunken.
On his return he earned a high school equivalency diploma and attended Trenton State Teachers College, where he graduated magna cum laude. Later, he took graduate courses at Columbia University and attended Rutgers Law School while working as a night janitor to support his wife and three children. #15 Races in 20 Years At 25, he went to work as a district leader with the Camden Democratic machine and pursued politics with the same energy.In 1968, he recalls being inspired by the presidential campaign of Robert F. Kennedy, who delivered a speech in Camden with a ''serene, almost spiritual quality.''
Starting with an Assembly race in 1969, Mr. Florio ran for public office 15 times in 20 years. During that time almost all of Camden's factories shut down and its white work force moved out. The new suburbanites, often enraged at the city and minorities, were pried loose from the Democratic coalition by Republicans during the Nixon and Reagan years.
But Mr. Florio worked to appeal to voters in both worlds. Beginning with his first, unsuccessful Congressional bid in 1972, when he ran on a ticket headed by George McGovern, he stressed day care, transportation, the environment, and other issues that defied easy labels of left and right.
In his 14 years in the House, Mr. Florio has won the respect of Democratic colleagues for his record on consumer, transportation and environmental issues, including his authorship of the 1980 Superfund law that allocated billions of dollars to clean up toxic-waste sites.
Though he lacked the intellectual breadth of Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey or Senator Daniel P. Moynihan of New York, Democratic colleagues say, he gained an unrivaled expertise in issues he concentrated upon. #2 Races for Governor Mr. Florio ran twice for governor, in 1977 and again in 1981, when he lost a substantial lead to be beaten by Mr. Kean by 1,797 votes.
At times during that campaign, Mr. Florio's manner seemed forced and rigid. The candidate turned prickly when questions turned personal. By the end, Mr. Kean was parodying his opponent's lengthy and technical responses.
Opponents said that the 1981 race revealed Mr. Florio for who he was: a brusque loner, well-versed in public policy but insensitive to people.
After he lost the governorship, a number of his associates went to work in Camden County, where, two years before, Mr. Florio and his supporters had overthrown the Democratic machine controlled by Mayor Angelo J. Errichetti.
Republicans say the best testament to Mr. Florio's use of government is the record of his allies who governed Camden County throughout the 1980's. Camden County government, they charge, has existed largely to promote the interests of Mr. Florio and his party.
 
'Spreading Money' Around
''They were spreading money to everybody and his brother,'' said Michael DiPiero, a Republican freeholder from Camden.
In one case, Joseph C. Salema, Mr. Florio's chief of staff, and Nicholas Rudi, a campaign aide who became the county administrator and treasurer, left their jobs to form a consulting firm that then received hundreds of thousands of dollars in no-bid consulting contracts from the county.
In another, Mr. Salema, Mr. Rudi and Mr. Florio, with other investors, bought the faltering Continental Bank of New Jersey with promissory notes that they never had to repay. The county subsequently deposited $2 million there.
After newspapers raised questions of impropriety, Mr. Florio sold his interest in the bank and donated the profits to Trenton State College.
In a third case, Dr. William Steinberg, a Florio campaign contributor, received a $1.1 million no-bid contract to supply staff doctors to the county hospital. Mr. DiPiero charged that the county could have obtained cheaper bids.
The Greater Camden Development Corporation was shut down in 1986 after being accused of distributing patronage and Federal housing money to allies of the Democrats. And the County Parks Commission, embroiled in charges that it handed out jobs to party loyalists, was abolished last year and is under a grand jury investigation.
Despite several investigations into charges of corruption, however, there have been no indictments.
''Jim Florio is the boss of Camden County,'' said Mr. Hensley of the Courter campaign.
But Mr. Florio says he was never involved in the workings of county government, instead devoting his time to his work in Congress.
During the 1980's, he says, his allies broke no laws and were engaging in common practices. But he says he was disturbed by such practices and supports efforts begun last year by the new Freeholder Director, Robert E. Andrews, a Democrat, to clean up county government and impose a strict ethics code. And he has proposed a strict ethic code for state government.
''With hindsight, did these people think about how it would look when people looked back?'' Mr. Florio asked. ''I suspect probably not.''

CORRECTION-DATE: September 16, 1989, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on Tuesday about Representative James J. Florio, the Democratic candidate for governor of New Jersey, referred incorrectly to an investment involving the Continental Bank of New Jersey. Mr. Florio was part of a group that bought the bank's building and land, not the bank itself.
In addition, the group has made payments on a promissory note used to finance the purchase.

HEADLINE: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

 BODY:
Seven out of 10 Americans approve of President Bush's strategy to fight drugs, and 6 out of 10 say they think that the plan, if enacted, will significantly reduce the nation's drug problem, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.
Even so, there was division on whether Mr. Bush would succeed in curbing illegal drug sales and use and whether his spending priorities were the right ones.
But despite those differences there was striking public agreement about the priority that drugs should command on the national agenda.
The proportion of Americans who cited drugs as the nation's most important problem has nearly tripled since the end of July, to 64 percent from 22 percent. The rise came after weeks of sustained news coverage of the worsening crack epidemic and the turmoil caused by cocaine barons in Colombia and after Mr. Bush's address to the nation Tuesday when he outlined his anti-drug policy. 
The percentage was the highest recorded for any single issue since the Times/CBS News poll began in 1976 and is one of the highest registered by any major national survey.
 
A National Consensus
Americans in every region and every income level reported that in some way illegal drugs had intruded upon their lives. Forty-eight percent of the adults questioned said they knew someone who had been ''seriously affected'' by illegal drugs, either through that person's drug use or another's. Twenty-eight percent said they knew of a specific drug seller or a place in their community where drugs were sold.
The nationwide telephone poll of 824 adults began Sept. 6, the night after Mr. Bush's speech, and concluded Sept. 8. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Over all, 69 percent said they approved of Mr. Bush's drug package, and 56 percent said that if it was enacted the plan would lead to a ''significant reduction'' in the drug problem. Seventy-three percent said they believed it was possible to significantly reduce the drug problem, while 19 percent said it was beyond control.
But there was division over whether Mr. Bush would actually reach his goal. Thirty-eight percent said he would be able to reduce the drug problem, but 44 percent said he would not.
Forty-seven percent of those surveyed said they had heard or seen Mr. Bush's speech, and of that group, 81 percent said they approved of his plan.
The program calls for higher spending in areas like building new prisons and increasing military and economic aid to Bolivia, Colombia and Peru, the primary sources of cocaine shipped into the United States. Roughly 70 percent of the money is earmarked for law enforcement and 30 percent for treatment and education. Forty-three percent of those surveyed said there was too much emphasis on law enforcement rather than on root causes of drug use like poverty and unemployment; 42 percent said the emphasis was appropriate.
The public was sharply divided on whether Mr. Bush's proposed $7.9 billion was an appropriate sum to fight drugs. The largest fraction, 38 percent, said it was the ''right amount.'' But 22 percent said it was ''too little'' and 16 percent said it was ''too much.''
There was general agreement that the Federal Government should spend more than in the past to combat drugs. Fifty-six percent said that in general they favored such higher spending, and 39 percent even said they would be willing to pay $100 a year more in taxes to increase the budget for drug programs, although Mr. Bush has pledged not to raise taxes.
While there was widespread familiarity with illegal narcotics among most age levels, most striking was the high percentage of young adults who reported being touched by drugs.
Among the 18- to 29-year-olds, 45 percent said they knew of a place in their community where illegal drugs were sold, or of a person who sold them. The figure dropped to 27 percent among 30- to 44-year-olds and to 26 percent among 45- to 64-year-olds.
Twenty-eight percent of the 18- to 29-year-olds said they had seen drugs sold in their neighborhood, as did 12 percent of those who are 30 to 64 years old.
There were clear generational patterns among those who said they had tried illegal drugs. Over all, 28 percent of those surveyed said they had tried an illegal drug, but the figure rose to 38 percent among 30- to 44-year-olds and 50 percent among 18- to 29-year-olds.
Mr. Bush's program puts new emphasis on punishing not only drug sellers but also drug users. Still, 47 percent of those surveyed said the sellers were more responsible than users for the nation's drug problem. Thirty-one percent said the users were more responsible, and 20 percent said the groups were equally to blame.
Sixty-one percent of those surveyed endorsed requiring ''workers in general'' to be tested for illegal drug use, a point stressed in Mr. Bush's plan. In a Times/CBS News poll in August 1986 only 44 percent favored such a policy. In the recent poll 24 percent said testing of workers would be an unfair invasion of privacy, a sharp decline from the 44 percent of three years ago.
Sixty-two percent said they would favor mandatory drug testing for high school students, while 27 percent said it would be an unfair invasion of privacy.
Mr. Bush's plan calls for a major increase in expanding Federal prisons for drug offenders, as well as stiffer penalties for drug users convicted for the first time. Eighty-four percent of those questioned said first offenders should be sent to treatment programs, while 8 percent said they should be imprisoned. Seventy percent said jail should be mandatory for repeat offenders, while 16 percent favored treatment.
 
Replies From Drug Users
Those who say they have tried illegal drugs are as likely as all adults to approve of Mr. Bush's plan. Sixty-four percent said of that group supported it, as against 69 percent of all adults surveyed.
But those who report having ever used drugs were more likely to say that law enforcement gets too much emphasis, as against treatment and education.
In addition, 75 percent of those who have tried drugs at some time said that someone who smoked marijuana occasionally should not be prosecuted, while 50 percent of the general public gave that response.
Mr. Bush has said he would not send troops to Colombia in a combat role, although White House officials said they would consider such a request if Colombia's President made it.
If there was such a request, 42 percent of those surveyed said the United States should send the troops, while 47 percent said it should not. Support for dispatching soldiers fell to 34 percent if the troops could be in Colombia for a year or more.
The poll showed that Mr. Bennett, a former Secretary of Education, is still not well known among the public. Seventy-three of those surveyed said they ''didn't know enough'' about him to have an opinion, 11 percent said they had a favorable opinion and 3 percent unfavorable.
For Mr. Bush, however, the approval rating was 70 percent, up from 61 percent in June, but statistically indistinguishable from the 67 percent registered in July.
Until the latest poll, the highest percentage of Americans listing a single issue in the Times/CBS Poll was in October 1979, when 52 percent cited the economy. In the Gallup Poll, which asks people to list more than one problem issue facing the country, 81 percent cited inflation in October 1974.
No current issue approaches drugs for capturing the public's interest as a major problem. The economy was a distant second in the Times/CBS News poll, cited by only 5 percent, followed by the poor, with 3 percent. In the Times survey six weeks ago, 22 percent cited drugs as the most important problem, followed by 9 percent for the deficit and 8 percent for unemployment and jobs.
When asked in a separate question for the most important problem facing the community they live in, the public mentioned drugs more than any other topic, with 35 percent saying it was the most important local problem.
George C. Edward 3d, a professor of political science at Texas A & M University who has studied public opinion and the presidency, said: ''The President is exploiting the moment, if you will, and I use that in a positive sense Normally, a President is not able to set the agenda quite so easily.
''But there has not been a lot of news in domestic policy recently and, rather remarkably, the media has given a tremendous amount of attention not only to the President's speech but to specials on drugs.''
 
How the Poll on Drugs Was Taken
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Sept. 6-8 with 824 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country.
The exchanges were chosen so as to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. The numbers were then screened to limit calls to residences.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of residential telephone lines and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
The percentages reported are the particular results most likely to match what would be obtained by seeking out all adult Americans. Other possible percentages are progressively less likely the more they differ from the reported results.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for people who are 18 to 29 years old it is plus or minus seven percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll.
