HEADLINE: House Fight Continues On Cutting Gains Tax

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
The House Ways and Means Committee will return to its struggle over capital gains tax reduction on Tuesday with committee Democrats and the House Democratic leadership no closer to a consensus than they were before the August recess.
The Ways and Means panel is under orders from the House Budget Committee to complete action on tax legislation by the end of this week, so committee proposals for raising $5.3 billion in new revenue can be rolled into the deficit reduction package Congress must pass by Oct. 16 if it is to avoid automatic budget cuts. The committee has already agreed on how to raise the revenue but has been stymied for weeks over an Administration-backed proposal to reduce the capital gains tax temporarily.
The capital gains proposal, sponsored by Representative Ed Jenkins, Democrat of Georgia, would reduce the capital gains rate - currently 28 percent for most taxpayers - to about 20 percent for 18 months. The proposal is supported by all 13 Republicans on the Ways and Means Committee as well as five other committee Democrats, giving Mr. Jenkins the 19 votes he needs for passage. 
 
Liberal Economists Oppose Plan
A group of liberal economists criticized Mr. Jenkins's proposal in a Capitol Hill news conference today, contending it would ultimately increase the budget deficit. ''An across-the-board, temporary tax cut, by encouraging the churning of assets, would worsen the shortsightedness that plagues the United States investment horizon,'' the economists said in a statement.
''A temporary tax cut will reward those who have already made profitable investments and not at all those who must choose whether to invest in the future. After a quick surge, revenues will fall both because capital gains realizations induced in the short term are at least partly borrowed from those that would have been realized later, and because the long-term economic benefits are negligible.''
The statement was signed by Henry Aaron, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution; Alan Blinder, chairman of the department of economics at Princeton University; Alan Auerbach, chairman of the department of economics at the University of Pennsylvania; Lawrence Summers, a professor of economics at Harvard University, and Joseph Minarik, executive director of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee.
 
Rostenkowski Proposes Indexing
To derail the Jenkins plan, the Ways and Means Committee chairman, Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, has proposed an indexing alternative that would allow taxpayers to avoid taxes on the portion of their capital gains solely attributable to inflation. Although Mr. Rostenkowski's plan has the general backing of the House Democratic leadership, it has so far failed to move any of the committee Democrats supporting Mr. Jenkins.
The issue was further muddled today when Representative Byron L. Dorgan, a liberal Democrat from North Dakota and a member of the Ways and Means panel, said he would propose yet another alternative to lower the capital gains tax rate to 19.6 percent permanently for taxpayers with incomes of less than $100,000, while extending the 33 percent marginal tax rate to certain upper-income taxpayers. His proposal would provide a smaller capital gains break for those with incomes between $100,000 and $200,00 and no break for those with incomes above $200,000.
Mr. Dorgan told reporters that while he preferred no change in the capital gains rate, if a rate cut was inevitable, it should be aimed at the middle class - those now taxed at a marginal rate of 33 percent - rather than the wealthiest taxpayers, who are taxed at 28 percent. He contended the primary benefits of the Jenkins and the Rostenkowski plans would go to taxpayers with incomes of more than $100,000.
Under current law, a taxpayer with two children and filing a joint return is taxed at a 28 percent rate on income between $47,500 and $105,000. Those with incomes between $105,000 and $260,000 are taxed at a 33 percent rate, while for those with income above $260,000, the rate drops back to 28 percent.
Mr. Dorgan's plan would maintain the 33 percent rate for those with incomes above $260,000.
The plan's emphasis on middle-income taxpayers may have some appeal among some House Democrats, but House Democratic leaders, fearful of endorsing any proposal Republicans might characterize as a tax increase, are likely to be wary of extending the 33 percent income tax rate to those who now pay at a 28 percent rate. Mr. Dorgan said, however, that he expected to raise the proposal on the House floor if it failed in the committee.

HEADLINE: Dow Loses 5.13 Points as Trading Slows

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stocks fell moderately yesterday in exceptionally slow trading as a late burst of blue-chip buying sharply shaved losses on the Dow Jones industrial average.
The Dow dropped 5.13 points, to 2,704.41, after being down more than 21 points in the early afternoon. At the same time, declines on the New York Stock Exchange, at 936, smothered the 530 issues that advanced. 
''A lot of the potential participants in the stock market are still on vacation,'' said Jack Conlon, executive vice president at Nikko Securities. ''The retail sales number on new domestic car sales for the first 10 days of September, to be released on Wednesday, should provide more action into Friday and next week.''
Other key economic indicators scheduled to come out this week are retail sales on Thursday, and business inventories, the United States trade balance, producer prices, industrial production and capacity utilization on Friday.
''There could be a decline beginning early next week that could lead to a correction of between 5 and 10 percent over the short term,'' Mr. Conlon said. ''If the drop occurs in an orderly fashion, however, it should not be viewed with alarm.''
 
Decline Doubled at Midday
Equities began the day broadly but only moderately lower from a blue-chip standpoint. The Dow was off about eight points after the first half-hour before more than doubling that decline at midday.
Some program trading and caution ahead of Friday's ''triple witching hour,'' when the spot contract in stock options - in this case September -stock index futures, and options on stock index futures expire, also curtailed buying. The next triple witching hour will come in December.
In the broader market yesterday, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 1.10 points, to 347.66, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index eased by 0.65, to 193.30.
Volume on the Big Board contracted sharply to a skimpy 126 million shares, from 154.1 million on Friday. This was the lightest volume since 68.87 million shares were traded on July 3.
With little conviction as to the direction of the overall stock market after the Dow's recent failed efforts to finish above its Aug. 24 high, investors appeared content, if not enthusiastic, about concentrating on special-situation issues, especially takeover-related stocks.
UAL, for instance, dropped 3 7/8, to 276 3/8. A spokesman for Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts, the New York leveraged buyout firm, said it was not interested in bidding for the parent of United Airlines. On Friday, Kohlberg, Kravis was said to have contacted the United Air Lines machinists' union about possibly bidding for the airline.
 
AMR Up on Trump Report
AMR rose 2 3/4, to 83 3/4, following a report in USA Today in which Dan Dorfman said that Donald J. Trump had taken a stake in the parent of American Airlines. Both parties declined to comment on the report.
Manufacturers Hanover Trust climbed 2 7/8, to 42 1/2. The company said it was holding talks on the possible acquisition of a part interest in its CIT Group subsidiary by the Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank of Japan.
Among the active issues, A.T&T. was the Big Board's busiest stock, rising 7/8, to 40, on a volume of more than 1.9 million shares. General Electric added 1/8 at 56 5/8; Eastman Kodak eased 1/8, to 49 3/4, and Exxon rose 1/4, to 44 5/8.
On the American Stock Exchange, the Amex market value index fell 1.67 points, to 382.43, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index slipped by 0.89, to 470.42.

HEADLINE: Accountants Group Urges A Financial Officer for U.S.

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
The American Institute of Certified Public Accountants has urged the Bush Administration and lawmakers to name a chief financial officer of the United States to oversee the recording, monitoring and reporting of the Government's financial operations.
Borrowing two other ideas from the private sector, the professional body is also proposing that the Government adopt a uniform financial accounting and reporting system to replace several hundred systems now in use. The organization would also like to see the Government submit to annual independent audits. 
 
Report by Study Group
The recommendations, detailed in a report that was sent to the Bush Administration and members of Congress over the weekend, are the results of an eight-member study group formed in 1987 by the organization to suggest ways of improving how the Government accounts for its vast operations. The institute, with 285,000 members, is the profession's national organization and principal self-regulatory body.
''I'm all for it,'' said Senator John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, who plans to reintroduce legislation backing a finance officer. ''Had there been a C.F.O., it is far, far less likely we would have had a Housing and Urban Development scandal breaking.
''I don't know how many H.U.D.'s are out there waiting to be discovered,'' Mr. Glenn added, ''but we'd like to get a C.F.O. in there making sure it does not happen again.''
Internal investigators at H.U.D. and Congressional panels have uncovered widespread favoritism and mismanagement in H.U.D. programs during the Reagan Administration. The agency has estimated that the mismanagement may have cost the Government more than $2 billion.
Other governmental accounting experts agree with the New York-based group's recommendation for a finance officer, but think the inevitable turf battles will prove its demise.
The leading contenders for the high-level position would probably be from the accounting community -possibly from the ranks of the study group itself. Mandating independent audits for more than 300 Federal agencies, departments and offices would also create huge amounts of paid work for public accounting firms.
''That could be self-serving,'' said Uwe E. Reinhardt, an economics professor at Princeton University. Comparison With Medical Profession Cornelius E. Tierney, the national director of government practice for Ernst & Young and the chairman of the study group, said he did not dispute that the proposal would strike some that way. ''But I don't think it's any more self-serving than the medical profession discussing a medical problem,'' he said.
The idea of creating a chief financial officer is not entirely novel. House and Senate committees have conducted hearings on the issue, and the Office of Management and Budget recently added the finance officer's title to an associate director of management.
Nonetheless, the accounting group contends that the chief financial officer needs the statutory support of Congress to be effective. Under the proposal, the executive would be appointed by the President, subject to Congressional approval, for 15 years.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mostly Lower in U.S. After Posting Gains Abroad

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed mostly lower amid profit taking on domestic markets today after rising in overseas trading. Gold prices edged lower. Analysts said the dollar's upward momentum was slowed by increases in market interest rates in other countries, including West Germany, and United States traders, fearing the dollar would decline in response to those developments, rushed to take profits. 
''Interest rate differentials begin to work against the dollar at this level,'' said Ronald Holzer, chief dealer at Harris Trust in Chicago.
 
Economic Data Awaited
In earlier overseas trading, the dollar rose, but dealers said three coming economic reports from Washington have made traders reluctant to push the currency much higher.
The Commerce Department's August retail sales figures will be announced on Thursday, and on Friday reports are due on the July trade deficit figures and August producer prices.
''Anyone buying dollars at this stage is taking a big risk,'' said an American investment bank dealer in London.
The financial markets are concerned that the Federal Reserve might change its monetary policy in response to the reports, which will give an indication of the economy's health. If the economy is strong, the Fed would be expected to keep credit tight - a move dollar investors would prefer.
The dollar fell against the British pound in New York. It cost $1.5460 to buy one British pound, compared with $1.5380 on Friday. In London earlier, a pound cost $1.5450, cheaper than the $1.5505 late Friday.
Other late rates for the dollar in New York, compared with Friday's prices, included: 1.9865 West German marks, down from 1.9950; 1.7135 Swiss francs, down from 1.7245; 6.6910 French francs, down from 6.7195; 1,425.875 Italian lire, up from 1,421.00, and 1.18715 Canadian dollars, down from 1.18745.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.9875 West German marks, up from 1.9795; 1.7150 Swiss francs, up from 1.7080; 6.6970 French francs, up from 6.6710; 2.2425 Dutch guilders, up from 2.2320; 1,424.75 Italian lire, up 1,421.70, and 1.1873 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1877.
 
Gold Prices Down
Gold prices slipped in all major markets. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid of $358.10 a troy ounce for gold, down from $359.40 on Friday, and on the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold slipped to $359.20 an ounce, from $359.40 on Friday.

HEADLINE: Allies Faulted On Dollar Rise

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
The director of a Washington research organization said today that economic cooperation among the leading industrial nations had collapsed, and as a result the dollar has risen to heights that will cause trade imbalances to worsen.
Speaking at a press luncheon, the director of the Institute for International Economics, Fred Bergsten, said that by allowing the dollar to rise 10 to 15 percent this year, the seven leading industrial democracies had insured that the current account deficit of the United States, which measures trade in goods and services, would grow by $80 billion to $200 billion by 1992. 
The Group of Seven, which is mde up of the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Canada and Italy, has attempted since 1985 to bring the world economy into balance by coordinating economic policies and controlling exchange rates.
Representatives of those countries will meet in Washington this month on the eve of the annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund.
Mr. Bergsten, a former top Treasury official during the Carter Administration, said the group's ''reference ranges'' for trading in the dollar had not merely been breached, they had all but disappeared.
As a result, the group has lost all credibility in the financial markets and currency traders are no longer so wary about driving the dollar up to levels that cannot be sustained by economic fundamentals, he added.
To improve the process of United States exchange rate policy-making, a new study by the institute recommends that Congress and private business be given a louder voice.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Press for Talks On Aid Tied to Exports

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
The Bush Administration told Congress today that it planned ''vigorous new negotiations'' to dissuade industrial governments from using foreign aid programs to expand their exports.
A report to Congress released today, which was mandated by last year's Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act, recommended such negotiations as part of a package to reduce the commercial disadvantage for American exporters from so-called tied-aid credit practices.
Under such practices, an industrial country, like France or Japan, gives a low-interest loan or grant to a developing country for a major project, like a power station or telecommunications system, but with strings attached: The equipment must come exclusively from that donor country. Legitimate or Unfair? Many industrial competitors consider the practice a legitimate way of allocating foreign aid. The United States regards it as unfair export competition. One of the reasons for the difference is that the American aid program has traditionally been geared more to satisfying basic human needs in developing countries. Relatively small sums are available to support exports or to generate the sort of activity requiring the purchase of United States industrial products. 
Some politicians and business people termed the initiatives announced today as weak and held out little hope that much would be achieved.
''In terms of the magnitude of the tied-aid credit problem, the Administration's response is minimalist,'' commented Willard M. Berry, vice president of the National Foreign Trade Council.
Representative Sam Gejdenson, Democrat of Connecticut, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee's Subcommittee on International Economic Policy and Trade, said the report was ''unrealistic.''
The negotiations called for by the study would be conducted within the Paris-based group of 24 industrial countries known as the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
According to estimates by the National Foreign Trade Council, an American business organization whose 500 member companies account for 70 percent of American exports, one-third of the $25 billion to $30 billion a year of capital goods traded worldwide is financed through tied-aid packages.
 
Up to $1 Billion in Losses
According to a report last April by the Export-Import Bank, the American agency that provides credit to the customers of American exports, American industry is losing up to $1 billion a year of foreign sales because of such export-linked foreign aid.
It is not the first time that the United States has sought to curb the practice through negotiations.
After O.E.C.D. talks that ended in the spring of 1987, an agreement was reached under which the concessional part of an export credit package was lifted from 25 to 35 percent, so that a donor country would have to give a larger aid donation to win the business. The hope was that by making it more expensive the practice would be discouraged.
Instead, by most estimates, tied-aid credit offers have increased. Their value in 1988 was placed by the Export-Import Bank at $15 billion, compared with $12 billion in 1986.

LENGTH: 1518 words

HEADLINE: REVIVAL IS URGED FOR WIDER I.R.A.'s

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12

 BODY:
Lloyd Bentsen, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, today proposed a restoration of widely available, tax-deductible individual retirement accounts as an alternative to President Bush's plan to lower the tax rate on capital gains.
The proposal by the Texas Democrat represented an attempt to capture some political advantage for Democrats on the tax issue. It was immediately endorsed by George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Senate Democratic leader, who said: ''The Senate and the American people now have a clear choice between competing plans to advance our economy. The Republican plan, the President's plan, is to give a very large tax cut to a very small number of Americans, those at the very top of the income scale. The Democratic plan, the Bentsen plan, is to give all Americans a tax incentive.''
After a speech tonight to a business organization, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, the Administration's chief economic spokesman, said he was not familiar with the details of the Bentsen proposal, but that ''I.R.A.'s are one of the things we are looking at.'' 
''The problem,'' he said, ''is that it's enormously expensive. Obviously, we have to take that into account.'' In his speech, Mr. Brady proposed a separate tax initiative, suggesting a reduction not only in capital gains taxes but also in taxes on corporate dividends as a step toward reducing the cost of capital to American companies, making them more competitive with those abroad and ending ''the bias of the tax system toward debt financing.''
Mr. Brady's speech, to the American Business Conference, an organization of medium-size, rapidly growing companies, was not intended as a rejoinder to Mr. Bentsen.
Rather, Treasury officials said, it was the first of a series of speeches by the Secretary this fall devoted to the competitiveness of American companies. It was his first important speech as Treasury Secretary that did not involve an immediate crisis like the budget negotiations, the savings and loan crisis or third world debt.
Mr. Bentsen's I.R.A. proposal came as Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, struggled to reach a compromise among committee members on alternatives to an outright cut in the capital gains rate. The committee met in closed session for two hours and came to no resolution, but there were indications that Mr. Rostenkowski made some headway toward a consensus among Democrats and Republicans on the panel.
Proponents of a capital gains tax cut have argued that reducing the rate would stimulate investment and capital formation. But Mr. Bentsen, who has in the past favored a reduction in capital gains taxes, said the I.R.A. deduction, by encouraging saving, was a better way to accomplish that goal. In broad economic terms, the larger a country's savings pool, the more savings, instead of borrowing, can be used to finance investment.
Neither Mr. Bentsen nor Mr. Brady addressed where the money would come from to offset the revenue lost from the tax breaks they suggested.
Mr. Bentsen said his plan, which would allow half the money invested in an I.R.A. each year to be deducted and would also permit penalty-free withdrawals to pay for college expenses and first-time home purchases, would cost the Government $1.2 billion in the first year, rising to $4 billion by 1994.
A reduction in the capital gains tax would actually raise several billion dollars for the Government in the first year as investors rushed to take advantage of the lower rate. Many experts believe it would lose significantly more in subsequent years, but the Bush Administration disputes that analysis.
A senior Treasury official said the Brady idea of allowing corporations to deduct the dividends they pay shareholders could eventually cost $30 billion to $40 billion a year in lost revenues if a full deduction is permitted.
The budget deficit, the official said, ''stands in the way of doing anything dramatic'' and meant that any dividend deduction would have to be put in place gradually.
Until the 1986 tax law was enacted, individuals could deduct from their taxes up to $2,000 a year for money invested in a retirement account. The deduction was especially popular among middle- and upper-income taxpayers.
The 1986 law, however, disallowed the deduction for taxpayers with incomes above $35,000 ($50,000 for a couple) who were enrolled in company pension plans. Since the law was passed, the number of people investing in I.R.A.'s has fallen sharply.
 
Stimulating Saving
Mr. Brady and Mr. Bentsen maintained that restoring the deduction would stimulate personal saving. But economists are divided on whether the old system actually increased saving or merely encouraged taxpayers to shift money that would have been saved anyway into an account with tax advantages.
Mr. Bentsen did not say whether his proposal to allow penalty-free withdrawals from I.R.A.'s to pay higher education bills and make a downpayment on a home would apply to existing accounts. As the law stands now, money is taxable when it is withdrawn, and a 10 percent penalty applies if it is withdrawn before the taxpayer reaches age 59 1/2.
Initial reaction in the Wall Street community to restoring widely available I.R.A. deductions was highly positive, with some Wall Street representatives predicting that some form of liberalized I.R.A.'s would sail through Congress because of the popularity of the issue and the support of such lawmakers as Mr. Bentsen, regardless of what would happen on capital gains.
Democrats have been reeling on the capital gains issue since early summer, when it became apparent that six Democrats on the Ways and Means Committee were prepared to break party ranks and vote for a rate cut. That would send the measure to the House floor, and Democrats are unsure they could win there.
The capital gains tax cut proposal currently pending before the Ways and Means committee, which is sponsored by Representative Ed Jenkins, Democrat of Georgia, would temporarily lower the capital gains rate to 19.6 percent from the current 28 percent rate paid by most taxpayers. It has the backing of the Bush Administartion and all 13 Republicans on the Ways and Means Committee.
The committee is scheduled to resume its deliberations on Wednesday. The panel must complete action on tax legislation by the end of this week so that its proposals for raising revenue can be incorporated into this year's deficit-reduction package.
In the meantime, in another concession to political pressure, Mr. Rostenkowski said today that he would favor repeal of rules that require companies to give the same tax-free medical insurance benefits to rank-and-file workers that they provide their executives. Lobbyists for small businesses, for which this is very expensive, have worked vigorously against the rules.
 
Not Cleared by White House
At the Treasury, senior officials, who did not wish to be identified, said Mr. Brady's speech had not been cleared by the White House. But the officials said an Administration working group on saving and the cost of capital, headed by Robert Glauber, Under Secretary of the Treasury for finance, had been meeting for six weeks with an eye toward producing proposals that could be included in President Bush's budget and State of the Union message early next year.
''One of the Bush Administration's top priorities,'' Mr. Brady said, is ''to maintain our competitiveness where it's strong and to rebuild it where it has faltered.''
Mr. Brady maintained that the cost of capital - what companies pay after taxes for equity and debt financing - was higher in the United States than in most other developed countries. ''Our high cost of capital makes long-term investments too expensive and forces capital into short-term projects,'' he said.
The first step toward bringing down the cost, he said, was to reduce the Federal budget deficit. Other steps, he added, were to enact Mr. Bush's proposal to lower the capital gains tax and to find ways to increase the rate of personal saving.
A fourth measure, he said, would be to ''work toward the goal of tax integration, removing the double taxation on dividends.''
Under current law, corporations must pay taxes on profits before those profits are passed on in dividends to shareholders. The shareholders must then pay income taxes on the dividends they receive. Many economists believe this system encourages debt financing, since interest payments, unlike dividends, are considered a deductible expense for corporations.
 
Brady Takes Issue
Mr. Brady took issue with those in Congress who would change the system by limiting the deductibility of corporate interest payments. That would be a ''mistake,'' he said, because it would ''make capital more expensive for American companies and hurt their ability to compete.''
Instead, he added, the tax on dividends should be lowered.
The senior officials who briefed reporters said the Treasury Secretary had not decided whether corporations that pay dividends or individuals who receive them should get the tax break.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Shortages Predicted for 90's In Professors of Humanities

BYLINE: By EDWARD B. FISKE

 BODY:
Unless preventive steps are taken soon, American colleges and universities face a major shortage of faculty members starting in the next several years, according to the most comprehensive study ever conducted of the academic job market.
Contrary to the common wisdom, the study, released yesterday, found that the biggest shortfalls will occur not in the sciences but in the humanities and social sciences, and that the shortage will be caused mainly by growth in student enrollments and not by large-scale retirements of professors.
''We need to increase overall production of new Ph.D.'s by two-thirds,'' said William G. Bowen, co-author of the report. ''In the humanities and social sciences, we need to double the current numbers.'' 
 
First Statistical Confirmation
The study was conducted by Mr. Bowen, former president of Princeton University, who is now president of the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, and Julie Ann Sosa, a Princeton graduate now studying at Oxford University.
Their research provides the first statistical confirmation of a faculty shortage that has been discussed anecdotally in academic circles for the last three years.
It also puts some new twists on the debate, starting with its rejection of prevailing thought that the expected faculty shortages will result primarily from the extensive retirement of faculty members hired as American higher education was expanding in the 1950's and 1960's.
 
Main Factors Are Demographic
While such retirements will create much of the vacancies, the year-by-year rate at which they occur is expected to be steady. The major cause of the shortage will be the opening up of new jobs to accommodate a growth in enrollment expected to begin in 1997. ''The main factors are demographic,'' Mr. Bowen said, referring to the bulge of students now moving through elementary schools.
This finding alone could reduce concern about new Federal legislation banning mandatory retirement.
''Eliminating mandatory retirement won't kill off jobs,'' said Mr. Bowen. ''You're talking about a couple of percentage points.''
The study, ''Prospects for Faculty in the Arts and Sciences: A Study of Factors Affecting Demand and Supply 1987-2012,'' is being published by Princeton University Press at 41 William Street in Princeton, N.J. 08540.
The picture the authors paint of what Mr. Bowen called a ''serious staffing problem'' in higher education contrasts sharply with popular images since the 1970's, when hiring became sluggish and the taxi-driving Ph.D. an established part of the American scene.
The study reported that in the 1987-1992 period, there will be 1.6 candidates available for each available teaching position. But by 1997-2002, the figure will drop to 0.83 for each job, with 30,934 new faculty members to fill an estimated 37,091 positions. . For 2002-2007 the figure is projected to be 0.82.
 
Where Real Shortfalls Lie
The study found that contrary to widespread belief, the pending faculty shortage would not be concentrated in the natural sciences. ''There's a problem in the sciences,'' said Mr. Bowen, ''but the real shortfalls lie in the humanities and social sciences.''
The study estimated that in the 1997-2002 period the candidates-to-jobs ratio would be 0.71 in the humanities and social sciences, 0.80 in mathematics and the physical sciences, and 1.13 in the biological sciences and psychology.
Mr. Bowen said a ''flight from the arts and sciences'' was the cause. His data show that from 1971 to 1985 the percentage of graduate and undergraduate degrees conferred in the arts and sciences fell to 25 percent, from 40 percent. By contrast, major increases occurred in business and engineering.
Mr. Bowen emphasized that as in any industry, the ideal situation would be a ratio of roughly 1.3 candidates available for each job. ''You never have a perfect match,'' he said. ''If you're looking for a Renaissance scholar, it doesn't help much to have an economist available.''
 
Rise in Doctorates Needed
The study estimated that restoring the overall ratio to the 1.3 level would require a 64 percent increase in new doctorates. To do so in the humanities and social sciences would require a 92 percent increase.
Quality problems are also an issue. A ratio close to 1.0 means that colleges are in the position of having to hire just about anyone who comes along. The quality issue is magnified, he said, by data showing that the proportion of doctorates being awarded by major research universities is declining.
The study focused on the arts and sciences in four-year institutions and did not cover professional schools or their undergraduate equivalents in fields like education, engineering or business.
Mr. Bowen emphasized that the findings of the study were projections rather than predictions. ''Enlightened policies can be adopted to increase the pipeline so that the shortages we envision do not come to pass,'' he said.
 
Steps to Ease Shortage
He said universities should shorten the time required to obtain a Ph.D., which now ranges from about 7 years in mathematics to more than 12 years in the humanities. One way of doing this would be to ease up on the number of hours that candidates must spend teaching.
Another need, he said, is to increase the number of fellowships and the amount they pay. Part of the responsibility for this, he said, lies with colleges and universities and part with the Federal Government, whose support for fellowships has declined substantially since the late 1960's.
''Prospects for Faculty in the Arts and Sciences'' is the first major study of the academic labor market since a 1974 report by Allan M. Cartter that discussed the tight conditions of the recent period.
The two researchers analyzed faculty employment data and other statistics compiled by the National Research Council and other sources. They were the first to use computers to develop overall conclusions about faculty employment by assembling data on various trends, like birth or college-going rates, and by factoring out Ph.D. holders likely to seek nonacademic employment and foreign nationals likely to return to their own countries.

HEADLINE: U.S. Expands Its Sanctions Against Panama

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12

 BODY:
The United States announced today that it has expanded economic sanctions against Panama in an effort to force Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to relinquish power there.
The State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said the measures included suspending imports of Panamanian sugar and widening the list of Panamanian companies and individuals associated with General Noriega to whom Americans will be barred from making payments.
The United States first imposed sanctions against Panama last year but so far they have failed to budge General Noriega, who is under United States indictment on charges of illegal drug trafficking. 
''All of these actions are a direct result of General Noriega's continued unwillingness to respect the will of the Panamanian people by stepping down and permitting the installation of a freely elected government,'' Miss Tutwiler said.
She said Panama's 1989 sugar quota of 30,537 metric tons has been reallocated to the other countries, which she did not name, that take part in the United States sugar quota program. The loss of the sugar quota denies the Panamanian Government close to $15 million in revenue, she said.
In addition, Miss Tutwiler said, the United States trade representative has suspended a further quota of 23,043 metric tons to which Panama would have been entitled because of a quota increase.
She also said that on Aug. 31, the Bush Administration expanded a list, first published last year, of Panamanian companies and individuals affiliated with General Noriega and the military-backed administration to which Americans cannot make payments. The list is undergoing further revisions and more additions will be published soon, she said, But she could not say how broad the expansion would be or how much revenue this action would keep from the Panamanian Government.
Although she acknowledged that the United States objective was General Noriega's removal as head of the Panamanian Defense Forces, she said the Administration could not be certain the new sanctions would achieve that goal.
President Bush opposed sanctions on China after Beijing's crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators last June, saying sanctions would hurt the people more than the leadership.
Asked to square that rationale with increased sanctions against Panama, Miss Tutwiler said, ''And as far as hurting the people, Noriega is hurting them more by staying.''

HEADLINE: Princely Love in Japan: A Semi-Public Thing

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 12

 BODY:
News flash from the Department of Fairy Tales Come True:
The second son of the Emperor and Empress of Japan was walking his girlfriend home from the university where she was studying three years ago, and he popped the question while they were waiting for a traffic light.
''I remember that I said something like, 'Will you spend your life with me?' '' Prince Aya, 23 years old, disclosed today about his street-corner marriage proposal, as Japanese reporters scooped up even the most mundane details of his engagement to the daughter of an economics professor.
The Prince made his comments at the first official announcement of his ''love marriage'' - as opposed to an arranged marriage - which became formal today when it was approved by the Imperial Household Council, a 10-member body headed by Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu.
Since word leaked last month of the Prince's match with Kiko Kawashima, a commoner whom he met in a bookstore near Gakushuin University in Tokyo, Japanese have been delighted by the prospect of a royal wedding. 
The current Empress of Japan, Michiko, was the first commoner to marry a future Emperor, but she was from an upper-class industrial family, whereas Miss Kawashima's father is a faculty member of modest means who lives in university housing in Tokyo.
Miss Kawashima is said to speak excellent English and spent some time in the United States when her father did some research at the University of Pennsylvania.
Many commentators have said what a relief it has been to have the Prince, a slight, smiling young man with long hair and a mustache, become engaged in a year when Japan has been otherwise preoccupied by political crises, scandals and the like.
Prince Aya appeared today with his 23-year-old bride-to-be to answer questions, like whether he was the first man she had ever fallen in love with. ''May I answer that?'' she said when the question came, then added simply, ''Yes.''
 
There's a Senior Prince
The Prince is actually second in line of succession to the Chrysanthemum Throne occupied by Emperor Akihito, son of the late Emperor Hirohito, who died in January. Only after the end of the mourning period for Hirohito next Jan. 7 can the young couple marry.
Japanese are eagerly awaiting news of the more politically and socially significant marriage of Aya's older brother, Naruhito, who is not yet engaged although he is 29. Naruhito is to become Emperor on the death of his father. News reports have suggested that some conservative members of the Imperial Household Agency did not want Prince Aya to announce his marriage before that of his older brother. Even Prince Aya said today that it would have been ''preferable'' for his brother to marry before him.
Palace watchers agree that the main problem in finding a bride for Naruhito is concern over the enormous obligations that would be placed on the woman who is to become the next Empress. These burdens have reportedly been hard on Empress Michiko, and it is said that many well-to-do families would oppose having a daughter take on such a life.
The princess-to-be is doing graduate work in psychology at Gakushuin University, the alma mater for many members of the royal family, and Prince Aya is studying zoology at St. John's College at Oxford University, where he will graduate next June.
News accounts say the two met in 1985 when she joined a nature-and-culture club that he was heading at Gakushuin University, and they went on outings and mountain-climbing expeditions together, always accompanied by friends and chaperones.
''I saw him talking to his friends, and I thought he was much more unpretentious than I expected,'' Miss Kawashima recalled today.
Both Prince Aya and Miss Kawashima are said to be good tennis players, skiers and lovers of the outdoors. She said today that one of the first things that impressed her about her future husband was his affectionate approach to animals, like the catfish and ducks at the Imperial Palace.

HEADLINE: Human Activity Is Found to Harm Wildlife Areas

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12

 BODY:
The wildlife on Federal preserves is being harmed by human activities ranging from water-skiing to military dogfight practice, Congressional investigators reported today.
Managers in the Interior Department know that secondary uses of refuges are ''causing direct harm to wildlife,'' the investigators from the General Accounting Office concluded.
But their report said the managers often gave in to ''intense'' local pressure for more recreational areas, or were forced by law to share ownership of the land with other Government agencies or private interests like those with drilling rights. 
The G.A.O., an investigative arm of Congress, reported on the refuges at the request of Representative Mike Synar, Democrat of Oklahoma, chairman of the House Government Operations subcommittee on the environment, and Representative Gerry E. Studds, Democrat of Massachusetts, chairman of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries subcommittee on the environment.
The Fish and Wildlife Service, a part of the Interior Department that manages the preserves, acknowledged the problems in testimony prepared for a joint hearing that was held today by the two panels.
David Olsen, an assistant director of the wildlife service, said a review was under way to see whether the management system should be changed.
 
Conclusions of Study
Among the findings of the Congressional investigators were these:
* On the Des Lacs refuge in North Dakota, power boating and water-skiing have disturbed migratory bird nesting and the broods of newly hatched chicks. The production of ducks and other birds is 50 percent below what it could be.
* At the Chincoteague refuge in Virginia, off-road vehicles and thousands of visitors on the beaches are threatening the breeding of piping plovers, an endangered bird, and reducing the number of other migratory birds.
* At the Cabeza Prieta refuge in Arizona, military exercises, including air-to-air missile firings, are believed to be harming the desert bighorn sheep and the endangered Sonoran pronghorn antelope. The exercises are authorized by Congress.
* Livestock grazing at the Browns Park refuge in Colorado is hampering efforts to improve goose and duck production, disturbing the nesting birds and destroying plant growth necessary to provide optional nesting habitats.
* Drilling for new gas wells and operating existing wells at the D'Arbonne refuge in Louisiana is destroying the habitat of endangered red cockaded woodpeckers and other wildlife. A Federal judge has permitted the continued drilling.
 
Issue of Compatibility
With Federal law requiring that refuge use be compatible with wildlife protection, Mr. Olsen said, ''The issue of compatibility determinations will receive a lot of attention'' in the Government review.
He said activities like water-skiing in the Des Lacs refuge ''would clearly seem incompatible.'' But he added, ''It is a historic use of the area, one that the local public has come to expect, and is therefore extremely hard to curtail or eliminate, as you might imagine.''
Mr. Olsen said the proximity of certain refuges to urban areas ''leads inevitably to pressure'' for picnic grounds, campsites, beaches, boat ramps, baseball fields, target ranges and other recreation. ''Once any of these forms of non-wildlife oriented public use becomes established,'' he said, ''it often increases and becomes difficult to terminate.''
The Congressional report said managers reported that secondary uses were occurring on 92 percent of all refuges, including ''all manner of public, economic and military activities,'' like power boating, mining, military air exercises and use of off-road vehicles.
Managers told the investigators that they were ''sometimes willing to accept the adverse effects of some harmful activities as the price of obtaining the good will of the local public or various economic interests.''

HEADLINE: David Dinkins, With a Roar

 BODY:
What a stunning victory - more decisive than anyone anticipated. David Dinkins toppled Ed Koch, the man who has held the title so long that ''Mayor'' and ''Koch'' blurred into one word, the politician who dared try for an unprecedented fourth term. Mr. Dinkins stopped him - by offering New Yorkers everything the Mayor is not.
The combative, driven, cheerleading Ed Koch masterfully brought New York through rough times. But a city now facing different torments hungers for change, and calm. Enter Mr. Dinkins -placid, contained, conciliatory. 
Mr. Dinkins maintained a gracious dignity throughout the campaign. Even on the last day, when the Mayor grabbed front-page attention with his call for unity, Mr. Dinkins shrugged, smiled -and remained comfortably in character. He is entitled to New York's applause, for his victory and for the honorable way he earned it.
Earned may also be the right word for Rudolph Giuliani's victory over Ronald Lauder, the cosmetics heir who lavished $13 million on his campaign. The two other Democrats, Comptroller Harrison Goldin and Richard Ravitch, conducted themselves with grace and restraint in the face of predictable defeat.
No one came within a mile of predicting so monumental a Dinkins victory. It could only have happened because a stream of white voters joined with blacks in supporting Mr. Dinkins - a hopeful portent that many New Yorkers yearn for racial peace and harmony. The general election is still to come, however. With the tragic racial murder in Bensonhurst raw in New York's memory, it's too early to conclude that the city has transcended polarization. This is a fit moment to recall a day last February. Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Giuliani met, at Mr. Giuliani's prescient suggestion, and pledged to defuse any potential racial misunderstanding. It's a pledge worth renewing.
The general election campaign offers voters the opportunity to hear the nominees on issues beyond race relations. They discussed their positions on crime and drugs early in the primary campaign. Then came Bensonhurst, overshadowing all else. New Yorkers will wish to know more about their views on the proposed City Charter overhaul, about land use, about economic growth. Who would they bring into government? Mr. Dinkins needs to demonstrate decisiveness and managerial skill; Mr. Giuliani has yet to show that he's more than a zealous crime buster.
But there's time for all that. At the moment, it's enough to reflect with gratitude on all Ed Koch has done for New York over 12 years, and with admiration on what David Dinkins achieved in the campaign. Six months ago, there were plenty of patronizing voices. What a shame, they said, that he had to throw away his comfortable job as Manhattan Borough President, in a lost cause. Now, with the Age of Koch suddenly crashing, those voices are gone, drowned out by the quiet roar of David Dinkins.

HEADLINE: Give the Poor Better Choices Than Drug Dealing and Addiction;
Dangers of Abuse

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Lest any hasty or careless reader of your excellent Economic Watch account of my work on Federal marijuana enforcement (Sept. 5) might have received a misimpression about my views on legalization, allow me to state them briefly.
If marijuana were legally available, as alcohol and tobacco are legally available, it might be nearly as widely used and abused, particularly by adolescents, as alcohol and tobacco now are. In my view, that would be a bad result, so bad as to overwhelm whatever cost savings and revenue gains legalization would bring. Cutting back on Federal marijuana enforcement seems to me an obviously wise step with very limited risk. Legalization, by contrast, would be a high-risk gamble against unknown odds.
 
MARK KLEIMAN
Cambridge, Mass., Sept. 8, 1989
 The writer is lecturer in public policy, Kennedy School, Harvard University.

HEADLINE: Need Should Determine Student Financial Aid

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A decision by the House of Representatives could have a severely adverse effect on the lives and prosperity of three million low-income Americans who depend on Pell Grant financial aid to attend college. By failing to increase Pell Grant funds to reflect rising college costs, increased student participation and a new funding estimate by the United States Education Department, the House plan reduces the top Pell Grant benefit level in the 1990-91 academic year by as much as 21 percent - from $2,300 to as little as $1,800.
The purchasing power of the maximum grant, which covered 46 percent of average college costs in 1979, covers only 29 percent of those costs today. Under the House plan, the grant's purchasing power falls below 23 percent, forcing even the neediest to assume heavy loan burdens. 
The House appropriation was accompanied by a committee statement decrying ''liberalizations in student aid rules'' that provided funds to ''nontraditional'' students, including students who do not receive financial support from their parents. This statement is very troubling. The central purpose of programs such as Pell Grants is to assure that ''nontraditional'' students have the same access to college as 18- to 22-year-old white males from affluent families.
That Federal policy has made it easier for low-income adults to attend college, often part time, is a great Congressional achievement, not a problem that needs fixing. That an increasing number of members of minorities, welfare mothers and unemployed adults can receive remediation and postsecondary education is a wise investment in our people, not an unwarranted strain on resources.
The leadership of the Senate must revise the House action. The Senate should move Pell Grant purchasing power forward, not backward, by passing a program budget sufficient to raise the maximum grant to $2,500, as provided in the Congressional budget resolution. Congress should reaffirm the principle that only financial need is a correct yardstick for deciding which students receive aid and how much.
 
JOSEPH S. MURPHY, Chancellor
City University of New York
New York, Aug. 30, 1989

HEADLINE: Comptroller Primary Won By Holtzman

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn, who built a reputation as a crusading Congresswoman into a tempestuous eight-year tenure as a prosecutor, won the Democratic primary race for New York City comptroller yesterday, virtually assuring her election as the city's chief fiscal officer.
Riding her high name recognition and strong support from organized labor, civil rights and women's groups, Ms. Holtzman handily beat her closest rivals by about 2 to 1. Assemblyman Alan G. Hevesi of Queens ran second and Frank J. Macchiarola of Brooklyn, the former city Schools Chancellor, came in third.
In unofficial results with 90 percent of the precincts reporting, Ms. Holtzman received 46 percent of the vote, Mr. Hevesi 25 percent, and Mr. Macchiarola 22 percent. 
Assemblyman Jerrold L. Nadler of Manhattan, who dropped out of the race last week more than $100,000 in debt and endorsed Mr. Hevesi, received 4 percent of the vote, while Stephen J. Rose, a registered nurse who described himself as a gay-rights advocate and was affiliated with the New Alliance Party, received 3 percent.
 
A Testy Campaign
Ms. Holtzman won in four of the city's five boroughs, beating Mr. Hevesi on his home turf in Queens. Mr. Macchiarola won in Staten Island.
Ms. Holtzman's rivals ran far behind her throughout a testy campaign, each struggling to hold her below the 40 percent plurality needed to avoid a runoff with the second-highest vote getter. She now faces token Republican opposition in the general election on Nov. 7.
A 48-year-old Harvard-trained lawyer who won praise for revamping the Brooklyn District Attorney's office, hiring more blacks and women and starting new programs, Ms. Holtzman has nevertheless been harshly criticized by some of her staff members in recent years, and by her rivals in this campaign, as a poor manager.
Now she is poised to succeed Harrison J. Goldin, who gave up the Comptroller's job to run for mayor, as chief guardian of the city's coffers, helping to guide the investment of its pension funds and the marketing of its bonds. In a campaign that stressed her reputation for rooting out wrongdoing, she pledged to fight waste and corruption.
Ms. Holtzman issued no position papers in the campaign although she did participate in five debates. The candidates differed only occasionally on substantive questions about how they would handle the comptroller's job, debating instead each others's qualifications and records.
In their final debate last week, Ms. Holtzman said that if elected she would create a ''blue-ribbon'' panel of experts to recommend how the comptroller's office might best be run. The office would be reshaped substantially if proposed changes to the City Charter are approved by the voters on Nov. 7, abolishing the Board of Estimate and confining the comptroller to a more strictly fiscal role.
In a hard-fought race in which the three leading candidates spent a total of well over $1 million for television advertising - a city record for a primary for comptroller - both Mr. Hevesi and Mr. Macchiarola attacked Ms. Holtzman's record as prosecutor.
 
Attacked Their Integrity
She responded late last week with an commercial attacking their integrity. She called Mr. Hevesi a crony of the late Donald Manes's ''scandal-ridden political machine'' who ''did nothing to stop the corruption,'' and charged that Mr. Macchiarola ''squandered millions and violated rules by hiring political cronies and friends'' when he was Schools Chancellor.
Mr. Hevesi, 49, a longtime member of the Assembly's Ways and Means Committee, ran third in the polls for most of the race, but moved ahead of Mr. Macchiarola after receiving endorsements from The New York Times, The Daily News and Newsday.
Mr. Macchiarola, 48, a professor of business at Columbia University, who also headed New York City Partnership, a civic and economic development group, styled himself as ''the fighting professor'' and ran a series of humorous commercials criticizing Ms. Holtzman's performance and qualifications.

HEADLINE: Home Rule Giving Way to Joint Plans

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

 BODY:
For three years, 20 Bergen County fire departments have been saving money on new equipment by joining a common purchasing plan. Last fall, officials from 50 of the county's 70 towns met in Ridgefield Park to discuss rising garbage costs.
Midland Park is discussing common bids for road resurfacing with Glen Rock and Ramsey. Rochelle Park is planning to join the Saddle Brook recycling program. Park Ridge and Montvale are exploring joint garbage collection, and throughout the county, towns facing a shortage of fire and ambulance volunteers, as well as the prospect of higher police salaries, are seeking to share expenses and equipment. 
In the past, such measures would have been regarded, in the words of one mayor, ''as political heresy,'' as eroding the sacrosanct concept of home rule in New Jersey. But in recent years the financial pressures facing northern suburbs have pushed more to band together to explore money-saving solutions, from sharing equipment to consolidating some services.
Bergen, along with Essex County, is in the forefront of such initiatives, which would have been unlikely 10 years ago, said William G. Dressel Jr., assistant executive director of the State League of Municipalities.
 
'A Financial Imperative'
The director of planning and economic development in Bergen, Chester P. Mattson, said that in meeting with officials of every community over the last 18 months to help draft a report for the state's master development plan, he was impressed with the willingness to look beyond municipal boundaries.
A reason, he said, is that local costs have soared as Federal aid has dwindled. ''Regionalism is a financial imperative, not an ideological preference,'' he added.
In his report, Mr. Mattson appended comments by municipal officials. Many dealt with home rule and revealed that many officials were ambivalent about home rule and willing to experiment with cost-saving.
''Home rule is the best thing and the worst thing that has ever happened,'' said Mayor Bernard Kettler of Woodcliff Lake. You can drive three miles from our town and find five fire chiefs. There is also a duplicating of equipment. Why should every town have its own hook and ladder? Its own snorkel? Why should there be several different Boards of Health? Every one of our municipalities operates like a small country.''
 
'To Think Regionally'
Of three towns that could share the costs of fire equipment, Mayor Richard Mancinelli of neighboring Park Ridge, said: ''In the past, this would have been regarded as political heresy. Fiscal realities are forcing us to think regionally.''
Mayor Leonard Nicolosi of Bogota was quoted as saying, ''The time will come soon where some moderating of home rule would be found necessary if a regionalizing of expenses could have beneficial results.''
The Pascack Valley Mayors' Association in north-central Bergen has long taken strong regional approaches. In its 20 years, it has been a lobby for Emerson, Hillsdale, Montvale, Old Tappan, Oradell, Park Ridge, River Vale, Washington Township, Westwood and Woodcliff Lake.
The group helped create the state's first municipal insurance pool. And it was a meeting of the mayors, confronted with a state mandate to purchase fire helmets and other equipment to meet Federal standards, that prompted cooperative purchasing.
 
Through Unanimous Vote
Two assistant fire chiefs, Richard Talley of Emerson and Victor Egg of Oradell, worked out the system, whereby each year chiefs in 20 towns from Ramsey to Fairview send lists for equipment to the two officials, who give them to the administrator of Hillsdale, Joseph S. Rompala, who processes the bids, this year on 225 items.
The president of the association, Mayor Robert Gardner of Westwood, said home rule had been preserved, because actions could only be taken by unanimous vote.
Elsewhere, rising garbage-disposal costs prompted the East Bergen Mayors Association to invite all county mayors to meet, said Mayor Fred J. Criscuolo of Ridgefield Park, who sponsored the initial meeting.
About 50 mayors attended and created a group to meet with county officials. The discussions have touched other concerns and prompted friendships among mayors that cross party lines and improved communications with county officials, Mr. Criscuolo said.
 
Guarantees for Localities
Mr. Dressel does not see such arrangements as threats to home rule. They are not static, he said, but ''constantly changing to meet the new demands of the day.''
The ''delicate balance'' in regional decision making is in guaranteeing that localities ''have a strong voice in the process, and are not dictated to by county or state government,'' he said.
Mr. Mattson said he was aware that many people considered regionalization a step toward centralized county control, ''the camel's nose in the tent.'' But, he added, the county's role should be to provide technical support.
''What I'm trying to say is that home rule is going to spawn whatever departures occur from it,'' Mr. Mattson said. ''How we move away from home rule toward regionalization is going to start with decisions that are made as part of home rule.''

HEADLINE: Colt Told to Rehire 800 Strikers; Back Pay Is to Be in Millions

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Sept. 12

 BODY:
An administrative law judge has ordered Colt Firearms to rehire 800 strikers and pay them lost wages, a ruling that could deliver millions of dollars to striking workers who have picketed for three and a half years.
A regional official for the strikers' union, the United Automobile Workers, estimated the total value of back wages at $40 million. That would average $50,000 per worker, said the official, Robert Madore.
But a spokesman for Colt, Michael Dunn, said that even if the judge's order is upheld, the company's liability would be less than $6 million. 
The decision by Judge Marvin Roth, though not final, was greeted with joy by members of Local 376 of the U.A.W., who have been on strike since January 1986.
''They can't believe we won the whole decision,'' Mr. Madore said. ''We see that the administrative law judge did his homework, ruled in our favor and we're ready and willing to go back to work.''
 
Unfair Labor Practices Cited
''This is wonderful,'' said Marie Lambert, who worked for Colt for 14 years before the strike. ''There haven't been any Christmas presents for my kids for the past three years.''
Judge Roth, in a ruling dated Thursday and released Monday, found that Colt had engaged in dozens of unfair labor practices during the strike.
The judge found that Colt unilaterally changed working conditions, failed to bargain in good faith, offered to settle separately with employees who quit the union and rejected the union's August 1986 offer to have strikers return to work under terms of their old contract.
The company has until Oct. 5 to appeal his decision to the National Labor Relations Board in Washington.
Mr. Dunn said lawyers for Colt would study the complex decision to determine whether to appeal.
About 1,050 workers walked off the job at Colt plants in Hartford and West Hartford on Jan. 24, 1986, after working 10 months without a contract.
Colt Firearms, which was put up for sale by the New York-based Colt Industries in April, has kept the plants operating using replacement workers and about 200 union members who crossed picket lines.
 
Hearing Last Year
If neither side appeals, the five-member labor board will adopt Judge Roth's decision, said John Sauter, assistant regional director for the labor board in Hartford.
The decision came more than a year after a six-month hearing on 28 complaints issued by the labor board's Hartford office against Colt.
The Hartford office had also issued two complaints against the union.
Judge Roth dismissed Colt's allegations that its negotiators had been threatened by the union but did find that union members were guilty of strike misconduct by threatening people and property during picketing. He ordered an end to such behavior.
A state review board ruled in April 1988 that the Colt workers were victims of a lockout and were entitled to millions of dollars in unemployment benefits. Colt appealed the decision.
 
M-16 Contract Loss
Despite the labor dispute, Colt Firearms management and striking union members in July joined forces in a bid to buy the firearms division from Colt Industries.
Mr. Madore, the union leader, said the potential $40 million liability could make the division less attractive to buyers.
''We think anyone from the outside is going to have to address the issue of back-pay liability,'' he said.
Mr. Madore attributed the difference in how much the union believes Colt owes the striking workers and what the company feels it owes them to the issue of back pay and when it stops. He said that union lawyers were reviewing the judge's decision, and that the union was prepared to appeal on the back pay issue, if necessary.
Colt suffered a serious setback last year when it lost the contract to produce M-16 rifles for the Army. Officials have denied that either the loss of the contract or the strike prompted the decision to sell the firearms division.
Colt was founded in 1836 by Samuel Colt, the inventor of the first successful repeating pistol. After his death in 1862, the company developed the six-shooter that almost every cowboy carried -the legendary gun that won the West. In addition to the M-16, the standard Army-issue rifle still used today, Colt manufactures the Colt .45 handgun, the King Cobra magnum revolver and the AR-15 rifle.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Learning Conditions in U.S. Get C-Plus on 'Report Card'

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12

 BODY:
American students have little incentive to achieve good grades, the head of the nation's largest school administrators' group says.
The official, Scott Thomson, executive director of the National Association of Secondary School Principals, examined learning conditions in the United States and compared them to those in South Korea and West Germany.
In a ''National Report Card'' that he prepared for the October issue of the association's journal, Mr. Thomson awarded South Korea an A-minus and West Germany a B-plus. He gave the United States a C-plus, saying, ''American society doesn't measure up.'' 
In preparing his report card, Mr. Thomson said on Monday that he examined five broad categories that researchers say consistently affect learning.
The United States received a D for prevalence of illegal drugs and B's for the percentage of its gross national product devoted to public education, the place of schooling in family value structure and the percentage of families below the poverty line. The only A for the United States was in the percentage of its 16-year-olds in school.
 
North Carolina Survey Cited
Mr. Thomson pointed to a North Carolina survey last year that found that half of the high school juniors were working, with 67 percent of these students working 20 hours or more a week. In South Korea, he said, students ''simply do not hold jobs while attending school.'' In West Germany, students are not in the job market except perhaps informally in family-owned businesses.
''Compared to their international counterparts, most American students not only have fewer incentives to achieve good grades, they also have more incentives to hold jobs during the school week,'' Mr. Thomson said in the article.
Mr. Thomson contended that many American students were lured into low-paying jobs to earn money for designer clothes promoted by advertisements on television. He said a market analysis concern, Teenage Research Unlimited, found that television's focus on the teen-age consumer market has now dropped to the age of 15 from 18 because the typical high school junior has nearly $60 a week in spending money from jobs and allowances.
''Brand loyalties are established at an early age, hence the hard sell to youth,'' Mr. Thomson said. ''The American television industry tends to view children and youth as consumers rather than as learners.''
Commenting on television and its effect on learning science and mathematics, Mr. Thomson said 71 percent of 13-year-old South Korean students consistently watched science programs, while only 37 percent of Americans of similar age watched such programs, the lowest of any group studied.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Lloyd Bentsen proposed restoring I.R.A.'s on a widely available, tax-deductible basis as an alternative to President Bush's plan to lower the capital gains tax rate. The move by the Senate Finance Committee chairman represents an attempt by Democrats to capture some political advantage on the tax issue. It came as the House Ways and Means Committee struggled toward a compromise on alternatives to a cut in the capital gains tax rate. [Page A1.] 
 
The service and investment sector of the economy showed a $200 million deficit in the second quarter, the Commerce Department said. It was the first such deficit in 30 years. [D1.]
 
The union that represents most airline pilots has been drained by the six-month strike at Eastern and has begun polling its members on whether to continue financial support for the walkout. [D1.]
 
Japan's trade surplus plunged 31 percent, helped by a surge in oil imports, strong domestic demand and a strong dollar. [D22.]
 
COMPANIES
 
Maneuvering to end the bankruptcy of Public Service of New Hampshire took an unanticipated turn as New England Electric made a takeover offer that would impose rate increases lower than those in a rate schedule that had previously been agreed upon. [D1.]
 
Dow Chemical and United Technologies will form a venture to build plastics, or composite parts, for the aerospace, automotive and military contracting industries. [D1.]
 
CBS's ''48 Hours'' is a valuable property, not because it is a hit in the ratings, but because it costs so little to produce. [D1.]
 
Fuji Bank agreed to buy all of Kleinwort Benson's stock, the first such purchase since the Fed agreed to allow Japanese firms to continue to act as primary dealers. [D1.]
 
Intel introduced a computer microprocessor that employs a breakthrough technology enabling it to perform two tasks at once. [D5.] Wang brought out a line of minicomputers that it says is three times more powerful than its current systems. [D5.]
 
Eli Lilly is recalling batches of all drugs made in an Indianapolis plant after the F.D.A. found manufacturing problems. [D4.]
 
Procter & Gamble said it would receive $125 million for violations of its patent on crisp and chewy cookies. [D4.]
 
TECHNOLOGY
 
Strict environmental rules are making landfills increasingly complex and expensive. But opportunities are opening up for companies that can meet the new standards. [D6.]
 
A Dallas company has developed an electronic operator system that uses voice synthesis and recognition technology. [D6.]
 
MARKETS
 
Stock prices edged up broadly on higher volume. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 2.85 points, to 2,707.26. [D8.]
 
Prices of Treasury issues were narrowly mixed in sluggish trading. Short- and intermediate-term issues again outperformed longer-dated securities. [D14.] Yields for C.D.'s and money market accounts continued to show small declines in the last week. [D6.]
 
The dollar was narrowly mixed as traders awaited new economic reports. Gold prices were also mixed. [D15.] Coffee prices plunged on indications that the U.S. will not support a return to international export quotas. [D15.]

The Reagan Administration's dollar policy nearly resulted in disaster in the early 1980's, two Government specialists say in a new book. They argue that Congress and private interests should be drawn into currency debates. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
 
The utility industry is changing, and competition may make it difficult for small companies to survive. Market Place. [D8.]

HEADLINE: U.S. Trade In Services At a Deficit

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12

 BODY:
The service and investment sector of the United States economy, where international surpluses have long been relied upon to offset deficits in merchandise trade, is now itself showing red ink.
Although the overall deficit in the current account - which represents trade in merchandise, services and investments - narrowed in the second quarter of 1989, the United States showed a deficit of $200 million in the service and investment sector, the Commerce Department said today, largely because of increased earnings by foreigners on assets held in the United States. It was the first time in about 30 years that this sector has shown a deficit. In the first quarter, the services and investment showed a surplus of $1.5 billion. 
The deficit in investment earnings reflected payments from United States entities of interest, dividends and other earnings from the holdings of American assets by foreigners, a trend that has been increasing in recent years. The deficit was seen by economists not as a dramatic new setback but as the inevitable result of Federal budget deficits and the need to finance them and support other activities by borrowing from and selling assets to foreigners.
 
Belt-Tightening Urged
''The bottom line,'' said William R. Cline, a senior fellow of the Institute of International Economics, ''is that we have to tighten our belts to service our debt.''
American investment and service receipts for the quarter rose $700 million, to $55 billion, the department said, but payments rose more than three times as much, to $55.2 billion. The resulting deficit was thought to have been the first since 1958, but the department said it was not sure of the exact date because of changes in the way the figures are gathered.
Taken by itself, the investment account had fallen into deficit for two quarters last year.
The overall American current-account deficit, which also includes unilateral transfers such as foreign aid, climbed $600 million in the quarter ended June 30, to $31 billion, the department reported.
The deficit in traded goods has been shrinking of late but many analysts believe this improvement might be ending because of strength in the dollar that makes United States exports more expensive in world markets and imported goods cheaper. In the spring quarter, the merchandise deficit narrowed by 2.3 percent, but this was not enough to keep the overall current account deficit from rising.
On Friday, the department is to report the monthly merchandise deficit for July, with analysts predicting it will rise to about $9 billion, from June's $8.1 billion.
Today, attention was focused largely on the swing into deficit, albeit not surprising, of the service and investment sector, a category in which the drain in the investment component is now offsetting continued good performance among such traditional export earners as insurance, accounting, advertising, brokerage, shipping and computer and medical services.
To maintain its advantage in tradeable skills the United States is pressing to bring services under the international trading rules administered by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
The investment account, however, is likely to increase its drag on the balance of payments. Receipts from American assets abroad rose slightly in the latest reporting quarter, but payments of income on foreign assets in the United States - direct investments such as plants or real estate and portfolio investment such as stocks and Government bonds - increased far more, the department reported.
The service and investment surplus, which peaked in 1981 at $43.8 billion, fell to $20.8 billion in 1984, then rose for three years in a row before plunging to $15.3 billion in 1988.
 
New Categories Included
This category does not include flows of capital, only the interest and other earnings associated with them. The department amended its procedures this summer to include educational, travel, business, professional and technical services. Without the change, said Christopher L. Bach, a Commerce official, the services and investment deficit would have been about $176 million.
But while Mr. Cline said the latest figures showed an urgent need for a change in American policy - by cutting the budget deficit and bringing down the international value of the dollar - others said there was no cause for alarm.
''If it's a concern, it's a very long-term concern,'' contended Roger M. Kubarych, a top official at Henry Kaufman & Company, the investment banking concern, declaring that the necessary investment in American productive capacity was, in fact, being sustained and that it did not much matter that foreign money was doing it.
Nonetheless, he added, the investment deficit ''should be a longer-term warning that we've got to get our savings rate up.''

CORRECTION-DATE: September 19, 1989, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday about the United States' current account deficit referred incorrectly to the change for the second quarter.
The deficit widened by $600 million, to $31 billion.
