HEADLINE: Pilots' Union Is Divided By Walkout at Eastern

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
The union that represents the vast majority of the nation's airline pilots has been drained by the six-month strike at Eastern Airlines and has begun polling its membership on whether to continue financial support for the walkout.
The strike has divided the union, the 38,000-member Air Line Pilots Association, as thousands of pilots at other airlines withhold their union-mandated contributions to the strike and as some leaders privately question whether the battle is still worth the expense. Some union leaders also worry that the costly strike has weakened the union's bargaining position in talks with other airlines.
The union has already put up $69.5 million for the strike, its president, Henry A. Duffy, said. Special strike contributions of $33 million have been assessed, of which $22.5 million has been collected. Almost $10 million has been raised by borrowing against the union's building in Herndon, Va. The balance of the spending has come from the union's major-contingency fund, now at $13 million. 
Mr. Duffy said the union could afford to pay strike benefits as long as members voted to continue their assessments and did not fall further behind in payments. The A.L.P.A.'s finances should bounce back quickly from the strike because even without a special assessment its union dues and major-contingency fund fees total 2.35 percent of members' annual salaries, which average $83,000, he said. The separate strike assessment is about 3.5 percent.
''One thing that this association has is a good recovery process,'' Mr. Duffy said.
The strike has not harmed the union's ability to negotiate with other airlines, he said. But some leaders of the union disagree, and are concerned that new applications of bankruptcy law and the high cost of the long strikes that followed deregulation of the airline industry have diminished the influence of the pilots' union.
 
Strike Weapon Questioned
The Eastern dispute ''has once again pointed out that strikes are not a way to deal with problems,'' said an A.L.P.A. executive board member who asked not to be identified. ''The way the laws are written, that weapon has been taken away from labor.''
The board member was referring to the apparently successful use of the bankruptcy courts by Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of Eastern's parent, the Texas Air Corporation, to shield Eastern from the strike.
By filing on March 9 for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, the airline has avoided paying its bankers and suppliers and therefore has conserved the cash to train replacement pilots and rebuild as a smaller carrier. The filing came five days after Eastern's machinists, supported by the pilots and flight attendants, went on strike.
The financial problems of the pilots' union come at a busy time for labor relations in the industry. Contracts at USAir, Delta Air Lines and United Airlines are all in negotiations or mediation.
The shortage of money has already affected bargaining at another airline, a top A.L.P.A. official said. Leaders of 5,000 pilots at Northwest Airlines abruptly abandoned strike threats and agreed to a new contract last month, in part because of concern that pilots at other airlines would refuse to pay benefits for two strikes, he said. ''If they aren't supporting 2,500 Eastern pilots, they sure aren't going to support 7,500 pilots,'' the official said. About 2,500 of the 3,500 pilots at Eastern when the strike began have not gone back to work at the airline.
Union officials at Northwest declined to comment. Mr. Duffy said the union could have paid for concurrent strikes at Northwest and Eastern.
 
Effect Called Minimal
Joseph P. Kernan, chairman of USAir's 3,200 pilots, and James H. Suckow, chairman of 7,500 pilots at Delta, both played down the impact of events at Eastern on their respective contract talks. ''The effect the Eastern strike has had on our negotiations has been minimal if at all,'' Mr. Suckow said.
But David Lewin, a business professor at Columbia University, disagreed. He said it would hurt the bargaining position of the union at other airlines.
Despite its problems, the union still has many strengths. It has contracts with every major airline except American, which has a small union, and Continental, another Texas Air subsidiary at which the A.L.P.A. retains organizing rights but no longer represents pilots.
National union leaders ''still can raise the money'' when it is needed, Mr. Kernan said. ''We're a resilient organization. We've had setbacks and we've come back, and we'll come back again.''
Indeed, the union was also short of cash after an unsuccessful walkout at Continental Airlines in 1983. After that strike the union started its major-contingency fund, which collects $1.5 million a month from members.
 
Real Estate Holdings
The union also has an office building in downtown Washington, that has been appraised at $25 million but carries only a $13 million mortgage, Mr. Duffy said. And it has other real estate holdings purchased for a total of $1 million and also not mortgaged, he said.
Finally, the major-contingency fund has made $7 million in secured loans to Eastern pilots that should be repaid next year, Mr. Duffy said.
A.L.P.A. officials also say the funds spent on the walkout - including preparations that began in 1986 -have struck Mr. Lorenzo a heavy blow. Indeed, Eastern was virtually shut down for four months, and its president estimates the strike's cost at $400 million. The airline plans to emerge from bankruptcy protection this winter with most of its pre-strike schedule intact but with little cash to cushion it against an economic downturn.
Yet the union's weakened finances were one reason for the executive board's decision on Aug. 18 not to call a national work stoppage at all airlines in support of the Eastern pilots. ''If there had been $100 million in the kitty, I would have worried a lot less about it,'' a board member said. ''The funds were not available.''
 
Assessments Reduced
The drain from the union's coffers has accelerated in the last two months as a growing number of pilots have reduced or stopped payments of their special assessments, said two executive board members who asked not to be identified.
Pilots are dropping out of the special assessment program or moving to extended payment programs at a rate of nearly 4,000 a month, the two board members said. Mr. Duffy said the rate was lower, although he did not have a precise figure.
The assessments have financed strike benefits of $600 a week for Eastern pilots on strike. The assessments have also paid for a public relations and lobbying effort that initially won widespread public support for the Eastern pilots.
Another A.L.P.A. executive board member said the Eastern pilots should return to work and questioned whether their strike benefits should be maintained. ''If you continue to tell people who are emotionally involved that you are going to pay them $2,400 a month, they have less incentive to face reality,'' he said.
 
Ballots Sent Out
Ballots have been sent to all union members asking whether the strike assessments should continue. The ballots are to be counted on Oct. 10. If the membership votes against the measure, the last biweekly benefits would be paid on Oct. 14, while the assessments would continue for another month to restore $10 million to the major-contingency fund.
''We anticipate a positive vote,'' said Edward J. Breen, the chairman of the Eastern pilots' strike committee.
But in interviews over the last three weeks, the chairmen of several A.L.P.A. chapters were less confident. ''In my view, it would be a toss-up,'' said Mr. Kernan at USAir, who added that he favored continuing the strike assessments.
In an earlier setback for Eastern pilots, the national union's executive board voted on Aug. 18 not to allow them to retain their seniority automatically if they took jobs at other airlines.
Worse off than the A.L.P.A. is local 553 of the Transport Workers Union, which represents 6,000 Eastern flight attendants. The T.W.U. does not have a strike fund, so the local was forced to create one after the strike began and hold fund-raisers for it, said Mary Jane Barry, the local's president. The fund makes payments only to members facing financial hardship.
The International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, which represents 8,500 striking Eastern machinists and ramp-service workers, has $100 million in its strike fund, enough to pay the current benefits of $100 a week for two years, a spokesman for the Eastern machinists said.

HEADLINE: Fuji Bank To Buy Unit Of Kleinwort

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
Fuji Bank Ltd. and Kleinwort Benson Ltd. announced yesterday that Fuji had agreed to buy 100 percent of the stock in Kleinwort Benson Government Securities Inc., a Chicago-based dealer in Treasury securities.
The deal is significant because it will give Fuji control over a primary dealer. The Federal Reserve trades securities directly with primary dealers and many institutional investors will place orders only with such firms. 
The agreement is the first purchase of an American primary dealer since the Federal Reserve Board voted in August to allow Japanese firms to continue to act as primary dealers in Treasury securities, although several Japanese firms had already acquired such control before the matter became an issue.
 
Law Passed in 1988
In response to complaints by American securities firms that they were being discriminated against in Japan, Congress passed the Primary Dealer's Act of 1988 as an amendment to the omnibus trade bill. It would have excluded Japanese firms from the elite group of primary dealers if the Fed found the Japanese Government had discriminated against Wall Street firms operating in Tokyo.
The Fed's ruling cleared the way for yesterday's announcement of the deal, which is worth $44 million. It has been under negotiation for two years, said Tom O. Chandos, a director of Kleinwort Benson in London.
Last year, just after Congress passed the trade bill, Fuji purchased 24.9 percent of the Kleinwort Benson unit for $14.5 million, keeping within the 25 percent limit set by the law. In addition, Fuji assumed the unit's subordinated debt that was held by its London-based parent.
American firms had complained that they were being excluded from the syndicates that bought bonds from the Japanese Government, denying them an essential product to sell to customers. In addition, the American firms said, officials in Tokyo were sharing important economic information with Japanese firms first, putting the American firms at a competitive disadvantage.
 
Concessions Have Been Made
Since then, the Japanese have made a number of concessions to the American firms, including offering more bonds for sale through open auction.
Despite the Fed's vote, some members of Congress expressed concern yesterday about the Fuji purchase. ''The Fed's decision opened the door for more of these deals to happen, and without responsive action on the other side of the Pacific, I think that the situation will remain unfair,'' said Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat.
Wall Street deal makers who work with the Japanese said a number of banks were considering investments in primary dealers. ''We've had a regular dialogue with all of the largest Japanese banks, and our view is that this is part of a continuing trend,'' said Mark J. Lerner, a vice president of the Japan Banking Group of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. ''Japanese banks are continuing to show interest in expansion in the American markets through select investment and acquisitions through firms such as primary dealerships.''
Fuji will be joining a number of other Japanese companies that control primary dealerships in the United States. Those companies include Nomura Securities, Daiwa Securities, Nikko Securities and Yamaichi Securities. Primary dealers are also controlled by Japanese banks, including the Industrial Bank of Japan, the Long Term Credit Bank of Japan and the Sanwa Bank.
The deal with Fuji, which is subject to approval by the Fed, would give the company a significant foothold in the American securities market by allowing it to learn in advance about Government securities offerings. That would increase the bank's legitimacy in that market in Japan, bringing greater amounts of capital from Japan to the unit, officials with both companies said.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Talk Is Cheap, Dollars Dear

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
IF President Bush decided to order tail lights for the Stealth bomber or buy a scrimshaw collection for the National Gallery, he would first have to convince Congress. But there is no such restraint on the unelected Government officials who spent $12 billion this summer to hold down the exchange value of the dollar - and kept it secret until last week.
I. M. Destler and C. Randall Henning, specialists in government at the Institute of International Economics in Washington, see nothing sinister in the way exchange policies are carried out. Day-to-day discretion and the legal right to keep decisions secret are needed to achieve maximum impact in currency transactions. 
But in their new book, ''Dollar Politics,'' they draw a sharp line between policy making and execution. They argue that the Reagan Administration's laissez-faire dollar policy, adopted without serious discussion in or out of the White House, led to ''near catastrophe'' in the early 1980's. Their proposed remedy: drawing Congress and private interests into future dollar debates before the fact.
Americans hardly noticed exchange rates until the 1960's, and for good reason. Europe and Asia failed or thrived on their ability to compete abroad, and their competitiveness depended heavily on their currencies' exchange value. But American manufacturers produced largely for the home market, and had little to fear from imports.
America's splendid economic isolation has gone the way of the vacuum tube. But business and labor lobbies have been slow to grasp the importance of exchange rates. Dollar policy has remained a political afterthought - a bone to throw to the resident ideologue at the Treasury, a few platitudes inserted in economic summit declarations to placate the foreigners.
As a result, Mr. Destler and Mr. Henning argue, there have been ill-considered swings from intervention to neglect. And while the costs of erratic shifts might have been supportable in the 1970's, continuing integration of world markets for money and goods has greatly raised the stakes.
In April 1981, Beryl Sprinkel, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, declared that the price of the dollar, like the price of computers or corn flakes, was best left to the free market. Over the next three years the dollar's exchange value rose by half, forcing hundreds of efficient American businesses to close or move abroad.
Only in 1985, with the trade deficit approaching the $140 billion level, did the Administration stop crowing about the high-flying dollar as evidence of the success of Reaganomics. And Secretary James Baker's decision to intervene, announced at the Plaza Hotel accord that September, came only after the dollar had already begun to fall.
The policy in force today, maintenance of the dollar's exchange value within an undisclosed band, exudes a vague sense of probity - the destination of the 747-of-state may be unknown, but almost everyone seems satisfied that the captain can fly around the thunderheads.
The plane's destination, however, may matter as much as the pilot's ability to avoid wind shear.
Dollar stability at current exchange rates implies United States current-account deficits exceeding $100 billion for the indefinite future. And as Walter Russell Mead of the World Policy Institute in New York argues, failure to cope with this chronic external imbalance is likely to halt the trend toward world economic integration. The resulting fragmentation of the industrial economies into isolated trading blocs, he says, would sharply reduce growth.
To Mr. Destler and Mr. Henning, the best way to insure that international finance receives as much attention as higher-profile budget and monetary issues is to make it a formal process.
Congress, they say, should create oversight committees that focus specifically on the dollar and the current account. The Administration should be required to review its exchange policy annually, reporting its findings to the public. And a business-labor advisory group on the dollar should be created, diffusing pressure for protectionism and focusing attention on broader issues of competitiveness.
Cynical political analysts scoff at the idea that the obligation to talk about exchange-rate policy will influence its substance. In Washington, where money talks and nobody walks, it is assumed that those with a stake in the issue already have adequate means to make their views felt.
But the experience of the early 1980's, when outsiders to the establishment were busy redrawing the world economic order on the backs of napkins, suggests otherwise. In any case, talk is cheap -and well worth the price if it even marginally increases the chances that George Bush and his successors will take consequences of current-account deficits more seriously.

HEADLINE: Dow Advances by 2.85 as Volume Rises

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stock prices edged up on a broad front yesterday as volume rose moderately.
The Dow Jones industrial average added 2.85 points, to 2,707.26, but that was well below the 10-point gain it was showing about an hour before the 4 P.M. close of trading. The secondary market showed much more strength, however, as advances on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered declines by 824 to 632. 
''Select technology and airline issues continued to be among the stronger and more active issues,'' said Brian Luedtke, an analyst at Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood Inc. in Minneapolis. ''Investors remain hesitant ahead of Friday's economic reports.''
Mr. Luedtke said that lagging areas had shown strength recently while leading averages ''have been caught in a consolidation range.''
Traders in both stocks and bonds remained nervous about the spate of economic data scheduled to be released on Friday, which includes reports on the Producer Price Index, industrial production, capacity utilization, merchandise trade and manufacturing and trade inventories and orders.
 
Takeover Issues in Spotlight
In yesterday's market, individual takeover-related issues remained in the spotlight. Volume on the Big Board rose to 142.1 million shares from a slow 126 million shares on Monday.
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 1.04 points, to 348.70, while the New York Stock Stock Exchange composite index tacked on 0.58, to 193.88.
Among individual issues, UAL rose 4 5/8, to 281. An employee-management group is offering $300 a share to take the United Airlines unit of UAL private.
Other airlines showed mixed results. AMR slipped a point, to 82 3/4; Delta gained 3/8, to 75 7/8; Pan Am was unchanged at 3 3/4, and USAir also stayed the same, at 48 1/2. The results of the group, however, helped lift the Dow transportation average by 7.47 points.
Procter & Gamble slipped 1/2, to 123 1/4, despite the fact that RJR Nabisco, Pepsico and United Biscuits agreed to pay the company a total of $125 million to settle a patent-infringement suit.
 
Chemical Stocks Advance
Some chemical stocks gained on news of an early-morning explosion at Quantum Chemical's ethylene unit. Union Carbide was up 1/2, to 29 5/8, while Ethyl gained 1 1/8, to 27. Dow Chemical, however, slipped 1/4, to 101 1/2.
Datapoint was the most active stock, slipping 1/2, to 5 3/8, on a volume of 2.7 million shares. Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor, said he had raised his stake in the company to 40 percent.
Among actively traded blue chips were A.T.&T., up 1/2, to 40 1/2; McDonald's 5/8, to 29 5/8; Exxon 3/4, to 45 3/8, and I.B.M. 5/8, to 116 7/8.
On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index rose 2.11 points, to 384.54, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index was up 1.44 points, to 471.86.
Technology stocks were strong in the over-the-counter sector. Lin Broadcasting, which said on Monday that it would merge its cellular telephone operations with those of the BellSouth, rose 1 3/4, to 108 1/2.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Narrowly Mixed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in continued sluggish trading yesterday. For the second straight session, short- to intermediate-term issues outperformed longer-dated securities.
Dealers said that demand from institutional investors for four-year and five-year Treasury notes was particularly strong. As much as $1 billion worth of the issues were rumored to have been purchased. 
''There is a lot of uncertainty around about the high-yield market, about the stock market and about the economy in general,'' one government bond trader said. ''As a consequence, there is tons of money that is just hiding out in the front end of the market right now. And that story will hang around for a while.''
 
Economic Reports Due
At least some of the questions about the economy will be answered tomorrow and Friday, when many reports, including retail sales and producer price data for August, are scheduled to be released. A number of market participants have indicated that uncertainty about the upcoming releases is momentarily preventing them from making any strategic decisions.
''We are bullish in the longer run, but think there is still a chance that the economy could show a little more resilience,'' said Roger A. Early, a vice president at the Federated Research Corporation, ''and that long-term interest rates could back up to 8.30 percent to 8.50 percent before heading lower.'' Federated Research is a unit of Federated Investors Inc., the Pittsburgh money management firm that manages more than $21 billion in Treasury securities. Bond prices eased again yesterday. In late trading, the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent bonds that mature in 2019 were offered at a price of 100 14/32, down by 7/32, to yield 8.08 percent, up from 8.06 on Monday.
Among the secondary Treasury note issues, the 8 1/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 22/32, up by 1/32, to yield 8.07 percent. And the 8 1/8 percent four-year notes were offered at 100 2/32, up by 3/32, to yield 8.10 percent.
 
Treasuries Fall Again
Treasury bill rates dipped again yesterday, following big declines on Monday.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.58 percent, down by 4 basis points, or hundredths of a point. And six-month bill rates dipped by 5 basis points, to a late-offered rate of 7.57 percent.
Elsewhere, new-issue activity in the tax-exempt municipal bond market picked up markedly yesterday, as about $1.5 billion in new competitive and negotiated deals, including the first issue from the Washington Public Power Supply System since 1982, were priced.
Aside from the Washington Public Power issue, which was increased to $721 million, from $450 million, the New Jersey Housing and Finance Agency offered $256 million worth of serial and term bonds in a negotiated transaction.
The largest single maturity of the issue is a $149 million issue of bonds that mature on Oct. 1, 2029. The bonds, which are subject to provisions of the alternative minimum tax, carry a 7.70 percent coupon and were priced at par.
Merrill Lynch Capital Markets was the lead manager for the underwriting, which is rated AAA by Moody's Investors Service Inc. The issue is insured by the Municipal Bond Investors' Assurance Corporation.
A number of issues were priced at competitive bid.
The largest was a $68.5 million offering of serial bonds from Mississippi.
Maturities on the bonds are from 1990 to 2009, with coupons ranging from 5.90 percent on bonds maturing next year, to 6.90 percent on those that mature in 2009.
 
Morgan Unit Wins Bonds
A bid from an investor group led by J. P. Morgan Securities, the investment banking subsidiary of J. P. Morgan & Company, won the bonds, which are rated AA by Moody's and AA-minus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the corporate debt market, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation priced a $276 million offering of senior debentures through an underwriting syndicate led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.
The 10 1/8 percent debentures, which mature on Sept. 15, 2009, were priced at $99.35, to yield 10.201 percent, 2.11 percentage points above the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds at pricing.
The issue, which is noncallable for life, is rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB by Standard & Poor's.
Activity in the secondary markets for corporate and tax-exempt bonds was light, the dealers said. The prices of most municipal issues dipped by about one-eighth of a point, the market participants said.
Meanwhile, long-term corporate issues dipped, also by about one-eighth of a point, while intermediate-term issues were unchanged.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Coffee Prices Fall on News Of U.S. Stance on Quotas

 BODY:
Coffee futures prices plunged yesterday on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange on indications the United States will not support a return to international export quotas that would raise coffee prices.
On other markets, sugar futures rose sharply; grains and soybeans were lower; energy futures weakened; precious metals advanced, and livestock and meat futures were mixed.
All New York coffee futures except the contract for September delivery plunged the permitted daily limit of 6 cents a pound. The September contract, which does not have a daily limit, tumbled 6.68 cents, to 81.48 cents a pound, a two-and-a-half-week low. 
Analysts said prices plummeted amid panicked selling prompted by a report that the Bush Administration will reject Colombia's plea for United States support in pushing for a resumption of export quotas among producer members of the International Coffee Organization.
 
Quotas Suspended in July
The 74-nation cartel suspended the quotas in July amid discord caused in part by American demands for controls on sales of coffee at cut-rate prices to Soviet-bloc nations that are not members of the coffee organization. The United States is the organization's largest consumer member.
A return to export quotas would lead to higher coffee prices and would help the economy of Colombia, which needs money to battle cocaine cartels.
Sugar futures prices soared in New York after the United States announced it had raised its 1989 sugar import quota by 860,000 metric tons, to 1.99 million, and had extended the import quota period by nine months to Sept. 30, 1990. Sugar futures rose 0.37 cent to 0.54 cent, with October at 13.95 cents a pound.
 
Soybean and Corn Down
Corn and soybean futures fell moderately on the Chicago Board of Trade, under pressure from a lack of overnight frost in the Midwest and forecasts for improved crop weather next week. Oat and wheat futures also retreated.
After the close, the Agriculture Department issued a new crop report revising downward its August estimates for 1989 United States corn and soybean production and raising its wheat-crop estimate.
West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 6 cents to 7 cents lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with October at $19.70 a barrel; heating oil was 0.64 cent lower to 0.15 cent higher, with October at 55.37 cents a gallon, and unleaded gasoline was 0.03 cent to 0.28 cent lower, with October at 56.89 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar and Gold Are Mixed As Traders Await Reports

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was narrowly mixed yesterday, marking time as traders awaited a batch of economic reports to be issued later in the week. Gold prices were also mixed. Traders were reluctant to make significant adjustments to their positions in advance of the reports due from Washington tomorrow and Friday, analysts said. 
The Government will issue its August retail sales figures tomorrow, and on Friday, reports on the July trade deficit and August producer prices and industrial production will be released.
The reports are expected to indicate how the economy is faring, providing clues on whether the Federal Reserve will adjust its policy on interest rates. Dollar traders hope the Fed will tighten credit, which moves interest rates higher and is bullish for the currency.
 
Focus on Producer Prices
Analysts said the market was most concerned about the producer price report, which will show whether inflation is accelerating. If it is, the Fed would be expected to nudge interest rates upward.
In London, the dollar fell against the British pound. It cost $1.5470 to buy one pound, more expensive than $1.5450 late Monday. In later New York trading, the pound rose to $1.5485 from $1.5460.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday, included: 1.9865 West German marks, unchanged; 1.7140 Swiss francs, up from 1.7135; 6.6920 Swiss francs, up from 6.6910; 1,422.125 Italian lire, down from 1,425.875, and 1.8725 Canadian dollars, up from 1.18715.
 
Dollar Rates in Europe
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Monday, included: 1.9880 marks, up from 1.9875; 1.7160 Swiss francs, up from 1.7150; 6.6950 French francs, down from 6.6970; 2.2330 Dutch guilders, down from 2.2425; 1,421.75 lire, down from 1,424.75, and 1.1892 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1873.
In Tokyo, where trading ends before Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell 1.04 yen, to 146.73 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 147.08 yen, and in New York, the dollar edged up to 146.905 yen, from 146.70 late Monday.
In New York gold trading, the Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $385.50 for a troy ounce of gold, up 40 cents from late Monday, and on the Commodity Exchange, gold edged up 30 cents, to $359.50. Gold was unchanged in London at $358.75 an ounce and fell in Zurich to $358.55 from Friday's $360. In Hong Kong, gold rose $1.03 an ounce, to $359.93.

HEADLINE: Japanese Trade Surplus Narrows by 31%

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 12

 BODY:
A surge in oil imports, robust domestic demand and a strong dollar helped narrow Japan's trade surplus by 31 percent in August, and economists here say the trend should continue for the rest of 1989.
The Government reported today that the trade surplus narrowed to an unadjusted $3.44 billion in August, from $4.97 billion a year earlier, marking the fourth straight month the trade gap has shrunk.
It also said the trade gap narrowed to an adjusted $4.43 billion in August, from $5.05 billion a month earlier. 
''The underlying trend is continuing,'' said Shoichi Enkyo, an economist at the Bank of Tokyo.
Japan's sensitive trade surplus with the United States shrank moderately, to $3.03 billion, from $3.24 billion a year earlier, as Americans continued their heavy purchases of autos and other Japanese-made goods. Shows Strength in U.S. ''If anything, it suggests that the U.S. economy is not quite as weak as people had thought,'' said Peter Morgan, chief economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities.
Japan's vehicle exports grew a surprisingly fast 4.7 percent on a rise in shipments to the United States, Europe and Asia, after year-to-year declines of 5.3 percent in July and 1.7 percent in June, Mr. Morgan said.
Some analysts said that past dollar weakness was continuing to increase the cost-competitiveness of American products on foreign markets. The dollar's recent strength against the yen has also cut Japan's export earnings by depressing the dollar value of Japanese exports contracted in yen, economists said.
''At a later date, however, the depreciation of the yen will add to export competitiveness'' in Japan, Mr. Enkyo said.
If the dollar stays strong, Japanese export volumes will eventually balloon, reversing the current narrowing trend in its surplus, economists warn.
 
Trend Seen Continuing
''This trend will continue at least through the end of this calendar year,'' Mr. Enkyo said. ''But toward spring, we could see the rather weaker yen increasing the volume of Japanese exports.''
Economists forecast a reduction in Japan's customs-cleared trade surplus to between $65 billion and $73 billion for this calendar year from $77.6 billion in 1988.
In the August period, the shrinking trade surplus was linked most directly to the stronger demand for higher-priced imported oil. The value of crude oil imports last month rose to $1.86 billion, up 39 percent from a year earlier. A buildup of inventories before the introduction of an oil import tariff in August last year led to plummeting oil imports that month.

HEADLINE: Eating Well

BYLINE: By DENSIE WEBB; Densie Webb, a freelance writer and editor, is a registered dietitian.

 BODY:
THOUGH it's hard to recall now, eggs once had high status. They were thought of as a wholesome, natural and nutritious food. But no more.
That belief has been shattered by the national obsession with cholesterol. Eggs - egg yolks to be exact - are one of the most concentrated sources of cholesterol in the American diet. Egg lovers who have wanted to eat less cholesterol but not eliminate eggs have generally turned to packaged egg substitutes to replace whole eggs in cooking. But the taste of several of these is, shall we say, different from real eggs. 
Enter real eggs advertised as having ''25 percent less cholesterol.'' The eggs, produced by R. W. Sauder Inc. of Lititz, Pa. and Rosemary Farm of Santa Maria, Calif., began appearing in supermarkets last year. They were said to have 25 percent less than the 274 milligrams of cholesterol that then constituted the United States Department of Agriculture standard. But it was soon discovered that regular eggs actually had less cholesterol than the Government standard.
''The 274 number was based on old data collected from the 1950's through the 1970's,'' said Cathy McCharen, the director of the Egg Nutrition Center in Washington, which represents the egg industry.
New analyses by the U.S.D.A. found that regular eggs had 213 milligrams of cholesterol. The lower number prompted the American Heart Association to adjust its longstanding recommendation that people eat no more than three egg yolks per week to no more than four. The association recommends total cholesterol consumption not exceed 300 milligrams a day.
Meanwhile producers have been working to develop eggs that will be significantly lower in cholesterol than even the new standard demands. Michael Foods Inc. of Minneapolis has developed a technique to remove 70 to 90 percent of the cholesterol from egg yolks. The company said it could not predict when the product would be on the market.
Full Spectrum Farms of Lancaster, Pa., is currently producing eggs that the company said contain only 169 milligrams of cholesterol each, 20 percent less than regular eggs. But Jeff Cramer, a chemist at the bureau of food and chemistry in the Pennsylvania department of agriculture who is testing the cholesterol claims of Full Spectrum Farms eggs, said the average cholesterol content is closer to 182 milligrams each.
The Full Spectrum eggs are produced by providing the chickens with special feed, controlled lighting and improved air circulation and quality, said John Albright, the president of Environmental Systems Inc., which owns Full Spectrum Farms.
They cost 25 to 30 cents more per dozen than regular eggs and are being distributed in northern New Jersey, Maryland, Delaware, Pennsylvania and Ohio; they may be available in New York City in the next few months. For consumers the best bet in the meantime may be egg substitutes, which, with a few exceptions, are cholesterol-free.
Though each is advertised as the next best thing to eggs, they vary in taste, texture and color.
Powdered egg substitutes are the least expensive and the quickest to mix and prepare, but they also tend to be the least appetizing in appearance and taste.
Liquid substitutes, which generally cost about three and a half times as much per serving as real eggs, usually look and taste better than the powdered type. They are frozen in containers like small milk cartons and must be thawed before use, which can take up to one hour, depending on the size of the carton.
While real eggs can keep in the refrigerator for up to five weeks, manufacturers advise against storing thawed egg substitutes in the refrigerator for more than 7 to 10 days. Powdered products, on the other hand, keep indefinitely.
Egg substitutes can generally take the place of whole eggs in baking, with fair to excellent results depending on the recipe and on whether a liquid or powdered product is used. Liquid egg substitutes work especially well in quick breads, cakes, coatings and batters, said Robyn Flipse, a registered dietitian in Ocean, N.J., who teaches classes on healthful cooking.
Though most ingredient lists on packages of egg substitutes begin with egg whites, indicating they are the predominant ingredient, corn oil is often added to replace the fat in egg yolks, and artificial flavors, colors and preservatives are included as well.
Egg substitutes are lower in total fat than real eggs, but few are fat-free. Most package instructions call for the addition of one teaspoon of margarine during preparation. While this does not add cholesterol, it can raise the fat level to that of a whole egg or higher. Using a nonstick pan or a vegetable spray eliminates the need for added fat. Nor are egg substitutes necessarily cholesterol-free. They may contain 15 to 120 milligrams of cholesterol, which is still less than the amount in whole eggs.
Unlike whole eggs - which are relatively low in sodium at 63 milligrams each, most of which is in the white, not the yolk - packaged substitutes contain as much as 220 milligrams in a serving equivalent to a single egg. People who are trying to cut down on cholesterol are likely to be watching their sodium intake as well.
An economical yet often overlooked egg option is to stay with the real thing and simply substitute two egg whites, which are cholesterol-free, for each large whole egg called for in a recipe. Or as a substitute for plain scrambled eggs, one whole egg beaten with one egg white per two-egg serving works well.
The yolk adds both color and flavor not found in pure egg whites or most egg substitutes. Though not as inexpensive as powdered substitutes, the one yolk- two whites mixture costs less than liquid substitutes and tastes better.
Omitting a single yolk cuts the cholesterol of a serving of two scrambled eggs in half, from 426 milligrams cholesterol to 213 - less than in two lowered-cholesterol eggs. If preparing more than a single serving of scrambled eggs, you can increase the ratio of egg whites to cut the cholesterol further.
Pure egg whites can be used for cholesterol-free scrambled eggs, but they taste bland and lack color. The whites are more appealing as an omelet mixed with other ingredients like bell peppers, onions, mushrooms and tomatoes.

HEADLINE: Los Angeles Mayor Faces Suit on Ethics; No Crime Is Charged

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 13

 BODY:
The City Attorney of Los Angeles filed a civil suit today against Mayor Tom Bradley, charging that he failed to disclose six personal investments as required by California law. But the City Attorney, ending five months of inquiry into possible conflicts of interest by the Mayor, said there was not enough evidence to press criminal charges.
The City Attorney, James K. Hahn, said his investigation had not been able to prove that the Mayor intended to use his influence to benefit various banks and companies with which he had financial ties. But he made it clear that he felt the 71-year-old Mayor, who recently won a fifth term, had lost his ethical compass. 
''No vindication of the Mayor's conduct is intended, implied or should in any way be inferred,'' Mr. Hahn said in a report. He said the Mayor ''clearly stepped into that gray area of the law between factual innocence and a chargeable offense, but our system of justice rightfully gives him and the rest of us the benefit of the doubt in such circumstances.''
 
Bradley Admits His Mistakes
In a long televised reply this evening, Mr. Bradley defended his ethics and admitted mistakes. ''When all is said and done,'' he said, ''the inquiry confirms what I have said all along: I did not engage in conflicts of interest. I did not violate the public's trust.''
The report was a major milestone in the troubles that have swirled around Mr. Bradley, a former police officer who has been widely credited with bringing racial harmony and economic prosperity to the nation's second largest city.
A number of articles in The Los Angeles Herald Examiner and The Los Angeles Times raised questions about Mr. Bradley's relationship with several banks the city did business with and about his ties with a project that has been under investigation by the city's Police Department.
Despite the criticism in Mr. Hahn's report, many local politicians believe Mr. Bradley has weathered this storm. But he faces other, potentially more serious, investigations by the Justice Department, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the State Attorney General. The Federal authorities are looking into Mr. Bradley's stock investments made through the investment firm of Drexel Burnham Lambert, which recently pleaded guilty to securities fraud, and his relationship to Michael R. Milken, who headed the firm's junk bond unit.
The civil suit filed by Mr. Hahn charges Mr. Bradley with six violations of the California Government Code, which requires public officials to disclose their personal economic interests. It charges that Mr. Bradley intentionally or negligently failed to report investments in companies like Trans World Airlines Inc., L.A. Gear Inc., and Gibralter Financial Corporation.
The fine for such infractions can total the amount of the investments, said by the two local newspapers to be about $2.2 million. But aides to Mr. Hahn said that it was likely that the Mayor would reach an out-of-court settlement for considerably less.
The report by Mr. Hahn, an elected official who has been considered an ally of the Mayor, painted a picture in sharp contrast with Mr. Bradley's reputation for honesty and with Los Angeles's reputation for comparatively clean government.
 
The Most Serious Charge
The most serious charge involved the Far East National Bank, which paid Mr. Bradley $18,000 in 1988 as a foreign trade advisor. On March 22, the Mayor called the City Treasurer, Leonard Rittenberg, asking why the city had withdrawn $1 million from the bank. After that, the Treasurer's Office deposited $2 million in the bank.
Mr. Bradley told investigators that he only inquired about the deposit and therefore, Mr. Hahn said, there was insufficient evidence that he intended to violate the law by using his influence to favor a bank for which he worked. Mr. Rittenberg concurred with the Mayor.
''Although the Mayor clearly exercised poor judgment in this particular instance, we did not find a violation of the law,'' Mr. Hahn said at a news conference today.
In his reply, Mayor Bradley asked Angelenos to ''remember how I've served this city for 47 years with honor and integrity. I work 16 and 18 hour days because I love this job.'' He conceded he had failed to fully disclose his financial interests but said these were ''technical errors'' resulting from his filling out his own forms. He has since established a blind trust for his assets.
The bulk of his comments addressed the Far East matter. He said he had returned the $18,000 fee, though not legally required to do so, and denied knowing that officials in the city Treasurer's Office had contrived documents to make it look as though the deposit was made through competitive bidding. ''I never doubted that the inquiry would conclude that I played no role in the deposit of city funds with Far East,'' he said.
After local news stories reported his links to the banks, Mr. Bradley resigned his positions at both Far East and Valley Federal Savings and Loan, where he had served as a paid director for a decade. While Mr. Bradley approved zoning changes favoring subsidiaries of Valley Federal, Mr. Hahn concluded the Mayor was unaware that they were owned by the bank.
 
No Evidence of Influence
Similarly, the City Attorney found no evidence that Mayor Bradley had influenced the placement of hundreds of millions of dollars of city deposits in Gibraltar Savings, in which Mr. Bradley owned bonds valued at more than $100,000, nor that he influenced city decisions concerning properties owned by Abraham Spiegel, a longtime friend and benefactor who founded Columbia Savings and Loan Association of Beverly Hills.
Mr. Hahn also investigated Mr. Bradley's ties to the Task Force on Africa-Los Angeles Relations, founded in 1978 to expand links between Los Angeles and African nations, which has been under investigation by the Los Angeles Police Department for its handling of $180,000 in city funds. Mayor Bradley's daughter, Phyllis, worked for the task force as a secretary for nine months and earned $16,697. Mr. Hahn found no conflict of interest on Mr. Bradley's part, but referred the report to the California Attorney General's office and the United States Comptroller of the Currency.
Reaction to Mr. Hahn's report today was one of shock. ''The change in perception is the significant issue here,'' said City Councilman Michael Woo, who represents Hollywood. ''The Mayor's previous image of a white knight has ben tarnished with the months of speculation.''
One of the Mayor's harshest critics on the Council, Zev Yaroslavsky, who had considered challenging Mayor Bradley this year, said the report pained a ''sordid picture'' of City Hall.
But Joseph R. Cerrell, a powerful political consultant here, discounted Mr. Bradley's transgressions. ''To put it religiously, these were venial sins as opposed to mortal sins.''

HEADLINE: U.S. Rejects Increase in Aid for Poland

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13

 BODY:
Despite appeals from Congress and officials in Poland, the Bush Administration has ruled out any major, immediate efforts to provide economic assistance to Poland, Administration officials said today.
Agreement on a course of action for Poland was reached at a meeting of the National Security Council last Thursday, the officials said, adding that it reflected American budget restraints and skepticism of the Treasury and the Central Intelligence Agency about the Warsaw's ability to control inflation and thereby begin to resolve longstanding economic problems.
The Solidarity leader, Lech Walesa, who is to visit Washington in November, has called for $10 billion of emergency assistance, involving $2.7 billion from the International Monetary Fund, $3 billion from the World Bank and $4.3 billion in new bilateral credits.
 
Other Proposals Also Rejected
After the Polish Parliament voted Tuesday to establish a government in which Communists are not dominant, the first since the 1940's, several members of Congress called for stepped up American assistance. 
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, urged that the Administration work with Congress on a ''united bipartisan substantial program of aid to Poland.''
When President Bush traveled to Eastern Europe in July, he proposed a package of aid totaling $119 million, including food and technical aid.
Administration officials said that as a result of the National Security Council meeting there would be no expansion of that package. In addition the council rejected proposals to undertake a food airlift and to double American technical assistance to Polish enterprises to about $200 million, and it decided to halt unpublicized efforts to persuade the World Bank to release $250 million for projects in Poland.
 
Encouraging Private Investment
The officials said the centerpiece of the Administration program for Poland would be a trip next week to Warsaw by Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher, who is taking with him a delegation of American business chiefs. The aim of the visit is to spur private investment in Poland.
Explaining the Administration's reluctance to undertake a major aid effort, a senior official said: ''The economic situation is still a swamp over there. Government unions are trying to be more militant than Solidarity, striking for large wage increases. It's still not clear that hard-liners in the Communist Party are reconciled to the new Government and want it to succeed.''
The decision to postpone the food airlift was taken because information is sparse about stockpiles of food in Poland. Chris Goldthwait, assistant general sales manager for the Foreign Agricultural Service, an arm of the Agriculture Department, is expected to visit Poland shortly to try to provide an accurate picture of its food needs. No Talks With I.M.F. The World Bank has been preparing a first wave of loans to Poland, intended chiefly to attack specific bottlenecks currently inhibiting Polish production and distribution. For example, the lack of capacity to produce cans of smaller size keeps Polish hams out of reach of many consumers, foreign and domestic.
But under new guidelines, the bank is reluctant to make loans to countries that have not agreed to economic adjustment programs with the International Monetary Fund. Polish officials have yet to sit down with the I.M.F.
Both the World Bank and the I.M.F. lend money for economic development, chiefly in developing countries.
Mr. Mosbacher said in an interview last week that he thought American business should be interested in investing in Poland because ''it's potentially a very large market, a market that has virtually no fulfillment.''
Several joint ventures are expected to be signed during his visit, involving such businesses as tourism and a Baltic fisheries operation near Gdansk for the export of cod and herring. ''They need a whole free enterprise system,'' he declared. ''They are looking for all the know-hows, from technology to accounting and finance, right across the spectrum.''

HEADLINE: Guerrillas Begin Salvador Talks By Offering a 3-Stage Peace Plan

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 13

 BODY:
Negotiations between the Government of El Salvador and the leftist guerrillas seeking its overthrow began here today, with the rebels presenting a peace proposal to bring the decade-long civil war to an end in three stages over the next five months.
The plan made public by the rebel group, the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, calls for an initial cease-fire no later than Nov. 15, to be accompanied by political, judicial and military measures by the Government.
If the Salvadoran Government agreed to the conditions, negotiations aimed at achieving a ''definitive cessation of hostilities'' would then take place by Jan. 31, the rebels said.
In response, the Salvadoran Government presented a plan that was limited to procedural matters. Participants said that the Government had proposed holding talks every two months at rotating sites, with the Roman Catholic Church present as a ''witness'' but barring the Organization of American States or United Nations observers the rebels have been demanding. 
Speaking for the Government delegation at a news conference tonight, Justice Minister Oscar Santamaria said the first day of talks had produced ''a positive balance.'' But Joaquin Villalobos, a rebel military commander, said the Government proposal was ''very poor'' and that he had expected ''to discuss something more than whether the table is going to be square or round.''
The talks here are the first between the two sides since President Alfredo Cristiani and his right-wing Nationalist Republican Alliance, took power on June 1. They come at a time of growing political pressure from El Salvador's neighbors and from a populace exhausted by 10 years of conflict.
 
Change to a Political Party
The rebel proposal calls for Mr. Cristiani to move up legislative and municipal elections now scheduled for 1991 and to pledge ''a self-purification and professionalization of the armed forces.'' He would also have to agree to ''guarantee the clarification of responsibilities and sentencing of those guilty'' of the 1980 assassination of a Roman Catholic Archbishop, Oscar Arnulfo Romero, and ''all those involved in death-squad activities'' that have resulted in thousands of deaths.
As rebel leaders were quick to acknowledge, that last point is likely to prove especially delicate. The founder and behind-the-scenes leader of the governing party, Roberto D'Aubuisson, has been implicated in the assassination of Archbishop Romero and is also said by diplomats to have commanded other death-squad activities.
In the second phase of the plan, the rebel group would ''take the first step toward its incorporation into political life.'' Mr. Villalobos said that meant the rebels would be transformed from a heavily-armed insurgent military force into a political party willing to compete in elections.
''It is a step that implies great risks, but we are prepared to assume them as a show of real will, even when negotiations for a definitive halt to the hostilities have not been completed,'' he said. But when asked whether that meant the rebels were also prepared to surrender all their arms, he declined to be specific, saying the issue was ''absolutely secondary.''
The final phase of the rebel proposal would require a ''restructuring of the electoral system'' and fundamental changes in the Constitution. But its central element would be ''recognition of a single national army and its gradual reduction to the size strictly necessary for the defense of national sovereignty,'' accompanied by the fusing of all Government-security organs into ''a single one, under civilian command.''
On several occasions in the past, the rebels have offered peace plans calling for an overhaul of and diminished role for the Salvadoran Armed Forces, demands that the Government has always rejected.
Many senior officers in the armed forces, which have quadrupled in size to about 56,000 in the course of the war, favor a military solution to the conflict and doubt the sincerity of rebel peace overtures.
Finally, the rebel plan calls for the United States to convert its military assistance program to the Salvadaron Government into ''an aid fund for the economic and social recovery of the nation.'' Over the last decade, Washington has supplied more than $3.3 billion in aid, including nearly a billion dollars in military assistance, to El Salvador. [In Washington, a Bush Administration official said it would be inappropriate to comment on the rebels' proposal to convert military aid into economic assistance. ''We are not negotiating with the rebels,'' the official said. ''We deal with the established Government of El Salvador.''] The rebels also asked for what they called ''constructive cooperation'' from the Bush Administration during the course of the negotiations and urged the United States Congress to become involved in the process.

HEADLINE: Teacher Union Faults History Books

BYLINE: By JULIE JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13

 BODY:
The five most commonly used high school history textbooks barely touch on such major figures as Washington and Lincoln and they largely ignore the passion and political significance of religion and economics in American history, according to a new study by the American Federation of Teachers.
The study, released here today, said the books are bland and sacrifice details for graphics and color pictures. It also said that despite attempts to integrate the roles of women and minorities in history, the texts too often leave those groups ''cordoned off into special boxes and features.''
''It's not a condemnation of the texts,'' said Paul Gagnon, a history professor at the University of Massachusetts at Boston, who spent two years compiling the report on the five history textbooks. ''They're not awful. They're not wrong. But they just don't offer enough help to teachers when we're facing increasingly complex problems in a diverse world.'' 
 
Teaching Being Criticized
The report comes amid debate over how social studies should be taught. The teaching of social studies has been criticized because high school students today generally know little about American and world history and geography. In May, the New York-Based Council on Interracial Books for Children, a smaller and more narrowly focused organization than the 710,000-member teachers' union, released a study on bias or ommissions in commonly used history books that reached conclusions similar to those in the A.F.T. report.
Professor Gagnon's report studied five textbooks: ''Triumph of the American Nation'' by Lewis Paul Todd and Merle Curtie, published by Harcourt, Brace, Jovanovich in 1986; ''People and Our Country'' by Norman K. Risjord and Terry L. Haywoode, published by Holt, Rinehart & Winston in 1982; ''The United States: A History of the Republic'' by James West Davidson and Mark H. Lytle, published by Prentice-Hall, a division of Gulf and Western, in 1981; ''History of a Free People'' by Henry W. Bragdon and Samuel P. McCutchen, published in 1981 by the Macmillan Publishing Company; and ''A History of the United States'' by Daniel J. Boorstin and Brooks M. Kelley, published by Ginn & Company in 1986.
Professor Gagnon said the books, generally used in the 11th grade, are read by two-thirds of the approximately five million students in American high schools.
 
Sympathy for Writers
While Professor Gagnon took the books to task, he expressed sympathy for textbook writers, who he said were often forced to condense details to fit the space allocated by the publishers.
Robert A. Richards, executive vice president of Harcourt, Brace, Jovanovich, who is director of the publisher's elementary and secondary programs, acknowledged that publishers were ''bound by space limitations.'' But he said they assume that many of the historical details left out of the high school texts have been covered in fifth grade textbooks as well as in textbooks for the eighth or ninth grades.
''The challenge to the publisher is to have as much coverage and be able to go into as much depth as possible and still offer a manageable textbook,'' Mr. Richards said. He noted that ''Triumph of the American Nation'' is 1,000 pages. ''Also part of this challenge is to provide a textbook that will satisfy a wide variety of state or city curriculum requirements and a wide variety of teachers.''
But Professor Gagnon's report asserted that the ''primary purpose of the American history course and its textbooks must be to help students understand what undergirds democracy.'' These were among the reports other conclusions:
* One textbook that offers no biography of Lincoln devotes 24 of 43 pages about the Civil War to pictures, maps and special features. The longest profile of the 16th President in any of the volumes is six paragraphs.
* Religious ideology from the Puritans to contemporary fundamentalist Christians is not dealt with adequately as a political influence.
* Little attention is paid to military strategy and practice from the Civil War to Vietnam.
''They have a format which reminds you of USA Today,'' the professor said. ''It's all graphics and colors and special features and little boxes inserted here and there.''
Rather than provide historical details that would augment intellectual discussion, he said the books ''are over-stuffed with features'' that help publishers sell the books to school districts, like the maps and charts.
 
Two-Year Courses Suggested
He recommended American history be taught over two years rather than one and that the subject be more tightly focused on the themes of democracy, economics and the nation's multicultural population.
The study was the third major report of the A.F.T.'s Education for Democracy Project, a joint venture between the union, the Educational Excellence Network, a private group of educators, parents and former goverment officials, and Freedom House, a human rights organization.
Mr. Gagnon's analysis raised questions about publishers who omit details on Lincoln or Washington while printing boxed ''mini-biographies'' of the Spanish explorer Cabeza de Vaca, Blackbeard the Pirate, Noah Webster and Tecumseh, the Shawnee chief who tried to unite the Indian tribes of the West.
Mr. Richards defended the approach. ''We feel that at the 11th grade most students know who Abraham Lincoln and George Washington is,'' he said. ''It's a matter of space in some cases. It's a matter of emphasis in others.''
Albert Shanker, the A.F.T. president, said the report brings to the light what may be a larger problem.
''That is that within the community there is not agreement on the issue of teaching history and democracy,'' Mr. Shanker said. ''There are still a lot of people who take the view that we're being too chauvinistic if we say democracy is superior.''

HEADLINE: U.S. Widens Inquiry on College Price Fixing

BYLINE: By JULIE JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13

 BODY:
A Justice Department inquiry into whether prestigious colleges and universities may have violated Federal antitrust laws in tuition and scholarship practices has been broadened to include six more schools, officials at the institutions said today.
The addition of Princeton, Brown, Cornell, Bryn Mawr, Wellesley and the University of Pennsylvania indicates that the inquiry now includes nearly 30 schools. The department is investigating whether elite institutions engage in a form of price-fixing by setting tuition, fees and financial aid at similar levels.
Amy Brown, a Justice Department spokeswoman, declined to comment today on the inquiry, other than to say, ''The antitrust division's investigation is continuing, and we are continuing to ask for information from schools.'' 
Ms. Brown would not say which institutions or how many are involved in the investigation. When the inquiry was announced last month, about two dozen schools were reported to be under scrutiny. Some of those that confirmed that they were questioned by the Justice Department were Harvard, Tufts, the University of Chicago, Williams, Bowdoin and Amherst. Officials at Princeton, Brown, Cornell, Penn, Bryn Mawr and Wellesley said in interviews today that each had received a confidential inquiry from the Justice Department on Monday.
The Government requested written answers to five questions on how they set tuition and scholarship levels. Schools were also asked to collect information on travel, expense accounts, telephone records and salaries, as well as planning documents reflecting the activities of officials who help set tuition and financial aid levels.
Since the inquiry was disclosed last month, college officials have acknowledged that it is a common practice to meet among themselves to discuss students accepted by more than one of them. The officers compare notes on how much the students can pay toward their tuition, room and board. As a result, some students receive almost identical aid offers from competing institutions.
But the colleges say there is nothing wrong with this practice. By avoiding bidding wars for the most desirable students, the officials say, they enable the students to choose their college on academic grounds alone. In a statement today, John F. Burness, vice president for university relations at Cornell, said, ''We believe Cornell's policies and practices are legal,'' and added that the university would take ''appropriate action'' if the Justice Department determines that they should be revised. Robert K. Durkee, Princeton's vice president for public affairs, said the Justice Department's inquiry ''covers a lot of ground'' and estimated that the material requested could fill boxes and boxes, if not buildings. ''All of us are a bit overwhelmed about how much is being requested and on how short a timetable,'' he said. The Justice Department has asked that the schools comply by Sept. 28.
Also today, an organization of private colleges issued a study intended to counter ''popular misconceptions'' that private colleges primarily serve the rich. The study, by the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities, was begun well before the Justice Department inquiry became known, It reported that the number of independent colleges charging less than $5,000 a year in tuition and fees is three times the number charging more than $10,000.
The report, based on statistics from the Government and the College Board, provides an economic and demographic profile of private college students.
It places the median income of the families of private college students at $34,000, $2,000 less than for students at state colleges. In 1988, it says, 32 percent of all freshmen in the study were the first in their families to attend college. That figure was 39 percent at Catholic colleges and 52 percent at historically black colleges.
Mr. Rosser, whose organization represents 850 institutions, including the Ivy League schools, noted that in 1988-89 private college tuition and fees ranged from less than $100 to $16,495.

HEADLINE: SENATE WEIGHS BAN ON FLIGHT SMOKING

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13

 BODY:
Temporarily frustrated by the parliamentary maneuvers of tobacco-state lawmakers, who are outnumbered but determined, the Senate today debated but did not vote on a measure that would permanently ban smoking on all domestic airline flights.
Passage is considered likely if a vote occurs, but Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, and Senator Wendell H. Ford, Democrat of Kentucky, today began to filibuster. The bill's proponents responded by filing a motion to shut off debate. A two-thirds majority is needed for cloture; the vote may occur on Thursday. 
''We won't succumb to threats,'' said Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, the sponsor of the smoking ban.
A ban on smoking on flights, while far from the ultimate taboo against tobacco, would carry both symbolic and practical significance, outlawing smoking in one of the places where smokers' rights conflict most directly with those of nonsmokers, to the irritation of both groups. Smoking is already prohibited on flights lasting less than two hours, or about four out of every five flights.
If the Senate passes the smoking ban as part of its transportation spending bill, it could become law when House and Senate conferees meet to write a final bill. In August, the House retained the two-hour rule in its version of the spending bill, but it did so without taking a separate vote on the question, because the tobacco lobby was afraid that a floor fight might lead to tougher restrictions.
The delaying tactic today suggests that the lobby is aiming for the same result in the Senate, in the hope that senators would tire of the prolonged debate.
 
Union Optimistic on Bill
But Jo Ellen Deutsch, a lobbyist for the Association of Flight Attendants, a union that supports the ban because its members suffer prolonged and repeated exposure to the smoke of passengers, said ''it still looks good'' for eventual passage of the bill.
She said her count indicated that the bill's backers had a big enough margin to guarantee defeat for a filibuster or an attempt to kill the proposal through other parliamentary objections.
Airlines do not take a public position on the smoking issue, but several airline officials have said privately that they hope the Government will ban smoking.
The airline officials said their companies would save substantial sums of money if smoking were banned from all flights. For example, the expenses of cleaning and repairing airplanes would be lower, and there would be added flexibility in making reservations and assigning seats to passengers.
The comprehensive ban on smoking would take effect 90 days after the transportation bill is signed by President Bush. Violations of the new rule would result in a $1,000 fine, and tampering with smoke detectors in airplane lavatories would be punishable by a $2,000 fine, as is already the case with the limited ban.
Although all the familiar arguments about the health, safety and economic repercussions of the smoking question were discussed in two days of debate, the issue boiled down to the question of one group's right to impose its preferences on another.
 
Conservatives Disagree
''People choose to smoke, but there is no choice about breathing,'' said Senator Orrin G. Hatch, a conservative Republican from Utah.
''People who smoke cigarettes have a right, too,'' said Senator Helms, another conservative, whose state is a prime tobacco producer. ''But they are going to have no choice.''
But the tone of the debate suggested that this fundamental issue has already been laid to rest with the partial ban on smoking, just as the national consensus supports the idea that secondary exposure to smoke is, like active smoking, a health hazard.
A series of scientific studies, while not conclusive, have lent plenty of weight to the conclusion that breathing in somebody else's smoke can be hazardous to health.
For example, reports issued in 1986 by the Surgeon General of the United States and by the National Academy of Sciences concluded that ''passive smoking'' caused disease, including lung cancer, in otherwise healthy nonsmokers, and increased the frequency of respiratory illness in children while impairing the development of their lungs.
Also in 1986, the National Academy of Sciences issued a second report on air quality inside aircraft cabins, which recommended a total ban on smoking in aircraft.
Last year, Surgeon General C. Everett Koop asked the National Cancer Institute to further study the issue, and based on results published this year in The Journal of the American Medical Association, he renewed the call for a total ban on airline smoking.

HEADLINE: Go After Companies That Abuse Pension Funds;
Look to Savings

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In ''How About Taxing Pension Fund Profits?'' (Op-Ed, Aug. 30), Nancy L. Kassebaum diagnoses one of our nation's major long-term economic weaknesses, but suggests an incorrect, even a counterproductive solution. The weakness is our apparent inability to save - the proposed solution would only discourage savings to a greater degree.
National savings provide the ultimate fuel for real economic growth. It is hardly a coincidence that Asia has been growing more than twice as fast as the United States for the last 10 years. 
The average savings rate of the Asian nations is in excess of 30 percent, compared to a pathetic 5.3 percent for the United States. For the average American, only real estate equity and pensions represent true savings. To tax either would kill the goose that lays the golden eggs of future economic growth.
Senator Kassebaum suggests that institutional investment managers have a ''short-term mentality'' toward portfolio investment, partly because they are ''increasingly hired and fired on the basis of their quarterly performance.''
I would argue first that it is the fiduciaries of those assets, rather than the investment professionals, who have the short-term perspective and, second, that the taxing of short-term gains would only serve to discourage additional savings - as it would add to the ultimate riskiness of the institutional investment process.
Had our legislators truly understood the severity of our savings problem, they never would have passed the provisions in the 1986 Tax Reform Act that reduced the American worker's ability to make annual contributions to pensions in pretax dollars from $30,000 to $7,500. It would appear that once again one of our elected officials is looking for a quick fix at the taxpayer's expense for Washington's inability to live within its means.
Senator Kassebaum inadvertently shows her true colors in her last paragraph, where her last sentence begins, ''In a time of budget deficit.'' I'm not the first, and I know I won't be the last, to suggest that our Federal Government should try to do a little saving as well. It just might set an example for the rest of us to follow.
 
FRANK J. KEELER
President, Invesco Mim International
 New York, Sept. 1, 1989

HEADLINE: Destruction of Our Schools and Fear in the Streets Are Connected

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Devin S. Standard, a young black man, writes about his growing fear that he might be killed, for no other reason than that he is black (Op-Ed, Sept. 2). On the same page, an older white man, Felix G. Rohatyn, writes about the urgent need to improve the New York City school system.
All decent and responsible people share Mr. Standard's outrage at the murder of Yusuf K. Hawkins and the growing danger to other blacks. Unfortunately, he seems to be making the same kinds of generalizations about whites that the whites who commit racial murders of blacks make. We are at even greater risk of being murdered by so-called ''common'' criminals in search of our money or even of thrills than we are of being murdered because of race. 
That people of color are more likely than whites to suffer from the social ills associated with poverty is the fundamental reason people of color most often commit crimes, against whites and other people of color. Until we address the social causes of crime and the need for prompt and assured consequences for crime, we will all remain in danger from the antisocial behavior of fellow citizens of all racial groups.
While the educational reforms listed by Mr. Rohatyn will not alone solve the social problems of poverty, whites and people of color have yet to demonstrate understanding of the extent to which the Reagan-era destruction of social programs has increased the numbers of the poor and the disparity in conditions between them and the affluent.
Most critics have also failed to understand the extent to which public education in the inner cities was stripped of resources in the fiscal crises of the 1970's, only to be virtually destroyed by the Federal withdrawal of support that followed.
I write to point a finger at all those who have presided over education budgets whose increases have not kept pace with inflation and all those who fail to acknowledge that our city contains far more children at risk of failure and children with special needs than state aid to city schools reflects. I write also to make the connection between these needs and the climate of fear in which Mr. Standard and all of us are doomed to remain, so long as we fail to support an educational system capable of providing equal opportunity to all of our children.
 
NORMA J. HART
 New York, Sept. 2, 1989
The writer is a psychologist with the New York City Board of Education.
