HEADLINE: The New York Primary;
For Koch, Sigh of Relief; For Aides, Tight Smiles

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
For a last hurrah, it sounded distinctly like a sigh of relief.
''I feel as though a burden has been lifted from my shoulders,'' said Mayor Edward I. Koch yesterday, after he stood on the steps of City Hall with the man who ended his bid for an unprecedented fourth term and pledged to do whatever he could to insure that David N. Dinkins, the Manhattan Borough President, would succeed him.
As he made his way through the corridor toward his office in the West Wing, Mr. Koch stopped to shake hands and embrace some of the people who have worked for him during his nearly 12-year tenure. The Mayor's relief - if it was just relief and not shock or even a desire to find some good in Tuesday's bad news - was shared by some at City Hall. But for many who work in or around the municipal government's jewel box of a headquarters, it was a day of tight smiles, forced laughs, gallows humor and hallway post-mortems. 
For the first time in a dozen years, New York City would have a new government, and many of them knew they would not be part of it.
''It's just strange having things that are beyond your control,'' said Frederick P. Schaffer, who left the office of the city's Corporation Counsel to become the Mayor's counsel this year. ''Not necessarily bad, just strange.''
Asked about his future, John LoCicero, the mayor's political adviser, said, ''I haven't even thought about it.''
One city commissioner simply waved a reporter away, saying, ''Let's just let it be.''
Robert W. Linn, the Director of Personnel and Labor Relations, said that in previous transitions a minimum of 300 to 400 high-level appointees, like commissioners and their deputies, have been replaced. Another 1,000 to 3,000 city officials, Mr. Linn said, ''are within the range of people who could well turn over.''
He added that while it was technically possible that the jobs of 10,000 to 20,000 city employees could be in jeopardy, such wholesale personnel bloodletting has not been a tradition.
 
'I'm Ready to Move On'
''I don't see what you gain unless you have people to fill the positions,'' said Stanley Brezenoff, the First Deputy Mayor.
Mr. Linn himself was in ''active discussions'' earlier in the year with a law firm, but decided to stay on in government to consolidate the city's labor relations and personnel departments. He said he did not regret his decision, though the fate of his work, like other Koch administration initiatives, is uncertain.
Mr. Brezenoff said he did not think there was a chance he would be asked to stay, adding, ''I'm ready to move on.''
Harrison J. Goldin, the City Comptroller, who finished fourth in the Democratic mayoral primary, will also be out of a job. Mr. Goldin said he would look for a position in the private sector, though he declined to elaborate. Asked if he thought he would be making more than his $105,000 annual salary, he said, ''That clearly is an option, a rather attractive option.''
Mr. Goldin said he was looking forward to the privacy accorded people who are not in government. For example, he said, releasing his tax records was the ''ultimate indignity.''
 
'I've Never Felt Better'
As for Mr. Koch, he categorically ruled out ''another run for anything.''
''I really don't know,'' the Mayor said, when asked what he would do come January. ''I don't think I'll be unemployed.''
Mr. Koch looked rested, if not yet completely recovered, from a grueling campaign and an anxious and disappointing Tuesday, his 4,237th day in office.
''In fact, I believe that I've never felt better,'' he said. ''I mean I wanted to be the mayor for the next four years, but I also believe that it is an enormous, wrenching job. Anyone who runs for it will only find out when they hold that job how difficult it is. So while I would have liked to be the mayor, I'm not upset that I'm relieved of the responsibilities.''
 
Comparing Last Defeat
It is impossible to know whether he was being candid, putting a good face on a defeat that ended an extraordinary political career or was in what one aide called a ''denial of depression'' phase. Or maybe Tuesday's returns had not yet sunk in.
After his concession speech, Mr. Koch went home to Gracie Mansion for coffee with several aides and advisers and soon had a visitor - John Cardinal O'Connor.
The Mayor began the morning after by attending the 7:45 A.M. service at the Park East Synagogue on 67th Street in Manhattan, then went to his ''lucky'' subway stop, at 77th Street and Lexington Avenue, to talk to New Yorkers.
Mr. Koch spent a lot of time during the past two days on the phone. With Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, he compared his last defeat, in the gubernatorial primary of 1982, with this one. ''You know when you beat me I was distressed, depressed, angry,'' Mr. Koch recalled telling him. ''I'm not distressed, I'm not depressed, I'm not angry.''
An aide said the Mayor told Richard Ravitch, former head of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, who finished third in the primary: ''Dick, from one loser to another, you'll get over it.''
 
A Chat With the President
Mr. Koch also received a call from the Rev. Jesse Jackson, a man who he attacked harshly last year. ''He said that he was very admiring, appreciative of my comments,'' the Mayor said, referring to his speech Tuesday night. ''He thought they were extremely helpful, said they established a moral tone which he was very supportive of. He said he was looking forward to coming in, sitting down and re-establishing our relationship, working together in support of David Dinkins.''
And about 3 P.M. yesterday, the Mayor chatted with President Bush, who invited him to lunch at the White House and complimented him on his graciousness in defeat.
There were varying opinions on when the Mayor and his advisers had concluded the cause was lost. Some thought it was not until the first results of exit polls started circulating on Tuesday afternoon. But others thought the situation looked bleak after the racial slaying in Bensonhurst and its aftermath.
The Mayor stressed a new message in the last week of the campaign, and especially its final days, when he began to talk about healing and reconciliation, themes Mr. Dinkins had emphasized. And then there was Mr. Koch's surprise proposal to Mr. Dinkins to hold a unity rally, a suggestion that resulted in yesterday's ceremony, which was attended by all four Democratic rivals. While no doubt meant to further that message, and his own political prospects, it also helped pave the way for Mr. Koch's harmonious exit from the race.
''I wanted to win,'' the Mayor said yesterday. ''I don't want to tell you that I did it for the game. Not at all. But I'm not - I don't want to stress this too much - I'm not, as people would expect, sad or depressed.
''I hope I'm remembered for all the good things that I did, not just the last few days,'' he said at another point. ''I've been a mayor for 12 years, in very difficult times. I hope that the span of memory covers 12 years and not just a week.''

GRAPHIC: The New York Times/Neal Boenzi As David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani battled each other for the mayoralty, Mayor Edward I. Koch conducted business as usual in City Hall. ''The time between now and Dec. 31 when I end my tenure at City Hall will be done in the regular governmental way,'' he said. ''Government goes on.'' HEADLINE: City Opera Is Struck; Fall Season Halted

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL

 BODY:
The New York City Opera orchestra, unhappy with the company's proposals on wages and guaranteed work, struck the opera last night before the beginning of the company's fall season, which was to have been a performance of Rossini's ''Barbiere di Siviglia.'' The strike imperils the rest of the City Opera's season, which is scheduled to run through Nov. 19.
The ensemble voted 53 to 4 Tuesday night at the New York State Theater to proceed with the strike (12 of the 69 members did not vote, but union officials said that was because the musicians knew the result was a foregone conclusion). The decision was tallied yesterday afternoon and announced at a news conference at Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, which represents the players.
The union set up its formally clad picket line an hour before yesterday's scheduled performance. Although no other unions representing opera employees have officially joined the strike, they did not cross the musicians' picket line. 
 
Discussion on March Sites
The picketing proceeded peacefully, apart from some squabbling with police and Lincoln Center security officers over where the marchers were allowed to promenade. In the end, some 45 musicians divided their time between the east side of the State Theater, the sidewalk along Columbus Avenue, and Dante Park between Broadway and Columbus Avenue, where a wind-and-brass group tootled operatic arrangements. After the 8 P.M. scheduled curtain time, a token number of marchers were allowed to picket briefly in front of the lobby entrance.
In the meantime, disappointed but resigned operagoers perused City Opera announcements on the doors of the theater lobby, which offered refund and exchange instructions, and considered their options for the rest of the evening.
The strike came after a summer in which the federation and the other principal performers' union, the American Guild of Musical Artists, had worked without contracts. Both unions' pacts had expired on May 30.
Sanford I. Wolff, the guild's national executive secretary, said yesterday that he was meeting daily with his fellow union officials, but that a formal decision to join the strike could not come before a meeting of the City Opera guild members set for Sept. 25. The guild represents soloists, the chorus, dancers and stage directors.
 
Informal Proposals
On Sept. 6, the federation gave the opera seven days' formal strike notice. Both sides conceded yesterday that the warning had galvanized the negotiations, which had stagnated over the summer. But although some informal proposals were made in intensive talks lasting over the weekend, the union felt by the last session, Monday night, that insufficent progress had been achieved, and continued with its strike vote.
At present, no new sessions are scheduled. Timothy Germany of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service has been in touch with the parties, but has not participated in the negotiations.
Both sides expressed regrets. ''I believe this is an unnecessary strike,'' said Martin J. Oppenheimer, the vice chairman of the City Opera board and its chief labor negotiator. ''With hard bargaining, the principals should be able to come to an agreement. I hope it will be a short strike.''
 
'It Seemed Hopeless'
''No one wants a strike'' said Frank Morelli, the orchestra's principal bassoonist and head of its negotiating committee. But, added John Palanchian, the vice president of Local 802 and for 22 years a City Opera violinist, ''We were so far apart it seemed hopeless.''
Christopher Keene, the newly appointed general director of the City Opera, would not discuss the dispute, but said in a statement: ''This strike is a difficult time for all of us - company members as well as the opera-loving public of New York. I hope we can reach an equitable solution and return to performing very shortly.''
Beverly Sills, Mr. Keene's predecessor, expressed regret through a City Opera spokeswoman, and Robert W. Wilson, the City Opera chairman, declined to comment.
The orchestra is seeking raises that far exceed the customary 5 percent to 6 percent increases of recent years. In the third and last year of its old contract, the minimum weekly base pay for five and a half performances was $755.25, with rehearsals compensated at an additional $22.59 an hour for most players. The orchestra has stated that its goal is per-performance parity with the orchestras of the San Francisco Opera and the Lyric Opera of Chicago, which would mean a raise of some 20 percent.
Mr. Oppenheimer has rejected that standard of comparison, pointing out that those companies' ticket prices are roughly double those of the popularly priced City Opera. ''We don't want to get into an exercise in which we compare ourselves with anybody else,'' he said.
 
Annual Raises and Workweeks
The company's last formal proposal in July offered annual raises of 4 percent in each year of a new three-year contract. But higher figures have since been discussed informally, both sides said.
The other major issue involves work weeks. Last season, orchestra members were guaranteed 23 weeks of full-pay work and six more weeks in which they would be employed or would be paid ''supplemental unemployment benefits'' amounting to one half their wages.
The company, faced with the expiration next spring of a five-year, $5 million grant by the philanthropist Lawrence Wien to produce spring seasons of ''classic musicals,'' is unwilling to offer guarantees for work it is not sure it can provide. The union takes the position that the company offered such guarantees before without sure knowledge of how it would provide for work - including the settlement in 1983, after a 54-day strike. Indeed, the union has argued, the presence of a guarantee sometimes stimulates companies into seeking additional engagements and financing.
 
Bolshoi Visit Questioned
Another issue is the proposed visit of the Bolshoi Ballet next summer to the City Opera's home, the New York State Theater in Lincoln Center, which Mr. Oppenheimer called ''99 and 44-hundredths percent sure.'' That would mean a curtailment of the opera season by three weeks. But Mr. Oppenheimer indicated that the company was willing to guarantee that the City Opera orchestra would be engaged for the Bolshoi, and that the visit from the Bolshoi was not part of a plan for regular curtailments of the opera season.
Both sides suggested yesterday that compromises were possible. Mr. Morelli said the orchestra had already broached the possibility of an elimination of its supplemental benefits, if they were compensated by higher wages and some additional workweeks. Mr. Oppenheimer indicated that the company's opposition to guaranteeing more weeks was negotiable.
Although summer attendance was ''a few percentage points under budget,'' according to Susan Woelzl, a City Opera spokeswoman, neither side suggested that the company was in any way encouraging a strike, or planned far-reaching reorganizations that would affect its union contracts.
 
No Pact Without Stoppage
This strike is part of a long history of City Opera labor turbulence. Except for 1986, no contract with the orchestra since 1962 was achieved without some sort of work stoppage. The 1983 strike came on the heels of Miss Sills's decision to combine the former spring and fall seasons into a single summer-fall season, thus shrinking the number of company workweeks. The dispute was settled after the other company unions put pressure on the orchestra.
Both sides recognized that a prolonged strike would threaten the entire fall season. After the scheduled end of the fall season, on Nov. 19, the company is not set to perform again until the final subsidized season of musicals in April 1990.
The musicians will receive an immediate $125 weekly from Local 802 strike funds, and an additional $100 in federation funds starting next week. The federation funds last for 15 weeks. The local funds end after seven weeks, when the musicians become eligible for $245 in unemployment benefits.
Ms. Woelzl said that ticket-holders could eventually exchange their seats for future performances, obtain refunds when the strike is over, or donate the tickets to the City Opera.

HEADLINE: Panel Votes Today on Gains Tax

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13

 BODY:
Dan Rostenkowski, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, today exhausted his options for compromise on capital gains taxes and scheduled a vote for Thursday on a cut in the tax rate. The cut is backed by the Bush Administration and supported by a majority of committee members.
The proposal, sponsored by Representative Ed Jenkins, Democrat of Georgia, would reduce the tax rate on capital gains to 19.6 percent for two years, from the current 28 percent rate. The rate would then return to 28 percent, but under an arrangement known as indexing, investors would then be allowed to exclude from taxation the portion of their profits solely attributable to inflation. 
Mr. Rostenkowski, caught between liberal Democrats who oppose any reduction and conservative Democrats who have sided with Republicans to support the Jenkins plan, has delayed a vote on it for weeks, hoping to reach a consensus on a more limited alternative.
 
Deal That Collapsed
Mr. Jenkins said that he and his allies agreed late Tuesday night to an alternative Rostenkowski plan but that the deal collapsed this morning. The chairman's plan would have permitted indexing of capital assets and more generous tax breaks for assets held 5 or 10 years. But liberals on the committee told the chairman the evolving plan had become politically indistinguishable from an outright rate cut.
Several who attended the closed meeting said they had argued that the Democratic Party should not be in the position of supporting a tax-rate reduction that provided its greatest benefit to the wealthiest taxpayers. They said a clean yes or no vote on the Jenkins plan, regardless of the outcome, was preferable to a vote on a compromise.
 
Sentiment Among Liberals
Representative Tom Downey, Democrat of Long Island, a member of the committee, said the sentiment among liberals had nothing to do with a proposal made Tuesday by Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas to restore tax deductions for individual retirement accounts as an alternative to a capital gains cut. Mr. Bentsen, who heads the Senate Finance Committee, has generally supported capital gains reduction but said his plan was a more equitable and fiscally responsible way to stimulate capital investment.
Earlier today, the House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, said that he supported I.R.A.'s and that it had been unfortunate that the deduction for contributions to the retirement accounts had been curtailed as part of the 1986 Tax Reform Act. ''If there is a way to restore the I.R.A.'s and finance the restoration of the I.R.A.'s, I would be glad to do it,'' Mr. Foley said.
Mr. Foley reiterated his opposition to a cut in the capital gains tax and said he would remain opposed regardless of whether I.R.A. deductions are restored. ''It can't be justified in terms of any value that we, the two parties, share in terms of economic growth or investment, and it's simply a tax break mostly for people in the highest income brackets who need it least,'' he said of a capital gains rate reduction.
Mr. Rostenkowski's decision to allow a committee vote, made after consultation with the Mr. Foley means the capital gains fight will eventually be waged on the House floor, where the tax panel chairman and House Democratic leaders will attempt to scuttle the Jenkins plan. Both sides have said a floor vote on capital gains reduction will be close, and Democratic leaders have acknowledged that they can lose it.
If the Jenkins proposal is adopted by the Ways and Means Committee, it will become part of a broader tax bill that raises $5.3 billion needed to meet the committee's contribution to a deficit reduction package for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. The panel has already agreed on provisions to raise the $5.3 billion, and for a time today Mr. Rostenkowski tried to convince one or more of the Democrats allied with Mr. Jenkins to agree to send only this ''bare bones'' tax bill out of the committee.
In exchange, Mr. Rostenkowski offered to permit a floor vote on the Jenkins proposal, but none of the Jenkins forces would agree.
Liberal Democrats on the panel are expected to try to weaken the Jenkins plan or amend it with provisions that would make it unpalatable to Republican supporters. But Mr. Jenkins said he was confident that he has the solid support of the 19 votes to win approval of the capital gains cut in committee.

HEADLINE: Senate Sustains Bush Veto Of Limits on Japan Jet Deal

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13

 BODY:
The Senate failed today by one vote to override President Bush's veto of Congressional restrictions on the joint American-Japanese production of an advanced jet fighter.
Lawmakers on both sides of the issue had anticipated that the vote would be close. But the 66-to-34 vote in favor of the override - just short of the needed two-thirds majority -was a measure of the growing tension between Congress and the White House over the direction and control of trade policy.
In the first test of a Bush veto, the Senate's failure to override narrowly averted what the President had portrayed as a serious encroachment on his constitutional powers, as well as a potentially embarrassing dispute with Japan at a time of heightened sensitivity over the huge American trade deficit with that country. 
The Congressional restrictions vetoed by Mr. Bush were the outgrowth of an agreement last year between the United States and Japan to cooperate in the development of Japan's next generation of fighter aircraft, a deal projected to be worth $6 billion. Instead of buying a new plane from the United States, Japan sought to develop its own fighter, based on the design of the highly successful F-16 but modified by the addition of its own components and technology.
After failing in May to block that agreement and thus the start of development work, the Senate approved a set of restrictions that would apply to any future agreement on the actual production of the new aircraft, called the FSX. The House adopted the same restrictions in June, and President Bush vetoed the measure on July 31.
Both the original FSX debate and today's debate on the veto override were laced with emotional rhetoric about the American trade deficit with Japan and how the joint venture might worsen it. At the heart of the controversy, however, is a more fundamental battle over turf as Congress seeks to exert new influence on trade and national security issues.
Indeed, many lawmakers have viewed the FSX fight as less a struggle over a single international transaction than a far-reaching example of how national security concerns have come to encompass economic issues. They point to the development and sale of high-definition television and other revolutionary telecommunications technologies as further arenas in which they hope Congress will be able to play a greater role.
Some senators, however, said Congress was going too far in its efforts.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, told his colleagues today that the FSX production restrictions were an interference with the executive authority of the President. ''What this resolution does is wrap a straitjacket around the President,'' he said. ''This resolution would set a dangerous precedent. It is a meddling micro-managing mistake.''
But Senator Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginia Democrat who was the principal author of the restrictions, said the resolution in which they are spelled out would improve the terms of the deal for the United States. ''The Japanese have proven adept at finding opportunites to deviate from agreements signed with the United States, and on several occasions simply violated those agreements,'' he said, citing deals on semiconductors and telecommunications.
The restrictions vetoed by Mr. Bush would have required the President to insure that all technology, military articles and military services provided to Japan in the development of the FSX be subject to arms export control laws. In addition, they would have required that any future agreement between the United States and Japan on production of the aircraft prohibit transfer of critical jet engine technologies to Japan and bar Japan from selling to other countries the FSX or any of its major subcomponents that were jointly developed with the United States.
The restrictions also included a nonbinding ''sense of Congress'' directive that any production agreement specify that American manufacturers receive at least 40 percent of the work.
Other provisions would have stipulated an advisory role for the Commerce Department in negotiating and implementing future agreements on the FSX program.
Senator John C. Danforth of Missouri, one of 12 Republicans who voted to override the veto, said the restrictions would not derail the agreement as some of Mr. Bush's supporters charged. ''This debate is about the drawing of lines between the President and the Congress on international trade issues,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Pilots' Offer for UAL Is Said to Be Ready

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
The $300-a-share offer for the UAL Corporation by the pilots' union and the company's top management is to be presented to a meeting of UAL's independent directors in Chicago today, people close to those making the bid said yesterday.
The sources said the board is expected to press Marvin Davis, the Los Angeles investor, to declare whether he wants to stay in the bidding. If he drops out, the board might decide to approve the pilot-management bid or it might delay final action for a short period to give other bidders a last chance to make an offer. 
Someone close to the bidding said yesterday that Mr. Davis or any other outside bidder would be at a disadvantage because they could not match the no-strike guarantees and cuts in wages and benefits that the union, the Air Line Pilots Association, has offered in its effort to win control of the airline.
Therefore, this source said, it is unlikely that Mr. Davis would try to top the $300-a-share bid.
 
Big Stake for Employees
Under the pilot-management proposal, United's 70,000 employees could end up controlling as much as 75 percent of the airline, making it by far the largest employee-owned company in the nation.
Stephen M. Wolf, the chairman and chief executive of UAL, sent a letter to employees yesterday explaining the advantages of an employee stock ownership plan.
''My personal opinion is that there is great cause for hope and optimism,'' he said. ''While, on one hand, I have been strongly against leveraging the balance sheet, once it became an inescapable end, the only question for me was who should own our company. Again for me, the only acceptable answer is our employees.''
 
Another Union May Join
A person close to the pilots' union said that another important union, the Association of Flight Attendants, had shown an interest in being part of the buyout plan.
Carol Holmes, the vice president of the union, which represents 13,500 flight attendants, said that the union had not yet acted but that on Tuesday the company had presented a proposal to join the buyout to the union's governing body.
A person close to the pilots' union said that Jack Pope, the chief financial officer of UAL, has arranged financing for the bid, which would total about $6.8 billion. Mr. Pope persuaded bank lenders to allow a reopening of some of the terms of the financing if United should find itself in a severe recession like the one that hit the industry in 1980 and 1981, the source said.
Also, the source said, the pilots' union would reopen parts of its seven-year contract under certain conditions, if the bid was approved.
On the other hand, the source said, if the airline does well and is able to repay debt much faster than expected, then some of the cuts in wages and benefits might be shortened or modified.
 
Some Possible Advantages
The airline could end up with an operating cost advantage over other airlines. The pilots, under a new contract, would take 10 percent cuts in pay. Also, rather than being paid for some hours worked, the pilots would get credit toward company stock.
The union would also be committed to a seven-year contract. It would not strike during that period and its members would be obliged to cross any picket lines put up by other unions.
The other major union at United. the International Assocication of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, remains unwilling to participate in the offer. It was, however, holding talks with parties who were part of the buyout effort.

HEADLINE: U.S. and India Sign Tax Pact

BYLINE: By SANJOY HAZARIKA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Sept. 13

 BODY:
After 30 years of negotiations, India and the United States signed an agreement yesterday to avoid double taxation, and American officials said today that the accord could set a precedent for tax relations between the United States and other developing nations.
Officials from both countries said they expected bilateral trade and American investment in India to increase substantially as a result of the agreement. They especially cited the transfer of high technology from the United States to India.
Parts of the treaty, especially the provisions dealing with royalties, make important changes from ''standard U.S. treaty policy,'' said American officials and diplomats involved in the negotiations. The only other country with which the United States shares such a treaty is China.
 
'A Legal Platform'
''What The treaty does is establish a legal platform for companies, citizens and permanent residents of both countries to define how much taxes they owe and to which Government,'' an official said. Thus American companies will no longer be subject to strict Indian rules that put a 30 percent tax on office revenues even if the business office functions here for only 15 days.
After Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi expressed an interest in the taxation issue during a visit to Washington in 1987, the negotiations were speeded up. The treaty was signed here Tuesday by the American Ambassador, John R. Hubbard, and India's Revenue Secretary, Nitish Sengupta.
''There have been rocky moments in Indo-U.S. relations, and the tax treaty is a very welcome piece of good news,'' said Louis Warren, the economic counselor at the American Embassy here. The United States is the largest foreign investor in India, with investments worth more than $600 million, and is also New Delhi's largest trading partner.

HEADLINE: Mexico and Banks Agree On Debt Accord Language

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The Mexican Government and a committee of banks announced an agreement today on detailed language covering the debt-reduction plan reached between that nation and the bank group in July.
The language, called a term sheet, will be sent to the more than 500 banks owed money by Mexico, officials said. The term sheet provides a list of options the banks may exercise to reduce the amount of Mexican debt on their books. 
The agreement also opens the way for Mexico to use a $2 billion bridge loan from the United States and other sources to help it meet its needs until the relief from the proposal becomes available.
''The agreement on the term sheet concludes the second stage of the process,'' said Angel Gurria, Under Secretary of the Mexican Ministry of Finance.
''As expected, it has taken several weeks since we reached agreement in principle in July, but the issues we confronted were new, extremely complex and economically of great importance, both to Mexico and the banks,'' he said in a statement released in New York, where the bank panel and Mexican officials met.
''After a period for review, we will visit financial centers around the world to explain the package and answer the banks' questions,'' Mr. Gurria said.
Mexico's agreement in principle with the steering committee of 15 creditor banks, reached July 24, was seen as a test of the policy of the Bush Administration for reducing third world debt and as a milestone for other debtor countries.
It represents the first significant reduction in a government's debt to commercial banks.
Under the agreement, each bank will have three options: a 35 percent reduction in principal, reduction of the interest rate on its loans to 6.25 percent from the current average of about 10 percent, or providing new loans equal to 25 percent of what Mexico owes the bank.
The deal applies to about $53 billion of Mexico's foreign debt, which is a total of $107 billion, second in the developing world to the $120 billion owed by Brazil.
 
Bank Accounting Rule
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (Reuters) - The Securities and Exchange Commission removed a potential obstacle to Mexico's debt-reduction plan today by confirming that banks in the United States that swap their loans for lower-value bonds would not have to record a loss.
An S.E.C. staff memorandum released today was in line with a ruling that governed a prototype bonds-for-loans swap that Mexico arranged last year. Under the ruling banks do not record a loss if the total receipts from repaying the loan under the renegotiated terms are equal to receipts under the old payment schedule.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: MEXICO (99%); UNITED STATES (94%);

HEADLINE: Foreign Exchange Trading Is Near $500 Billion a Day

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The world's foreign exchange market is growing rapidly, according to reports released by central banks yesterday. London is still the largest foreign exchange market in the world, but the United States and Japan are catching up.
The worldwide market is nearing $500 billion in total transactions. And as foreign exchange trading grows, it is playing a larger role in reflecting worldwide reaction to economic news and to American economic policy. 
Far more than just several years ago, the movement of the dollar on any day tends to influence the moods of the bond and stock markets.
The foreign exchange market in the United States, which is No. 2, grew by 120 percent over the last three years, the reports said. At $128.9 billion, it now rivals the size of the government securities market, where daily trading is at $125 billion to $150 billion.
In London, trading volume was $187 billion, up by 107 percent from $90 billion in March 1986. In Tokyo, where the growth was the sharpest, the average volume was reported to be $115.2 billion, up by 140 percent from $48 billion in March 1986.
The trading figures are from reports by the central banks, including the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The last survey was conducted three years ago. The reports are the broadest and most coordinated effort to measure foreign exchange activity.
The market has grown as world economies have become more interrelated and capital markets more integrated, said Gretchen Greene, the senior vice president in charge of foreign exchange at the New York Fed, which did the American survey. This internationalization of the economy has led to easier capital flows and has opened the opportunity for people and companies to invest abroad, which has increased the need for swapping currencies.
 
Looking to Hedge Risk
The volume of trading has also risen, she said, because more commercial banks and investment banks are getting into the business, partly because it is seen as a new avenue for profits. And more companies are using the market to hedge their risk in doing business in other countries.
The Federal Reserve report does not detail the specific nature of the trading - that is, whether it is mostly by speculators. But Ms. Greene said the survey showed that only about 12 percent of the trades reported were with customers not involved in regular foreign exchange trading.
The New York Fed said that average daily trading in April totaled $128.9 billion, up from $58.5 billion in March 1986 and from $18 billion in 1980. This combines the trading completed by banks and other institutions, mostly investment banks based in the United States. Of the total, 40 percent was done by subsidiaries of foreign banks.
The figures are adjusted to remove double counting of trades between institutions in the United States. But the totals reported for each country are not adjusted for this double counting, so adding the individual figures do not give a precise amount for worldwide volume.
 
Plenty of Movement
The Fed's report does not disclose the volume of trading by institution, but it does show that it is a volatile business and that a lot of movement exists among the leaders. Ms. Greene said that four of the top five institutions in 1986 fell to the bottom of the Top 10 list this year and that two institutions fell off the list this year.
The West German mark is still the leading currency traded against the dollar, but the Japanese yen is gaining. This year, 32.1 percent of the volume was in marks, down from 33.7 percent in 1986, while the volume of yen trades was 26.4 percent, up from 23.7 percent in 1986.
Almost two-thirds of the trading is direct, or spot-currency trades, the same proportion as in 1986. But currency options, a tool used to limit risk, have grown to 4.3 percent of the volume this year, from nine-tenths of 1 percent in 1986.
Other countries reporting yesterday included France, Canada and the Netherlands, where the trading volume was much lower. It was $26 billion in France, $16 billion in the Netherlands - with the double counting of trades - and $15 billion in Canada.

HEADLINE: Car Sales Off 2.8% on Low Supplies

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 13

 BODY:
Sales of American-built cars dropped by 2.8 percent in early September as consumers found that some 1989 models were in short supply at dealers after two months of brisk sales that had surprised some analysts.
On a seasonally adjusted basis, the domestic industry sold vehicles at an annual rate of 6.8 million units in the Sept. 1-10 period, compared with the 7.4 million average rate since the start of the year.
Analysts said the Ford Motor Company's inventory of new cars was the thinnest, contributing to the company's 6.6 percent drop in sales, to 37,044, for the latest period. The General Motors Corporation posted sales of 66,445, or 1.7 percent higher, and the Chrysler Corporation reported sales of 19,007, a 6.7 percent increase. 
 
Overall Sales Down
Over all, the eight domestic manufacturers, including the four Japanese auto makers that build cars in this country, posted sales of 132,004, compared with 155,131 in the 1988 selling period. The percentage decline is adjusted to account for seven selling days during the latest period, compared with eight selling days in the corresponding period last year.
Earlier in the summer, many of the analysts said that auto makers were producing too many cars in light of some forecasts that the economy and sales would slump, but that had not been the case.
''In retrospect, the companies gave rebates that were more generous than necessary,'' said Scott Merlis, an analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company in New York. ''The problem has switched from the demand side to the supply side.''
Mr. Merlis said inventories of 1989 Chevrolet Corsica and Beretta, Ford Taurus, Buick LeSabre and Chrysler's Sundance and Shadow models were all lower than normal, which probably meant that certain models were not available at some dealerships.
''Generous rebates are still in effect,'' said Charles Brady of Oppenheimer & Company in New York. ''But when the only car left out there in the dealer's lot is orange with a burgundy interior, they don't work.''
 
Other Factors
David Healy, an analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., also in New York, who has been pessimistic about car sales for most of the year, said low inventories were only part of the reason for lower sales. ''That's some of the reason for the beginning of the fall collapse,'' he said. ''I think there is a lot more demand for the 1989's than there is going to be for the 1990's.''
In two weeks, the domestic companies officially begin selling their 1990 models, with retail prices that promise to be significantly higher than those for 1989. But executives of the Big Three auto makers have declined to speculate whether they will continue the rebates, and if so, how large they will be.
''I think the companies are going to go eyeball-to-eyeball with the consumer for 20 to 30 days'' without rebates to test demand, Mr. Brady said. ''With fourth-quarter production schedules so low, they're not running a big risk of getting stuck with many cars.''

HEADLINE: Dow Loses 27.74 Points to Close at 2,679.52

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stocks dropped sharply yesterday, as weaker bond and dollar prices prompted a late round of program trading.
The Dow Jones industrial average ended 27.74 points lower, at 2,679.52, after being down only 7 points an hour before the close. Yesterday's close was the first time in three weeks that the Dow ended a day trading below 2,700.
In the broader market, declines on the New York Stock Exchange far exceeded advances, by 912 to 555.
By late in the day, the bellwether 30-year Treasury issue was off about half a point, while the dollar was moderately lower against most leading currencies. 
 
Volume Increases
Volume on the Big Board increased to 175.3 million shares, from 142.1 million on Tuesday. Many investors moved from the sidelines, puting aside any inclination to remain inactive while awaiting several economic reports scheduled for release tomorrow.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was down 3.24, to 345.46, and the New York Stock Exchange composite index was down 1.59, to 192.29.
''What we saw today was a roller-coaster session triggered by traders' vacillating perceptions about the economic outlook,'' said Eugene E. Peroni Jr., chief technical analyst at Janney Montgomery Scott Inc. in Philadelphia.
''In the last hour, when the Dow failed to cross above 2,700, selling programs jumped in to push the market down,'' Mr. Peroni added. He said the market is ''exhibiting visible signs of wear and tear as investors grow impatient with the Dow's inability to make any decisive headway since setting a new peak.''
Analysts said the market was also adversely affected by rumors that Merrill Lynch faced large losses from its dealings in high-yield ''junk bonds.'' The rumors were quickly denied by Merrill, but Merrill's shares ended the day off 1 3/8, to 32 7/8.
Traders said there were rumors that Merrill held a large position in junk bonds. The junk bond market has been jittery in recent days, partly because of the cash-flow problems of the Campeau Corporation, a large issuer of junk bonds. A Merrill Lynch spokesman said of the rumors that the firm had suffered big losses, ''They're all false.''
National Semiconductor was the most active stock on the Big Board, rising 3/8, to 7 7/8, on a volume of nearly 3.5 million shares. Thomas Kurlak, a Merrill Lynch analyst, made favorable comments on the semiconductor group.
Circle K dropped 1 3/4, to 7 3/4, and was the biggest percentage loser. The company said it had terminated solicitation of proposals to acquire it and had suspended its dividend.
 
Possible Takeover Seen
Burlington Resources rose 3/4, to 47 1/2, on 1.75 million shares. The company said it knew of no reason for the activity, but traders said there were rumors that the company might be an acquisition target.
MGM/UA Communications was up 1 1/2, to 21 1/4. The company said it had received a takeover bid from a company listed on the New York Stock Exchange, but did not identify the company.
Active blue chips included A.T.&T., which dropped 1/2, to 40; Exxon, off 7/8, to 44 1/2; General Electric, down 1 3/8, to 55 1/2; and I.B.M., off 1 1/2, to 115 3/8.
On the American Stock Exchange, the Amex market-value index slipped 0.77, to 383.77. The Nasdaq composite index of over-the-counter trading dipped 0.03, to 471.83.
In over-the-counter trading, MCI Communications rose 1 3/8, to 42 1/2, after a Salomon Brothers analyst, Lap Y. Lee, reiterated a ''buy'' recommendation on the stock, traders said.
Mack Trucks dropped 1/2, to 11 1/8. The company said it expected to report a net loss of about $50 million for the third quarter and substantial losses for the fourth quarter.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar in a Broad Decline; Gold Prices Up on Comex

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined against all key foreign currencies in quiet trading yesteday.
Gold prices rose slightly after falling overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $359.90 an ounce, up 40 cents from Tuesday. 
Linda McLaughlin, a currency trader for Chemical New York Capital Markets Group, attributed the dollar's decline largely to renewed concerns that West Germany and Japan might soon raise their interest rates, helping to strengthen the yen and mark.
 
Economic Data Awaited
But she said yesterday's trading was relatively light as many dealers preferred to keep a low profile in anticipation of a spate of economic data.
Today the Government is scheduled to release its report on August retail sales. Tomorrow reports on August producer prices, industrial production and July merchandise trade are due out.
In New York, the dollar finished at 146.40 yen, down from 146.91. And sterling fetched $1.5585 in New York, up from $1.5485.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.9725 West German marks, down from 1.9865; 1.6990 Swiss francs, down from 1.7140; 6.6525 French francs, down from 6.6915; 1.18405 Canadian dollars, down from 1.18725, and 1,415.00 Italian lire, down from 1,422.125.
Gold traded at $358.50 an ounce in London late yesterday, down from $358.75 bid Tuesday. In Zurich, gold fell to $358.25 an ounce from $358.55. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold closed at a bid of $359.93 an ounce, unchanged from Tuesday.
Silver prices were little changed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery fell to $5.07 an ounce, from $5.07 Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Detroit Mayor Easily Wins Primary but Faces Runoff

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 13

 BODY:
Mayor Coleman A. Young, one of the first blacks to lead a major American city, won a big victory Tuesday over a dozen challengers, with Representative John Conyers Jr. coming in third in the city's nonpartisan primary.
Mr. Young will face Tom Barrow, an accountant who is a nephew of the prizefighter Joe Louis, in a runoff election in November. Mr. Barrow ran against the Mayor in 1985, Mr. Young received 103,827 votes, or 51 percent, and Mr. Barrow received 48,695, or 24 percent. Mr. Conyers, a 13-term Congressman, received 36,247 votes, or 18 percent. Ten other candidates shared the rest of the vote, with City Council President Erma Henderson taking a distant fourth place.
Mr. Young, 71 years old, celebrated his success at a reception where music from Michael Jackson's ''Bad'' album boomed over a sound system. 
 
'The War Is Not Over'
''Don't celebrate too long, because the war is not over,'' he said. ''The victory is not won.''
Mr. Conyers, who entered the race a day before the filing deadline in May, refused to concede during a brief appearance at a reception Tuesday night. At a news conference today, Mr. Conyers conceded the election but defended his strategy, saying, ''Campaigns by their nature are disorganized.'' Asked what he would have done differently, he said, ''I would have started earlier.''
Mr. Barrow, 40, has campaigned virtually since losing the 1985 race 39 percent to Mr. Young's 61 percent. But he has never held office and does not have a well-financed political machine to match Mr. Young's.
''I think Barrow unfortunately is not going to be able to mobilize the kind of organizational structure necessary to unseat the Mayor,'' said Wilbur Rich, an associate professor of political science at Wayne State University who has written a biography of Mr. Young. ''I think he'll try to replay the 1985 election, which is not going to be enough to give the Mayor serious competition.''
Mr. Barrow campaigned on what he called Mr. Young's favoritism of development over neighborhood renewal. Mr. Young, meanwhile, emphasized jobs and riverfront development created during his 16 years in office. $5 Million Raised Mr. Young reported raising $5 million for what he said would be his last election, to be the first five-term Detroit Mayor.
The manager of the Barrow campaign, Geoffrey Garfield, said Mr. Barrow's grass-roots approach could match Mr. Young's media barrage.
''Now that people know that Coleman can be beaten, we expect fund raising will pick up,'' Mr. Garfield said. ''We got this far against a 25-year Congressman that everyone thought was going to wipe us out. It was the most organized campaign this city has seen in 20 years.''
Mr. Conyers, whose campaign appeared unfocused, had been given a slight edge over Mr. Barrow in pre-election polls because of his quarter-century in Congress representing Detroit's west side.
In other mayoral elections Tuesday, Mayor Don Fraser of Minneapolis easily topped a field of seven candidates in a nonpartisan primary, but still must face his leading challenger, Jens Peterson, a firefighter, in November. Both are running on the Democratic Farmer Labor Party label.
In neighboring St. Paul, where Mayor George Latimer is retiring, City Council President Jim Schneibel, also of the Democratic Farmer Labor Party, led a field of nine candidates. Former City Councilman Bob Fletcher finished second and will face Mr. Schneibel in November.
 
Mobile Mayor Is Unseated
In Mobile, Ala., Mike Dow unseated Mayor Arthur Outlaw in a bitter mayoral election in Alabama's second-largest city. Mr. Dow had 30,444 votes, or 56 percent, to 23,715, or 44 percent, for Mr. Outlaw, who is chairman of the State Republican Party, in the nonpartisan race.
Some viewed the race as an early test of Gov. Guy Hunt's strength for a 1990 re-election. The Mobile area strongly supported Mr. Hunt, who is a Republican, in 1986 and is considered Republican territory. Some of Mr. Dow's supporters were aligned with Attorney General Don Siegelman, who is considered one of Mr. Hunt's potential Democratic opponents.

HEADLINE: THE NEW YORK PRIMARY;
The Candidates on the Issues

 BODY:
In separate interviews last month with The New York Times, David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani discussed their views on major issues facing New Yorkers. Here are excerpts from their responses:
Q. What can you, as mayor, do to restore civility and reduce racial tension?
DINKINS: I think much of it can be by example. He can set a tone, an atmosphere. High on my agenda is to try to improve the climate in race relations generally. 
GIULIANI: We need to restore a sense of unity and we need to restore a sense of common purpose in the city. And the way a mayor does it is by talking decently and in a way that emphasizes all our similarities.Every time I talk to a group of people, whether it's a black group or a white group or a Latino group, I get the same questions. People are concerned about the same things. I think a mayor has to let people know that.
Q. How many more police officers does the city need?
DINKINS: I've committed right now to doubling the number of community patrol officers in the first four years. Im talking about something in the neighborhood of 800. But I would also like to see officers on top of that, 2,000, 1,500, 2,500. If you ask people what they want, they will tell you a cop on the beat.
GIULIANI: I'm certain we need somewhere between 4,000 and 5,000 police officers over the next three to four years. Beyond that, it's really a question of what happens to the crime rates.
Q. How would you perk up the New York City economy and create jobs?
DINKINS: We need to diversify our economy. We need not to be at the mercy of an October in Wall Street. We need to assist the garment industry and graphic arts. We need to think of incubators which would assist small businesses with the struggle to get started. You give them different kinds of assistance.
GIULIANI: What the city is going to do, it's going to have to show progress to business leaders here. We're going to have to show progress in rolling back the crime problem, rolling back the drug problem. The mayor taking charge of our school system and leading a radical reform of the system.
Q. What would you do about New York City's health-care crisis?
DINKINS: We've got to recognize the need to pay home health care workers, for instance, decent salaries. Because the failure to do so keeps some people in the hospitals at $500 to $1,000 a day, whereas peanuts would permit them to go home because there was somebody to care for them.
GIULIANI: The mayor should assume the role as leader of the hospital health system in New York, which is both a private and a public system. The mayor should become a spokesman, with them, for getting the kind of additional subsidies and help that they're going to need, and increases in the rates from Albany, which is something that is being considered right now.
Q. What can a mayor do about homeless and mentally ill people living in the streets?
DINKINS: If we want to get the people off the street, we have to provide an alternative that is viable. It costs us about $33 to $36 a day for folks at a place like the Fort Washington shelter. It costs under $25 a day, a person, with services, with supportive services, in a decent S.R.O. So, in other words, it is not us saying 'Oh, we can't afford that.' We're spending the money wrong.
GIULIANI: You have to develop a system of rescue centers around the city to replace the barrack-like shelters and supported S.R.O.'s for people who have more substantial problems than just not being able to afford a place to live. And I dont believe that would be any more expensive than the barrack like shelters that we now have.

HEADLINE: Rules Passed by Metro-North Could Help to Rout Homeless

BYLINE: By DAVID E. PITT

 BODY:
The Metro-North Commuter Railroad adopted draft rule yesterday intended to regulate public conduct aboard trains and in passenger stations in New York State, including Grand Central Station.
Although the proposed rules would prohibit everything from smoking and littering to spitting and specific forms of sexual conduct, some appeared aimed specifically at the homeless, who are especially numerous in Grand Central.
The draft rules would also forbid such acts as washing oneself at a drinking fountain; washing ''clothing or other personal belongings'' in restrooms or at any other sources of water; changing clothes or ''remaining undressed'' in any Metro-North site; lying on ''floors, platforms, stairs or landings''; occupying more than one seat, and creating ''unreasonable noise.'' 
The proposals were approved unanimously and virtually without discussion at a monthly meeting of the railroad's board.
 
Harassment Is Charged
The would also prohibit the dispensing of ''food or commercial merchandise with or without charge'' except ''pursuant to the terms of a lease, license, operation agreement or concession'' granted by the railroad or the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
Advocated for the homeless and civil rights lawyers immediately denounced the proposed regulations as illogical and mean-spirited, saying they appeared to be part of barely disguised effort to displace the homeless through police harassment.
A staff report by a Metro-North lawyer, Robert Bergen, said the proposed rules were intended ''to codify in a single document standards of conduct for Metro-North's customers and employees and for the public at large.''
Peter Stangl, the Metro-North president, described the proposals as part of a continuing effort by the M.T.A. to make all of its agencies codify ''quality of life'' regulations.
''But,'' he said ''there are also people pretending to be homeless who are selling crack and committing other crimes in Grand Central, and we want them out of there.''
 
Now a Criminal Problem
Asked whether the rules might create unnecessary confrontations between the Metro-North police and homeless people, he said: ''I don't think they will do that. The purpose of these ules is not to increase confrontation.''
But Norman Siegel, executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, said, ''It's inevitable that there will be confrontations.''
These rules would transform a social and economic problem into a criminal problem,'' he said. ''If Metro-North would just continue its work with the city agencies and homeless advocates,'' Mr. Siegel said, ''The might be able to accomplish the same thing.''
Last month, the railroad helped coordinate a five-day program in Grand Central intended to coax the homeless to shelters or into drug or alcohol treatment programs. Official hope the program, involving the city's Human Resources Administration and private agencies, will eventually be put into effect throughout the M.T.A. system.
Under the proposed rules, violators would be issued summonses, ejected, or both. They would also be subject to fines of up to $50 and 30 days in jail.
''Obviously, things like spitting, littering and urinating in public are not acceptable behavior,'' said Fred Griesbach, director of the New York State Coalition for the Homeless. ''But these are things that are going to happen when people don't have bathrooms of their own.
''I've never considered people who are trying to keep themselves clean as people committing a criminal offense,'' Mr. Griesbach said.
The proposals must still be discussed at a formal public hearing and will ultimately require action by the full M.T.A. board.

HEADLINE: Bush Doubles Food Aid to Poland After Being Pressed by Congress

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
In a reversal apparently prompted by pressure from Congress, President Bush announced today that the United States would double food aid for Poland to $100 million in the next fiscal year.
The President said in a White House statement that the new assistance, which would supplement aid from the European Community and is intended to reach Poland before winter, ''underscores our continuing commitment to assist the Polish Government and people.''
At a National Security Council meeting last week, Administration officials reportedly ruled out an immediate, major increase in aid. But leading members of Congress of both parties told the President he needed a high visibility program to demonstrate support for the new Polish Government, the first since the 1940's that is not dominated by the Communists. 
 
Dole Pressed for Increase
A White House official acknowledged this afternoon that the program ''comes out of discussions we had with people on the Hill.''
The Senate minority leader, Bob Dole, who met with top Polish leaders last month, told Mr. Bush that there was a limited time for action to help the fledgling Government. A spokesman said the Kansas Republican had been told by Poland's new Prime Minister, Tadeusz Mazowiecki, that ''anyone who gives now, gives twice.''
Lawmakers welcomed the President's action, but several said it did not go far enough.
 
'Stopgap Effort' Seen
Senator Patrick J. Leahy, chairman of the Agriculture Committee, called it a ''stopgap effort that fails to give Poland the long-term help it needs to restructure its agricultural economy and to sustain the world's newest democracy.''
The Vermont Democrat has proposed a program of forgiveness of Poland's $2 billion of agricultural debt to the United States, as well as financial aid and a broad range of technical assistance.
The Senate Foreign Relations Committee is expected to draft a financial aid package for Poland next week. ''The White House was starting to feel a general sense of political pressure to do more than they have,'' a committee staff member said.
At a National Security Council meeting last week, Administration officials concluded that because of continued economic disorder in Poland - with raging inflation, strikes for large wage increases and uncertainty about the Communist Party's willingness to let the new Government succeed - it was not realistic to proceed with any large-scale aid.
The additional assistance announced today will come from an existing budget authorization under the Food Assistance Program, a standing program to provide food aid, and requires no legislation.
The first $50 million, announced on Aug. 1 as part of a total $119 million package for Poland, was a grant. The new $50 million represents a combination of grants of surplus foods, concessionary loans and subsidized sales.
Together with $8.4 million in emergency food aid in the current fiscal year, which ends Sept. 30, the new program brings to $108.4 million the total food assistance for the two years - offered in such commodities as meat, corn, butter, butter oil, cottonseed, sunflower oil, cotton and rice.
The effort is in tandem with the $140 million that the European Community has pledged in food aid as part of a coordinated effort called for by Mr. Bush at an economic summit meeting in Paris in July.
The precise allocations still have to be worked out with the Polish Government. One danger is that the sudden supply of commodities, competing with similar Polish products, could depress domestic production.
It was not clear whether all the food would stay in Poland or whether export would be authorized to give the Poles some needed foreign exchange.
Mr. Bush said it was his intention that the food aid ''support long-term reform of the Polish agricultural system by providing much needed commodities during a transitional period toward a market economy.''
Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader whose non-Communist trade union movement has a dominant role in the Warsaw Government, is expected to visit Washington in November.
Mr. Walesa has called for $10 billion of emergency aid.

LENGTH: 2507 words

HEADLINE: House Committee Votes 19 to 17 To Reduce Tax on Capital Gains

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
A divided House Ways and Means Committee approved legislation today to cut the tax on capital gains, handing President Bush an important political victory and setting the stage for a bruising fight on the House floor later this month.
The committee's 19-to-17 vote was an embarrassing defeat for one of the most powerful members of the House, Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who heads the committee. Mr. Rostenkowski hoped until the end to fracture an alliance between six conservative Democrats and all 13 Republicans on the panel. He repeatedly delayed a vote to avoid a floor battle that would pit Democrats against one another as well as against the Republicans and the Administration.
Those who want a lower tax rate on capital gains, as the nation had before the Tax Reform Act of 1986, assert that the lower rates encourage investors to trade assets like stocks, bonds and real estate more frequently. That makes more capital available to business for expansion or new ventures, they say. 
 
No Guarantee
Opponents contend that there is no guarantee that such capital will be productive and that the lower rates benefit the rich at the expense of the working classes.
Although the capital gains cut has Administration backing, it differs somewhat from the proposal first advanced by Mr. Bush in his 1988 election campaign. At the White House, Marlin Fitzwater, the President's spokesman, said, ''We are pleased by the vote, and we will be working hard to sustain it on the floor.''
The measure adopted today was written by a Democrat, Representative Ed Jenkins of Georgia. Democrats who opposed the cut, including Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, directed their criticism at the President rather than members of their own party.
''This is Bush's folly,'' Mr. Gephardt said. ''This was George Bush's idea to help out his wealthy friends, and it was George Bush's efforts that made this happen today.''
 
'Better Paying Jobs'
But Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the committee's senior Republican, praised the committee action, say-ing it would ''mean better paying jobs for more Americans.'' He disputed Democratic contentions that it was a boon for the wealthy. ''This cut will benefit family farmers, small businesses, timber interests and it will not add to the deficit,'' he said.
Earlier this week, Mr. Rostenkowski won agreement from the supporters of a capital gains cut for a limited alternative, but the liberals on the committee rejected the plan. They insisted that Democrats had no business supporting tax breaks that primarily benefited the wealthy.
That message became today's rallying cry for the House Democratic leaders, who pledged to seek defeat of the capital gains tax cut and to come up with an alternative that a majority of the party could support.
''What we did here is something for the wealthiest Americans that will eventually be paid for out of the pocketbooks of middle- and low-income workers,'' Mr. Gephardt said. ''It will raise the budget deficit, it will not help the economy, and it is not good tax policy.''
The Jenkins measure would allow investors to ignore 30 percent of their profit on sales of assets in calculating their taxes, if those assets are held more than one year and sold between Sept. 14, 1989, and Dec. 31, 1991. Capital gains are currently taxed at the same rate as ordinary income, which is 28 percent for most taxpayers. The exclusion would temporarily have the effect of reducing their capital gains rate to 19.6 percent.
 
Adjusting for Inflation
Once the tax break expires, investors who sell assets acquired after Dec. 31, 1991, would not be taxed on the portion of any profits attributable solely to inflation. This procedure, known as indexing, was part of Mr. Rostenkowski's compromise plan, and committee Democrats said it might well be incorporated in the alternative Democratic leaders present on the House floor.
The cut in the capital gains rate is part of a larger tax bill that is expected to raise $6.9 billion in the 1990 fiscal year that begins Oct. 1, more than enough to satisfy the tax committee's obligation for the deficit reduction package that Congress must pass in the next month.
The tax bill includes enhanced tax credits for child care, reductions in the surtax that Medicare recipients pay for insurance against the catastrophic costs of serious illness, and extension of a variety of popular tax breaks that have expired or are due to expire at the end of the year. It effectively repeals a much-disputed requirement that employers not discriminate against lower-paid employees and retirees in health-care plans, and it restricts the tax advantages of some leveraged buyouts.
To offset the bill's revenue losing measures, the bill includes higher benefit premiums for Medicare recipients, a new excise tax on ozone depleting chemicals, extension of the telephone excise tax and a speedup in the collection of payroll taxes for large companies.
Crafting an alternative to the committee measure that is acceptable to an array of Democrats and at the same time is attractive enough to scuttle the capital gains cut will be no easy task. Perhaps a third of the House Democrats favors some cut in the capital gains tax, including traditionally liberal lawmakers from states with sizable timber interests and family farms. People in these enterprises would stand to benefit from lower capital gains taxes.
In a rehearsal of the intraparty bargaining to come, committee Democrats today offered a series of amendments to the Jenkins plan. These measures, all defeated, would have aided lower-income taxpayers and restored the right, in general, to deduct contributions to individual retirement accounts from taxable income. They would also have raised the top tax rate on the wealthiest Americans to 33 percent from 28 percent. The intention was to match the rates paid by some upper-middle-income taxpayers, who are caught in what is known as the ''33 percent bubble'' because of a 5 percent surcharge.
 
'Middle-Class Massacre'
''It was a middle-class massacre,'' said Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of Long Island, as he emerged from the closed session in which votes were taken today. Mr. Rostenkowski was equally angry.
''Amendments dedicating some of the proceeds of this plan to drug enforcement and deficit reductions were rejected,'' he said. ''Over and over again, sometimes through tie votes, a bare majority of the committee decided that a tax cut for the wealthiest of Americans is more important than any other economic issue.''
Mr. Rostenkowski, who avoided reporters and issued a written statement after the vote, said it would be ''a financial disaster to this country.''
''Today's action, which could be a first step in the unraveling of tax reform, is the ultimate expression of feel-good economics,'' he said. ''The President and his supporters want the American people to believe that there is no price to pay for this tax giveaway. In just a few years, the people will find out just how misguided this plan is.''
The six Democrats who sided with the Republicans in support of the capital gains tax cut were Mr. Jenkins, J. J. Pickle of Texas, Mike Andrews of Texas, Beryl Anthony of Arkansas, Andrew Jacobs of Indiana and Ronnie Flippo of Alabama.
 
Renewed I.R.A.'s
Among the alternatives, the proposal that seems to be gathering the greatest momentum is to restore the deduction for contributions to I.R.A.'s. Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Committee, advanced the idea earlier this week, arguing that it would encourage the saving needed to assist capital formation in the United States while conferring a tax benefit on a far broader segment of Americans than a capital gains tax cut.
''The Bentsen proposal is popular among Democratic members because it is the kind of political cover that everybody needs,'' one Ways and Means Committee aide said. ''You can be against capital gains and for the middle class, and that is the perfect place to be.''
 
Highly Charged Debate
The highly charged political debate over the capital gains cut has largely obscured the longstanding economic arguments on the issue. Proponents of a cut contend that taxing profits from investments at a lower rate than ordinary income encourages people to buy stocks, bonds, real estate and the like, thereby making more capital available to business, so that it can expand or develop new products.
In a statement issued after the capital gains vote, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady touched on those themes, praising the committee action as ''a major step forward in providing incentives for long-term investment in the United States.''
Opponents of the capital gains cut argue that without impossibly complicated regulations and restrictions, there is no guarantee that investment money will flow to productive businesses or high risk ventures, where capital is most needed. The two sides also differ over the long-term impact of a capital gains cut on the Federal budget deficit.
While there is general agreement that the initial wave of buying and selling by investors to take advantage of the lower rate will bring money in to the Treasury, there is considerable disagreement about whether the lower tax rate will eventually mean lower or higher revenues.
 
By AGIS SALPUKAS
After a two-week battle, a $6.75 billion bid that would make United Airlines the nation's largest employee-owned company was approved last night by the parent company's board.
The directors of the UAL Corporation accepted the $300-a-share offer from a group that includes pilots and top executives at the airline, the nation's second largest, and British Airways. A rival bidder, the investor Marvin Davis, apparently dropped out earlier, people familiar with the bidding said.
The deal still needs the approval of shareholders and the Department of Transportation. Little resistance is expected, but the Transportation Department has in the past raised concerns about foreign carriers buying into American airlines.
 
'The American Perestroika'
Under the proposal, British Airways would end up owning 15 percent of the company, the management group 10 percent and the other employees 75 percent.
Analysts said the buyout would be a milestone in relations between American labor and management.
''This is the American perestroika,'' said Gene Keilin, a general partner at the investment banking firm Lazard Freres & Company who helped assemble the deal, comparing it to the economic reorganization in the Soviet Union.
Analysts predicted yesterday that other airlines and big companies might become candidates for buyouts led by unions and management to prevent outside investors from gaining control.
 
Employees Not All Owners
But experts on employee-owned companies said that teaming up on a buyout might be the easy part. They predicted that conflicts and problems would come not only at the management level, where executives and union leaders will have to work together, but also at lower levels, where attempts would be made to motivate the pilots and possibly other workers involved in the deal to improve productivity and involve them more in running the company. [Page D5.] One of the biggest problems facing the new company may be that not all employees will become owners. Stephen M. Wolf, chairman and president of UAL and a member of the group whose bid was accepted, said all of the more than 60,000 UAL workers would be invited to participate in a stock ownership plan.
But so far, United's more than 20,000 machinists, who have been at odds with its 6,100 pilots over the future of the company, have refused to participate in the takeover. United's unionized flight attendants opened negotiations yesterday about entering the buyout.
After the deal, the company's 15-member board would reflect the diverse ownership. At least eight members would be independent of any of the buyout groups. Management would appoint three directors, the participating unions would choose three and British Airways would appoint one.
Unlike other companies in which employees gained ownership, UAL is not struggling and does not need such a buyout as a last resort. Instead, UAL is a strong, profitable company, and it had an offer from a wealthy investor in Mr. Davis.
''This is by far the largest deal in which employees are buying a highly profitable company,'' Mr. Keilin said.
Mr. Davis started the bidding for the company, and his most recent offer was for $275 a share. But he could not win concessions from other unions to match those the pilots had offered in their proposal for the company.
The stake that would be held by British Airways reflects the rising number of international agreements in the airline industry and the trend toward creating airlines without national identities.
The buyout would also make United Airlines more competitive, because of concessions on wages and benefits by United's pilots. Other carriers may be forced to lower their own costs.
The takeover group has obtained $3 billion in financing from banks led by Citicorp and the Chase Manhattan Bank. The group must still raise another $4.2 billion to meet the buyout sum and cover debt. But both Citicorp and Chase said they would be able to raise the rest of the money.
Sharon Kalin, an arbitrager who has followed the deal closely, said the group would have no problem getting the rest of the money because banks are eager to lend in a takeover of a profitable American company whose cash flow comes mostly from the United States.
UAL said it would begin a tender offer for all the outstanding common shares of the company at $300 a share in cash beginning Sept. 21.
The company also said its managers and advisers would be available for inquiries by other investors who may want to bid for UAL, but as of last night no other bids were expected.
Mr. Davis, who had indicated earlier that he might want to raise his bid, was considered to be unlikely to stay in the bidding after the board's action yesterday.
Jim Fingerorth, a spokesman for Mr. Davis, said the investor would not have any comment on the UAL board's action but would make a statement today.
 
British Airways Meeting Set
Colin Marshall, president and chief executive of British Airways, which is participating in the pilot-management group offer, met with analysts in New York yesterday and outlined the advantages that an alliance with United would provide for both carriers.
British Airways has agreed to put up $750 million of the $1 billion of equity in the proposal. In addition to getting a 15 percent interest in UAL, it hopes to find other ways for the two carriers to cooperate - in maintenance and flight scheduling, for example.
A spokesman for British Airways said Mr. Marshall had told analysts that the carrier would hold a special shareholders' meeting in the first half of October to vote on the buyout.
