LENGTH: 672 words

HEADLINE: House Panel Assails U.S. Policy on Khmer Rouge

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
The Administration's policy of supporting a settlement in Cambodia that would bring the Khmer Rouge guerrillas into a transitional government came under stinging attack today in Congress.
The Administration's position on the Khmer Rouge was known before, but it has become a more contentious issue with the approach of a Vietnamese withdrawal from the country, which is to be completed this month. The Vietnamese have backed Cambodia's Communist Government for the last decade in its fight against the Khmer Rouge and its non-Communist allies, including Prince Norodom Sihanouk.
A peace conference of the competing factions ended last month in Paris without agreement on a power-sharing arrangement, and continued fighting appears likely. Doubts are being raised among lawmakers about whether the United States should continue backing Prince Sihanouk, with either lethal or nonlethal aid, especially considering his alliance with the Khmer Rouge. 
 
Resistance to Pol Pot
''The United States of America does not have the luxury of recusing itself from moral judgments,'' said Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa. ''In this regard there is a view of many, including this member, that Pol Pot should be brought before an international tribunal for war crimes.''
The Khmer Rouge, led by Pol Pot, is blamed for the death of more than a million Cambodians under their rule between 1975 and 1978, when Vietnam invaded.
In the Administration's first Congressional testimony on Cambodia since the Paris talks, the Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, Richard H. Solomon, appeared today before the House Subcommittee on Asian and Pacific Affairs.
Mr. Solomon said that while on the surface the Administration's position in Paris of allowing the Khmer Rouge to be part of a transitional power-sharing arrangement in Cambodia might not seem ''particularly morally impressive,'' it was the only policy that was realistic and held out a possibility of ultimately undermining the Khmer Rouge through political means.
The major question before the Administration as it considers Cambodia policy today, Mr. Solomon said in prepared remarks, is this: ''Should the Khmer Rouge, responsible for genocidal violence of the 1970's, be totally excluded from the political process with only a military option? Or, should it -less its top leadership - be given a limited stake in a transitional political coalition that would, under international supervision,'' face the test of Cambodian elections?
''From an American perspective,'' he said, ''we want no role for the Khmer Rouge in a future Cambodian government.'' But he said Prince Sihanouk, China and the six members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations felt that the chances of peace would be better if the Khmer Rouge took part in an interim coalition. Such a coalition would also include Prince Sihanouk, the Hanoi-backed Hun Sen regime, and followers of former Prime Minister Son Sann.
''We are not schoolchildren in this business,'' said Mr. Solomon, alluding to the history of Khmer Rouge brutality. ''The chances of avoiding continuing conflict are not very good. But we firmly believe that the chances are much better to get this problem under control if you have a structured political settlement than if you just leave a situation that is totally unstructured or unconstrained, where civil conflict is almost a certainty.''
Representative Chester G. Atkins, Democrat of Massachusetts, told Mr. Solomon there was ''every indication from people that the Khmer Rouge will continue to fight whether they are part of a settlement or not.''
''It would seem to me that there is no reason we would want to insist that the Khmer Rouge be part of a settlement other than the fact that Sihanouk wants it,'' Mr. Atkins said. ''It would seem that in light of the outcome in Paris that Sihanouk is increasingly playing a personal agenda which relates to his own political aggrandizement and less and less of a nationalist Cambodian agenda.''

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Barney Frank's Public and Private Lives: Lonely Struggle for Coexistence

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
When he was first elected to the State Legislature from the Back Bay of Boston in 1973, Barney Frank's friends told him that if he was going to be a politician he would have to spruce up. His hair was a mess, his shoes were unpolished, and, to be blunt, he was fat.
Barney Frank, aggressive to the point of irritating, brilliant to the point of arrogant, responded in a classically Barney Frank manner. Instead of losing weight, cutting his hair or polishing his shoes, he produced a campaign poster. Above a huge picture of a bloated Barney, his black hair tousled (but his shoes at least unseen), was the headline ''Neatness isn't everything. Re-elect Barney.''
Today that poster has the most prominent spot on the wall in the Washington office of Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts. 
Mr. Frank points up at the poster as he explains what was wrong with his life back then - how he tried to divide his public from his private life, how he could not handle the strain of this and, finally, how he made a personal blunder that threatens now to wreck a political career more successful than he ever imagined possible as a boy growing up in Bayonne, N.J.
Mr. Frank is a homosexual. In 1987, he became the first member of Congress to voluntarily acknowledge this, answering honestly a question that he had instructed a reporter to ask him. That moment, he said, was the end of a long struggle for him to stop ''conceding on the private side and having people judge me wholly on the public side.''
 
Looking Back Over a Lifetime
In a political time when things that were once nobody's business have now become everybody's business, the exploration of the Massachusetts Democrat's private life, now under way on the front pages of newspapers and in the House ethics committee because of his relationship with a male prostitute, is singular, forcing not just the public but Barney Frank himself to delve back over his life. ''I'd always been interested in public policy,'' he said in his office this week, ''I had not thought growing up that I was likely to be an elected official. I was Jewish and gay and I knew that.''
He pumped gas at his father's truck stop in Jersey City. He went to Harvard. He took every politics course there was. He tried to write a doctoral thesis, but did not have the patience. He went to work in Kevin White's victorious mayoral campaign and then went with him as executive assistant to Boston's City Hall. With the encouragement of friends, he won a seat in the Legislature.
Through these years, and on to Congress in 1980, Mr. Frank did not so much conceal his private life as abandon even trying to have one, he said. Mr. Frank, who is approaching 50, says he thinks younger gay men understand better how to make a life than he did. ''In my case it was compounded by the fact that I was overweight,'' he said. ''My sense of personal self-esteem was pretty low. My estimate of my social skills was pretty low.''
Publicly, success followed success. In 1979, the Rev. Robert F. Drinan was told by the Pope to leave Congress. Mr. Frank ran for the seat and won. ''I was enjoying my public life a lot,'' Mr. Frank recalls, but felt ''a sense of desperation at the state of my personal life.
 
Facing a Long-Delayed Issue
So in 1983, after winning election to a second term in the House, he said, ''I began to think about how I would deal with the personal side and tried various combinations and permutations.'' But he had waited so long to seek a private life, that when he finally tried, he said, he did not really know how.
''It wasn't just being gay,'' he said. ''It was having this sense of being awkward, of being an outsider of being a minority in so many ways.''
So, he said, his efforts were tentative and, in one case, disastrous - his involvement with Stephen L. Gobie, a male prostitute who then conducted his business from Mr. Frank's Capitol Hill apartment. Many supporters of Mr. Frank are trying to understand why, as one of them put it, a man as smart as Barney is did something so dumb.
''It is generally not understood that gay people often have a prolonged social adolescence,'' said Mr. Frank's friend and supporter, Thomas Stoddard, executive director of the Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund, the oldest national gay rights group in the country. ''They have to deal with questions of dating and sexual adolescence at a later stage. This was part of Barney discovering who he was. Most people understand when it happens to an 18-year-old heterosexual male. It's the same phenomenon.''
Barney Frank has outgrown the man of the campaign poster. As part of his effort to put his personal life together he has slimmed down, is neater. His suits are better. His hair, now graying, is somewhat neater, although his shoes could still use some polish. He lives in a stable relationship with another man.
 
Haunting Experience
But the personal struggles of the old Barney Frank have come back to haunt him, particularly the day in 1985 when he answered an ad in a gay newspaper. At the other end of the telephone was one Stephen L. Gobie, young, strapping, smooth-talking. Mr. Frank, by his own account, paid him $80 for sex, and then befriended him, hoping he could turn Mr. Gobie away from drugs and prostitution. He wrote letters on behalf of Mr. Gobie to his probation officer. Mr. Gobie called Mr. Frank ''sweet and low''-sweet guy, low on cash.
Two years after the two men parted company, Mr. Gobie has decided to tell his tale, mostly in a series of interviews with The Washington Times. Each time the story begins to lag, he adds new details. Not only did he use Mr. Frank's Capitol Hill apartment for prostitution, which Mr. Frank says he did not know. but Mr. Gobie also serviced Congressional wives, he says. He said he used Mr. Frank's car for trysts and that Mr. Frank quashed the parking tickets by sending them to the House clerk; Mr. Frank says he is gathering up all his canceled checks to the District of Columbia parking bureau to disprove this. It is ironic that Mr. Frank's sexual orientation - or at least the public acknowldgment of it - would have kept him from office in earlier days, because as a politician he is something of a throwback. He can walk out on the floor of the House and debate ideas, live and in person, with wit and intelligence. He does not read speeches.
''He is about the quickest mind I've ever met,'' said Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn.
His ability to synthesis situations or ideas made him a prominent spokesman for the liberal wing of his party. In a debate over abortion, he accused the anti-abortion forces of believing that life begins at conception, and ends at birth.
 
Fond Memories of Childhood
He draws his oratorical inspiration not from Clay or Webster but from Shemp Howard, who was one of the Three Stooges and the husband of his father's cousin. Some of his fondest memories of childhood, he said, were when his mother took him to the comedy movies in Newark where they would laugh together at Laurel and Hardy, Abbott and Costello and Moe, Larry and Curly.
''It's precisely because things that we talk about are so deadly serious that humor is essential,'' Mr. Frank said.
Once, he asked Mr. Stoddard if he would like to come as his date to a White House dinner, where perhaps Senator Bob Dole and his wife, Elizabeth, one of Washington's most prominent couples, would also be attending. ''We'll be the gay Doles,'' Mr. Frank said. Mr. Frank can be a little too sharp-edged, however. ''I am impatient,'' he said. ''The impatience has come across as arrogance.'' Even Mr. Frank's explanation has that edge as he says he sometimes feels that in Washington ''there are hundreds of people and part of what they get paid for is to waste my time.''
Arrogance, even a streak of hubris, is what some of his colleagues perceive when Mr. Frank does things like filing an ethics complaint against Representative Gus Savage, Democrat of Illinois, asking that the committee investigte charges that Mr. Savage accosted a woman in the back seat of a Government car while he was on an offical visit to Africa just a few weeks before Mr. Frank's own troubles started.
Mr. Frank draws a strict distinction between public and private activity, maintaining none of his problems ever affected his work. ''People are capable of having messed up careers and wonderfully successful private private lives and vice versa,'' he said. ''It may be that you would have bad judgment that would negatively affect both. But my answer would be that during the period I was feeling weakest about my private life, people were saying nice things about my public life.''
 
Friends See Improvements
Actually, friends say, they have noticed improvements since he came to Congress. At first, they recall, he bounced from issue to issue. Now he focuses more, in the last few years, helping to usher through the 1987 housing act and playing an important role in the debate on last year's immigration law.
Mr. Frank's usual buoyancy was missing as he sat in his office the other day trying to talk. He rubbed his hands together and often held them over his mouth as he spoke, like an insecure boy. The intercom buzzed. ''Take a message and hold the calls,'' he says, ''unless it's Herb or Ann.''
Ann is his sister, Ann Lewis, the Democratic consultant. Herb is Herb Moses, his companion, who is an economist. Things would be much worse without him, Mr. Frank said.
''One of the things that happens when you are public and you are dealing with it is you can get to meet people,'' Mr. Frank said. ''I met somebody who is a throughly thoughtful and sensible guy. He's younger than I am, but he's more mature. He's been a wholly positve influence. I thought I'd managed by '87 to put some of that personal crazyness behind me. I guess I didn't fully do that.''

HEADLINE: REAGAN TO LEAVE HOSPITAL TODAY

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROCHESTER, Minn., Sept. 14

 BODY:
Former President Ronald Reagan is to leave for his Los Angeles home Friday from a hospital here where he underwent brain surgery last week, a spokesman for Mr. Reagan said today.
Physicians caring for the 78-year-old Mr. Reagan ''are completely satisfied with his recuperation,'' the spokesman, Mark Weinberg, said in a daily briefing for reporters.
Mr. Reagan's surgery last Friday entailed the drilling of a hole in his skull to drain a blood clot on the right side of his brain. The subdural hematoma resulted from a fall from a horse during a vacation two months ago. 
The blood clot was Mr. Reagan's second from the horseriding accident and was detected in a routine medical checkup at the Mayo Clinic here last week. Mr. Reagan faces a small but significant risk of the formation of another subdural hematoma, doctors not connected with his case have said.
 
Trips to 6 States Canceled
Mr. Weinberg said the Mayo medical team had ''not yet addressed'' plans for Mr. Reagan's care in California. But he said the former President had canceled a trip to New York and five other states that was to begin next Monday. Mr. Reagan had been scheduled to visit New York, New Jersey, Massachusetts, Ohio, Virginia and Arizona to receive awards and give speeches.
Today, Mr. Reagan paid calls on children who are patients in St. Marys Hospital, which is part of the Mayo Foundation. He also had two prominent visitors - Secretary of Labor Elizabeth H. Dole and Boris N. Yeltsin, the maverick Soviet politician, with whom he met for the first time.
After a 20-minute meeting with Mr. Reagan, Mr. Yeltsin said, ''It seemed as if he feels pretty good.''
Mr. Yeltsin, the 58-year-old former Moscow party chief, said he had asked for the visit because of his ''very high regard'' for Mr. Reagan's contributions in improving Soviet-American relations.
Both countries have to work to solve mutual economic, social, ethical and moral problems, Mr. Yeltsin said.
Mr. Yeltsin, who is on an eight-day tour of this country, said he and Mr. Reagan talked about ''a fair number of things,'' including life in the two countries.

HEADLINE: Soak the Poor! Trash the Economy!

 BODY:
Misleading. Deceptive. Faithless. Such was the decision yesterday by six Democratic members of the House Ways and Means Committee to break rank and vote with the Republicans to lower the capital gains tax for two and a half years. The Democratic leadership now confronts the huge task of reversing the committee's vote on the floor of the House.
The decision was misleading because the Gang of Six promises that the vote will raise tax revenues, thereby preserving valuable tax preferences that would otherwise end. But the revenue increase would last only a year or two, as the country's wealthiest families rush to sell appreciated assets before the tax holiday ends. 
After this initial orgy, revenues would fall steadily and sizably. Congress would then be forced to raise someone else's taxes, or cut even more Federal programs. It's a sure bet that the ultimate losers will be poorer than the families enriched by the Gang of Six.
The decision was deceptive because the Gang of Six, led by Ed Jenkins of Georgia, claims the vote will promote long-term productive investment. Yet the cut is temporary, and would mainly reward old investments. Does the Gang of Six really believe that a windfall profit on past investments affects decisions about future investment? Moreover, most money for venture capital now comes from pension and other tax-exempt funds. Tax cuts for individuals cannot possibly affect the investment decisions of tax-exempt organizations.
The decision is faithless because it violates the bargain struck in the 1986 Tax Reform Act. Marginal tax rates for the rich were reduced from 50 percent to 28 in exchange for full taxation of capital gains and closing other tax loopholes. Now the Gang of Six wants to retract a big part of the bargain.
If earned and unearned income are taxed unequally, investors will put their money where taxes are low, not where productivity is high. The 1986 tax reform equalized the rates and eliminated this perversion. Yesterday, the Gang of Six voted to unravel this victory.
Rather than ruin the tax code, the Democrats and their Republican allies on the committee could have proposed constructive improvements. They didn't. But the full House and Senate still can. Here's how. Index capital gains. Capital gains are unfairly taxed in one respect. The increased value of long-held asssets reflects some inflation and some real profit. Indexing capital gains is warranted, so inflationary increases in price are not taxed.
The committee did provide for indexation. But it made two mistakes. First, the bill allows for indexation of past investments. Investors deserve no belated gift. And giving a tax break on past investment does nothing to spur future investment. Second, the committee would index nearly all assets. This is ill advised. Indexation of corporate equity is justified. Indexation of real estate, which is already tax-advantaged, is not.
Restore I.R.A.'s. Recent research shows that tax-deductible Individual Retirement Accounts boosted the nation's savings rate. This is one tax shelter that is worth resurrecting, as Senator Lloyd Bentsen has proposed. But the House committee rejected the idea.
Ease taxation of dividends. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady recently recommended reducing the tax on corporate dividends. Currently, when firms borrow, they can deduct the interest. But they pay tax on dividends to shareholders. This inequality encourages excessive borrowing. To correct it by making all dividends exempt from taxation would mean an intolerable revenue loss. That's why Mr. Brady wants only a partial exemption. But Professor Lawrence Summers of Harvard has a better way to limit the cost: exempt only dividends on new issues of stock.
Repeal Section 89. Pressure from small business forced the committee to gut Section 89 of the tax code. This law says that if a company offers tax-free health plans to well-paid employees, it must offer comparable plans to lower-paid workers. Section 89 is notoriously complex and unworkable, and eviscerating it would be a blessing - but only if Congress then aims at the right target: setting a limit on how lavish any health plan can be and still be tax-exempt.
The Ways and Means Committee acted recklessly yesterday. That puts heavy responsibility on the House leadership to defeat the bill on the floor. If that fails, then the Senate becomes the last line of defense against a shameless effort to reward the rich and pervert the tax code.

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
Sssh! And Scram! A Library Fights The Homeless

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT

DATELINE: MORRISTOWN, N.J.

 BODY:
At the front desk of the public library, there is a spiral notebook for patrons to jot down comments. Usually, people write to complain about things like dim reading lights or not enough books on rock climbing.
Over the last several months, though, a different kind of concern has crept into the book. Most are unsigned. Here are a few: ''Please do not allow bums to sit here all day long.'' 
''This is not a bus terminal or a homeless shelter or a sanitarium.''
''These bums sitting near the books make me nervous.''
''I'm going around Robin Hood's bend trying to avoid with displeasure these smelly people who don't even pay taxes.''
In this prosperous suburb 35 miles west of New York City, the growing ranks of homeless people have stepped into the public eye from their unseen shelters in wooded areas, abandoned cars and shopping-mall parking lots. And a lot of people do not like what they see. ''It's brought out a lot of emotions that haven't been vented,'' said Eunice Jadlocki, director of a soup kitchen in St. Peter's Episcopal Church, across the street from the library.
About 20 homeless men and women usually wait in the library until the soup kitchen opens for lunch at noon. Many sit quietly and read.
Even so, some librarygoers complain, they sometimes stare at people or just smell awful. ''The haves don't want to look at the have-nots,'' said Richard Kreimer, a 40-year-old homeless man who grew up in this town of 17,000 people. Mr. Kreimer has been ordered to leave the library on several occasions because of his body odor and disheveled appearance.
Dressing well is not an immediate concern of the homeless, said Anne Hartman, a real-estate agent who is past president of the soup kitchen board. Most worry more about their next meal and a place to sleep than a bath or change of clothes.
''It's a very hard problem,'' the library director, Barbara Rice, said. ''We want to serve everyone in the community. But we're not social workers.''
This year the library banned ''unnecessary staring'' and required patrons to have dress and personal hygiene that conformed to the ''standard of the community for public places.''
The American Civil Liberties Union in Newark, fearing the regulations might discriminate against homeless people, intervened on Mr. Kreimer's behalf.
In July, the library modified its policy, prohibiting staring with the ''intent to annoy'' another person and offensive hygiene when it was a ''nuisance.''
''Morristown is a quiet middle-class community that, until recently, has been insulated from the problems of homelessness,'' said Elizabeth J. Miller, a lawyer for the A.C.L.U. in Newark who is representing Mr. Kreimer.
Add Morristown to the list of hundreds of other suburban towns and villages in the New York metropolitan region struggling to deal with homelessness and its causes - alcoholism, mental illness, soaring housing prices.
In this town, the library offers the most public glimpse of the community's ambivalance in addressing the problem. It is a problem that is growing worse.
The soup kitchen at St. Peter's served 17,100 meals last year, compared to 11,166 in 1986. Two years ago, the Morris Shelter moved, to a 45-bed site from a 14-bed site, to meet the demand from homeless men and women and their families across the county.
About 30 percent of the people at the shelter have jobs, but cannot afford to rent, at $700 a month and up, or buy, $200,000 and up, a place to live.
Many are the sons and daughters of county residents caught in a housing squeeze caused in part by economic growth. Lawyers and doctors' offices occupy many older houses. ''Homeless people don't have a chance,'' said Deborah Smith, 32, a mother of three who grew up in nearby Dover and stayed at the Morris Shelter for five months recently, until she found a house she could afford to rent.
Morristown, as the county seat and most urban place in Morris, also attracts a large number of troubled people.
Besides the soup kitchen and shelter, there are a state mental hospital, a county jail, drug-rehabilitation centers and a shelter for teen-age girls.
''We're torn,'' Mayor David V. Manahan said, ''between being a good neighbor and being taken advantage of.''

SECTION: Section B; Page 6, Column 3; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 487 words

HEADLINE: Professor Solomon Fabricant, 83, New York University Economist

BYLINE: By ALFONSO A. NARVAEZ

 BODY:
Solomon Fabricant, an educator and economist, and his wife, Bessie, died in an automobile accident Wednesday near Katonah, N.Y. Dr. Fabricant was 83 years old, and his wife was 82. They lived in South Salem, N.Y.
Dr. Fabricant was a professor emeritus of economics at New York University, where he had taught since 1946. He was also director emeritus of the National Bureau of Economics Research, where he was associated with Dr. Arthur F. Burns, President Dwight D. Eisenhower's chief economic adviser. 
Dr. Fabricant did extensive research on productivity and economic growth and was considered the foremost authority on what constitutes a recession. He was also a prolific writer on topics like productivity, economic principles, economic growth, war and defense economics and income and philanthropy.
''He was a great research leader during his entire career,'' said Dr. Geoffry Moore, director of the Center for International Business Cycle Research at Columbia University. ''He helped guide the research activities of several generations of economists.''
 
Joined University in 1946
Dr. Fabricant was born in Brooklyn on Aug. 15, 1906. He received bachelor's degrees from New York University and City College, a master's degree from Columbia in 1930 and a Ph.D. in economics from Columbia in 1938. He worked as an accountant from 1925 to 1929 and then joined the National Bureau of Economic Research. He was with the bureau from 1930 to 1972, serving as director of research from 1953 to 1965.
He joined the faculty at New York University's Graduate School of Business in 1946 as a lecturer, became an associate professor in 1947 and full professor from in 1948. He was named professor emeritus in 1973.
Over the years, he served as a consultant and a member of many governmental boards, including the Bureau of the Census, the New York State Tax Commission, National Security Resources Board, Office of Science and Technology, National Commission on Productivity and the President's Task Force on Science Policy.
Among the books he wrote are: ''Captial Consumption and Adjustment'' (1938); ''Economic Progress and Economic Change'' (1954); ''Primer on Productivity'' (1969), and ''Productivity Growth: Purpose, Process, Prospects and Policy'' (1978).
He was a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, the American Association for the Advancement of Science and the American Statistical Association. He was also vice president of the American Economic Association and was a trustee of the Economic History Association.
The Fabricants are survived by two daughters, Ruth Lowell and Sarah Corbin, and a son, Peter, all of Manhattan, and one grandchild.
Dr. Fabricant is survived by a brother, Arthur, of Boynton Beach, Fla., and Mrs. Fabricant is survived by three brothers, Jack and Martin Blacksin, both of Washington, and Murray Blacksin, and a sister, Ruth Matloff, both of Brooklyn.

TYPE: Obituary

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (97%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (97%); FLORIDA, USA (79%); 

CITY: NEW YORK, NY, USA (92%);

HEADLINE: Arts Endowment Official to Run Met Opera

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL

 BODY:
The Metropolitan Opera announced yesterday that Hugh Southern, the acting chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts and the man who brought the half-priced TKTS booth to Duffy Square, would become its new general manager.
Mr. Southern, a 57-year-old British citizen who has been a United States resident since 1956, will succeed Bruce Crawford, who resigned in November to become chairman of the Omnicom Group, an advertising agency. Mr. Crawford remained at the Met until April 1; Mr. Southern will assume the position on Nov. 1.
His appointment as the Met's chief administrative officer will not directly affect the responsibilities and prerogatives of James Levine, who remains the company's artistic director but who will naturally work closely with Mr. Southern in shaping Met policy.
The new general manager's background is in arts administration with an emphasis on theater and audience development, rather than on artistic creation or decision-making. He was a management associate of the San Francisco Opera in the mid-1960's and was acting manager of its touring Western Opera Theater. 
 
Role in New York City
But he is best known for his role at the National Endowment, where he has overseen that agency's programs as its No. 2 executive since 1982. For 14 years before that Mr. Southern was the executive director of the Theater Development Fund, a New York organization originally intended to encourage the production of quality plays on Broadway and off. Its most visible function, however, is its program, at the TKTS booths and through other means, of providing reduced-priced tickets to theatrical and dance events. On Broadway alone, the fund's ticket sales now account for 12 percent of revenues and 18 percent of attendance.
Mr. Southern was selected for the Met job after a 10-month search. Mrs. Gilbert W. Humphrey, president and chief executive officer of the Met and head of the search committee, said 420 candidates were considered.
''I am thrilled about the appointment,'' Mrs. Humphrey said yesterday. ''Of all the candidates, Hugh Southern was the one who everybody said was the most diplomatic and good with people.''
Asked about Mr. Southern's relative lack of operatic qualifications, Mrs. Humphrey said: ''That did concern us. But with all the candidates, we put down the pluses and the minuses in columns, and we felt that his attributes outweighed his liabilities - his administrative experience, his way of getting along with people, his relation with the board and his ability to help with fund-raising.''
 
'My Primary Qualification'
She added, ''He's had to use his diplomacy with all this 'gafuffel' with Senator Helms.'' Mr. Southern has been had a calming role in conferences with members of the Senate and House during the recent debate over Senator Jesse Helms's effort to restrict Federal money for art deemed ''obscene or indecent.''
Mr. Southern agreed. ''I don't think my primary qualification for the position is a knowledge of opera,'' he said. ''But I do bring a sensitivity to artistic matters and certain managerial skills.'' He added that he had been ''an enthusiastic amateur member of the opera audience for a long time,'' and had been active in the deliberations of the opera-musical theater program of the endowment.
A key consideration in the search was finding a candidate with ample arts-administration experience who would nonetheless work well with Mr. Levine. It was felt that the conductor's role in defining artistic policy would compensate for Mr. Southern's operatic inexperience.
''I've had only one meeting with him, so it would be premature to try to spell out our responsibilities,'' Mr. Levine said yesterday, in between rehearsals for Gershwin's ''Porgy and Bess'' and Puccini's ''Trittico.'' ''But when I met the man, I felt confident I could work with him.''
Mr. Levine added that he was consulted throughout the search process by the board committee. #2 Special Interests Mr. Southern reported a cordial first impression of Mr. Levine: ''We've met and we've talked, and I'd say there are very good omens for a collaborative, constructive relationship.'' He said he had not met with Joseph Volpe and Marilyn Shapiro, the Met's two assistant general managers, but would next week.
While Mr. Southern said it was premature to discuss his long-range plans for the Met, he has long been interested in theatrical innovation and - through his work with the Theater Development Fund - the opening of fine arts to wider audiences.
Yesterday he said he considered it his mandate to insure that ''this remarkable, unique institution will continue to make the kind of cultural contribution it has throughout its history.''
''But,'' he added, ''I do think it important that the Met use its prestige and position to exert and express leadership in the operatic world.''
He said he was a strong supporter of an innovative ancillary company, or ''mini-Met'' (the Met is planning three seasons of venturesome fare at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Majestic Theater starting in 1991). But he doubtd the economic feasibility of new opera in as large and expensive a theater as the 4,000-seat Metropolitan Opera House.
 
A Trend at the Met
The appointment of Mr. Southern continues a trend in the selection of recent Met general managers away from the professional opera administrator typified by Sir Rudolf Bing and toward people with close connections to the board and to sources of money.
Mr. Southern's immediate predecessors, Mr. Crawford and Anthony A. Bliss, both came from the inner circles of the board. Thus as general managers, they were a direct link to the board of what has long been the performing arts institution with the largest budget in the United States. The Met's projected budget this season is between $90 million and $100 million.
By picking a general manager with strong ties to public arts support -Mr. Southern also had two temporary jobs with the New York State Council on the Arts in the 1970's and was on the Mayor's Committee for Cultural Policy for New York - the Met board has continued its new policy of tapping people with strong managerial and fund-raising connections.
Mr. Crawford is expected to continue to have a leading role at the Met. He remains a member of the board's executive committee and chairman of its finance committee. And his belated joining of the search committee early ths summer appears to have galvanized its energies.
Mr. Southern was born in 1932 in Newcastle-on-Tyne, England, and graduated from Cambridge University, where he directed plays. His mother was stage manager of London's Lyric Theater Hammersmith in the 1920's. He is married to Kathy L. Dwyer, deputy executive director for programs and policy at the American Association of Museums in Washington.
In assuming his post at the Met, Mr. Southern will receive a considerable raise. His salary at the endowment is $78,500. While the Met has declined to reveal its executive salaries, it has not denied reports that Mr. Crawford's salary was close to $300,000.

HEADLINE: G.M. Idles Plant in Atlanta And Stirs U.A.W.'s Anger

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 14

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation said today that it was idling its Lakewood assembly plant in Atlanta, prompting an angry charge of hypocrisy by the United Automobile Workers' new executive in charge of relations with G.M.
The No. 1 auto maker, which has been saddled with too much plant capacity throughout the 1980's for the number of vehicles it has been selling, said it did not have a vehicle program to replace the current production at Lakewood of Chevrolet Caprices and Buick Estate Wagons, which will cease in March.
G.M. said 2,200 salaried and hourly workers are currently employed at the plant, although about 1,000 already are on temporary layoff.
A Buick spokesman, meanwhile, declined to comment on the future of the Estate Wagon. The Chevrolet Caprice is also built in G.M.'s assembly plant in Arlington, Tex., but both vehicles might be built at Arlington as part of a new generation of rear-wheel-drive full-size cars. 
The union's angry blast came from Stephen P. Yokich, U.A.W. vice president, who assumed his current post two months ago. His anger was an indication of a worsening climate of labor relations between the company and the union. Moreover, Mr. Yokich said some ''cooperative programs'' between G.M. managers and hourly workers were not working well.
 
Cooperative Programs
Mr. Yokich replaced Donald Ephlin, who was an outspoken proponent of the auto maker's cooperative programs, which sought to formalize worker involvement in management issues like quality and productivity improvements. Mr. Ephlin's criticism of recent G.M. plant closings had been somewhat muted; many G.M. managers and executives have been saying they are anxious to find out if Mr. Yokich is as enthusiastic about cooperative programs as Mr. Ephlin was.
''We are tired of the hypocrisy of congratulating workers for a job well done and rewarding them with layoffs,'' Mr. Yokich said in a statement, noting that the G.M. announcement had praised Lakewood workers for 60 years of ''building fine products.''
Technically, the Lakewood plant could be reopened at some future date if General Motors decided to locate a vehicle program there, a company spokesman said. But Lakewood is the fourth G.M. assembly plant to be idled since ratification of the 1987 labor agreement with the U.A.W. that barred permanent plant shutdowns. The other idled plants are in Leeds, Mo.; Pontiac, Mich., and Framingham, Mass., and G.M. unofficially acknowledges it is unlikely they all will reopen.
Under the terms of the 1987 agreement, G.M. was permitted to idle plants if it was forced to do so by falling sales. But Mr. Yokich said, ''G.M. management is not trying nearly hard enough to fulfill its obligations under the national agreement and to source offshore production back into domestic plants if necessary to maintain employment here.''
 
'Short-Sighted Decisions'
Mr. Yokich also said G.M. senior management ''continues to make short-sighted decisions that shatter morale and suggest that the near-term bottom line is still what matters most'' at G.M. headquarters.
''There's still time for G.M. to demonstrate that it truly wants a new relationship with the union and union workers,'' he added, ''but episodes like this aren't helping at all.''
G.M. said both hourly and salaried workers would be eligible for a variety of unemployment benefits, but a U.A.W. spokesman said some of the benefit programs do not have much money left in them because of the number of layoffs at G.M. in the last two years.

HEADLINE: 'Junk' Market Nervous As Selling Continues

BYLINE: By ANISE C. WALLACE

 BODY:
In an attempt to ease the fear and uncertainty that has gripped the ''junk bond'' market in recent days, Goldman, Sachs & Company yesterday told its institutional customers that the investment firm stood ready to provide trading liquidity and buy junk bonds ''across the board.''
The statement was similar to one it made on Oct. 20, 1987, the day after the stock market crash.
Nevertheless, prices for the high-risk, high-yield bonds drifted lower during the day, market participants said. An official of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. said the average issue declined $15 per $1,000 of face value. 
Traders said the unsettled conditions could last for several weeks or even months. More than $10 billion in new issues are slated to be sold in the coming months, officials at First Boston said. But at the same time traders and portfolio managers are bracing for more forced selling by savings and loan associations, mutual funds and Wall Street firms that have accumulated large inventories of junk bonds and want to limit their losses.
''It's pretty ugly out there,'' said Zane E. Brown, executive vice president of Equitable Capital Management, a subsidiary of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, which has $1.9 billion invested in junk bonds. ''I'm not sure it's prudent to spend your cash today.''
During the day, the RJR Holdings issue lost $12.50 per $1,000 valuation while Macy's bonds declined $7.50, dealers said.
Late yesterday afternoon, however, investors bought $300 million of notes offered by the Johnson Coca-Cola Bottling Company. Portfolio managers said the issue was picked up because the company has unusually strong cash flow even though it carries a junk bond rating. [D12.] Many professional and individual investors appeared to agree with Mr. Brown's assessment of the junk bond market. Yesterday, Fidelity Investments in Boston reported it had received almost 1,000 telephone calls from nervous holders of its $1.8 billion High Income Mutual Fund. Investors switched more than $16 million out of the fund, almost triple the average daily amount of money that moves into or out of the fund, said Neal Litvack, vice president of marketing for the mutual fund company.
 
A Structural Shift
While many traders and analysts acknowledge that the supply-and-demand characteristics of the junk market are undergoing a significant structural shift - the supply of new bonds from companies like the Bibb Company and Petrolane Inc. is increasing while demand for bonds from regular buyers is contracting -few are willing to say that this is the end of the junk market.
''I think the junk market is a legitimate part of capital markets,'' said Michael F. Holland, president of Salomon Brothers Asset Management. ''But it will be less of a factor in financing takeovers.''
Some analysts say stock prices -which have often risen on takeover speculation - could be hurt by the weakness in the junk bond market. As a result of this fear, stocks of rumored takeover targets like Woolworth and Armstrong World Industries fell sharply yesterday.
''The hot-money takeover game is over,'' said Michael Metz, an investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Company. ''The whole network is being disassembled.'' He said that takeovers would continue but that acquirers would use cash or stock instead of junk bonds to finance deals.
If merger and acquisition activity declined, the implications could be serious for many Wall Street brokerage firms. Almost one-third of their profits in recent years have come from acquisition-related fees, said Michael L. Goldstein, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company in New York.
 
'Tip of the Iceberg'
Moreover, the weakness in the junk market could hurt the Wall Street firms' trading desks. The firms that make secondary markets in junk bonds typically hold approximately $200 million of bonds as inventory, Mr. Goldstein estimated. Those bonds have been falling in value almost all year, he said, so several firms could have large trading losses. ''We might be at the tip of the iceberg,'' he said.
On Wednesday, Merrill Lynch & Company denied that it had suffered large trading losses in junk bonds.
Even though Wall Street firms have abandoned certain markets in recent years, Mr. Goldstein said he would be surprised if any of these firms decided to halt their junk bond operations. The practice is too closely connected to the profitable merger and acquisitions business.
Despite recent defaults on junk bonds, Michael Milken, the former Drexel executive who is credited with developing the junk market, said yesterday that there was still ''tremendous opportunity'' for high-yield securities. The Associated Press reported that Mr. Milken, speaking to an investment group in New York, urged investors and traders to evaluate securities on a company-by-company basis, because not all companies in a given industry would fare badly in a recession.
 
More Difficulties Are Seen
Still, several professional investors said the junk bond market was likely to experience more difficulties as large investors try to sell their holdings and other highly leveraged companies find themselves unable to make their debt payments. They said large investors like savings and loans and mutual funds could drive down prices of actively traded issues like RJR Holdings, Duracell, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich and Safeway if they needed to raise cash quickly.
''I'm worried about the junk market,'' said Peter Nadosy, a managing director of Morgan Stanley & Company and portfolio manager in its investment management division. ''I think it's cracking up.''
Mr. Nadosy and others noted that the problems encountered by companies like Campeau, Seaman Furniture and Resorts International were being reported during good economic times.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
How Has Bush Done So Far?

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
THE Bush Administration this month released a report on its ''initiatives and accomplishments.'' So far, how does its record stack up?
The economic expansion is still rolling, but at a slower pace. The recovery that began under President Reagan, after the deep 1981-82 recession, is now in its 82d month. The Bush Administration intends to keep the expansion going indefinitely; it has warned the Federal Reserve not to raise interest rates, lest tight money produce a recession. 
The White House says consumer price inflation has ''remained under 5 percent for the past seven years.'' But the inflation rate has oscillated. After averaging 3.8 percent from 1982 through 1985, it fell to 1.1 percent in 1986, and then rose to 4.4 percent in 1987 and 1988. The Consumer Price Index rose at a 6.4 percent rate in the first half of 1989, but most economists expect it to average just a little above 5 percent for the entire year as economic growth slows.
The President's budget strategy is to approach balance gradually by restraining spending growth and not raising taxes. Mr. Bush is determined to cut the capital gains tax to stimulate savings and investment. Yesterday, the House Ways and Means Committee approved a cut despite strong Democratic opposition.
Mr. Bush's white paper hails the April 14 agreement with Congress to meet the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings deficit target of $100 billion for the fiscal year 1990, ''with no new taxes.''
The 1989 budget year will wind up with a $161 billion deficit, $25 billion beyond the $136 billion target, according to estimates of the Congressional Budget Office. That office forecasts that the ''baseline'' budget deficit, if present policies continue, will be $141 billion in 1990, well above the $100 billion Gramm-Rudman target. And it projects a budget deficit higher than $140 billion every year through 1993, even without ''off-budget'' measures.
The Administration has shallow pockets, and looks for others to spend or lend money for programs it wants. The President's ''strong support'' for Poland and Hungary, as they move toward ''pluralism, democracy and market economic policies,'' calls for $115 million for Poland and $25 million for Hungary. His war on drugs seeks an extra $176 million, to bring 1990 up to $7.9 billion; his goal is to halve the supply of illegal drugs in 10 years.
On Aug. 9 Mr. Bush signed the Financial Institution Reform, Recovery and Enforcement Act of 1989, to rescue the failed or failing savings and loans; it is expected to cost taxpayers at least $100 billion, and possibly double or triple that amount. The White House says ''the President's plan'' calls for ''tough standards to help insure such a crisis never happens again.''
L. William Seidman, head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, who is gearing up for a $300 billion auction of ailing savings institutions, said, ''My guess is that between 30 and 50 percent of the failures are directly due to fraud, insider abuse, or just plain mismanagement - but these factors probably contributed to the demise of over 75 percent of the failed institutions.''
Other financial debacles may lie ahead. The Federal Housing Administration insurance fund, which covers $277 billion worth of mortgages, has only $1.2 billion in reserves. The F.H.A. is losing well over $1 million a day - it lost more than $450 million in 1988 - and its next audit is expected to show greater losses this year.
Legislation before the House and Senate to lower the down payment home buyers must pay to qualify for F.H.A. insurance and raise the maximum size of an F.H.A.-insured loan would exacerbate risks of another financial disaster.
With feeble resistance from the Bush Administration, the dollar has risen more than 20 percent against foreign currencies since the start of the year; this may worsen the trade deficit.
The Bush Administration is already very hard up when it comes to making loans or grants overseas. Under the so-called Brady plan, it has ''taken the lead in encouraging commercial banks to reduce the debt and debt service burdens of developing countries,'' and urged the International Monetary Fund and World Bank to do the same.
Agreement has been reached between Mexico and the commercial banks, proving, the White House says, that the Brady plan is ''viable.'' But tougher cases lie ahead in Brazil, Argentina, Peru and other developing countries.
The President has vetoed what he considered an excessive increase in the minimum wage by Congress. He has initiated a program to phase out steel import quotas over two and a half years, announced additional deficiency payments of 10 percent to producers of wheat, feed grains, rice and upland cotton, and directed the Secretary of Energy to develop a ''comprehensive energy strategy for the nation.''
No slogan has yet been attached to the overall Bush program. Its new paper on accomplishments carries Mr. Bush's ''kinder, gentler America'' over from the campaign, but a White House spokesman cautioned, in an interview, that this phrase applies only to domestic affairs like child care and aid to the homeless, not to military and foreign policy.

HEADLINE: Mosbacher in Japan: Little Progress Seen

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 14

 BODY:
Secretary of Commerce Robert A. Mosbacher, ending a three-day trip to Japan today, made little apparent progress on trade questions. He left many Japanese and Americans here wondering about the Bush Administration's goals.
During his visit, Mr. Mosbacher met with Japan's new Prime Minister, Toshiki Kaifu, as well as a number of Cabinet ministers and business leaders who were taking the measure of the Commerce Secretary for the first time.
In this visit, largely ceremonial, Mr. Mosbacher struck two themes: the need for agreements that will start a flow of Japanese technology to the United States, and the need for structural change in the Japanese economy to reduce prices and spur consumer demand for imports. 
 
One Agreement
Mr. Mosbacher did reach one agreement, to extend a cooperative research pact between the United States and the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation in semiconductors, telecommunications, computers and computer networking and time and frequency measurements. The accord, first signed in 1984, was only slightly enlarged.
But Mr. Mosbacher got off to a bad start when, while visiting South Korea, he declared that the Korean market was more open than Japan's. Few foreigners in the business community agree with that view because of Korea's outright ban on many types of imports.
In Tokyo, where many American business executives waited to hear about specific goals and more sophisticated strategies to open Japan's markets, Mr. Mosbacher said little about either, at least in public.
 
Carrot and Stick
Instead, he said the United States would ''balance the carrot and the stick'' and declared himself a ''bottom line kind of guy'' who left the ''esoterics'' of curing America's $50 billion-a-year deficit to others.
''I feel like we are back eight years to the start of the Reagan Administration,'' said the top official of a major American corporation's Japan subsidiary after Mr. Mosbacher gave an off-the-record speech to the American Chamber of Commerce in Japan. ''We keep changing teams and bringing them up to speed, and the Japanese keep the veterans around. Another executive, from a major computer concern involved in disputes with Japan, said after the speech, ''We were waiting for a real plan of action, and it never came.''
Meanwhile, Mr. Mosbacher and his staff appeared to be backpedaling on American plans to rush into high-definition television research. Although he originally supported a major initiative, Mr. Mosbacher said here this week that while ''HDTV is important, you can't look at it in a void,'' and added that its role in other technologies, from digital switching to fiber optics, needed study. He said the United States had time because ''HDTV won't be used until the U.S. market is ready to accept it.''
Japan seems to take the opposite view. It has already spent $900 million or more in research and has begun experimental broadcasts of HDTV signals for an hour or so a day. Japan hopes to begin regular broadcasts in a few years, and today NHK, Japan's Government network, said it had licensed Texas Instruments to make semiconductors for HDTV receivers, mostly in Japan.
 
Disagrees With Verity
Mr. Mosbacher said little about some recurring irritants in trade relations. But he expressed clear disagreement with his predecessor, C. William Verity Jr., who said on a visit to Japan last fall that American construction companies were not putting enough effort or money into cracking the Japanese market. ''We don't agree with Verity's perception,'' Mr. Mosbacher said, complaining that American companies have still landed few contracts.
Mr. Mosbacher also became entangled in one of Japan's thorniest debates: whether the high prices here give American companies a chance to compete.
''The cost of doing business in Japan does ultimately constitute a trade barrier,'' Mr. Mosbacher said.
Sounding a theme from the newly started ''structural initiative'' talks to eliminate fundamental trade barriers, Mr. Mosbacher pressed Japan to allow ''Japanese consumers to enjoy the same freedom of choice and benefits'' as American consumers do. He complained that Japan paid $600 million more than it should have for domestically made satellites, and that it costs three times as much to buy a Sanyo cordless telephone in Tokyo as it does in New York.
But Mr. Mosbacher said he was ''optimistic'' about the outcome of the current dialogue with Japan on the removal of structural impediments to trade. ''My idea of measurable progress,'' he said, ''is something I can show to Congress.''

HEADLINE: Bank Profits at Record High

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
Commercial banks reported their most profitable six months ever in the first half of the year, the Government said Wednesday.
Although profits of $7 billion in the second quarter at 12,944 commercial banks were down from the record $7.3 billion earned in the first quarter, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation reported that the $14.3 billion total in the first half was more than in any previous six-month period. 
''I think the industry has a chance to beat last year's all-time record earnings,'' the F.D.I.C. chairman, L. William Seidman, said at a briefing. Banks posted profits of $25.1 billion in 1988. But he said the year's earnings figures could be affected adversely by troubles involving third world debtor nations, real estate loans or the direction of the economy.
Second-quarter 1989 profits rose in 39 states, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico and declined in 11 states, John J. Quinn 3d, senior banking analyst for the F.D.I.C., said.
Connecticut, Massachusetts, New York and Rhode Island all reported declines in earnings in the second quarter, and the Northeast was the only region to show a year-to-year increase in the proportion of banks losing money, the F.D.I.C. report said.

HEADLINE: A Milestone for Labor But No Silver Lining

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
The pending takeover of the UAL Corporation by a group including its pilots' union and its management is a coup for the labor movement. But experts on employee-owned companies say that difficulties even more trying than winning control of the company may lie ahead.
These experts predicted that conflicts and problems would come not only at the management level, where executives and union leaders would have to work together, but at lower levels, where attempts would be made to motivate workers to improve productivity and involve them more in running the company.
But the experts also said that employees who own a company could look at problems more as management does. 
 
Machinists' Position
Another big challenge for the management and pilots of UAL, the parent of United Airlines, would be how to handle the 20,000-plus members of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers at the airline, who have so far refused to participate in the buyout.
Louis R. Schroeder, the president of District 141 of the machinists' union, had urged the UAL board to reject the pilot-management offer because it ''jeopardizes the livelihoods of the work force and the long-term viability of the carrier.''
If the buyout is approved by shareholders and regulators, the employees at United who participate in the deal would end up owning 75 percent of the company. To translate that sense of ownership into higher productivity has often proved to be a painstaking task that leads to only small results, said Peter Cappelli, an expert on labor relations in the airline industry.
 
Risks Seen for Unions
Mr. Cappelli, a professor of management at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School, also warned that there were risks for the unions, whose role would be redefined.
''They can't continue to act as adversaries of management as in the past,'' he added. ''The long-range question for the union is: why would its members want to continue to have it around?''
Under the contract to which the pilots agreed as part of the $6.75 billion takeover deal, the union, the Air Line Pilots Association, has agreed to huge changes in its relationship with management.
That management would be made up mostly of UAL executives like Stephen M. Wolf, the current chairman, who would be president, and John C. Pope, who would remain the chief financial officer.
 
No Strike for 7 Years
The pilots have promised to give up their ultimate weapon, the strike, for the duration of a seven-year contract, whose length is itself unusual in American industry. The 6,100 pilots at United would also be committed to resolve disputes with the company through binding arbitration.
Layoffs would also be on hold for seven years. So if a recession were to hurt the industry, United might find it difficult to cut back to ride out hard times. On the other hand, the pilots have agreed to a 10 percent cut in pay and cuts in other benefits.
Some analysts said it would make little sense for the pilots to strike because they would in effect be striking against themselves.
The pilots have also promised to cross the lines of other unions, including the machinists, who could continue to play their historical adversarial role.
 
Seemingly Strange Position
The pilots' and the machinists' unions have been rivals, having fought bitterly in the courts for the three years it took the pilots to get to the stage of board approval of the deal. The machinists' leaders have said that the added debt would weaken the airline and that its members had no interest in becoming owners.
Thus the new company could find itself in the strange position of having the pilots, and possibly even the flight attendants as well, becoming owners, while the machinists could end up even more alienated.
To persuade UAL's independent directors to support the bid and to assure that management would not be just a creature of the unions, the pilots' union agreed to a 15-member board on which eight members, a majority, would be independent.
These members are expected to be business people and professors and may also be drawn from government.
The pilots would be able to elect at least one of their leaders to the board - expected to be F. C. (Rick) Dubinsky, the chairman of the Master Executive Council, the governing body of the Air Line Pilots Association at United.
Joseph Blasi, whose specialty has been labor relations at employee-owned companies, said that only when ownership is combined with committees made up of workers and management can productivity be increased.
''It will be hard, but Stephen Wolf must come forward with detailed plans to radically increase employee involvement,'' he said.
Mr. Blasi, a professor of management and labor relations at Rutgers who has acted as a consultant for the pilots' union, said the union and Mr. Wolf had already run into differences on how labor-management committees would function at United.
Setting up the structure for joint cooperation has also often proved simpler than persuading workers and middle managers to participate.
 
The Experience of Avis
Joseph V. Vittoria, chairman and chief executive of Avis Inc., which has been owned by its employees under an employee stock ownership plan for two years, said that one of the most exhausting parts of his job has been to travel to the widely scattered stations of Avis and explain to employees how they can participate in managing the company.
Mr. Vittoria has attended hundreds of meetings with small groups of employees and said he has had many instances of success. He recalled that one shop steward, an 18-year union employee, went back to his work area and began to tell workers that certain slack practices would no longer be tolerated.
Mr. Vittoria said the shop steward told them, ''Either get up to speed or you're gone.''

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Major 'Junk Bond' Sells Quickly

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The high-yield ''junk bond'' market, reeling from financial problems at a broad range of companies, got something of a boost late yesterday, when Salomon Brothers successfully priced a $300 million issue for a major Coca-Cola bottler.
The issue from the Johnston Coca-Cola Bottling Group Inc. in Tennessee was so strongly in demand that underwriters had firm commitments for the $300 million before it was priced.
''It just shows that deals for high-quality names can still get done,'' one investment banker close to the transaction said.
That view was reiterated by portfolio managers, who said that despite the deterioration in the financial health of other junk bond-issuing companies like the Southland Corporation, Lomas & Nettleton and retailers like Federated Stores and Allied Stores, a large part of the market remained healthy. 
 
Demand for High-Quality Names
''There is still a lot of demand for high-quality names because they are selling at yield spreads of between 4 percentage points and 4.5 percentage points above 10-year Treasuries,'' said Mark Vaselkiv, a vice president at the $1.15 billion T. Rowe Price High-Yield Fund. ''We haven't begun to see any deterioration in credit quality or cash flow in these types of issues.''
Still, prices of secondary high-yield issues continued to slide yesterday, if not so sharply as on Wednesday.
By late in the day, prices of most high-yield issues were down by about 1/2 point. And while a degree of calm returned to a market jolted on Wednesday by the severity of the problems confronting the Campeau Corporation, the parent of Federated and Allied, deep concerns remain.
''It may be foolhardy to dismiss the possibility of more Campeau-like incidents, even if the economy averts recession and instead enjoys a disinflationary soft landing,'' said John Lonski, a senior economist at Moody's Investors Service.
''But until the still considerable threat of recession has passed, the performance of high-yield bonds may be hindered by one of the most crippling forms of uncertainty - fear of the unknown.''
 
Retail Sales Report Cheered
A report suggesting the economy may indeed have moved to a slower, less-inflationary rate of growth cheered participants in the market for Treasury securities, where prices of notes and bonds rose.
A burst of buying in the Treasury markets followed the release of retail sales figures for August that were being interpreted as showing some signs of weakness.
Over all, the sales figures, aided by robust auto purchases, rose by seven-tenths of a percentage point. But the gains once those sales were factored out were a much more modest two-tenths of a percentage point. And gains recorded for July were revised downward.
The figures prompted buying that was later tempered by the Federal Reserve Board, which drained reserves from the banking system around midday. The sales of Government securities by the Fed came as the open-market rate for overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market was trading at 8 7/8 percent.
 
Long-Term Bond at 8.11%
In late trading, the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 100 3/32, up 7/32, to yield 8.11 percent. The 8 1/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 27/32, up 7/32, to yield 8.03 percent. And the 8 1/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 11/32, up 5/32, to yield 8.05 percent.
Treasury bill rates were mixed. Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.56 percent late yesterday, up seven basis points, or hundredths of a point. Meanwhile, six-month bill rates were unchanged, at a late offered rate of 7.55 percent.
The Johnston Coca-Cola high-yield deal priced late yesterday was a two-part offering consisting of $100 million worth of senior notes and $200 million of subordinated debentures.
The 10 1/4 percent senior notes were priced at par, or $100, and mature Sept. 15, 1999. The 11 3/8 percent subordinated notes were also priced at par, and mature Sept. 15, 2001. The senior notes are rated Ba-2 by Moody's and BBB- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. The subordinated notes carry a B-1 rating from Moody's and a BB+ rating from S.&P.
Elsewhere, activity in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate issues was volatile again yesterday, as prices moved erratically in response to developments in the high-yield and Treasury markets. By late in the day, dealers said that prices of long-term and intermediate securities had moved higher by about 1/8 point. In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, prices dipped by 1/8 point to 1/4 point, according to participants.
Among the new tax-exempt issues priced yesterday was a $200 million issue from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
The issue, which was sold at competitive bid, consisted of two parts. A group led by Paine Webber bought $100 million of the bonds, which are not subject to provisions of the alternative minimum tax. This part of the issue consisted of serial bonds with maturities from 2004 to 2010, and a term bond that matures in 2024.
The serial bonds carry coupons ranging from 7 percent in 2004 to 7.15 percent in 2010. The term bonds were priced to yield 7.25 percent.
A group led by Prudential-Bache Securities bought the second $100 million part, which is subject to alternative minimum tax provisions.
The serial bonds in this part also carry maturities from 2004 to 2010. The issue also includes a term bond maturing in 2024. Coupons on the serial bonds range from 7.25 percent in 2004 to 7.40 percent in 2010. The term bonds carry a coupon of 7.25 percent.
The issue is rated A-1 by Moody's.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Spot Contracts for Copper Surge to a 4 1/2-Month Peak

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Copper for spot delivery on New York's Commodity Exchange surged to a four-and-a-half-month high yesterday as the market ignored news of a settlement of a miners' strike in Chile and focused on continuing supply disruptions in other parts of the world.
Copper futures settled 1.5 cents to 4.9 cents higher, with the spot contract for delivery in September at $1.373 a pound, the highest settlement for a spot copper contract on the Comex since April 28.
The settlement of a two-week-old strike at the Chilean Copper Company's El Salvador mine had been expected and caused little market reaction. The mine, which produces about 100,000 tons of copper annually, is the smallest of six major copper mines worldwide that have suffered recent supply disruptions, and at least three of those remain shut down. 
Others still shut are the Bouganville mine in Papua New Guinea, closed since mid-July by terrorism; Mexico's Cananea mine, which went bankrupt on Aug. 20, and a mine owned by the Highland Valley Copper Company in British Columbia that has been shut down by a strike since July 6.
 
Other Supply Jitters
Weather-related problems at another mine in Papua New Guinea and a recent strike by Zambian copper miners have also contributed to the supply jitters, analysts said.
''There's still about 600,000 tons of capacity shut down and that's a substantial tonnage,'' said Fred Demler, a metals economist in New York with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. ''I think the market realizes that even if all the problems were resolved today, there would still be tightness in refined supply for several months.''
In Chicago, meat and grain futures were bolstered by the announcement of new food aid from the United States to Poland.
President Bush announced a $50 million increase in the aid and Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, proposed a Polish food-aid package that includes 500,000 metric tons of corn, 100,000 metric tons of wheat and 20 million to 30 million pounds of pork.
Energy futures succumbed to a spate of profit taking on the New York Mercantile Exchange. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 12 cents to 15 cents lower, with October at $19.72 a barrel.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rebounds in the U.S.; Gold Prices Are Also Higher

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
After closing lower overseas, the dollar rebounded to finish higher in choppy domestic trading yesterday.
Gold prices rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $360.50 an ounce, up 60 cents from Wednesday. 
Traders said the Bank of Japan entered the market overnight to sell a large amount of dollars, which pushed the dollar lower overseas. Then dealers in Europe moved to trim their dollar holdings ahead of today's release of United States merchandise trade figures for July.
But dealers at home used the impending Commerce Department report as a reason to buy dollars, pushing the currency higher in a seesaw session.
''We don't want to be stuck short of dollars if it's a good number,'' Michael McDonald, a trader at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago, said of the trade deficit figure.
Economists are projecting a trade deficit of $7 billion to $9 billion for July. The Government is also scheduled to release the Producer Price Index for August, a figure that can ultimately influence the dollar.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar closed at 146.85 yen, up from 146.40 yen on Wednesday. And 1 cost $1.5540, cheaper than $1.5585 on Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Wednesday, included: 1.9750 West German marks, up from 1.9725; 1.7040 Swiss francs, up from 1.6990; 6.6605 French francs, up from 6.6525; 1,418.50 Italian lire, up from 1,415.00, and 1.1850 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1841.
Silver prices were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery slipped to $5.055, from $5.067 Wednesday.

HEADLINE: S.E.C. Nominee Says 'Junk Bond' Market Seems Sound

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
President Bush's nominee to head the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that the market for high-yield ''junk bonds'' still seemed sound despite tremors touched off by the cash binds of some debt-laden issuers, most recently the Campeau Corporation.
Richard C. Breeden, the nominee, told senators at his confirmation hearing today that while junk bonds were subject to liquidity risks - their ready marketability might be in question - they so far posed no special danger.
''I'm not suggesting that there is any particular problem in the marketplace today,'' said Mr. Breeden, the White House policy assistant and former Wall Street securities lawyer. 
 
Effects of Savings Rescue
Mr. Breeden added that while the savings-industry rescue legislation, of which he was a main architect, would mean much less investment in junk bonds by savings and loan associations, the insurance companies and others have been entering the market and would take up the slack. Over all, Mr. Breeden contended, liquidity in junk bonds is greater now than it was three or four years ago.
The liquidity risk in junk bonds is in addition to the other two significant categories of risk applying to a greater or lesser degree to nearly all bonds - the market risk of a rise in interest rates and the credit risk that the principal might not be repaid.
But Mr. Breeden's views on various other topics remained largely unexplored because the Senate Banking Committee treated him deferentially and did not ask pointed questions. And despite expectations of the staffs of both the committee and the commission, the President's 39-year-old nominee was not questioned at all about his relative inexperience.
 
Vote Is Expected Soon
No discernible opposition appeared, and after the three-hour session the committee's chairman, Donald W. Riegle Jr., said the panel would vote soon, presumably to recommend confirmation to the full Senate.
An example of the committee's careful treatment of Mr. Breeden came when Senator Riegle, a Michigan Democrat, asked him whether it was true that the securities markets were close to being shut down by the authorities during the 1987 crash. Mr. Breeden responded that he did not know because he was not ''in the loop.'' Mr. Riegle did not ask how Mr. Breeden would approach this subject as S.E.C. chief.
David S. Ruder, the current chairman, came in for heavy criticism two years ago when word circulated that he had discussed, in general terms, a brief trading halt.
 
Advice Sought on Takeovers
Senator Terry Sanford asked Mr. Breeden whether he would be willing to advise Congress on anti-takeover legislation. But the North Carolina Democrat, who has expressed keen interest in the subject after takeovers of RJR Nabisco and Burlington Industries, did not ask whether Mr. Breeden favored such an idea or opposed it.
When Senator Riegle asked Mr. Breeden whether he considered the economy to be overleveraged, the nominee called this a ''complex'' issue that he did not want to address ''with a hip shot.''

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Increased 0.7% in August

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
Retail sales rose a moderate seven-tenths of 1 percent in August because of strong automobile sales, but analysts foresee growing sluggishness in the remainder of the year.
The Commerce Department said today that retail sales increased to a seasonally adjusted $144.3 billion in August after a five-tenths of 1 percent gain in July. Sales had remained flat in June after rising eight-tenths of 1 percent in May. 
Analysts said the report was consistent with the ''soft landing'' scenario sought by the Federal Reserve as it moves to keep inflation under control while permitting continued, but slower, economic growth.
The White House press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, said the August figure was ''an indication of continued but slow growth in the current economic expansion, which is now in its 82d month, so it's good news.''
Auto sales, which represent about 20 percent of retail sales, advanced 2.6 percent last month, driven by end-of-model-year sales incentives and the threat of steep price increases for 1990 models. Those sales had risen 1.7 percent in July.
 
'Outlook Is Poor' for Auto Sales
But Michael K. Evans of Evans Economics Inc., a Washington consulting firm, said the outlook was poor for automobile sales, which slipped in early September. ''Auto sales have peaked,'' he said. ''October will be way down. So total retail sales will be down.''
Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Company, agreed, saying, ''I think we will see a decided weakness in auto spending in the fourth quarter.''
Excluding the automobile category, retail sales edged up only two-tenths of 1 percent in August.
Sales of durable goods, big-ticket items that are expected to last more than three years, rose 2.4 percent on top of an eight-tenths of 1 percent gain in July. On the other hand, sales of nondurable goods fell four-tenths of 1 percent after rising that amount a month earlier.
Among durable goods. building materials advanced 2.2 percent and furniture and other home furnishing sales gained 1.6 percent, reflecting in part, analysts said, both increased home sales and remodeling.
 
Apparel Sales Up
The only advances in the nondurable goods category were apparel sales, up 1.1 percent in part because of back-to-school clothes shopping, and drugstores, up 1.4 percent.
But general merchandise sales, including department stores, did not benefit as much from the back-to-school spending, analysts said, and fell nine-tenths of 1 percent.
Other declines in the nondurable categories included food stores, down two-tenths of 1 percent; service stations, down 1.5 percent, reflecting falling gasoline prices, and restaurants and bars, down 1 percent.
