HEADLINE: Debate Over Drug War Focuses on Financing It

BYLINE: By DAVID ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
The debate between the Bush Administration and Congress over drug policy involves not only how much money to spend and where to spend it but also how to raise the money without breaking the budget agreement reached last spring.
These disagreements over money set off another debate on Capitol Hill today between William J. Bennett, the Federal drug policy director, and members of a House Government Operations subcommittee. After more than a week of relatively tame hearings, today's was clearly the most contentious, with members scolding Mr. Bennett and the drug director firing back at them.
''I think this is the phoniest war that I've ever seen launched,'' Representative Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California, told Mr. Bennett at one point. 
 
'Petty and Micromanagement'
Moments later, Ms. Boxer opened a line of questioning on how best to finance the drug effort. ''If we're critical,'' she said, ''it's because there are some problem areas here that have to be discussed, and I think if it's healthy dialogue and debate today, maybe we can resolve some of the problems.''
''It hasn't been healthy so far,'' Mr. Bennett shot back. ''It has been petty and micromanagement. I don't appreciate it.''
''In this committee, sir, or do you mean generally?'' interjected the committee chairman, John Conyers of Michigan.
Mr. Bennett said he was referring to the questioning of his chief of staff, John Walters, by Representative Glenn English, Democrat of Oklahoma, about using radar planes over Colombia to detect airborne smugglers.
''I'm sorry you feel that way about it, Mr. Bennett,'' Mr. English said.
While the debate went on, lawmakers in both parties held caucuses to figure out how best to work out financing of a drug plan. There was disagreement on both sides, particularly among Democrats, who offered different ideas about how to raise the money, with some favoring specific cuts in other Government programs, others pushing an across-the-board approach and still others wanting new taxes.
 
What Bush Wants
The President has called his proposal a $7.9 billion plan, but that figure is much higher than the amount that would be spent in the next fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1.
The budget agreement for fiscal 1990, which set the outline for lowering the budget deficit to $100 billion, contemplated spending $4.1 billion on drug programs. Since then, President Bush has recommended spending an additional $500 million, and the money must come from somewhere.
The President wants to take it from specific Government programs that have strong support in Congress. They include the Economic Development Administration, juvenile justice and state grants for refugee assistance.
Democrats in the Senate, who must carry the brunt of the debate for the party, want to spend $1.2 billion more than the President recommended and propose that the financing come from lowering spending for nearly all Government programs by a fraction of a percentage point. That would mean a larger reduction at the Pentagon than the Administration has been willing to accept.
The issue is complicated by the distinction between budget authority, also called appropriations, and outlays, or spending.
 
Like Buying a Car
Budget authority is the permission granted a Government agency to make commitments to spend money - for salaries, construction of prisons, police equipment or whatever - and the money may be spent over several years.
Outlays are the actual dollars spent in a particular fiscal year for the specific activities.
Stanley E. Collender, a budget specialist at Price Waterhouse, uses the analogy of the purchase of a $10,000 car with a three-year loan. When the contract is signed to purchase the car, it is comparable to budget authority for the full $10,000. But actual outlays are only the down payment and the monthly payments in the first year, significantly less than $10,000.
One of the reasons budget authority for the drug program is much higher than outlays is that funds for prison construction would be spent over several years.
 
Outlays Are What Matters
While budget authority is more important in the long run because it represents the eventual scope of the drug programs, outlays are all that matters in meeting the deficit target set by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget law and the urgent issue Congress and the President must confront now, barely two weeks before the beginning of the fiscal year.
In his budget message last February, Mr. Bush proposed $6.4 billion in budget authority for drugs and $4.1 billion in outlays. The agreement he reached with Congress in April included these outlays.
In his crime proposals in May he sought additional budget authority of $700 million for drug programs, and in his drug control speech last week, he asked for $716 million more. Those two requests would lead to a total of $500 million in new outlays in the next fiscal year that were not included in the budget agreement. The total budget authority would be $7.9 billion.
The House of Representatives has approved appropriations bills considering the funds for drugs sought in the President's February budget request. That leaves it to the Senate to find the money to accommodate the President's requests made since then.
Many Senate Democrats have argued that the President's proposals are not sufficient to meet the country's drug problem. This week, Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, chairman of the Appropriations Committee, suggested $2.2 billion more than the President wants in budget authority. An analyst at the Congressional Budget Office said the additional outlays under the Byrd proposals would be $1.2 billion.
 
Conciliatory Signal
That amount of money could be raised, Mr. Byrd calculated, by a 0.575 percent across-the-board cut in budget authority in most Government programs. Richard G. Darman, the President's budget director, objected to the Byrd plan, in part because of the cost to the Pentagon.
But Mr. Darman said he could accept a more modest .225 percent cutback proposed by Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina. The Congressional budget analyst said the Hollings plan would raise more than enough to pay for the $500 million in new spending proposed by Mr. Bush but not nearly enough to pay for all Mr. Byrd suggested.
The White House, sending a conciliatory signal to Congressional Democrats, said today it was willing to compromise on the Bush proposal, even if it meant spending more money.
''We have always said from the very beginning that we're willing to be flexible on financing,'' said Marlin Fitzwater, the President's spokesman. ''The best way to do that is to sit down and talk about it.''

HEADLINE: Jets Wonder if Absences Make the Players Grow Softer

BYLINE: By GERALD ESKENAZI, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 14

 BODY:
Barely three weeks after the Jets signed three important veterans for a total of $2.5 million this season, the club will face the Cleveland Browns on Sunday with one missing, one returning from an injury and one out of shape.
Beyond this week, though, runs a deeper current. The front office and Coach Joe Walton wonder what effect the players' summerlong absences had on their physical condition, especially after two of them were hurt on the first passes thrown to them.
Walton barely hides his bitterness over the ankle injury that has sidelined Wesley Walker for at least the next six games. And Walton's best player, Al Toon, missed the season opener and is not completely healed from a shoulder injury. And Johnny Hector, who went through only his second workout today, was so out of shape after reporting on Wednesday that he suffered leg cramps. 
''You've got to write about history,'' said Walton, referring to players who had been locked in long contract disputes, then came back and were injured. ''Look what happened to the Giants last year: Banks, Bavaro, Landeta. Look what happened to the tight end on Minnesota this year, Jordan. We must have training camp for some reason.''
 
'Injuries Speak for Themselves'
Steve Gutman, the club president who signed the three Jets in recent days, today stopped barely short of blaming the absences for the injuries. But he is not ruling that factor out. ''Statistically, the injuries speak for themselves,'' Gutman said. ''Look at what happened to the Giants last year. We've had other players in the past come in late and suffer injuries. So far, two have been injured this year.
''I don't think there's any question that we were disappointed that Wesley and Johnny and Al - and Reggie McElroy, as well - took the way they did. All could have used camp. But you stay with the negotiations until they're successful.''
Walker, the deep-threat wide receiver, missed his first pass in the second quarter against the Patriots last Sunday and twisted an ankle.
 
Toon Moving Well
Toon was injured when he went over the middle for a pass in the final exhibition game at Kansas City, muffed it, fell, and hurt his shoulder when the Chiefs' Kevin Ross landed on him. But Toon was able to move well today, enhancing his chances for a return.
''The way Al was hurt could have happened at any time,'' said the Jets' trainer, Bob Reese. ''But there was a feeling among the coaches that if he was in football condition he would have made the catch. If he made the catch, he might not have fallen.''
''I don't want to talk about the injury,'' Toon said. ''It's a controversial issue and I don't want to create controversy.''
Reese conceded that trying to make a correlation between missing training camp and getting injured is ''all anecdotal, even though you wonder about it.''
''We tend to remember the ones who get hurt,'' he said.
He described Walker's injury as happening ''after he missed the ball, and then relaxed.''
''That's when he got hit,'' Reese said. ''But maybe if his timing had been better, he might have caught the ball and then the injury wouldn't have happened. But scientifically, you can't say cause and effect.''
Walker disputed that the catch had a role in his injury.
''There's people who come to camp on time and get a foot caught, too,'' he said. ''It was just weird.''
In any event, Gutman sounded frustrated today at the turn of events.
''I would have to think the players are smart enough to think training camp is essential to their performance and their career and they gain little or no economic advantage by holding out,'' he said. ''In fact, it cost one player a great deal of money.''
Toon signed for about $1.1 million for this year, while Walker agreed to $770,000 and Hector $650,000. But Hector lost about $40,000 for missing the opening game.
Brian Washington was a Jet for a day, then suddenly quit. The club picked the safety up on Wednesday after he was cut by the Browns. A Jets official said Washington told the club, ''I don't want to play football anymore.'' . . . Jeff Lageman, the No. 1 draft choice, is a likely starter at outside right linebacker because of Tim Cofield's groin injury.

HEADLINE: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

BYLINE: By KATHERINE BISHOP, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HONOLULU, Sept. 13

 BODY:
The use of smokable methamphetamine, which produces a much longer period of euphoria than crack and is followed by a more disturbing psychological reaction, has reached major proportions here and has begun to appear in several cities on the mainland as well.
Experts on substance abuse fear that use of the drug, called ice, could grow to devastating proportions among many of the nation's addicts, especially if efforts are successful to halt the smuggling of cocaine from abroad. The drug can be made cheaply and easily in this country in the same clandestine laboratories that are now used to make speed, the powdered form of methamphetamine, a synthetic stimulant of the nervous system that is a form of amphetamine.
''There is an urgent need to stop the flow of cocaine from overseas, but there are plenty of dangerous drugs that are made in the U.S.A.,'' said Donald Hamilton, a spokesman for William J. Bennett, the Federal drug policy director. ''Experts are warning us that smokable methamphetamine will be the drug plague of the 1990's.'' 
And James N. Hall, the executive director of Up Front Drug Information Center in Miami, a nonprofit research foundation, agreed, saying: ''Drugs from clandestine labs will demand attention because the United States is becoming a big producer of drugs. In the 1990's, most drugs used in America will be made in America.''
At present, most of the smokable crystals of methamphetamine are made in Hong Kong, Korea and the Philippines and smuggled here by Asian drug gangs.
Law-enforcement officials say that ice, which was virtually nonexistent in Hawaii only 18 months ago, has already become its most serious drug-related problem. Arrests in Honolulu for the possession or sale of ice have reached 400 this year, more than double the arrests in connection with cocaine and crack, its smokable derivative.
In addition, the arrests of sellers and users of ice are now being reported by the police in the areas of San Francisco Bay, Los Angeles, San Diego and Phoenix and in parts of central Florida, though the numbers are not high. Law-enforcement authorities and those working in drug treatment centers say there have been no reports of the use of ice in New York City.
In Honolulu, as in cities on the mainland where crack is epidemic, medical and mental health centers are beginning to show the strain of treating ice users.
 
'They Go Absolutely Crazy'
Alma Y. Takata, the chief of the mental health division of the Hawaii State Department of Health, said Honolulu is averaging six hospital emergency room admissions a night for people being treated for symptoms caused by smoking crystal methamphetamine.
''They go absolutely crazy,'' Mrs. Takata said. ''They are bouncing off the walls. You've never seen anything like it. They're much more belligerent than those on crack.''
She said a survey of the 700 people who appeared for emergency treatment in the last six months showed that 50 percent had been using the drug by itself or in conjunction with another drug like alcohol.
Although ice creates feelings of euphoria followed by severe depression just as crack does, its effects differ significantly.
Instead of the 15-minute high with crack, the high from ice may last as long as 24 hours, and the psychological crash is much worse. In addition to euphoria, crack, which is a stimulant, may produce highly excitable and agitated behavior and severe but short-lived depression. With ice, along with depression, are symptoms of acute psychosis not normally associated with crack that last up to 48 hours. Severe paranoia, hallucinations, delusions and an impaired ability to speak coherently make its addicts temporarily indistinguishable from paranoid schizophrenics.
 
Weight Loss and Insomnia
Like those abusing crack, ice users initially suffer weight loss and insomnia because of the stimulation from the drug. On a physical level, the drug can produce irregular heartbeat, convulsions and cause body temperature to rise as high as 108 degrees, which can bring kidney failure.
Of special concern to those trying to treat users are studies demonstrating that addiction to amphetamines is as severe as addiction to cocaine. Research surveyed by Dr. Louis Harris of the Medical College of Virginia showed that monkeys taught to press a lever to receive an injection of either amphetamines, cocaine or nicotine would press the lever until they died rather than stop to eat or sleep. Heroin and alcohol were found to be less addictive.
Mrs. Takata said her office is planning to ask the State Legislature for money to devise a plan for comprehensive short- and long-term treatment of ice addicts. The obstacle is not in devising a new method of treatment, but in providing an adequate number of treatment spaces in programs already dealing with addictions to other drugs. Thus far, only a small number of treatment programs exist for ice addicts and those are through private groups that contract with the state.
Karl D. Muller is the director of a crisis response team working for the state that responds to calls of people acting bizarrely on the streets of Honolulu. More and more, those people turn out to have been smoking ice, he said.
 
'An Instant Psychosis'
''Every person on ice I have seen has to be in restraints,'' Mr. Muller said. ''We look upon ice as an instant psychosis.''
Most cases are taken to the emergency room at Queen's Medical Center in downtown Honolulu. Dr. Donald C. Fancher, the director of the emergency department, said that users displayed violent or aggressive behavior toward anyone, necessitating more security guards to restrain them. ''They pound on the walls, threaten - they're out of control,'' Dr. Fancher said.
While the acute toxic affects of the drugs normally dissipate in 48 hours, there is evidence to suggest that patients have ''permanent psychological problems if they abused it a lot,'' Dr. Fancher said.
Synthetic stimulants of the central nervous system from the amphetamine group were first synthesized in Japan in 1919 and have since had prescribed medical uses in the treatment for falling asleep at inappropriate moments, or narcolepsy; for hyperactivity in children, and for obesity. The illegally sold methamphetamine form can be made from a wide variety of heated chemical compounds, some of which are easy to obtain.
Dr. Marvin Snyder of the National Institute on Drug Abuse said that smokable methamphetamine ''produces a higher level of the drug in the brain in a shorter period of time'' than speed, which in powdered form is snorted or can be heated into liquid and injected.
The basic apparatus for making ice already exists in small chemical laboratories, many of them on the West Coast, where speed is now illegally made. The highly volatile cooking procedure is simple to set up in abandoned factories, for example, or in buildings in remote rural areas.
Illegal marijuana cultivation and clandestine production of powder methamphetamine make up the bulk of domestic drug production with the manufacture of LSD and PCP playing a much smaller role. But experts say that ice presents a much more frightening alternative.
 
Enormous Profits for Dealers
Speed has long been called the poor man's cocaine because of its price. But the ice dealers have held the price above that of cocaine, thereby creating enormous profits. They have been able to maintain this high price because of the long-lasting effects of the drug and because of the appeal of its newness, officers here say.
Ice is being sold in one-gram sealed plastic bags for about $400. It is also sold in $50 bags of one-tenth of a gram, the amount normally used for a high. Experts say that it only cost a few hundred dollars for the chemicals to produce a pound of nearly pure methamphetamine that can be dissolved in water or acid and cooked to produce large crystals.
The police report that cocaine, from which crack is derived, sells for about $110 a gram here.
Maj. Mike Carvalho of the Honolulu Police Department's narcotics unit said that the arrest this week of a street dealer is typical. The suspect was found to be in possession of 10 grams of ice, $55,000 in cash and a pistol.
The authorities say that abuse of ice at this stage of its evolution cuts across all social, economic racial and ethnic lines, but tends to be concentrated among people in their late teens and early 20's. The experts say that most ice users have not yet fully realized the extent of the suffering that takes place once the euphoria subsides and the experts believe that once the side-effects are known, the drug will lose its cachet.
 
'Nice for the Middle Class'
One Honolulu doctor who has treated many users of the drug said his patients often look like the girl next door.
''It seems clean because you don't have to use a needle or go to a crack house and it's available,'' said the doctor, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified. ''It has the panache of cocaine when it first came out - something nice for the middle class.''
A special group of state, local and Federal authorities has resulted in the prosecution of 21 dealers involved in larger smuggling activities. In one such case, 13 pounds of ice sent from Hong Kong were seized.
Although the drug is normally shipped here from Asia, one recent seizure netted ice that had first been shipped to Portland, Ore., and then brought into Honolulu, in an attempt to avoid customs inspection.
In San Francisco, spokesmen for the Haight-Ashbury Free Medical Clinic and the Larkin Street Center report that speed is the drug most used by young people living on the streets in these areas. Both clinics are concerned that ice will take its place.
''We've been hearing about it from kids with a real sense of excitement,'' said Michael Shriver, a substance abuse counsellor at Larkin Street. Young people report that the drug is showing up on the streets and it's believed to come from Los Angeles and is known as L.A. crystal. ''They think it's a drug from heaven because of the long duration of the high. We're really scared about what will happen.''

HEADLINE: U.S. VOICING FEARS THAT GORBACHEV WILL DIVIDE WEST

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
In advance of new high-level Soviet-American talks, top officials of the Bush Administration are expressing concern that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policies could lead to the breakup of the Western alliance and the disintegration of the postwar European order.
While in the past Bush Administration officials justified their cautious approach toward Mr. Gorbachev by citing doubts about his sincerity, remarks today by President Bush and on Wednesday by Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger put on the record additional reasons that until now had been largely stated in private. The argument is that Mr. Gorbachev's loosening of the Soviet hold on Eastern Europe and the Baltic republics could bring about damaging instability in Europe and delude many Western nations into rushing to Moscow's assistance without regard to NATO's long-term interests.
 
Meetings Due Next Week
The comments by Mr. Bush and his top aides have been driven by the Administration's perceived need to outline its views in advance of meetings next week between Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union and Mr. Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. In addition, the Administration is gearing up for calls in Congress for further cuts in the military budget and a new Soviet public relations offensive at the United Nations General Assembly, which also opens next week. 
There has been some ambiguity in the Administration's position. It has welcomed the new Soviet openness in dealing with the outside world and the less repressive atmosphere in the Soviet Union. And Washington has also not been unhappy with Moscow's faltering economy and political problems at home, which have reduced Moscow's military threat.
 
Pressure for Concessions
But the Administration has been concerned that sympathy for Mr. Gorbachev could bring about pressure for unneeded concessions from the West, leading to unforeseen problems in Europe and to a more unstable and dangerous situation than the more familiar East-West split that has dominated the political map of Europe in the postwar years.
In a speech Wednesday at Georgetown University that clearly reflected Administration thinking, Mr. Eagleburger said, ''The process of reform in the Soviet bloc and the relaxation of Soviet control over Eastern Europe are bringing long-suppressed ethnic antagonisms and national rivalries to the surface, and putting the German question back on the international agenda.''
Saying the American-Soviet domination of world politics since the end of the World War II had suppressed many of these antagonisms, Mr. Eagleburger added, ''We are now moving into, or I should say back into - for such has been the nature of international affairs since time immemorial - a world in which power and influence is diffused among a multiplicity of states.''
This multipolar world, he said, is not ''necessarily going to be a safer place than the cold war era from which we are emerging, given the existence and indeed proliferation of weapons of mass destruction.
''For all its risks and uncertainties, the cold war was characterized by a remarkably stable and predictable set of relations among the great powers,'' he went on. ''A brief look at the history books will tell us that we cannot say as much about the period leading from the birth of the European nation states up through the outbreak of the Second World War.''
 
Destabilization Feared
While not advocating a return to the rigid divisions of the cold war, he said nevertheless that there is ''the danger that change in the East will prove too destabilizing to be sustained.''
In comments to reporters from regional publications, Mr. Bush said today that while he welcomed changes taking place in the Soviet Union, he took the attitude President Truman took. ''I'm like the guy from Missouri - 'show me' - and take your time and do it right,'' he said.
''Europe has had peace for some 40 years now,'' the President said, ''and if you look at your textbooks, why you'll see that that's a long time in an area of the world that has been troubled by conflict, in an area of the world that has involved us in this century in two massive wars.''
Interviews with senior Administration officials indicate that these statements have been prompted by the events in Eastern Europe and the Baltic republics over the summer, as well as Mr. Gorbachev's declarations last week about potential instability in the Soviet Union. The pressure by Soviet nationalities for greater autonomy and the threat of a crackdown from Moscow brought into stark relief for Administration officials the explosiveness of Mr. Gorbachev's program.
The publicly stated concerns coming out of the Administration about those difficulties have been clearly noted in Moscow, and with obvious distress.
 
Cold War 'Inertia' Feared
''Are these statements consistent with the concept of breaking out of the policy of containment, or do they reflect the inertia of the cold war period?'' the Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman, Gennadi I. Gerasimov, said at a news conference in Moscow.
Mr. Eagleburger's remarks gave a glimpse into why the Bush Administrations still seems to see as many dangers as opportunities in Mr. Gorbachev's efforts. Indeed, the Deputy Secretary began his speech by warning: ''We Americans tend to be much less aware of the dangers inherent in success. We are a confident and optimistic people, and in our approach to international affairs we tend to focus on the challenges of the moment and pay little heed to the long run.''
''Gorbachev is no anti-Communist and he intends to make the Soviet Union as strong as he possibly can,'' Mr. Eagleburger said. ''Nevertheless, it is true that the changes introduced by Gorbachev offer the first realistic hope for a transformation in the nature of the Soviet system and for a qualitative improvement in East-West relations.''
Already, he continued, ''we are hearing it said that we need to take measures to insure the success of Gorbachev's reforms.
''This, however, is not the task of American foreign policy, nor should it be that of our Western partners,'' said Mr. Eagleburger, who in recent years worked as a consultant with former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger. ''Our task, after all, is to devise policies which will serve our interests, whether Mr. Gorbachev succeeds or fails. And our common goal ought to be the maintenance of the security consensus which has served the West so well over the past 40 years until the process of democratic reform in the East has truly become irreversible.''
Mr. Eagleburger warned that as the Soviet Union appears to adopt more soft-line foreign and domestic policies, there will be a real danger that the Western tendency ''toward unilateralism on trade matters'' will be ''matched in the field of security relations'' with the East bloc.

HEADLINE: Wave of Protests Developing On Profits From AIDS Drug

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
The prospect of huge profits from the sale of the AIDS drug AZT is bringing a wave of protests against the Burroughs Wellcome Company, the drug's manufacturer.
Advocates for people with AIDS are organizing boycotts of other company products, and Government lawyers are considering whether to invoke a 1910 law that would allow Federal officials to override the company's patents to make larger supplies available.
Recent findings indicate that the number of people who could benefit from taking AZT has increased from about 45,000 people with AIDS to include as many as 600,000 people who are infected with the AIDS virus but have no symptoms.
 
Only Drug Licensed
AZT, or azidothymidine, is the only drug licensed to treat AIDS; its use stops the multiplication of the virus. 
It is among the most expensive drugs ever sold for daily use for a long period. At current prices and in usual doses, the drug costs each patient about $8,000 a year. Its cost, which has long raised protests from doctors and advocates for AIDS patients, may now yield what some analysts are calling astronomical and unconscionable profits.
The company has not said what its costs were in bringing it to market; industry analysts estimate that they range from $80 million to $180 million. Sales for the fiscal year that ended last month were $220 million, and profits before taxes have been estimated at as much as $100 million. With the new wave of patients, sales could reach $1 billion annually by 1992, analysts say.
Burroughs Wellcome officials have maintained that the price is high because the costs of research, development and manufacturing the drug have been high while the number of patients they can sell the drug to has been relatively small. In addition, the company has said it began to research and make the drug when other companies did not want to take the risk. Efforts today to reach officials of Burroughs Wellcome for comment were unsuccessful.
 
National Boycott Being Organized
A national boycott of Burroughs Wellcome products is being organized by more than a dozen groups of advocates for AIDS patients. One measure being considered is sending letters to all doctors in the country asking them to substitute an antibiotic made by another company for one that Burroughs Wellcome makes.
Lawyers for the Public Health Service and for Congressional committees have begun to look into the possibility of using an 80-year-old law under which the Government could ignore the patent rights of Borroughs Wellcome and have the drug manufactured at a far lower cost by another company. The law was last invoked in the 1950's, when military sought a lower price for tetracycline than that offered by drug companies in the United States.
The law provides that the Government may override patent protection when the action is important for the welfare of the nation. The company whose patent was negated cannot sue the Government under normal patent law, but it may recover a ''reasonable compensation'' in the Court of Claims, a special court that considers claims against the Federal Government.
Government lawyers said they were not sure if action under the law would be possible in the case of AZT. Although the Government subsidizes its purchase, it does not actually buy the drug itself.
 
Congressional Hearings Planned
Congressional hearings into the pricing of AZT are being prepared, and an article in The Journal of the American Medical Association today called the high cost unnecessary and the authors of the article said in a press conference that the company is guilty of ''price gouging''.
On Thursday, people in New York, San Francisco and London protested against the manufacturer by beginning a campaign of pasting small stickers that read ''AIDS profiteer'' on its products.
At the New York Stock Exchange, five protesters and two amateur photographers were arrested Thursday when they chained themselves to the balcony overlooking the exchange floor and unfurled a banner that said ''Sell Wellcome.'' Burroughs Wellcome is a subsidiary of Wellcome P.L.C. of England and no stock in it is traded on American exchanges. Stock of the parent corporation is traded on the London exchange. The new wave of people who may take the drug - those who are healthy, but infected, and have signs that their immune system is weakening - may take a dose of 5 capsules per day, considerably less than the dose of 12 capsules a day for people with AIDS.
 
Cost Estimates Vary
Various estimates have been made of the cost of manufacture, from one by Mathilde Krim of the American Foundation for AIDS Research of about 7 to 15 cents per capsule, to industry analysts who say it may cost 33 to 53 cents per capsule. A patient pays about $1.75 a capsule.
An even more important determinant of cost is the size of the market the company is selling to, said Robert Uhl, a pharmaceutical analyst with Salomon Brothers in New York. To cover the cost of manufacture and recover the cost of development, a small market means a far higher price. Mr. Uhl said the company has probably already recovered its cost.
Analysts give different estimates for the profits made by the compnay on the drug, depending largely on how profits are counted. John A. Falkenberg, an analyst with the British investment bank of Barclays Dezoete Wedd, Inc. in New York said a before-tax profit which does not discount many costs would be $100 million on 1989 sales of $220 million. After subtracting other costs, it might be a quarter of that amount, he said.
''But pharmaceutical companies when they look at making a drug, assume all the worst case scenarios -that there will be few patients, the product will have problems, it will have a short market life,'' said Leonard Schifrin, a health care economist at the College of William and Mary in Virginia.
''The company wants to build up a very nice nest egg to recover costs, and so the price of drugs like AZT seems very, very high. Then, when the worst cases do not happen, but instead there are more patients and a longer life in the market, it can turn those worst cases into billion-dollar bonanzas,'' Dr. Schifrin said.
''You might argue about how high the price has been,'' Dr. Schifrin said, ''but this is a very high profit industry. Profits are twice as high as in other industries, and that has become the norm.''
''Now with the larger market it, the price must come down. It would be uconscionable if it did not come down,'' Dr. Schifrin said.

HEADLINE: Polish Finance Minister's Tricky Mix: Hard Times and Free Markets

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARSAW, Sept. 15

 BODY:
Poland's new Finance Minister says he can move the country's badly limping centrally planned economy toward more capitalism only if he can impose budget austerity and create a market economy.
The problem, Finance Minister Leszek Balcerowicz said in an interview, is that he is supposed to do both at once.
Mr. Balcerowicz, a 42-year-old economist whose nomination was confirmed by Parliament on Tuesday with the rest of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki's new Cabinet, said the quandary is this: only free markets supplying more everyday goods, which do not exist, as well as a capitalist-style safety net of unemployment payments and job-search agencies, which Poland's Communist economy has never known, could sweeten the unemployment and social dislocation that austerity threatens to bring.
Alluding to the belt tightening he is about to prescribe for Poland, he cautioned, ''In no country in the world in which such measures were introduced were there no deflationary effects.'' 
 
Trip to I.M.F. Meeting Weighed
''The problem is we have to act on two fronts at once,'' Mr. Balcerowicz said in the interview Tuesday. ''On the one hand there is the question of stabilization, while at the same time we must undertake institutional changes leading to a market economy.''
As a result, he said the new Government would move quickly to get loans from the International Monetary Fund to help it overhaul the economy. If necessary, he said he would travel to Washington later this month when I.M.F. officials gather for their annual meeting to argue Poland's case.
Certainly, Mr. Balcerowicz (pronounced bal-tser-OH-vich), who earned a doctorate in economics in Warsaw before earning an M.B.A. in economics in 1974 at St. John's University in New York, is aware of the pitfalls. He said Poland would have to quickly introduce ''social safeguards'' like unemployment payments, retraining programs and job-placement agencies to ease the jarring effects of austerity.
Austerity is a touchy issue in Poland, where economic deterioration has set off cycles of social unrest every decade or so since the war, toppling governments in 1956, 1970 and 1980. Recognizing the potential risks for the new Solidarity-led Cabinet, he said, ''I would hope the trade unions would participate'' - a reference to not only the Solidarity union but also the Communist unions, which have said they are not willing to accept a drop in living standards.
 
Split Seen in Economic Team
With that in mind, Mr. Balcerowicz, who was a Communist Party member until he resigned in December 1981 to protest the imposition of martial law in Poland, pledged to work closely with the new Labor Minister, Jacek Kuron, the Solidarity supporter and longtime dissident who is a veteran of 10 years in Polish prisons, and who is often numbered among the ministers with strongest social-democratic leanings.
Indeed, the nomination of ministers like Mr. Kuron has led to speculation that Mr. Mazowiecki's economic team, which is led by Mr. Balcerowicz, is essentially split between ministers oriented toward market economics and others favoring moderate policies aimed at avoiding social dislocation. Mr. Kuron is known as a tough defender of workers' rights whose views on economics are colored more by socialism than any brand of liberal free enterprise.
Mr. Balcerowicz was at pains to deny that there is such a division. ''If there is such a split, we certainly have not noticed it,'' he said of the first meetings of ministers responsible for the economy.
Developing a private sector will be no easy task. To make privatization work, Mr. Balcerowicz said, Poland must overhaul the way the economy keeps its books, to obtain fair values, and create institutions or build up those so underdeveloped as to be incapable of making a market economy work, such as banks, securities exchanges and, perhaps most urgently, a convertible currency.
Under the proposals outlined by Mr. Balcerowicz, the new Government would waste no time in imposing budget austerity and cracking down on tax evaders among the huge nationalized enterprises.
Asked whether there was fear of widespread bankruptcies among the dinosaurs of Poland's rust belt, he replied that Poland could draw on examples from Western Europe, ''aimed at making the program as painless as possible.''
''But we have to see declining industries disappear,'' he said. ''There is no hesitation as far as direction is concerned.''

HEADLINE: Drought-Stricken Areas Find Relief After Rains

BYLINE: By WILLIAM ROBBINS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GRANT CITY, Mo., Sept. 14

 BODY:
They came too late to do much for this year's crops, but bountiful, soaking rains over the last few weeks have brought relief from the drought that has persisted for more than a year across much of the Farm Belt.
Experts disagree on whether the drought is over or merely eased. It began in 1988 and devastated crops from Ohio to Texas and Montana and prompted Congress to spend almost $5 billion for relief to farmers.
But the rains, saturating topsoil and seeping deep into the subsoil, are nurturing lush new growth of pasture grasses, refilling long-dry cattle ponds and bringing new hope for new crops, especially winter wheat, which some Middle Western growers are planting for next summer's harvest. 
''These rains have virtually eliminated the long-term drought,'' said Douglas LeComte, chief of the agricultural weather section of a division run by the Agriculture Department and the National Weather Service.
 
'Reluctant to Sound All Clear'
Peter Leavitt, executive vice president of the Weather Services Corporation, a private consultant in Bedford, Mass., agreed up to a point. ''From the standpoint of the Midwest, it's fair to say the drought is over,'' Mr. Leavitt said this week. ''But I'm a little reluctant to sound the all-clear. This doesn't relieve nature of the responsibility of being beneficent next year. We always want to put borders on things, but nature doesn't let you do that. It wants to be a continuum.''
Mr. Leavitt said the rains had followed a pattern much like that of the drought itself, which persisted for some time in the East and then expanded westward last year, through corn-growing areas of Pennsylvania, Kentucky, Ohio and Indiana and lower Mississippi Valley. Meanwhile, a drought that had persisted in the Northwest expanded eastward, into the western Corn Belt of Illinois, Iowa, Nebraska, South Dakota and Missouri.
''We still had the drought this year in the western Corn Belt,'' Mr. Leavitt said. ''We just didn't have the heat. In the absence of heat, a little moisture went a long way.''
Some of the most generous relief came to Kansas, a state so severely stricken that it produced little more than half its normal crop of winter wheat this year. But now, as the fall planting time for the next crop approaches, Kansas has just enjoyed its rainiest week of the year. David Salmon of Global Weather Services, a division of Knight-Ridder Financial News, said this was Kansas' fourth week in a row of above-normal rainfall, and its 11th out of the last 16.
 
Areas Still Getting Relief
Among the last places to get relief have been southwestern Iowa, where National Guard trucks are still hauling water to nine towns; most of Nebraska, and several counties here in northwestern Missouri.
In those areas many farmers, like Eddie Costin of Grant City, had seen their ponds and pastures dry up, had watched their crops shrivel and had been forced to sell off many of their breeding cattle.
But now at least six inches of rain has fallen in some of the hardest-hit parts of Iowa over the last few weeks, four to six inches in Nebraska and more than six inches in this part of Missouri, delighting many like Mr. Costin. The rains came in time to bring his pasture grasses back to lushly green new life, refill his ponds and save the remaining 46 cows, he said.
Ken Hubbard, director of the High Plains Climate Center at the University of Nebraska, said the rain ''postponed any drought we were experiencing, at least until next year.''
 
'Too Much Moisture to Plant'
In Ottawa, Kan., Jack Beauchamp was equally pleased, even though the rain had forced him to delay planting his winter wheat. ''Now we've got too much moisture to plant,'' he said. ''That's quite a change from this time last year, but you're not going to hear me complaining.''
The principal area of the Farm Belt that is still dry is the wheat country of the Northern Plains, principally the western Dakotas and eastern Montana.
Richard Heim, a meteorologist at the Weather Service's National Climatic Data Center in Asheville, N.C., takes a dim view of those who say the drought is over. He notes that even large amounts of rainfall are slow to change moisture in the subsoil, which affects rivers, underground water supplies and deep-rooted plants like trees and corn. Mr. Heim notes that at the end of August, the subsoil was still very dry in parts of Colorado, Illinois, Iowa, Kansas, Michigan, Minnesota, Nebraska, North Dakota and South Dakota.
All the recent rains are expected to have little immediate effect on food prices; that will have to await next year's harvest. The Agriculture Department continues to predict that food-price inflation for this year will run from 5 to 7 percent. Most of that rise has already occurred.
 
Impact on Corn Harvest
In 1988, because of the drought, American farmers produced 4.9 billion bushels of corn, the most important crop as far as food budgets are concerned because it is the principal ingredient in feed for livestock. That was the smallest corn crop since 1983, another drought year, but it was still larger than earlier forecasts. That, experts say, was largely because the roots reached down into subsoil moisture that lingered despite the absence of rains.
The Agriculture Department's forecast for this year is 7.3 billion bushels, smaller than the averages of recent years and smaller than the department's earlier estimate. Mr. Leavitt said the problem was too little moisture in the subsoil of the western Corn Belt. ''When it came time in midsummer for the corn to go into overdrive, the moisture wasn't there,'' he said.

GRAPHIC: Recent rains, too late to save this year's crops, have brought some relief from the drought that gripped the Farm Belt for more than a year. On his farm in Grant City, Mo., Eddie Costin checked a pond that was dry about three weeks ago. (The New York Times/David Hutson)

HEADLINE: NORTHEAST GAINS SOME POPULATION

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
After a decade of population decline, the industrialized Northeast and Midwest have experienced modest gains since 1985, but 87 percent of all the nation's growth in the 1980's has been in the South and West, the Census Bureau said today.
The nation's population as a whole has grown by an estimated 19.3 million people from 1980 to 1988, to a total of 245.8 million, the bureau's annual report of state population estimates showed. Of that, 16.8 million was in the states of the South and West. 
Among the fastest growing states, the report said, were Arizona with a 28.4 percent increase since 1980, California with a 19.6 percent increase, Florida with a 26 percent increase, and Nevada, with a 31.7 percent increase.
The report this year covers state population changes in 1987 and 1988, as well as selected figures showing changes since 1980.
In the Northeast, the population has grown by 1.5 percent in the past three years, which is an annual rate in the region that is faster than any year since 1970.
Don Starsinic, a Census Bureau demographer, predicted that the New York metropolitan area, which now has a population of 18,120,200, is likely to increase to 18,200,000 by the end of the decade, bringing it back to its population of 1970.
But Mr. Starsinic added, ''It will be more concentrated in the areas outside New York City, although the city will recoup some of its loss.'' For census purposes, the New York metropolitan region stretches from Ocean County, N.J., on the south to Orange County, N.Y., on the northwest, Danbury, Conn., on the northeast and Suffolk County, L.I., on the east.
The fastest-growing areas in the metropolitan region continue to be the outer counties.
In terms of actual population numbers, California's growth of 4.6 million since 1980 was greatest. The state's total now is 28.3 million.
The Los Angeles metropolitan area grew by 2.3 million people from 1980 to 1988 to a total of 13.8 million, or almost half the state's population, Florida grew fastest in the decade, among states with populations of more than 5 million, climbing 2.6 million to a total of 12.3 million.
If California and Florida were the biggest gainers for the decade, the three biggest losers were Iowa, West Virginia and Wyoming, due to slumps in the farm and energy economies.

HEADLINE: 6 in the Arts Win New $100,000 Prize

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
The six winners of a new $100,000 Japanese prize for lifetime achievement in the arts, the Praemium Imperiale, were announced yesterday at Rockefeller Center.
The winners are Pierre Boulez of France, in music; Marcel Carne of France, in theater and film; David Hockney of Britain and Willem de Kooning of the United States, in painting; Umberto Mastroianni of Italy, in sculpture, and I. M. Pei of the United States, in architecture.
The Praemium Imperiale, or Imperial Prize, was created last year by the Japanese Art Association to show Japan's commitment to fostering the arts. It was the idea of Prince Nobuhito Takamatsu, younger brother of Hirohito and governor of the association until his death in 1987. 
''Japan is criticized all over the world for putting too much emphasis on economic development,'' Hiroaki Shikanai, vice chairman of the association, said in an interview before the prizes were announced. ''I believe it should take a course as a nation that puts more emphasis on culture.''
The money for the prizes, he said, came largely from the Fujisankei Communications Group, which he heads. It owns television stations and newspapers in Japan.
Mr. Shikanai said the six winners, each of whom will receive a medal and $100,000, were chosen by the association's board from lists of nominees provided by committees in the United States, France, Italy, Britain and West Germany.
 
The Winners
Schuyler G. Chapin, a member of the American committee, read a short description of each winner at today's ceremony. He said of Mr. Pei, who is 72 years old, ''His major works are, in a word, stunning.'' They include the East Wing of the National Gallery of Art, the Pyramid of the Louvre in Paris and the Morton H. Meyerson Symphony Center that just opened in Dallas.
Mr. de Kooning, 85, the Dutch-born painter, was among the originators of the school of Abstract Expressionism, which dominated painting for much of the postwar era.
Mr. Hockney, 52, was born in Britain, but his paintings of Los Angeles scenes epitomize the highly colorful, figurative painting style associated with the West Coast.
Mr. Mastroianni, who will be 79 on Thursday, is an Italian artist of ''originality, passion, and drama,'' in Mr. Chapin's words. He was known for miniatures for much of his career, but he began creating large abstract sculptures after World War II. He is ''one of the few to reflect the moral habits of our civilization,'' Mr. Chapin said.
 
Only Pei Is Present
Mr. Boulez, 64, the French former conductor of the New York Philharmonic and other major orchestras, is a teacher and composer whose life was devoted in large part to interpreting modern classical music. ''Present and future students of music in this century must study Boulez's extraordinary oeuvre to gain any sense of progress in the glorious art of music,'' Mr. Chapin said.
Mr. Carne, 83, the director, has seen his most celebrated works, including ''Hotel du Nord'' and ''The Children of Paradise,'' become some of the century's most popular classics.
Of the winners, only Mr. Pei was present at the announcement yesterday. Afterward, he told a press conference that he was numb.
''It's an excellent idea,'' he said of the new prize. ''But it puts a heavy burden on those who are nominated and eventually get the prize, and I for one feel that burden very much.''
The prize ceremony and awarding of the money will take place Oct. 27 in Japan.
The prize has been widely seen as part of an effort by various Japanese groups to use the wealth gained through its economic success to promote cultural exchanges and other activities. Japanese groups recently have invested in American film companies and given large grants to universities for the study of Asia.
The official name of the award in Japanese is the World Culture Award Established in Honor of Prince Nobuhito Takamatsu. One or two prizes in each category are to be awarded each year, meaning the prize money could be as much as $1 million.
 
Selecting the Winners
Nominations for the prizes were made by committees headed by four former Prime Ministers and David Rockefeller, the investment banker who is the chairman of the Museum of Modern Art in New York. The former Prime Minsters are Edward Heath of Britain, Jacques Chirac of France, Amintore Fanfani of Italy and Helmut Schmidt of West Germany.
Mr. Shikanai said the main task of the chairmen is to organize committees of experts in their countries to make nominations. ''They had to be influential enough to form that kind of committee under them,'' he said.
Mr. Rockefeller, who spoke at yesterday's lunch, said his committee had met for a day and a half to consider its nominations. Among the members of the American committee are Mr. Chapin, former dean of the Columbia University School of the Arts, the composer Stephen Sondheim, Kirk Varnedoe, director of painting and sculpture at the Museum of Modern Art, Lloyd Richards, the head of the Yale Drama School, S. Dillon Ripley, secretary emeritus of the Smithsonian Institution, and Ada Louise Huxtable, a former architecture critic for The New York Times.
''It would be my guess that the awards in five important cultural fields will complement the Nobel Prizes very well,'' Mr. Rockefeller said at the news conference, ''and will come in these fields to have an importance comparable to the Nobels in other fields.''
Mr. Shikanai said that while nominations were made by the international advisory committees, the final choices were made by the trustees of the Japan Art Association. He said most of the 11 trustees were top Japanese business executives, some of whom had connections to museums, and also included Shunichi Suzuki, the Governor of Tokyo, and Jiro Arimitsu, the president of the Japan Art Academy.

HEADLINE: Talk to China - Despite the Chill

 BODY:
The Administration's decision to continue talks with Beijing about closer trade relations reflects the conviction that such talks serve both countries' long-term interests. The violence in Tiananmen Square and the ensuing political oppression have chilled official contacts. But the Administration calculates, correctly, that ending the trade talks would do lasting damage. 
The discussions involve China's membership in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the international agreement that governs most of the world's imports and exports of manufactured goods. The talks have barely inched along for several years. There is no prospect that the Chinese will gain membership soon, and even talking about it alarms opponents of doing business with a repressive Communist regime.
Anger at the turn of events in China's internal politics is wholly justified. But it should not deter the Western powers from trying to encourage a return to the path of economic liberation that Beijing was pursuing before Tiananmen Square.
Politics aside, there's no easy way to incorporate state-controlled economies into the GATT. It links market economies whose prices are set by market forces. A government like China's can raise or cut prices without regard to cost, making tariffs meaningless. For example, if the U.S. tariff on imported fireworks were 10 percent, Beijing could wipe out the effect by dropping prices 10 percent. Poland, Czechoslovakia and Rumania are GATT members in a limited sense, and China is officially an ''observer'' in the current Uruguay Round of global negotiations to reduce all trade barriers. The Russians want to participate too; in the current atmosphere of encouraging Mikhail Gorbachev's perestroika, they should be welcome. But America is still proscribed from accepting them as equal trading partners under a 1974 law - the Jackson-Vanik Amendment - that requires freer emigration rights for Soviet Jews. Repeal of that law is overdue, but that's an ideological fight Washington is not yet ready for.
The White House claims that the talks with Beijing are ''low level''; that's a face-saving fabrication. It would be smarter to say that, for the time being, there's no big push for progress. One reason is the post-Tiananmen chill. But another, which applies equally to China and the Soviet Union, is that the Administration will have its hands full persuading Congress to accept the import liberalization that's being negotiated in the Uruguay Round; to raise sensitive East-West trade issues at the same time would make matters only worse.
For now, it's sufficient just to keep talking. In the long run, everyone's best interests will be served by integrating the Communist powers into the Western trading system. Free trade fosters prosperity - and peace.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: End the Artificial Rationing of Taxi Medallions

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You reported only one sentence of my testimony at the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission hearing Aug. 9 (news story, Aug. 10), giving the impression that I support a fare increase. I do not. As I said in my testimony, taxi fares are too high in relation to the true costs of cab owners and operators, such as gasoline, insurance, amortization of the vehicle and compensation for the driver. Payment that reflects the value of a medallion - the symbol of the artificially limited right to operate a street-hail cab - is not a true cost. 
Current fares cover true costs and generate enough extra revenue to support medallion values of $140,000, evidence that fares are excessive related to real costs.
I also indicated to the commission that, while fares are too high, relative to operation, they are low relative to the publicly borne costs of congestion, air pollution, and wear and tear on the streets. I said that a properly structured fare increase could help reduce these costs, but any such increase should be taxed away by the city to help defray the substantial public costs of maintaining streets and managing congestion. I also stated that, because taxis are relatively efficient users of New York City's streets, the city should take even stronger actions to discourage the use of private cars.
The best taxi policy is to end the artificial limit on the number of medallions and to start managing congestion. Medallion prices on the private market would fall to zero, supply and demand for taxis would be in balance, and more drivers could afford to become owner-operators concerned with providing a service, rather than reaping a windfall on an unproductive financial asset each time the fare is raised.
 
ELIZABETH A. ROISTACHER
 New York, Sept. 1, 1989
The writer was the economics consultant to the Mayor's Committee on Taxi Regulatory Issues, 1981-82.

HEADLINE: Breaking One of South Africa's Barriers

BYLINE: By DAVID MARGOLICK

 BODY:
Vernon Grigg's application for a Supreme Court clerkship was heavy with conventional credentials. He is a student at Yale Law School. He had an honors degree from the University of Michigan and a year at the London School of Economics. He had also apprenticed at two top law firms, was a licensed glider pilot and had performed in a singing group called Up With People during halftime at Super Bowl XVI.
But this application was different from most. The Supreme Court was the Supreme Court of the Transvaal, a province in South Africa - and Mr. Grigg is black. 
 
First Black Law Clerk
Last week Mr. Grigg, an American, began working for Judge Ronald Goldstone of the Johannesburg Supreme Court, becoming the first black law clerk ever under apartheid. Indeed, he might just be the first black person ever in Judge Goldstone's chambers, aside from the custodian who vacuums the floor. In his new post he will research cases and perform other law-related chores.
The laws of apartheid apply to foreign blacks visiting South Africa. Even were he so inclined, Mr. Grigg could not eat in whites-only restaurants or ride in whites-only buses. But he is permitted to live in a white neighborhood, with the judge's other clerk, a white.
Already he has been mistaken for a houseboy. He has also been the target of confused stares from black and white South Africans alike, who cannot quite figure out where he fits into a society with clearly defined racial niches. It is an eerie experience, yet in a way it is precisely what the 26-year-old from Tucson, Ariz., wanted.
 
Going to Observe
Shortly before he left the United States, Mr. Grigg, who has taken a year's leave of absence from Yale, spoke of why he was headed to South Africa and what he hoped to accomplish there. As he envisions it, his role is to be more that of observer and scholar than political advocate; he is far more anxious to learn about apartheid than to make a point about it.
''If I can be a role model for students in this country or an inspiration for anyone there, that I welcome,'' he said. ''But do I go there intending to attract a tremendous amount of attention, or wanting to become a political Ping-Pong ball? Not at all.''
Before he left, Mr. Grigg read up on the history of the Dutch East India Company and the story of the voortrekkers. He learned a smattering of Afrikaans - words like ''ras'' for ''race'' and ''Kaffir,'' a name for members of the Bantu tribe now used as a derogatory term for blacks, ''volk'' and ''veld.'' He studied the works of W. E .B. DuBois and the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. and pondered America's own racial past with more than academic interest. ''I've been told to think that going to South Africa is like going back to Selma in 1920,'' he said.
There were other, more practical preparations. He packed the same shirt he wore when he first flew solo, which he figured had already helped him through times of stress. He bought some life and health insurance, as well as a whistle at the Yale Co-op. And, for reasons of self-identity as well as security, he treated himself to a new pair of Nike high-tops. ''If I have to roll, I can,'' he said.
 
'Allegations of Complicity'
Mr. Grigg has taken his share of criticism for accepting the clerkship, particularly from white classmates. With varying degrees of tact, they faulted him for legitimizing apartheid, or, even worse, enforcing its decrees.
''They were all allegations of complicity - that I'm going to be writing the opinions that sentence political activists to hang,'' he said. Were it not for the reassurances of the law school's dean, Guido Calabresi, he might have backed out of the project altogether.
''The importance of Vernon's trip and what he can accomplish far outweighs the risk he'll be used as window dressing for a racist system,'' said R. Scott Greathead, a New York lawyer who helped establish the Orville H. Schell Jr. Center for International Human Rights at Yale, which is sponsoring Mr. Grigg's clerkship. Mr. Schell, who died in 1987, was a New York lawyer active in international human rights.
The son of a career military officer stationed in places like El Paso, Tex., Charlotte, N.C. and Kearney, Neb., Mr. Grigg encountered discrimination long before reaching South Africa. Always, he says, there were people like a public school teacher, a white man, who warned him that black students had to be twice as good as everyone else, then promptly knocked down his grade to prove his point.
He came to Yale in September 1987, where he hoped to further his interest in children's rights. But like many law students, boredom and frustration set in once the intimidation wore off. The course work struck him as too detached from reality, the career trajectory too corporate.
''The way I want to practice law is going to have to be very tactile, helping people rather than corporate bodies,'' he said. ''I wanted to leave the library, leave the ivy-covered walls and conference rooms and hit the streets, to learn how the things I'm learning can be used to make the world more as I would have it.''
In his second year he took a seminar called ''The Limits of Law as an Instrument of Social Change,'' taught by Professors Burke Marshall and Joseph Goldstein, along with Justice Aharon Barak of the Israeli Supreme Court, then visiting at Yale. That fed his desire for field work and led him to Judge Goldstone, one of South Africa's more liberal jurists. In South Africa, as in New York State, the Supreme Court is the trial-level court, although it hears some appeals.
''I didn't anticipate any problems and I'm sure there won't be any,'' Judge Goldstone said in a telephone interview from his Johannesburg home. ''People are intrigued, but I can't see anybody raising any objections to it.'' He declined to discuss his views on apartheid, though he has implicitly criticized it in speeches abroad.
Mr. Grigg first met the judge in February when he was visiting at Harvard's Center for International Affairs. The checking-out process went both ways. ''He made it clear that he wasn't an apologist for apartheid,'' Mr. Grigg said. ''He convinced me that he's sincere in his convictions, self-critical, constantly reevaluating what he can and cannot, will and will not do.
''I do not intend to consciously avail myself of the privileges I get because I'm American,'' Mr. Grigg continued. ''I resent and reject the notion of being an 'honorary white person' and I don't intend to become one.''

CORRECTION-DATE: September 20, 1989, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on Saturday about a Yale law student who works as a law clerk for a Supreme Court judge in South Africa misidentified the judge. He is Richard Goldstone.

HEADLINE: To Revive Newark, State Shuffles Its Workers

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, Sept. 14

 BODY:
In the latest attempt to breathe more life into the heart of this city on the mend, the state is moving 2,000 of its employees from offices near Pennsylvania Station into three downtown buildings that are now either unoccupied or largely vacant.
Local and state officials hope the transfer will put more people on Newark's streets and more customers in its stores and restaurants. Although the move is not scheduled to take place till next year, several businesses have opened in the immediate area in response to the plans, suggesting that the officials may be right.
But the plans, completed this month, do not sit well with everyone. Though the state employees union has agreed to cooperate, some state workers resent being used as tools of urban revitalization. 
 
'We Don't Trust You'
''They're putting state employees in an area that's more dangerous and less convenient,'' said Joseph C. O'Hara, chief of the Bureau of Gas Rates in the Board of Public Utilities. ''Forget it.''
Other workers are concerned about security in the new buildings, which are on blocks that are less heavily used than the current offices. They are also worried about parking and access to buses and trains.
Then there is an underlying mistrust that many employees feel toward the state and its promise to provide safe, clean and comfortable offices.
''We told them flat out, 'This sounds good, but we don't trust you,' '' said Michael J. Hopkins, president of Local 1037 of the Communications Workers of America, which represents most non-management state employees in Newark and which has been working without a contract since July.
State employees have been deployed to help the recovery of downtowns in other cities, including New York, where two years ago state offices were moved from the World Trade Center to sites elsewhere in the city, including Gertz Plaza in Jamaica, Queens. The idea has been pending here for more than a decade.
But each previous attempt was derailed by opposition from union leaders, who believed that the deteriorating and overcrowded conditions at the current offices, at 1100 Raymond Boulevard, were preferable to the darkened and deserted streets west of Broad Street to which workers would have been transferred.
 
'High Marks'
This time the picture is different. Although still weak, Newark's downtown as a whole is now recuperating from decades of decline, and most storefronts are occupied. Also, this time the state took extraordinary measures to win the support of labor.
''You've got to give them high marks on this one,'' said Mr. Hopkins of Local 1037.
The block-long building at 1100 Raymond Boulevard is owned by the Newark Center Building Company, a group of New York investors. The state has leased space in it since 1956; today, nearly 2,000 employees in many departments, including Consumer Affairs and Labor, work there.
An additional 1,000 employees will be moved from four other Newark buildings and offices in Bloomfield, East Orange and West Orange.
The Raymond Boulevard building is just down the street from Pennsylvania Station. Once surrounded by derelict old buildings, then by huge parking lots, 1100 Raymond now sits in the middle of Newark's Gateway district, a developing complex of office buildings containing more than 2 million square feet of space, roughly equivalent to the Empire State Building.
 
Bringing In Shoppers
Everett Shaw, who serves as president of Newark's corporate revitalization group, Renaissance Newark, as well as the city's $1-a-year deputy mayor for development, said that the city supports the state relocation because it would have a double effect: bringing thousands of people into the city's shopping district, and freeing a valuable development site.
The building's owners had tried to sign a new lease with the state but are not worried about finding a new tenant. They may try to raze part of the building and replace it with a 20-story tower.
The three buildings into which the employees will be moved are within three blocks of the current offices. They are 707 Broad Street, once occupied by a Two Guys department store; 153 Halsey Street, the former Gibraltar Building, owned by the Prudential Insurance Company of America, and 31 Clinton Street, which once housed Essex County Community College.
The state will lease about half the space in the Halsey Street and Broad Street buildings, and all the office space at 31 Clinton Street, which is substantially smaller. The total lease will be for 674,882 square feet, at $13.7 million a year.
The owners have agreed to renovate the three properties thoroughly, and asbestos removal has begun.
 
In Search of Lunch
Each of the three buildings will have stores or restaurants on the ground floor, but no employees' cafeteria, which will force workers to take to the streets in search of lunch. Planners hope the employees will stroll by the many small shops along Halsey Street as well as the city's only remaining department store, Macy's, which is now half-empty.
For the owners of the office buildings, getting the state as a major tenant is expected to make leasing the remaining space easier. Mr. Shaw said the city would plant trees, build new bus stops and add a new kiosk where city police officers would be stationed 24 hours a day. He said he also expected Macy's to refurbish its store.
Small businesses in the area are looking at the 3,000 new potential customers with relish.
''They are sure going to be a plus,'' said John D. Petrozzino, a Newark high school prinicipal who with two partners opened the Downtown Cafe Thursday across Halsey Street from the old Two Guys building.
Paula T. Saje, business manager for Computer Realty Management, which has just signed leases for three of four vacant stores it owns on Halsey Street, said the state's move has helped tremendously.
While concerns of safety and transportation, which led state employees to vote overwhelmingly against a similar proposal in 1983, still remain, Mr. Hopkins, the union local president, said that a survey last fall found workers to be almost evenly divided over the plan. Possible 'Paradise'? To overcome lingering apprehension, last November the state invited a group of union shop stewards to visit newly renovated offices in Trenton, where a similar plan is proceeding. Nestor Ocampo of Elizabeth was one of those who made the trip, and came back impressed.
''They did a very good job there, and if we have anything like that here it will be paradise,'' said Mr. Ocampo, a disability claims adjudicator within the Department of Labor.
James Sconamilio, an investigator with the Division of Consumer Affairs, said he thought that splitting the bulk of employees into three separate buildings might create inefficiencies, and that parking would be less available for the 52 percent of state workers who drive to work.
As for boosting local businesses, Mr. Sconamilio does not expect to contribute much. ''I only get a half hour for lunch,'' he said. ''Where are you going to go on that?''

HEADLINE: Your Money;
Long-Term Plan Yields Stock Gain

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
If a small investor had spent the last 20 years doing just what Wall Street professionals often say the little guy does - buying high - that person could have more than quadrupled the money invested, a new study from T. Rowe Price shows.
The Baltimore-based mutual fund and investment management firm calculated what would have happened to a portfolio if an investor had put $2,000 a year into equities at the year's peak and reinvested all dividends quarterly.
Right off the bat, the investor would have had a paper loss. Buying at the 1969 peak would have resulted in a Dec. 31 portfolio value of $1,772. And the next year, the investment would still be in the minus column with a value of $3,887. By the third year, however, the portfolio's value would have grown to $6,420 and by 1979, it would have been up to $28,416, a 29.6 percent return over 10 years. And in the second decade, thanks to the bull market of the 1980's, it took off, surging to $171,757 on July 31. 
Of course, past is not necessarily prologue. And the study assumes the investor left the money in through thick and thin, not selling low - the other error that professionals attribute to the little guy. But the study contains a number of lessons for investors, the most important being the value of patiently following a long-term strategy, says Steven E. Norwitz, vice president of T. Rowe Price who directed the study, and other professionals.
''For those with a long-term investment horizon and the discipline to stay the course, the commitment to invest may be more important than the timing of the investment,'' Mr. Norwitz said.
Similarly, Gilbert S. Meem Jr., senior vice president, investments, of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., recommends that people invest in equities only if they can leave at least 85 percent of the portfolio invested for at least three years. ''It will take nine or 10 months to position the account, and it could lose money in the first year and a half, but patience will pay off,'' he said. ''It's not easy because you have to overcome emotionalism and because brokers always want to sell you something.''
Mr. Norwitz cited several reasons for the quadruple returns of the last 20 years. On an annual basis, the average return was 10.1 percent, which well outstripped inflation.
''One reason this 'worst-case scenario' produced such surprisingly good results is that a substantial part of the rise in value reflects shares acquired through reinvestment of dividends,'' he said, noting that dividends of almost $35,000 would have been received. The low prices of the first decade enabled the investor to acquire a great many shares, so that when current payout is compared with the investor's cost basis, there is a high return.
''Another advantage of investing with a long-term view is that volatility and the chances of incurring a loss are substantially mitigated over longer time periods,'' he said.
Mr. Norwitz said that staying fully invested was also crucial to the strong results. Citing a study by Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, he noted that from 1979 through 1988, every dollar invested in an index fund mirroring the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index would have grown to $4.52, while each dollar invested in Treasury bills would have reached $2.39. Had investors been out of the stock market in the five best months of each year, their equity dollar would have reached only $2.68.
''The risk of trying to time the market is not being in the market at critical moments when it counts the most,'' he said.
Tim Kochis, national director of executive financial consulting for Deloitte Haskins & Sells, suggests that investing in index funds is precisely what most individual investors should do with a substantial part of their portfolios. ''If you are going to be in the market for more than 10 years, I don't believe you can outwit it,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Inventories Are Up 0.6%; Sales Off 0.9%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
Business inventories climbed six-tenths of 1 percent in July, the biggest gain in three months, while business sales fell by nine-tenths of 1 percent, the Government reported today.
A combination of falling sales and rising inventories would normally provoke some recession fears, but analysts for the most part expressed little concern over the report.
''The rise in business inventories is potentially a problem, but when it is taken in context with other data, it is not very worrisome,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Company. 
Supporting this view, the Federal Reserve reported today that industrial production posted a three-tenths of 1 percent increase in August, the best showing in four months, reflecting a rebound in auto production.
Economists said the rise in industrial output, along with a gain in retail sales in August, was an indication that factories would not be scaling back production to bring output more in line with demand.
Many analysts believe that outside of the auto industry, inventories have been kept at fairly lean levels and they are predicting that overall production will post moderate gains for the rest of the year.
The rise in inventories in July pushed the total stockpile of unsold goods to a seasonally adjusted $785.5 billion. The increase was led by a 1.1 percent rise in inventories held by manufacturers. Inventories at the retail level rose three-tenths of 1 percent, while wholesale inventories were unchanged.
The combination of falling sales and rising inventories put the ratio of inventories to sales at 1.54 in July, meaning that it would take 1.54 months to exhaust inventories at the July sales pace. The June ratio was 1.51.
The drop in total sales matched the decline of nine-tenths of 1 percent reported in February and was the largest sales setback since a 3 percent drop in January 1987. The July decrease left total sales at a seasonally adjusted $511.09 billion. Sales at the manufacturing level fell by 1.8 percent while sales by wholesalers were off eight-tenths of 1 percent.
Retail sales were the only area of strength, rising by five-tenths of 1 percent in July.
