HEADLINE: Industrial Production Posts Largest Gain in 4 Months

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
Industrial production increased three-tenths of a percent in August, the biggest gain in four months, the Federal Reserve Board said today.
The August gain followed revised increases of one-tenth of a percent in July and two-tenths of a percent in June after remaining flat in May. The Fed had originally reported an increase of two-tenths of a percent in July and declines of one-tenth of a percent in both May and June. 
''That's not only stronger than expected, but the revisions were substantial,'' said Michael K. Evans of Evans Economics Inc., a Washington consulting firm. ''The economy never really slowed down,''
 
Manufacturing Called Sluggish
But William K. MacReynolds, forecasting director of the United States Chamber of Commerce, said the gain was only 2.8 percent over August of last year, compared with a rise of 5.7 percent in 1988. ''Growth in the manufacturing sector has been sluggish throughout 1989, falling farther behind the growth in the services sector,'' he said.
The Fed credited almost all the August growth to a rebound in production at automobile factories and a pickup in coal mining after a strike.
''Excluding motor vehicles, output of both consumer goods and business equipment was sluggish during the summer,'' it said.
At the same time, the central bank reported that the operating rate at factories, mines and utilities remained unchanged at 83.8 percent of capacity in August. The operating rate measures not only output, but also changes in productivity levels.
Factory use had declined one-tenth of a percentage point in June, the central bank said. The rate had reached a 10-year high of 84.3 percent in December 1988 and last January. Last month's operating rate was unchanged from August 1988.
''Unchanged capacity utilization in August signals the likelihood that inflationary pressures have declined substantially in the last several months,'' Mr. MacReynolds said.
The closer the nation's industry gets to full operating capacity, the greater difficulty it has producing enough to meet demand, leading to shortages and price increases. Analysts generally consider an operating rate of 85 percent or more to be an indication of inflationary pressures.
Industrial production at manufacturing plants making both durable and nondurable goods rose two-tenths of a percent last month after remaining flat in July and increasing three-tenths of a percent in June. Output was up 2.3 percent at mines and oil wells but fell 1 percent at utilities.
The operating rate rose one-tenth of a percentage point, to 84 percent, at manufacturing plants. The rate had peaked at 84.7 percent in January.
The Fed said its industrial production index in August stood at 142.4 percent of its 1977 base, up from 142 percent in July.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Fell 0.4% in August

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
Producer prices fell four-tenths of 1 percent in August, the third straight monthly decline, the Labor Department reported today.
As an inflation indicator, the report was somewhat more favorable than expected, and it apparently contributed to a rise in the bond market today. Still analysts noted that the decline in the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods resulted from a drop in the price of energy and that oil prices have recently been rising.
They also said that the index would have shown an increase of five-tenths of 1 percent if food and energy, two major components subject to erratic swings, had been excluded. This contrasted with a small decline in that calculation for July. 
 
Worries Over 'Core' Inflation
''I'm concerned about the failure to appreciate the upward drift in this 'core' inflation,'' said Stephen S. Roach, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. Without food and energy, producer inflation is running more than 25 percent faster in 1989 than last year, he said. ''And I don't think that's something to take lightly,'' he added.
Some other economists agreed. ''It's going to be hard to get these core rates down,'' said Kathryn L. Kobe, a vice president at Joel Popkin & Company, a Washington consulting firm that specializes in price trends. ''We still are somewhat concerned about inflation.''
There was, however, some comfort to be found in the indexes for producer prices at the intermediate and crude stages of production. The intermediate index fell three-tenths of 1 percent, after two straight declines of two-tenths, while the index for crude goods dropped 1.9 percent after showing a slight rise in July.
This suggested that no worrisome surge in inflation is likely in the foreseeable future. That could mean that the Federal Reserve, which seems to have been following an essentially neutral monetary course in recent weeks, would not need to shift to a tighter policy that would push up interest rates.
The subdued price behavior at the intermediate and crude levels ''could portend some good inflation numbers in the next few months,'' said Veronika C. White, an economist at the First Fidelity Bancorporation in Philadelphia.
Finished goods are those that are ready for sale to the ultimate user; an example would be a shirt. Using that example, the intermediate good would be a bolt of cloth and the crude good would be the raw cotton from which the cloth was made.
Price inreases at the producer level were running at an annual rate above 9 percent in the first few months of the year, causing fears of accelerating inflation. But with the recent declines, the rate for the eight months through August now stands at 4.4 percent. For the 12 months through August, producer prices have risen 4.2 percent.
After a lag of several months, producer prices are reflected at the consumer level. Through July the Consumer Price Index for 1989 had risen at an annual rate of 5.5 percent. The consumer price figures for August are to be reported Tuesday, and anlysts expect a modest increase.
 
Big Declines in Energy
The drop in the energy component of the finished goods index was 7.3 percent, more than twice the declines of June and July. Gasoline tumbled another 12.1 percent in August after a 7.2 percent drop in July. Natural gas and home heating oil, which had risen in July, fell 5 percent and 2.1 percent, respectively, last month.
Consumer foods rose three-tenths of 1 percent as increases accelerated for beef and veal, dairy products and bakery products. The prices of eggs and pork turned up, after having fallen in July. Fish and pasta prices continued to rise. Poultry fell less than in July. Soft drinks, fresh fruits and roasted coffee turned down.
Apart from energy and food, the prices of passenger cars had the most effect on the index. Car prices rose five-tenths of 1 percent in August after dropping 1.9 percent in July.
The capital equipment category, which was unchanged in July, advanced three-tenths of 1 percent.
Among intermediate goods, lower prices for energy and manufacturing materials were the main contributors to the decline, as they were in July. The nondurable manufacturing items that fell in price included plastic resins, paints, papers, fertilizer materials, medicinal and botanical chemicals and inedible fats and oils.
The index of durable manufacturing materials fell for the fifth straight month, with hefty declines for steel mill products, shaped aluminum products and ferrosilicon.

HEADLINE: Dow Gains 9.69 Points After Wide Swings

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stock prices rose moderately yesterday while trading volume increased sharply.
After an up-and-down week, the Dow Jones industrial average finished 9.69 points higher, at 2,674.58, but for the week the Dow was down 34.96 points and closed well below 2,700, a level closely watched by technical analysts.
Advances on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered declines by 837 to 651. 
Volume on the Big Board climbed to 234.9 million shares, from 149.3 million on Thursday. This was the biggest turnover in nearly three months.
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 1.90 points, to 345.06, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index gained 0.64, to 191.59.
 
Dow Variations
The Dow average swung widely during the day. It was up 15 points and down 5 points in early trading, rebounding from Thursday's 14.63-point deficit. Several Government economic reports issued yesterday had less impact than widely expected.
Yesterday the Commerce Department reported that business inventories rose six-tenths of 1 percent in July, up from a revised three-tenths of 1 percent increase in June. At the same time, the Government reported that the July trade deficit narrowed to $7.58 billion, from $8.01 billion, the lowest since December 1984.
In other reports, industrial production gained three-tenths of 1 percent in August, compared with a gain of two-tenths of 1 percent in July, while the August Producer Price Index fell four-tenths of 1 percent, the third straight monthly drop.
Analysts said the producer price and industrial production statistics appeared to eliminate the possibility that the Federal Reserve would relax interest rates for the remainder of the year.
 
Lacking Conviction
''The economic releases and the triple witching hour provided a volatile day,'' said Jack Barbanel, portfolio strategist at First Global Asset Management Inc. in Princeton, N.J. ''Volume was impressive but the breadth of the market still lacked conviction.'' The triple witching hour occurs when stock options, options on stock indexes and futures on stock indexes expire at the same time. Stocks tend to vacillate wildly on these days because of the wide use of computer programs to expedite trading.
''Caution still ruled the day,'' Mr. Barbanel said. ''Looking forward, the key is whether the Fed will do something with interest rates, which I don't see.''
He said that the market remained cautious about the validity of fixed-income issues, especially ''junk bonds,'' which offer high yields. ''Until these issues are resolved, the market should remain choppy,'' he said.
 
Airline Stocks
The AMR Corporation dropped 1 3/4, to 75 7/8. The company, along with some other airlines, has recently been considered a takeover candidate.
MGM/UA Communications rose 1 7/8, to 22 1/2. Qintex Ltd. of Australia said that it had agreed to acquire MGM for $25 a share, topping an offer by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation.
Exxon was the most active issue, up 1/4, to 44 7/8, on 3.4 million shares. A.T.&T. was the second-most-active stock, rising 3/8, to 40 5/8, on nearly 3.3 million shares.
UAL fell 3/4, to 279 3/4. The company announced an agreement to be acquired for $6.75 billion by its pilots, management and British Airways P.L.C.
Actively traded blue chips included General Electric, up 1 3/8, to 57 1/4; I.B.M., off 1/4, to 115 1/2; USX, up 5/8, to 34 1/8, and Eastman Kodak, off 3/8, to 47 3/4.
On the American Stock Exchange, the Amex market value index slipped 1.30 points, to 379.64, while in over-the-counter trading the Nasdaq composite index dipped 1.21 points, to 467.57.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 43, Column 1; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Prices Gain Strongly After Wild Rumors Arise

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold futures prices made strong gains yesterday on New York's Commodity Exchange after being pulled back from three-year lows by unfounded rumors that President Bush had been shot and that a major United States bank was near collapse.
''From what we can see, it was purely rumor-driven,'' said John Jonat, a metals trader with Deak International Inc.
On other markets, energy futures advanced, grains and soybeans were mixed, and livestock and meat futures were mixed. 
Gold futures settled $3.40 higher across the board, with the contract for delivery in October at $365.20 an ounce. Silver futures were 2.7 cents to 2.9 cents higher, with September at $5.084 an ounce.
Analysts said the moves in the metals markets were mainly reactions to the dollar, which strengthened early in the day after positive reports on inflation and the trade deficit, then collapsed in the afternoon amid the wild rumors.
 
'A Complete Reversal'
''We had a complete reversal,'' said Craig Sloane, a metals analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company in New York.
The market gave more credence to the talk of an impending bank collapse than to the rumors about President Bush, analysts said, because the financial markets were jittery about the credit troubles of the Campeau Corporation, the retailing giant.
For the gold market, which has been weakening gradually for months, the turnaround could mark a turning point, Mr. Sloane said.
''New lows were made, and then you came up with a higher close on the day,'' he said. That could signal the start of a big bull move, he said.
Energy futures also rallied late in the session on the New York Mercantile Exchange, more than offsetting the technically inspired losses that had accrued earlier in the week.
West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 19 to 26 cents higher, with October at $19.96 a barrel; heating oil was 0.74 to 0.91 cent higher, with October at 55.95 cents a gallon, and unleaded gasoline was 0.74 to 0.90 cent higher, with October at 57.50 cents a gallon.
Grain and soybean futures finished mixed on the Chicago Board of Trade.
The corn market weakened late in the session when a rumored Soviet corn purchase failed to materialize.
Gerald Zusel, manager of the Balfour Maclaine Corporation's floor operations at the exchange, said the speculation was premature.
''You buy during the harvest, not before the harvest,'' he said.

HEADLINE: FOOTBALL;
Lageman to Be Starter In His First N.F.L. Game

BYLINE: By GERALD ESKENAZI, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 15

 BODY:
Suddenly today, the Jets began to look as they did on paper when training camp started in July.
The linebacker Jeff Lageman, the team's No. 1 draft choice, was announced as a starter for his first professional game when the Jets face the Browns at Cleveland on Sunday. Al Toon, the Pro Bowl wide receiver who missed the Jets' opener, will be able to see action, and Johnny Hector, the versatile runner, has been added to the roster. 
Tim Cofield said he has never heard of Wally Pipp, whose headache kept him from playing first base for the Yankees and gave an opportuity to Lou Gehrig. Gehrig stayed for 2,130 consecutive games. But Cofield may turn out to be a Pipp, with a groin injury. Lageman will step in, although Coach Joe Walton said he believed the rookie, who will be the outside right linebacker, could ''use a couple more weeks.''
 
A Rush Start
It is a rush start for Lageman, who missed the first 33 days of camp in a contract dispute. He has been with the team for only 23 days. Until Cofield was injured, it was too late for the rookie to take the job from the veteran, who won it in Lageman's absence.
Lageman, at 6 feet 5 inches and 250 pounds one of the biggest linebackers in club history, had been penciled in at outside right linebacker, where he would presumably terrorize quarterbacks and haul down runners. Until now, though, the best he has looked has been wearing the uniform. He seemed almost stoic today in reflecting on his first pro start.
''Before a game I'm not a big rah-rah type,'' said Lageman, who was an economics major at the University of Virginia. ''I'll be high for the game but I can't be worrying about it.''
Lageman is realistic enough to know that Bernie Kosar and the Browns will try to exploit the right side of the Jets' defense. Ron Stallworth, another rookie, is at right end. ''If I were the coach, I would,'' the rookie said matter-of-factly.
 
Light Workouts for Toon
In a perfect Jets world, Toon and Wesley Walker would be at their accustomed wide-receiver positions. And Hector would be replacing Freeman McNeil at running back on short-yardage and teaming with him on passing plays.
Although Toon's injured shoulder has not completely healed, the Jets have apparently avoided the potential disaster of facing the powerful Browns without either starting receiver. Walker is sidelined for at least six games with an ankle injury.
Toon's workouts have been light and he wore a red jersey so his teammates would not bang into him. He will rotate with Michael Harper and JoJo Townsell, bringing in Walton's plays.
Meanwhile, Hector, who agreed to terms this week and is not in game-condition, has been added to the 47-player roster and taken off the exemption list. Walton said he will decide Sunday whether to suit him up.
Lageman, Toon, Walker and Hector all had lengthy contract disputes. Walton believes that Toon's and Walker's absences contributed to their injuries.
 
 One More Sack for Browns
 The Browns have been credited with another sack in their rout of the Steelers last Sunday: they produced seven sacks, eight turnovers (including five fumble recoveries), and positioned 13 points on turnovers. . . . Scott Mersereau, benched during the Jets' game against the Patriots, will return to start at nose tackle. But Paul Frase will also see action there. . . . Marty Lyons, bothered by a sore shoulder, will start at left end.
